text:
THE INDIA OFFICE LIST FOR 1886.

CONTAINING AN ACCOUNT OF THE SERVICES OF THE OFFICERS IN THE INDIAN SERVICE AND OTHER INFORMATION.

COMPILED FROM OFFICIAL RECORDS BY DIRECTION OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA IN COUNCIL.

LONDON: HARRISON AND SONS, 59, PALL MALL, BOOKSELLERS TO HER MAJESTY AND H.R.H. THE PRINCE OF WALES.

1886.

Price Six Shillings.
PREFACE.

The India Office List, of which the First Edition is now published, contains a brief statement of the services of each member of the India Office Establishment, of the higher grades of the Civil Service of India, and of other Government servants in civil employment in that country.

Owing to considerations of space it has been found necessary in the case of some classes of public servants to include only those who have reached a certain rank in the Service as indicated by their substantive rate of pay.

A Revised Edition of the work will be published annually, and the names of those whose services are recorded will be retained until their retirement from the public service, and in some cases for life. The present issue contains a certain number of retired civilians and others, selected on account of the positions they held on retirement, or for distinctions conferred on them in recognition of their services.

The issue of the present Edition has been delayed from unavoidable causes, chiefly the incomplete records available in many cases. It is intended that subsequent Editions shall be published about the middle of each year, and shall be corrected, as far as possible, up to the end of the preceding year.

The work has been compiled mainly from the separate histories of services published under the direction of the supreme and local governments in India, supplemented, where possible, from private sources.

The Registrar and Superintendent of Records will be glad to receive from those concerned early intimation of errors or omissions in this or future issues. Any communication which will entail alteration in the subsequent Edition should reach the India Office before the 1st June.

India Office,
1st October, 1886.

(a.) Mr. Baker was at first 'Agent' for the settlement of Madras, which was under the jurisdiction of the Presidency of Bantam in Java from its foundation in 1639 till it was itself created a Presidency in 1653. In 1658 the Settlements in Bengal were subordinated to Madras and so remained to 1681.

(b.) Three months after his arrival with a commission to supersede Sir E. Winter, Mr. Foxcroft was, on a charge of disloyalty, put into confinement by Sir E. Winter, who resumed office and retained it till the 22nd August, 1668, when Mr. Foxcroft was released and reinstated by the commissioners from England.

(c.) By the Company's Commission, dated 14th Nov., 1681, received 17th July, 1682, the Bengal Agency was made a Government 'without any subordination to Fort St. George.'

(d.) Mr. Yale also acted during Mr. Gyfford's absence in Bengal from 8th Aug., 1684, to 26th Jan., 1685.

(a.) Madras having been captured by the French on the 10th September, 1746, the government of the settlement devolved on Mr. John Hinde, the Deputy Governor of Fort St. David.

(b.) Mr. Hinde died at Fort St. David on the 14th April, 1747, previous to the receipt of the Court of Directors' despatch of 24th Jan., 1747, creating Fort St. David the Head Settlement, and appointing Mr. Hinde president and governor.

(c.) The Court's despatch ordering Mr. Floyer's dismissal from the service was received at Fort St. David on the 6th July, 1750.

(d.) The seat of government was re-established at Madras on the 5th April, 1752, four years after its restoration to the English by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle.

(e.) Governor for second time. By order of Mr. George Stratton and the majority of the Council was placed under arrest and detained at St. Thomas's Mount on the 24th Aug., 1776. He was allowed to return to the Madras Garden House on the 28th April for change of air, and died there on 10th May, 1777.

(f.) Acting governor second time. Suspended by the Governor-General and Council under section IX of the Regulating Act.

## GOVERNORS OF BOMBAY.

| Names | Assumed charge of office | Remarks |
|-------|--------------------------|---------|
| The Hon. Sir Abraham Shipman (a) | Appointed 'General and Governor' on the 19th March, 1662, was prevented from landing in Bombay by the Portuguese, and died on the island of Anjediva in October, 1664. Secretary to Sir Abraham Shipman, succeeded him in command, and came to Bombay as governor in February, 1665. He remained in power till the 5th November, 1666. | |
| Mr. Humfrey Cooke | 5 Nov., 1666 | Died 21st May, 1667. |
| The Hon. Sir Gervase Lucas | 22 May, 1667 | Officiating. |
| Captain Henry Garey | 23 Sept., 1668 | Died in Surat on the 14th July, 1669. |
| Sir George Oxenden | 14 July, 1669 | Died in Surat on the 30th June, 1677. |
| Mr. Gerald Aungier | 30 June, 1677 | |
| Mr. Thomas Rolt | 27 Oct., 1681 | |

(a.) The first four governors held Bombay for the Crown. The Island was handed over to the Company on the 23rd Sept., 1668. For the next nineteen years (1668-1687), except for occasional visits, and during three years (1672-1675) of Governor Aungier's rule, the Governors of Bombay spent almost the whole of their time in Surat, of whose factory they were presidents. During this time, Bombay was administered by an officer styled Deputy Governor. The transfer, in 1687, of the headquarters of the Company's power to Bombay to a great extent did away with the need of a Deputy Governor. But in spite of the change the title continued for many years to be borne by the second member of the Council. It would seem to have fallen into disuse some time between 1720 and 1738.

(b.) Child was Governor and General with his headquarters in Bombay, whither he moved from Surat on the 2nd May, 1687, and where he died on the 4th Feb., 1690. In the year 1683, Bombay was the scene of a revolt against the Company's authority. The head of the rebellion was Captain Richard Keigwin, the third member of the Council. Placing the Deputy Governor under arrest, Keigwin ruled Bombay in the King's name from the 27th Dec., 1683, to the 19th Nov., 1684, when on promise of pardon he handed over the Island to Admiral Sir Thomas Grantham.

(a.) Under Gayer, Waite, and Aislalie—that is from 1694 to 1715—Bombay Governors held the title of General. During the last three years (1701-1704) of his nominal command Gayer was in confinement in Surat.

(b.) Proceeded to Madras on duty in Aug., 1793, and thence joined the Council of the Governor-General as Commander-in-Chief in India on the 28th Oct., 1793.

(c.) Was appointed Governor of Bombay by the Honourable the Court of Directors on the 4th Aug., 1841, but, before he could take charge of his appointment, he was assassinated in Cabul on the 28th Dec., 1841.

THE INDIA OFFICE LIST.

RECORD OF THE PUBLIC SERVICES OF OFFICERS AND OTHERS.

DESCRIPTION OF SERVICES.

ABBOTT, HENRY BRYAN, Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1861; served with the 109th foot; joined the Bombay staff corps, June, 1873, and was appointed assistant to the governor-general's agent in Rajputana; officiating settlement officer, Ulwur, 1874; officiating political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, 1875; political assistant, Maunpoor, and deputy Bheel agent, 1875-76; on special duty at Jhallawar, 1876-77; superintendent of Jhallawar, 1877; additional political agent, Jhallawar, 1883; graded as additional political agent, 1st class.

ACWORTH, HARRY ARBUTHNOT (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Brighton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue and political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1879; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, March, 1881; from 1881 to December, 1884, served as assistant collector, deputy collector, and acting junior collector of salt revenue; member of the mixed commission at Goa, Dec., 1884; assistant municipal commissioner, Bombay, June, 1885; deputy municipal commissioner, July, 1885.

ADAMS, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1861; from April, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; deputy commissioner Lalitpur, in the Jhansi commission, April, 1877; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, in 1878 and 1880; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

ADAMSON, CHARLES HENRY ELLISON, Captain, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1868; served with 5th brigade at Kirkee and Rangoon till 1870; admitted to the Madras staff corps, 1870; joined the Burma commission Dec., 1871, and served as assistant magistrate, assistant commissioner, and officiating magistrate, and president of municipal committee, Rangoon; deputy commissioner June, 1885.

ADAMSON, HARVEY, M.A., Bengal C.S., (British Burma).—Educated at the Gymnasium Old Aberdeen, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived at Rangoon, 17th Dec., 1877; and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, 2nd grade, March, 1881.

ADDIS, DAVID FOULIS, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Universities of Glasgow and Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883.

AGNEW, WILLIAM FISCHER, Judicial Department, Burma.—Reporter for Indian law reports, high court, Calcutta, 1878; advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1879; recorder of Rangoon, March, 1884; officiating judge, high court, Calcutta, 1885.

AHSANUDDIN AHMAD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed assistant magistrate and collector on probation under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1881.

AIKMAN, ROBERT SMITH, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Madras College, St. Andrews, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1867, and served in the N.-W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine relief duty, Feb. to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1870.

AINSLIE, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1845; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector in Cuttack, and was specially employed in 1850-51 and 1851-52 in the suppression of Meriah sacrifices in the Khond districts; magistrate of Rungpore, July, 1852; railway commissioner, East Indian railway, Jan., 1856, to March, 1857; magistrate and
collector, Bhagulpore, March, 1857; railway commissioner, Eastern Bengal railway, 1858, and subsequently of the South-Eastern railway also; from Aug., 1863, served in the judicial department, and was appointed civil and sessions judge of Patna, Jan., 1864; president, tea commission Nov., 1867, to April, 1868; officiated as judge of the high court, Calcutta, from Nov., 1870, and was confirmed in that appointment May, 1873; retired, April, 1880.

AITCHISON, Sir Charles Umpherston, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., M.A., LL.D., Bengal C.S., (Punjab).—Educated at the University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner and magistrate; transferred to Punjab, May, 1857; personal assistant to judicial commissioner, July, 1858; officiating under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1859; deputy-commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1865; officiating commissioner, Lahore, Aug., 1867; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1867; from April, 1868, served in the foreign department, government of India, as officiating secretary, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1870; on special duty in Thuggy and Dacoity department, Oct., 1877; chief commissioner, British Burma, 31st March, 1878; provisional member, governor-general's council, July, 1880; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 4th April, 1882.

AITCHISON, John R., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Clapham Grammar School; supernumerary writer, 14th Feb., 1860; clerk in registry department, Oct., 1860; and employed in military department, 1867; junior clerk, Nov., 1872; funds department, 1873; military department, 1874; deputy resident clerk 1880; senior clerk 1885.

ALCOCK, John Backhouse, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, and railway magistrate; from Jan., 1884, acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and as 3rd grade judge and sessions judge in Khândesh.

ALEXANDER, Ernest Bruce, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1874, to March, 1881, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer in Fatehpur and Moradabad, and was appointed junior secretary to the board of revenue in addition to his other duties in 1877, and was placed on special duty under the orders of the board, Feb., 1879; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Jan., 1883; officiating judge, small cause court, May, 1883; officiating magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, Aug., 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1885.

ALEXANDER, George, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1823; arrived in India, Nov., 1824; assistant secretary, board of revenue, Western Provinces, Feb., 1826, and to the central board in March, 1826; officiating commissioner of the Soonderbunds, July, 1827; head assistant to the lower board of revenue, Jan., 1828, and to the Sudder board April, 1829; officiated in the appointments of assistant secretary to government, collector of Backergunge, junior secretary, and secretary to the Sudder board of revenue, 1829-32; first assistant to collector of sea and inland customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1832; deputy secretary to government, general department, March, 1833; member of committee for concentrating the public offices, Oct., 1833; deputy secretary to government of India, and to the government of Bengal, in general, foreign, and financial departments, Nov., 1834; postmaster-general, July, 1839; retired 1845.

ALEXANDER, George, Major, Bengal S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign H.M. 76th regiment, Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 30th Jan., 1864; from April, 1869, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner; town magistrate, Akyab, Jan., 1879; appointed a deputy commissioner, Feb., 1882, and promoted to 3rd grade, March, 1885.

ALEXANDER, Nathaniel Stuart, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 10th July, 1883; from Oct., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Aug., 1884.

ALLEN, Charles Francis Egerton, B.A. (Cantab), Judicial Department, Burma.—Called to the bar (Inner Temple) 1871; admitted advocate of high court, Calcutta, Nov., 1873; law examiner, Calcutta University, Dec., 1874, and again in 1875 and 1876; acting judge of the Calcutta court of small causes, 1875-76; lecturer on English law in the Presidency College, Calcutta, Feb., 1876, and professor of law (temporary) May, 1877; from June, 1877, served as government advocate, Rangoon, and acted as recorder of Rangoon for various periods.

ALLEN, David Bird, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant to director-general of statistics, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

ALLEN, Thomas Taylor, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1861; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1867; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1880; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan., 1883; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1883.

ALLEN, William, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, acting 1st class deputy collector in Scinde, acting assistant conservator of forests, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; 1st assistant collector, Dec., 1882.

AMBICA CHURN SEN, Bengal C.S.—Ap-
pointed under the native civil service rules assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884, on probation.

AMIRTO LALL CHATTERJEE, B.L.—From 19th May, 1862, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Moorshedabad, April, 1873; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Nuddea, April, 1880.

ANDERSON, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Gordon's Hospital, New Grammar School, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty, Jan.-May, 1878, and again, Nov., 1881, in the forest department; forest settlement officer, April, 1882; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1883.

ANDERSON, FRANCIS CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Oct., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Aug., 1881; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Feb., 1882; acted as secretary to chief commissioner in Oct., 1882.

ANDERSON, HENRY AIKEN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1873; and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant, and was appointed officiating under secretary to Government, Punjab, March, 1880, and assistant political officer, Kurram, under the Government of India, Aug., 1880.

ANDERSON, JAMES, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; on special duty connected with the Wahabi case, June, 1870.

ANDERSON, JAMES DRUMMOND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan.-Dec., 1882.

ANDERSON, JOHN ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and was also a student of the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner.

ANDERSON, J. W. M., Colonel, Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—First commission, Jan., 1855; from Nov., 1863, served in the revenue survey department, Mysore, as assistant superintendent and deputy superintendent; from April, 1881, served as superintendent of the Scinde settlement survey; 1st grade superintendent, Jan., 1885.

ANDERSON, ROBERT HILDEBRAND, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1876; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

ANDERSON, W. R. L., Captain, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Oct., 1870, 63rd foot; admitted to the Bombay staff corps, Oct., 1871; aide-de-camp to Governor of Bombay, 1876; deputy accountant-general, military department, Jan., 1882.

ANDREW, DAVID CLAPHAM, Major, Bengal S.C., Survey of India.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 7th March, 1860; joined the revenue survey department as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1862; deputy superintendent of revenue survey, 3rd grade, Jan., 1878; was in charge of Bassein District, British Burma survey, Nov., 1879, and was transferred to the South Deccan survey, Nov., 1880.

ANDREW, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

ANDREWS, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 30th March, 1876.

ANLEY, GEORGE AUGUSTUS D'AUVERGNE, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of India as executive engineer, 4th class, 25th Jan., 1861; served in the Bengal public works department, and temporarily under the municipality of Calcutta; officiating assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1876; held charge of office of chief engineer, and secretary to Government of Bengal Dec., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1882; 2nd class (temporary) April, 1882.

ANUNDORAM BOROOAH (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Gowhatti Government School and Presidency College, Calcutta University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1872; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1883.

ARBUTHNOT, SIR ALEXANDER JOHN, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1842; served in the revenue department as assistant collector and magistrate, and also held the posts of Malayan translator to government, secretary to the college and university boards, and deputy and acting registrar to
the Sudder court; director of public instruction March, 1855; chief secretary to government and additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Oct., 1862; member of Madras Council, Oct., 1867, to Oct., 1872; temporary governor of Madras in the absence of Lord Napier, Feb.-May, 1872; retired from the Madras civil service, Oct., 1874; member of governor-general's council, June, 1875, to 1880, and acted as president of the council, Nov., 1878, and March, 1879; vice-chancellor of the university of Madras, Oct., 1871, and of the university of Calcutta, Oct., 1878; counsellor of the Empress of India, Jan., 1877; is the author of various publications on educational and other subjects in connection with India, among which are 'Reports of selected cases determined in the Court of Foudjari Adawlut,' 1851; 'A compilation of papers relating to public instruction in Madras,' 1855; 'Memoir of Sir Thomas Munro,' 1881, &c.

ARBURTHNOTT, JOHN CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagalpur, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner.

ARMSTRONG, FRANCIS B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham Proprietary College, and King Edward's School, Birmingham; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 30th March, 1869; senior clerk, Sept., 1883.

ARMSTRONG, JOHN SCOBELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd March, 1866; from Sept., 1866, served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, and collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1883.

ARNOLD, GEORGE, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk in storekeeper's department, Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, Oct., 1855, to Dec., 1858; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, Dec., 1858; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877.

ARNOTT, JAMES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Glas.) Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and served in the military department till Aug., 1868, and subsequently as assistant-surgeon in the David Sassoon Hospital, Poona, and in the European General Hospital, Bombay, and as professor of pathology in the Grant Medical College; also acted as civil surgeon, and registrar of marriages, Poona, and in medical charge of the Deccan and civil engineering colleges, and as superintendent of the lunatic asylum and jail; acting surgeon, Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; surgeon, European general hospital, Bombay, March-April, 1882; professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, and obstetric physician, Jamsetji Nizibhoy Hospital from April, 1882.

ARUNDEL, ARUNDEL TAGG, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in various districts of Madras from Aug., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate; private secretary to governor of Madras, July, 1875; acting deputy director, revenue settlement, April, 1878; president of the municipal commission, Madras, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; principal assistant to collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1884.

ASHBURNER, LIONEL R., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Broach, Surat, and Kaira; on the outbreak of the mutiny in 1857 was appointed superintendent of police, Kaira, and organised a body of horse and foot for the protection of the eastern frontier; special commissioner for trial of rebels, 1858; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1861; revenue and police commissioner, N. division, 1872; member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1877; retired, 1883.

ASHTON, G., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 7th April, 1884; attached to financial department.

ASHUTOSH GUPTA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, Lohardugga, on probation, March, 1885.

ASTON, HENRY FAURE (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Educated at the South African College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political assistant in Káthiáwar (April, 1871, to June, 1874); acting judge and sessions judge, railway magistrate and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881, to March, 1883; 1st grade assistant judge and sessions judge, Aug., 1883; judicial assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, March, 1885.

ATKINS, JOHN DE COURCY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

ATKINSON, EDWIN FELIX THOMAS, B.A., F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S., North-Western Province).—Educated at the Irish Missionary College, Ballinasloe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from July, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dün, and was placed on special duty under the forest department, July, 1870; in charge of N.W. Provinces Gazetteer, June, 1872; officiating junior secretary to government, May, 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1874, and in 1875; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, April to Nov., 1875; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, March, 1877; from March, 1877, served under the government of India, in
the financial department, as officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, and was confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1886; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, Aug., 1878; accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Madras, Dec., 1879; officiating accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1881; accountant-general, Bengal, July, 1882; officiated as comptroller-general and head commissioner of paper currency, in 1882, 1883, and 1884.

ATKINSON, JOHN NATHANIEL, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; on special duty under the commissioner of salt revenue, April, 1885.

ATLAY, B. T., Venerable, M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, 17th Oct., 1867; chaplain of St. Paul's Cathedral and of the general hospital, Dec., 1867; senior chaplain, Oct., 1877; officiating commissary to the Lord Bishop of Calcutta, April, 1878, and March, 1883; chaplain of Naini Tal, Feb., 1879; senior chaplain, St. Paul's Cathedral, Jan., 1882; officiating chaplain in charge of the diocese, March, 1883; Archdeacon of Calcutta, Sept., 1883.

AULAD HUSSAIN, KHAN BAHA DUR, C.I.E., Uncov. C.S., Central Provinces.—Joined the service, 29th July, 1844; settlement deputy collector, Aug., 1856; from Dec., 1864, served as assistant commissioner; on special duty at the Delhi assemblage, Dec., 1876; made C.I.E., Jan., 1882; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, July, 1883; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Raipur, Jan., 1885.

AUSTIN, WARE PLUMPTRE, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Gloucester School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial department from May, 1866, as assistant magistrate and collector, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; district and sessions judge, North Malabar, Oct., 1884.

BADCOCK, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1866; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was placed on special duty, as settlement officer, Bhagulpore, July, 1873, and also in the office of the board of revenue, Calcutta, Jan., 1879; officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1883.

BADEN, EDMUND, Auditors' Department, India Office.—Writer, 4th Jan., 1859; senior inspector, Sept., 1860.

BADEN-POWELL, BADEN HENRY, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Paul's School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; assistant commissioner, May, 1862; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab and Scinde, Aug., 1865; from July, 1866, to April, 1869, served as small cause court judge, Lahore, and subsequently in the forest department as officiating conservator and officiating inspector-general, and was placed on special duty, Nov., 1872, and April, 1876; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, April, 1880; on special duty in Madras, Oct., 1880, to Oct., 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawulpindi, Oct., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1882; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, May, 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

BADGLEY, WILLIAM FRANCIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, April, 1857; arrived in India, May, 1857; appointed to the Topographical Survey, May, 1865, and was employed in Rewah and Bundelcund, and in the Khasi, Garo, and Naga Hills; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Dec., 1880; in charge of Guzerat survey, March, 1884.

BADOCK, HENRY W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 11th Feb., 1876.

BAGNELL, HENRY WILLIAM JAMES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eastbourne College, Keble College, Oxford, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 1st Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883.

BAILEY, FREDERICK, Major, R.E., Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as a lieutenant, R.E., 12th Nov., 1854; served under the military department till July, 1867, when he was appointed assistant engineer, 1st grade, P.W. department; executive engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1871; from Aug., 1871, served in the forest department as deputy conservator and superintendent of forest surveys; conservator of forests, and director of Indian forest school, in addition to his duties as superintendent of forest surveys, Sept., 1878; promoted to 2nd grade of conservators, April, 1883.

BAILLIE, DUNCAN COLVIN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Inverness Academy, Glasgow Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner.

BAINES, JEROVOSE ATHELSTANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, acting educational inspector, and cantonment and railway magistrate; on special duty at Bombay as compiler of general administration report, Sept., 1878, and again Sept., 1879; acting under secretary to government revenue, financial, and general departments, March, 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations in Bombay Presidency, and under secretary to government, general department, census, April, 1880; and assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Dec., 1882.

BAKER, EDWARD NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; services.
placed at disposal of census commissioner, March, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1882; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1884.

BAKER, FRANCIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Berkhamstead Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, first assistant secretary to government, Nov., 1873, and again in 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, April, 1874; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1878, and officiated as secretary, Sept., 1878; officiating junior secretary to government, March, 1881; under secretary to government, May, 1881; superintendent of Dehra Dun, March, 1884.

BAKER, MONTAGU BERNARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and acting judge and sessions judge; acting judicial commissioner in Scinde, and judge of the Sadar court, April, 1879; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Kandeish, May, 1882; 1st grade judge, Aug., 1883.

BALLS, CHARLES WILLIAM, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed assistant to traffic manager, Persian Gulf telegraph, 1863; storekeeper, 1866; chief clerk, London office, 1870; visited the Persian Gulf stations on special duty in 1870; took inventory of all government property, which was afterwards valued, and made the basis of a complete stock account of the department in the Persian Gulf; acted as accountant for six months in 1867.

BANNERMAN, PATRICK WILSON, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Indian Army, June, 1852; assistant to the superintendent, Neemuch, July, 1859; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1861; political assistant, Bhopawar July, 1865; also Bheel agent and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps; political agent, Bhagelkund, 1876; political agent, Bhopal, 1881; resident, Gwalior, 1883.

BANTON, WILLIAM, Accounts Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 29th Dec., 1848; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Sept., 1858; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; also assessor of income tax, 1879.

BARBOUR, DAVID MILLER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1864; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1873; accountant-general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Lahore circle, June, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1878; accountant-general, Madras, and commissioner of paper currency, Jan., 1880; on special duty with the government of India, May, 1881; accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Jan., 1882; Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1882; secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, July, 1882.

BARCLAY, ERNEST, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 18th Sept., 1861, as French interpreter to the supreme court, Madras, acting deputy clerk of the crown and acting assistant registrar, and was appointed government solicitor, Feb., 1876.

BARKLEY, DAVID GRAHAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; officiating small cause court judge, Delhi, Sept., 1863; personal assistant to commissioner, Umballa, Nov., 1864; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the chief court, Nov., 1870, and again at Simla, June, 1871, and at Lahore, April, 1872; assistant sessions judge, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1874; additional commissioner, Delhi, May, 1876, and subsequently at Jallundar and Lahore; officiating chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1878, and again in judge 1880; civil and sessions judge, Nov., 1880; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, Sept., 1881; additional judge, chief court, Jan., 1882; additional member of governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, May, 1883; judge of the chief court, Punjab, Feb., 1885.

BARLOW, GEORGE NELSON, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1855; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and salt agent, Pooree, and was appointed junior secretary to the government of Bengal, June, 1862, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1866; commissioner of the Patna division, April, 1878, and of the Bhagulpore division, June, 1878.

BARLOW, RICHARD WELLESLEY, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from Feb., 1857, and was appointed acting judge, small cause court, Tellicherry, Nov., 1869; acting civil and sessions judge, Chingleput, Feb., 1870; from 1871 to 1878 served as collector and magistrate of Chingleput, and subsequently as commissioner, Nilgiris, 1878-1880, and again in 1881; government member of the Lawrence Asylum committee, April, 1878; acting member, board of revenue, May, 1880; collector and magistrate, and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; collector of sea customs and of the Madras district, and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1883; acting resident, Travancore and Cochin, Feb. to Aug., 1884.

BARNES, HUGH SHAKESPEARE, Bengal C.S., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Educated at Malvern College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to financial department of government of India Dec., 1876, and appointed assistant to accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces; private secretary to the financial member of the governor-general's council, 1878-79; on special
duty under the foreign department, 1880-81; acting 2nd assistant to the governor-general's agent in Biluchistan, 1882; political agent at Pishin, 1883.

BARNETT, EBENEZER M., Store Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 10th Nov., 1852; junior clerk, store department, July, 1860; senior clerk, March, 1868.

BARR, D. W. K., Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Sept., 1864; boundary commissioner, Rewa Kantha, and Malwa Bheel agency, 1869; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1870; officiating political agent, 2nd class, Jodhpur, 1878-79, and in Bhagelkund 1881; additional political agent, 1st class, Bhagelkund, 1882; also superintendent, Rewa state.

BARRON, WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, Dec., 1858; arrived in India Feb., 1859; served with the Peshawur mountain train battery in the Mahsood Wuzuree expedition, 1860; assistant revenue surveyor June, 1862; served as assistant surveyor with the Umbeyla expedition, Oct., 1863; assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1866; was employed in the Punjab and N.W. frontier districts, and also in Assam; deputy superintendent of survey, April, 1870; was subsequently in charge of the N.W. frontier revenue survey, and afterwards of the Moradabad and Budaun surveys; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Aug., 1884.

BARROW, FRANK HUNTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bruton and Felsted Grammar Schools and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884.

BARROW, OSCAR THEODORE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Gloucester College School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to financial department, government of India, Oct., 1882; officiating assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Feb., 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, May, 1885.

BARRY, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 14th Feb., 1863; from Dec., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; employed on famine duty under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Banda, Aug., 1877; from May, 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Jaunpur, Nov., 1882.

BARRY, WILLIAM RUSSELL, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Birkenhead Proprietary School, Shrewsbury School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1873, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiated as assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate of Jhansi, and as assistant secretary to government; junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; officiating under secretary to government, March, 1881, and again in 1883 and 1884; 1st assistant secretary to government, May, 1881; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, March, 1884.

BARSTOW, HENRY CLEMENTS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from July, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; served under the Government of India, foreign department, Jan., 1874, to Oct., 1875, as officiating political agent, 1st class, Bhopal; officiating superintendent, Dehra Dun, Feb., 1876; officiating civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Banda, Jan., 1880; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Cawnpore, April, 1880.

BARTER, JOSEPH FRANCIS, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the Madras medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1860; from April, 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acted for various periods as inspector-general of jails and as sanitary commissioner; rank of surgeon-major July, 1873; sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and inspector-general of dispensaries, Central Provinces, Dec., 1878; civil surgeon and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Nagpur, July, 1883.

BARTHOLOMEW, ROBERT, Major, Gen. List, B.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 2nd April, 1862; from 1st Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Aug., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Delhi.

BARTLETT, HUBERT FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Feb., 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1885.

BARTON, EBENEZER JOHNSTONE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; from Sept., 1863, served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1882; also served as officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Sept., 1871, and was on special famine duty, Bhagalpore division, Dec., 1873.

BATEMAN-CHAMPAINE, SIR JOHN UNDERWOOD, Colonel, R.E., K.C.M.G., Director in Chief, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Addiscombe; appointed 2nd lieutenant, Bengal engi-
neers, June, 1853; served through the Indian Mutiny as adjutant, Bengal sappers and miners, at siege of Delhi (wounded), Lucknow, &c; executive engineer in Oude, 1853 to 1862; in 1862 proceeded to Persia, and has since then been employed uninterruptedly in connection with the telegraph to India; has represented India at various international conferences at Berne, Rome, St. Petersburg, London, Paris, and Berlin.

BATESON, ROBERT SANDER, Brigade-Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1856; arrived in India, and was attached to military department as assistant surgeon, 7th Aug., 1856; placed in medical charge of the civil station and in executive charge of jail at Umballa, Nov., 1871; civil surgeon, 2nd class, Oct., 1877; brigade-surgeon, Oct., 1882.

BATTEY, HERBERT, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of logic and moral philosophy in the Deccan College, Poona (1872-75), assistant judge and sessions judge (1st grade, Feb., 1885), and acting judge and sessions judge.

BAYLAY, CHARLES ALLEN, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1857; assistant commissioner, Berar, Jan., 1866, and subsequently in Loodianah; political assistant, Rajputana, 1873; officiating political agent, Jeypoor, 1876-77; political agent, Haraoti and Tonk, 1879; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, 1880.

BAYLEY, CHARLES STUART (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Heidelberg; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, January, 1878; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, March, 1881, and subsequently in the financial department, Oct., 1882; member of the executive committee, Calcutta international exhibition of 1883-84, Aug., 1883; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural departments, Feb., 1884; officiating registrar, high court, Feb., 1884; under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural departments, June, 1885.

BAYLEY, LYTTELTON HOLYOAKE (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Advocate-general, Bombay, 17th March, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1869; acting chief justice, May-Dec., 1883.

BAYLEY, SIR STEUART COLVIN, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India 4th March, 1856; assistant magistrate and collector, 24 Pergunnahs, Nov. 1855; junior secretary to government of Bengal, Feb., 1863; officiated as secretary to the government of Bengal in 1865, 1867, and 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Monghyr, Feb., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, May, 1867; commissioner, Dacca division, July, 1873, and subsequently of the Patna division, Sept., 1873; secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; additional secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1877; personal assistant to H.E. the viceroy, for famine affairs, Sept., 1877; additional secretary, government of India, public works department, famine branch, Dec., 1877; secretary, government of India, home department, June, 1878; officiating chief commissioner, Assam, June, 1878, also officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July-Nov., 1879; chief commissioner of Assam, June, 1880; resident, 1st class, Hyderabad, March, 1881; governor-general's council, 9th May, 1882.

BAYNE, CHARLES GERWIEN, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Uppingham and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating assistant to the secretary to chief commissioner.

BEACHCROFT, FRANCIS PORTEN, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

BEADON, CECIL, Lieutenant-Colonel, Madras Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 24th March, 1883; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; on special duty in connection with viceregal durbar, Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, June, 1883, and subsequently in the Lahore division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1885, Simla.

BEADON, HENRY SNEYD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sherborne and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 14th November, 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1864; sub-registrar of assurances, June, 1866; officiating private secretary, lieutenant-governor of Bengal, March, 1871; under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1871; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1873; officiating senior superintendent of survey, Feb., 1875; 1st inspector, registration offices, July, 1876; inspector-general of registration, Bengal, Jan., 1878; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

BEAMAN, FRANK CLEMENT OFFLEY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting assistant superintendent of police; acting assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, March, 1882, to Jan., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate and political agent, March-April, 1883; from April, 1883, served in the judicial department, and was appointed acting judicial assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, May, 1884, and 3rd grade assistant judge, May, 1885.

BEAMES, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 16th March,
1858; from March, 1859, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and from Dec., 1861, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1873; officiated as commissioner, Orissa division, Aug., 1873, and subsequently as commissioner of the Chittagong, Rajshahye, and Cooch Behar and Dacca divisions; commissioner, Burdwan division, Nov., 1881.

BEARD, H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India store depot, 1st Feb., 1866; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

BEATTY, JOSEPH, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1852; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from March, 1855, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer; supervisor of the canals, Godaveri, May, 1874; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Aug., 1877; promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1878.

BEAUMONT, THOMAS, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., F.R.C.S.I., Madras Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 13th Sept., 1857; served under the military department till Feb., 1864, when he was appointed residency surgeon, Indore; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, June, 1881; also superintendent of vaccination and superintendent of medical school.

BEAUMONT, WILLIAM, Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 27th May, 1858, as assistant superintendent, and deputy superintendent; reorganisation committee, Madras, March, 1871; promoted to 1st class deputy superintendent, June, 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882.

BECKETT, HENRY BARRON, Punjab Administration.—Served from 10th May, 1860, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating inspector of schools, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Peshawur, Aug., 1884.

BEGBIE, ALFRED GLYNN, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer in the railway department, Central India; executive engineer, Oct., 1871; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; officiating deputy controller of accounts, Bengal, Aug., 1874; officiating examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1875; controller of accounts, Mysore, Aug., 1875; examiner guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, 1878; Punjab Northern railway accounts, 1880; officiating deputy accountant-general, Calcutta, April, 1883; examiner, 2nd class, in the accounts establishment, June, 1884.

BEHARY LAL GUPTA (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Colootola Branch School, Calcutta, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1871; on famine relief duty, Sept., 1874; presidency magistrate, Calcutta, and coroner of Calcutta, June, 1881.

BEIGHTON, THOMAS DURANT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived 4th Dec., 1867; from January, 1868, served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating small cause court judge, officiating district and sessions judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty in connection with boundary disputes on the Bhutan frontier, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879.

BELCHAMBERS, J. H., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Deputy registrar, appellate jurisdiction, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1878.

BELCHAMBERS, R., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Registrar of the high court, Calcutta, from 1862; is also keeper of records, taxing officer, accountant-general, and sealer.

BELL, HORACE, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, 7th July, 1862; served in the Central Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; subsequently served on the Punjab northern state railway, and on the Rajputana railway, as superintendent of way and works, and as acting manager, also as officiating engineer-in-chief on the Sindia and Neemuch state railways; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1881; engineer-in-chief, Dacca and Mymensingh surveys, Dec., 1881; while on furlough superintended assistant engineers on practical course in England; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1883; on special duty, Aug., 1883, on committee for considering reorganisation scheme for public works department; manager and engineer-in-chief Tirhout state railway.

BELL, JAMES GIBERNE, Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, infantry, Dec., 1851; from 17th Nov., 1855, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant resident, deputy commissioner, and officiating commissioner of West Berar; judicial commissioner, and civil appellate and sessions judge, Amraoti, April, 1877; has acted on several occasions as commissioner of the Hyderabad assigned districts.

BELL, MATTHEW DENNY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

BELLETT, G., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed to the Bengal educational service, 9th Oct., 1860; served successively as 2nd master, head master, and professor, Dacca College; inspector of schools, Nov., 1868; professor, Presidency College, Dec., 1873; principal, Berhampore College, May, 1875; 2nd class, educational service, March, 1876; subsequently served as officiating principal, Patna College, inspector of schools, officiating principal, Presidency College, and officiating director of public instruction (Jan., 1883).

BELLEW, HENRY WALTER, C.S.I., Deputy Surgeon-General, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1855; arrived in India, 24th March, 1856; served under the military department up to Jan., 1868, and subsequently as civil surgeon in the Punjab; on duty with Ameer of Kabul, March, 1869; deputed to Kashmir, April to Nov., 1869; served with the Seistan and Yarkand missions in 1871.
and 1873; residency surgeon, Nepaul, Feb., 1876; on special duty under the government of India, in the foreign department, April, 1876; rank of surgeon-major, July, 1876; sanitary commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1877; served under foreign department of government of India in connection with Kabul mission and Kurram field force, 1878 and 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Nov., 1881.

BENNETT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to take up land for railway purposes in Fyzabad, Feb., 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Gonda, March, 1872, to Feb., 1875; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Sept., 1878; officiating secretary to government, Oudh revenue department, Sept.-Nov., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882; acting secretary, board of revenue, July, 1844.

BENGERS, ALFRED, Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 20th Nov., 1866; junior examiner, June, 1867; senior examiner, July, 1877.

BENNETT, J., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; services placed at disposal of civil department, Sept., 1870; civil surgeon, Murree, Dec., 1872; superintendent of vaccination, Punjab, July, 1877; superintendent-general of vaccination, Punjab, Jan., 1881; deputy sanitary commissioner, Eastern Circle, Dec., 1881, to April, 1884; civil surgeon, Mooltan, Jan., 1883; also superintendent of central jail, Dec., 1883.

BENSLEY, EDWIN CLEMENT, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1859; served from 22nd July, 1863, as civil assistant surgeon at Midnapore and Rajshahye; civil surgeon, Oct., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, Feb., 1871.

BENSON, RALPH SILLERY, B.A., LL.B., Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, North Arcot, June, 1882; on special duty as secretary to the local self-government committee, Oct., 1882; forest settlement officer, May, 1883; acting under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, Jan., 1885; acting registrar, high court, July, 1885.

BENSON, THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tavistock Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, manager of the Awa estate under the court of wards, officiating district and session judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

BENTHAL, ERNEST, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 19th Dec., 1865; junior clerk, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1877.

BENTON, ALEXANDER HAY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Feb., 1864, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Peshawur, Nov., 1884.

BERESFORD, LORD W. L. DE LA P., Major, V.C., 9th Lancers.—Military secretary on the personal staff of the viceroy and governor-general (Rt. Hon. Earl of Dufferin, G.C.B., G.C.M.G., K.P.), 13th Dec., 1884.

BERKELEY, JAMES CAVAN, Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Oct., 1857; served in civil employ from 1863; political agent, Haraoti and Tonk, 1874; political agent, Bhagalcund, 1878-82; political agent, Jacobabad, 1882; officiating resident, Gwalior, 1883; on special duty, Kashmir, 1884; political agent, Bundelkhand, 1884; officiating resident, Nipal, 1885.

BERNARD, SIR CHARLES EDWARD, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S., (British Burma).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was appointed under secretary to government of India, financial department, Aug., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as judge of the small cause court, Nagpur, settlement officer, secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1864), commissioner of Nagpur division (Feb., 1869), and acting judicial commissioner; from May, 1871, to Jan., 1875, served in Bengal as member of the lieutenant-governor's council, and acting secretary to the government, first in the judicial department, then in the revenue department, and lastly in the scarcity and relief department; from Nov., 1876, served as commissioner of Nagpur division; services placed at disposal of department of agriculture, revenue, and commerce, Jan., 1877; secretary to Sir Richard Temple, Bart., K.C.S.I., deputed on a special mission to the Bombay and Madras Presidencies, Jan., 1877; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; additional secretary to the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Aug., 1877, and in the financial department Dec., 1877; secretary to the government of India in the home, revenue, and agricultural department, June, 1880; from July, 1880, acted as chief commissioner of British Burma, and was confirmed in this appointment April, 1882.

BERNARD, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Jan., 1885.

BERRY, FREDERICK CHARLES, B.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Ushaw College and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open
competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; also held acting appointments at various times as district superintendent of police, small cause court judge and cantonment magistrate, and deputy commissioner; acting superintendent of central jail and meteorological observatory, Nagpur, Jan., 1882; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Feb., 1882; on special duty, and appointed superintendent of affairs in Kalahandi State, March, 1882; political agent, Bhowani Patna, April, 1882.

BEST, JAMES WILLIAM, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimborne Grammar School and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from April, 1864, as assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate in various districts; from Jan., 1875, served as district and sessions, South Canara, Sept., 1877.

BETTINGTON, ALBEMARLE, late Bombay C.S.—Entered the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1830; served in the usual grades in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1843; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, 1849; inspector-general of prisons and commissioner of police, Bombay, 1855; retired 1861. Has published a work on 'The Destruction of Life by Snakes and Hydrophobia.'

BEVERIDGE, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating deputy commissioner, Cooch Behar, and magistrate and collector (2nd grade, April, 1874); on special duty in Munipore under the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1863; from Oct., 1874, served in the judicial department as officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879.

BEVERLEY, HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1865, and Aug., 1867; registrar-general of assurances, March, 1867; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1870; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1870; officiating inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Aug., 1876; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1877; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation, March, 1880; special census officer of Calcutta and suburbs, Dec., 1880; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Nov., 1883; judge of the high court of judicature, May, 1885.

BHAGWAN CHUNDER CHAKARBUTTI.—From 9th October, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, Khoolna, May, 1884.

BIDDULPH, THOMAS HENRY STILLINGFLEET, Financial Department, Government of India.—From July, 1869, to March, 1871, served as accountant, public works accounts, in Central India and Punjab, and as examiner of railway accounts; probationer in financial department March, 1871; assistant to the accountant-general N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1874; on special duty at Durbangah in Bengal, June, 1874, to May, 1875; from Jan., 1879, served as assistant accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces and also in the Punjab, Nov., 1881, to April, 1882, and as deputy accountant-general in Madras, April-Oct., 1882; officiated for various periods as deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; controller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884.

BIDEN, W. M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Mark's College, Chelsea, and King's College, London; provisional assistant, art library, South Kensington Museum, 1870; clerk, 2nd class, India Store Depot, 1st July, 1875; B.A., London University, 1880.

BIDIE, GEORGE, Deputy Surgeon-General, A.M., M.B., F.L.S., F.R.C.S.E., F.R.G.S., C.I.E., Madras Medical Department.—University of Aberdeen; joined the medical service as assistant surgeon, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; was subsequently employed as civil surgeon of Guntoor, 1859-61, medical officer of the Mysore farm commissariat establishments and medicinal garden, Hoonsoor, 1861-64, professor of botany and materia medica in the Medical College, acting principal medical storekeeper, and superintendent of the lunatic asylum, Madras, and served in Mysore and Coorg, Nov., 1867, to Feb., 1868, on special duty in the coffee districts; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department (military), March, 1870; superintendent of the government central museum, Aug., 1872, to Dec., 1884, and again Jan., 1885; on special duty at Ootacamund in connection with cinchona commission, Oct., 1873; fellow of Madras university, April, 1879; secretary to the surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, left wing, April, 1880, to Nov., 1884; brigade surgeon, Feb., 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; served in public department, Nov.-Dec., 1883, in connection with Calcutta International Exhibition, and special committee for promotion of art and manufacture; deputy surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, British Burma division, Dec., 1884-Jan., 1885; sanitary commissioner, Madras, April, 1885.

BIGGS, C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 3rd April, 1882.

BIGGS, T. HESKETH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 26th Sept., 1868, and served as assistant accountant-general in Bombay, the Central Provinces, and Madras; assistant comptroller-general, Dec., 1873; on special duty in Madras in connection with the inquiry into certain frauds in the stamp department, Dec., 1873, to Feb., 1874; served subsequently in the Punjab, the Central Provinces, Bengal, Bombay, and Assam, as assistant accountant-general, officiating for various periods as deputy accountant-general; appointed comptroller, Assam, Aug., 1880; officiating comptroller of Indian treasuries Oct.-Nov., 1883; deputy accountant-general, Punjab, in 3rd class of the financial department, 1885.
BIGNELL, W. K. D'O., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, Feb., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Nagpur, Jan., 1868; served in the Punjab from 1873; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1881.

BIGNOLD, THOMAS FRANK, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1859; arrived in India, 12th May, 1859; assistant magistrate and collector June, 1860; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, May, 1866; officiating superintendent of akbarae, Sept., 1871; officiating inspector-general of registration, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1875; also officiating inspector-general of jails, Dec., 1873; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1874; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; subsequently served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1879.

BIRCH, EDWARD ALFRED, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; Behar famine, March, 1874; civil surgeon at Hazaribagh, May, 1874, and subsequently at Darjeeling and Nuddea; from Nov., 1881, officiated as surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, and also held charge of the office of sanitary commissioner, Bengal, June-July, 1882, and acted as professor of midwifery at the Medical College, and obstetric physician, Eden Hospital, May, 1883; surgeon superintendent, Presidency Hospital, sub-pro tem., Dec., 1883.

BIRCH, ERNEST G., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1849; served in the revenue and survey departments, Bengal, and was appointed superintendent of survey, northern division, 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Baraset, 1858; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, 1860; civil and sessions judge, Moorsheadabad, 1864, and subsequently of Shahabad; additional judge of Chittagong, 1870; district and sessions judge of Burdwan, 1872; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1873; retired 1879.

BIRCH, FREDERICK MACDONALD, Colonel B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 15th May, 1854; from Jan., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty at Cashmere, July, 1864, and again, Dec., 1878, and with the financial commissioner's office, May, 1866; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1879, to Oct., 1880, and subsequently in the Mooltan and Hissar divisions; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Nov., 1880.

BIRCH, WILLIAM BRERETON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 30th Nov., 1858, and was posted to 32nd Native Infantry, Bengal; served with the China forces 1861-62; joined the Bengal police department July, 1863, and served as superintendent in various districts; member of Calcutta examination committee for judicial and police officers, March, 1867; vice-chairman, Burdwan municipality, March, 1867; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and a visitor of the Presidency jail and lunatic asylums, Feb., 1869; commanded Sylhet frontier police battalion, on Looshai expedition, Sept., 1871, to March, 1872; 2nd assistant superintendent, Andamans, April, 1873; 1st assistant superintendent, 1885.

BIRD, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from June, 1866, and was appointed principal assistant collector, May, 1881, district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Oct., 1884, and collector and magistrate in the same district, Feb., 1885.

BIRD, CHARLES PAVIN (Barfrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.
