(Punjab).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner.

BIRD, HUBERT MOORE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portarlington School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1885.

BIRDWOOD, SIR GEORGE C. M., C.S.I., M.D., Statistics and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at the Plymouth Grammar School and University of Edinburgh (M.D. and M.R.C.S., 1854); Bombay Medical Service 1854; between 1855 and 1857 served under the military department, and also held temporary charge of the civil station of Sholapore, including the jail; during this period served in the Persian War of 1856-57; from April, 1857 to 1868, held successively the professorships of anatomy and physiology, botany, and materia medica in the Grant Medical College, Bombay; curator of the Government Central Museum, Bombay, 1857, and with the assistance of Dr. Bhau Daji and the leading natives of Bombay founded the Victoria and Albert Museum and Victoria Gardens, Bombay; Sheriff of Bombay 1864, and subsequently registrar of the University of Bombay; special commissioner for the government of Bombay at the Universal Exhibition at Paris 1867; appointed to assist Dr. Forbes Watson in connection with the annual exhibitions at South Kensington commenced in 1871; special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India Office, Jan., 1878; is also visitor to the India Museum; author of the following publications: a paper 'On the Genus Boswellia (Frankincense Trees)', Linn. Trans. of 1869; 'Handbook to the British Indian Section of the Paris Universal Exhibition of 1878;' an official 'Report on the Miscellaneous Old Records of the India Office,' published in 1879; a work on 'The Industrial Arts of India,' published in 1880 by the Science and Art Department; and of several other handbooks on Indian art published by the department in connection with Indian exhibitions held at York, Berlin, Copenhagen, Stockholm, and Amsterdam; is a royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition of 1886, and a member of the finance committee appointed to assist the Prince of Wales in connection with the exhibition.

BIRDWOOD, HERBERT MILLS, M.A., LL.M., Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of
1858; arrived, 26th Jan., 1859, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the judicial department, and secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, acting assistant political agent, senior assistant judge and session judge, and registrar of the high court; judge and session judge, Surat, March, 1875; 1st grade judge, Dec., 1877; on special duty at Oodeypore, Sept., 1880; judicial commissioner in Sind and judge of the Sadar court, Feb., 1881; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1881; judge of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1885.

BIRDWOOD, WILLIAM ILBERT, Major-General, late R.E.—Joined the Madras Engineers 1825; appointed to the public works department June, 1830; served in the grades of assistant and civil engineer; district engineer, Tanjore, Jan., 1857; superintending engineer, south circle, March, 1859; deputy chief engineer, 1859; chief engineer and secretary to government of Madras, June, 1862; retired, Sept., 1863.

BIRKS, ARTHUR RAWSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Highgate School and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, April, 1874; served in the grade of assistant commissioner, and acted as collector of customs, Bassein, March, 1878, and as judge of Moulmein, 1880-1882; on special duty in Rangoon, Aug., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, May, 1884.

BISHOP, EDWARD F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 15th March, 1866; senior clerk, June, 1882.

BISSET, WILLIAM SINCLAIR SMITH, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Dec., 1866, as assistant engineer, Rohilkund canals; railway branch, Bengal, 1870; executive engineer, Punjab northern railway, March, 1871; officiating deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, April, 1872; deputy consulting engineer, Lahore, 1875; manager, Holkar State Railway, Feb., 1876; on special duty, Madras famine relief works, 1877; manager, Rajputana and Sindia Railway, Sept., 1879; class 1, grade 2, state railway revenue establishment, June, 1881.

BLACK, CHARLES E. D., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Harrow; writer, India office, 20th Sept., 1869; geographical department clerk, July, 1873; detached in 1880 to be assistant private secretary, and subsequently, from May, 1884, principal private secretary to H.M.'s secretary of state, home department (Rt. Hon. Sir William V. Harcourt); secretary to the royal commission on the blind, the deaf and dumb, &c., July, 1885; clerk for geographical records, India office, Sept., 1885; author of the 'Abstracts of the Reports of the Surveys and other Geographical Operations in India' from 1873 to 1878.

BLANC, HENRI JULES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., F.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 7th Aug., 1859, and served in the military department and also as acting civil surgeon in various stations, and as superintendent of vaccination; served in the China War, 1860-62, and was a member of the Abyssinian mission, 1864; superintendent of Yerrowda central jail, April, 1875; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibho Hospital, Bombay, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical College, May, 1878; also acted as professor of anatomy, and curator of the museum, May-June, 1879; physician, European General Hospital from June, 1883.

BLATHWAYT, CHARLES GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, Kanara, Oct., 1882.

BLENNERHASSETT, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton and Wimborne Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district judge, 3rd grade, March, 1883.

BLISS, HENRY WILLIAM, B.A., Madras C.S.—Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras from Aug., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Feb., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served as commissioner of salt revenue, and of abkari revenue, and was appointed customs collector throughout the Madras Presidency under the Sea Customs Act of 1878, Aug., 1882; on duty to Bombay, Oct., 1879, and to Calcutta and N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, to examine the working of the salt department; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; on duty to Orissa to report on the system of salt administration, Jan., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with the abkari committee, March, 1884.

BLISSETT, T., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st March, 1859; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Arracan division, Aug., 1869; personal assistant to director-general, 1873-75; served subsequently in the Dacca and Sind divisions, and in the store department, and from 1882 in Bombay; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1883.

BLOOMFIELD, ALFRED, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, March, 1856; served in the Central Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1867; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1876; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Balaghat, Aug., 1881.

BLYTH, GEORGE FRANCIS POPHAM, Ven., M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Archdeacon of Rangoon, Oct., 1879.

BLYTH, WILLIAM DUNBAR, M.A., Bengal
C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Collegiate Institution, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1880, and under secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; on deputation as under secretary in the judicial, political, and appointment departments, May, 1882.

BODDAM, WELBY WROUGHTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission 12th Dec., 1851; arrived in India 2nd July, 1852; served with the military police 1857-61; district superintendent of Lahore police, Feb., 1861; deputy inspector-general March, 1878; promoted to 1st grade, May, 1881; officiating inspector-general, Punjab, March, 1883.

BOILEAU, HENRY, Major, B.S.C.—Served under the military department from May, 1865, to April, 1873, when he was appointed officiating assistant commissioner, Burma; on special duty to Mandalay, May, 1873; assistant commissioner, 4th grade, and superintendent of immigration, Sept., 1874; also sub-registrar of deeds, Rangoon, Aug., 1875; on special duty in connection with the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Nov., 1876; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Jan., 1877; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, and small cause court judge, July, 1878; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, June, 1881, continuing to be employed as cantonment magistrate.

BOLSTER, J. A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Feb., 1872.

BOLTON, CHARLES WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, Royal College, Mauritius, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Oct., 1872; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, April, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1879; officiating under secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural department, Feb., 1880; on deputation as under secretary in the judicial, political, and appointments departments, government of Bengal, Feb., 1883; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, March, 1884.

BONAVIA, EMANUEL, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th August, 1857; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1857, and served under the military department up to Dec., 1861; assistant civil surgeon, Lucknow, Dec., 1861; on special duty, May, 1866; health officer, Lucknow, and superintendent of museum, observatory, and agricultural society's garden, April, 1867; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1869; was engaged for some time in 1872 under the military department in analysing drinking water; principal of medical school at Balrampur, in addition to other duties, Jan., 1873; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Sept. to Nov., 1874, and again Jan. to March, 1877, also officiating as inspector-general of prisons, Oudh; officiating civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1877; civil surgeon, Etawah, Dec., 1881.

BONUS, JOSEPH, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, March, 1857; joined the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer, June, 1859, and was employed on the Bombay harbour defences, Oct., 1860; from Sept., 1861, served as deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind; officiating deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, railway branch, March, 1870; from Nov., 1871, served as superintending engineer on Indus Valley state railway, and officiated as engineer-in-chief, Aug., 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, July, 1873; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, Sept., 1876; transferred to Punjab northern state railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, July-Oct., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Pindi-Peshawur section, Oct., 1879; superintending engineer, 1st class, April, 1881; acting consulting engineer for railways, and joint secretary to government, Bombay, with temporary rank of chief engineer, 3rd class, May, 1882; senior deputy consulting engineer and under secretary to government, railway branch, from Nov., 1883.

BOUGHEY, GEORGE FLETCHER OTTLEY, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1860, as assistant engineer, railway branch, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Rajputana railway, Sept., 1870; (temporary) deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, April, 1877; officiating assistant director, state railways, central system, 1878; assistant secretary, railway branch, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1879; personal assistant to chief engineer, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces, 1880; officiating manager, Nizam's state railway, Jan., 1881; manager, Indus Valley and Kandahar railway, Jan., 1882; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Oct., 1882.

BOULTON, CHARLES FREDERICK, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—Arrived in India, 6th Aug. 1852; on military duty up to Sept., 1856, when he was appointed acting assistant collector and magistrate, Satara; from 1860 served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate; superintendent, Bombay, Baroda, and C.I. railway police, Jan.-Aug., 1866; served subsequently in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting judge and sessions judge; manager of encumbered estates in the Karachi, Hyderabad, and Shikarpur collectorates, March, 1877; collector and magistrate Dec., 1879; acting commissioner in Sind, March-June, 1884.

BOURDILLON, JAMES AUSTIN, Bengal S.C.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; officiating under secretary, government of India, financial department, Sept., 1874, and subsequently in the home department, March, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Dec., 1875; from Aug., 1876, served in the registration department as inspector of registration offices,
and officiating inspector-general; deputy superintendent of census, Dec., 1880; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1881.

BOUTFLOWER, W. N., B.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department from 9th Aug., 1869, as professor in the Agra College, and officiated as principal, July-Dec., 1872; 3rd professor in the Muir Central College, Allahabad, Oct., 1874; officiating inspector of schools, July, 1875, to May, 1876; professor of mathematics, Muir College, March, 1876; 3rd grade of educational officers, April, 1878; officiating meteorological reporter to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April-June, 1881.

BOWER, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Caistor Grammar School, Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th December, 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

BOWIE, MATHEW MORTON, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Central Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th June, 1858; from June, 1863, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Delhi assemblage, Nov., 1876; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, June, 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Nagpur, March, 1881; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, April, 1882.

BOWRING, LEWIN BENTHAM, C.S.I., late Bengal, C.S.—Educated at Mount Radford School, Exeter, and at Leipzig; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1843; assistant magistrate and collector, 1845; assistant to treasurer, Calcutta, 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847-49; deputy commissioner, Punjab, 1849-54; private secretary to Lord Canning, 1858-62; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, 1862-70; retired 1870; has published 'Eastern Experiences,' and contributed papers to the Asiatic Society of Bengal.

BOXWELL, JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1883; also served as inspector of schools, July, 1865, and settlement officer, Midnapore, March, 1877.

BOYS, HENRY SCOTT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from Dec., 1864, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed superintendent of the encumbered estates of Sitapur and Kheri, June, 1872; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, March, 1883; deputy commissioner, and grade, July, 1883; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

BRADBURY, JAMES FRANCIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; also served as officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Sept., 1876, officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1878, and officiating district and sessions judge.

BRADFORD, SIR EDWARD RIDLEY COLBOURNE, Colonel, K.C.S.I., M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Cornet, 6th light cavalry, Madras, Feb., 1854; political agent, Bhagalpund, 1871; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, 1875; agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1879; also chief commissioner of Ajmere.

BRADLEY, HERBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in South Canara as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting head assistant, and was in charge of the South Canara forests, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner, salt revenue, April, 1885, and on special duty with the commissioner, July, 1885.

BRADLEY, J. A., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state.

BRAJENDRANATH DÉ, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Hare School, Calcutta, Canning College, Lucknow, Calcutta University, and St. Mary's Hall, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 6th September, 1875; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector.

BRANDRETH, ASHTON MILNES, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1857; served in the public works department from 8th Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, assistant principal, Thomason College, and executive engineer; transferred to the Punjab, Sept., 1861, and served on the Western Jumna Canal; assistant secretary, government of India, May to Dec., 1863; assistant secretary, public works department, Punjab, May, 1867; officiating assistant to chief engineer and secretary to Government, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; officiating superintending engineer, Western Jumna Canal, April, 1871; principal, Thomason College, Feb., 1879.

BRANDT, FRANCIS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from June, 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, and in the departments under the chief secretary, acting sub-secretary to board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty, board of revenue, 1872; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, April, 1874; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1877, and afterwards in the Nilgiris, 1883; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, June, 1878; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Sept., 1884.
BRANFOOT, ARTHUR MUDGE, Surgeon-Maj., M.B., M.R.C.S.E., L.R.C.P.L., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th March, 1872; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1872, and served under the military department till March, 1873, and subsequently as civil surgeon at Canada, and Madras, and as resident surgeon at the general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology in the Medical College, April-July, 1878; assistant physician, general hospital, and professor of hygiene, Medical College, July, 1878; superintendent of the lying-in-hospital, and professor of midwifery, Medical College, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884.

BRANSON, JAMES CHARLES EMERTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1882, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

BRASHER, ALFRED, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed traffic manager, Persian Gulf telegraphs, 1863; superintendent, London office, 1867; director of traffic 1880; had charge of London training school in autumn, 1863; had executive charge of examinations for Indian telegraph department from 1867 to the opening of Cooper's Hill College; projected mean tariff between India and Europe, which replaced rates to different countries; has been on special duty to Constantinople, Vienna, Berlin, and Berne; has made public translations of the international telegraph conventions of Rome, St. Petersburg, London, and Berlin.

BRERETON, ASHLEY F., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School; supernumerary writer, 13th Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Jan., 1869; junior clerk; financial department, April, 1874; senior clerk Nov., 1885; transferred to revenue statistics and commerce department, 1886.

BRERETON, REGINALD HUGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

BRETT, ALFRED CORBYN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; from Aug., 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; from May, 1878, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1880.

BRETT, CECIL MICHAEL WILFORD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, May, 1885.

BRIDGES, JAMES EMILE, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Royal College, Tournoi, and University of Bonn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, land revenue, and agricultural department, and officiating director of agriculture, Nov., 1884.

BRIGHT, WILLIAM ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

BRIND, CHARLES BROWNLOW, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, Punjab, Dec., 1884.

BROADFOOT, RAMSAY DOUGLAS (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Kensington School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate and acting sub-collector and magistrate.

BROCKMAN, W. D., A.M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the Punjab as sub-assistant revenue surveyor, 1852-55; joined Thomason College at Roorkee, and from there was appointed to the public works department, April, 1858, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer; transferred temporarily to railway department, Nov., 1859, to Dec., 1860; employed on famine relief works on Ganges Canal in 1861, and again in 1877-78 in the Rae Bareli division; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1874; on special duty in the public works secretariat, Nov., 1878; promoted temporarily to superintending engineer, 3rd class, Aug., 1881; superintendent of works, Agra, Oct., 1883.

BRODHURST, MAYNARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1850; arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1850; from Oct., 1851, to Sept., 1858, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1858, and appointed magistrate and collector, Ghazipur, May, 1862; from Feb., 1870, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge, Benares, and was temporarily additional judge of the high court in 1874; on special duty to Singapur, April to Aug., 1876; also served as president of the commissions appointed in 1872 and 1879 respectively to inquire into the charges brought against the sub-judges of Mirzapore and Farakhabad; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1881.

BRODIE, VERNOR ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India 6th Jan., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; senior assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1885.

BROJENDRO COOMAR SEAL, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 23rd Oct., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial department,
Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1880, and district judge, Bankoora, and assistant session judge, Burdwan, April, 1881.

BROOKE, THOMAS HENRY BARSTOW, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, April, 1855; arrived in India, 13th May, 1855; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, and as judge of the small cause court, Jubbulpore, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Nov., 1874; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, March, 1883.

BROOKE, W. R., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 13th Sept., 1857; superintendent, Bombay, Jan., 1866; served in the Punjab, 1860-1871; 1st grade superintendent Aug., 1877, officiating as director of traffic; director, construction branch, June, 1883.

BROOKE, WILLIAM SAURIN, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1858; arrived in India 3rd January, 1859; served in the Central Provinces from Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; acting assistant settlement officer, Chanda, Oct., 1865; acting registrar-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, May, 1869; deputy commissioner, and class, Oct., 1881; acting inspector-general of police and jails, Aug.-Nov., 1883.

BROWN, JOHN ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating cantonment magistrate.

BROWN, JOHN CROMMELIN, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India 24th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; was employed in the public works department, Nov., 1879, to April, 1880; on special duty, Dec., 1880.

BROWN, THOMAS EDWIN BURTON, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1858; arrived in India, 11th Feb., 1859; from Nov., 1860, served as professor of chemistry and chemical examiner, medical school, Lahore; principal, medical school, March, 1872; professor of surgery and midwifery in addition to his other duties, April-Dec., 1876; also officiated as civil surgeon of Lahore on several occasions, and as meteorological reporter, July-Aug., 1879.

BROWNE, C. M., Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1854; joined the public works department, June, 1850, as assistant engineer, Punjab; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1868; officiating assistant to chief engineer, Punjab, Nov., 1868; assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary, public works department, Punjab, May, 1871; assistant to chief engineer, military works, Murree, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, Aug., 1873; superintending engineer, Punjab (provincial), Feb., 1877; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883.

BROWNE, LORD HENRY ULIK, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, Dec., 1850; arrived 1st Sept., 1851; served in the revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; also served as private secretary to the president of the governor-general's council, Feb., 1858, under secretary to the government of Bengal, July, 1859, officiating under secretary to the government of India, home and financial department, April, 1860, registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, April, 1861, superintendent of stamps and stationery, Oct., 1865, and officiating additional judge, Jessore and Nuddea, Feb., 1867; commissioner, Chittagong division, Dec., 1869, and subsequently of the Presidency, and Rajshahye and Cooch Behar divisions; chairman of the justices of the peace, Calcutta, Feb., 1872, and officiating member, board of revenue, June, 1878.

BROWNE, JAMES, Colonel, C.B., C.S.I., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, May, 1860, as assistant engineer in the Punjab; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1873; superintendent of works, Indus Bridge, Indus Valley state railway, Jan., 1875; assistant secretary to government buildings and road branch, Punjab, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Oct., 1882, military works; transferred temporarily to railway branch for employment on the Hurnai road, Biluchistan, 1883; engineer-in-chief, Sind-Pishin state railway, 1884; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1884.

BROWNE, JAMES FRANCIS, Ven., B.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Divinity College, London; junior chaplain, Madras, 20th July, 1870; senior chaplain, July, 1880; archdeacon of the diocese of Madras and commissary to the Lord Bishop, Feb., 1884; senior joint chaplain of St. George's Cathedral, Feb., 1884; in charge of the diocese, May to Oct., 1884.

BROWNE, JOHN FREDERICK (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 22nd Jan., 1856; served in the revenue, judicial, and survey departments, and was appointed superintendent of survey, May, 1861, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1869; from Nov., 1869, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1877; on special duty connected with the settlement of the disputed boundary between Munipore and Assam, Dec., 1870; officiating judicial commissioner of British Burma, March to June, 1883.

BROWNE, WILLIS, A.I.A., Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 15th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; actuary clerk, Feb., 1882.

BROWNING, COLIN ARROTT ROBERTSON, M.A., C.I.E., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Senior inspector of schools, N.W. Provinces, 26th June, 1862; acted as director of public instruction, Central Provinces, May, 1864, to March, 1865, and as inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, April-Oct., 1868, and again March, 1869, to July, 1870; director of
public instruction in Oudh, July, 1870; inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, Oct., 1873; on special duty at Calcutta in connection with education conference in 1882.

BROWNLLOW, HENRY ALEXANDER, Colonel, R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1847; deputy superintendent, Ganges Canal, Feb., 1852; and afterwards on the Eastern and Western Jumna Canals; superintendent, Eastern Jumna Canals, 1858; superintending engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, March, 1865; 1st grade superintending engineer, Sept., 1870; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1872; superintending engineer, Bari Doab, Punjab, April, 1874; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, 1876; officiating inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, April, 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, irrigation, July, 1878; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, Feb., 1882.

BROWNRIGG, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rossall and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

BRUCE, RICHARD ISAAC, C.I.E., Political Department, Punjab.—1st assistant to governor-general's agent in Biluchistan, 1877; political agent at Thal-Chotiali from 1882.

BUCK, EDWARD CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from May, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and officiating secretary, board of revenue; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1875; commissioner for the government of India at the Melbourne International Exhibition of 1880; officiated as secretary to the Government of India in the revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881, and was confirmed in that appointment April, 1882.

BUCKLAND, CHARLES EDWARD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; attaché, foreign department, Nov., 1871; officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Barrackpore, Jan., 1874; on special duty in Behar, Jan., 1874; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1875; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, April, 1874, to Jan., 1877; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1876; private secretary to Sir Richard Temple during his mission to Madras and Bombay, Jan., 1877; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, May, 1878; private secretary to president of governor-general's council, Nov., 1878; officiating press commissioner with government of India, Feb., 1879; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bengal, May, 1880; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1882.

BUCKLE, HENRY, Uncov. C.S., Burma.—Served in the Burma commission from 7th Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, and was in charge of the town magistrate's office, Akyab, Sept., 1871, to Nov., 1874, and of the Hill Tracts of Northern Arakan, Dec., 1874, to Jan., 1876; in command of an expedition beyond the frontier against the Shandus, Nov., 1876; from June, 1878, served as deputy commissioner in Hanthawaddy and the Thongwa district, and was promoted to 2nd grade, April, 1882.

BULLEN-SMITH, JAMES RICHARD, C.S.I.—Additional member of council of governor-general of India, for making laws and regulations, 1860-1877; member of council of secretary of state for India, June, 1884; has held the offices of sheriff of Calcutta (2 years), president of the Bengal chamber of commerce (3 years), and president of the bank of Bengal; was a director of the East Indian Railway Company, 1881-84, and of the Bengal and North-Western Railway Company, 1882-84.

BULLOCK, FREDERICK D'OLBERT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School, St. Aubin's Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant-commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judge small cause court, Delhi, Jan., 1873; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1882; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

BULLOCK, FREDERICK SHORE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, assistant superintendent and small cause judge of Dehra Dun, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Oct., 1882; officiating district and sessions judge, Allahabad, May, 1883.

BULLOCK, ROBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, Madras army (infantry), 11th Dec., 1858; from July, 1862, served in the Berar commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant resident, officiating small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (March, 1880).

BULMAN, ALBERT ROBINSON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Richmond Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1878; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1882.

BURGESS, GEORGE DOUGLAS, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1870, and served in the British Burma commission as assistant commissioner, assistant collector of customs, and deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officer in charge of state prisoners, Jan., 1879; secretary to chief commis-
sioner, July, 1881; officiating commissioner, Tenasserim, Sept., 1884.

BURKITT, WILLIAM ROBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880.

BURLS, E. GRANT, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 20th Oct., 1863; junior clerk, store department, Dec., 1865; senior clerk Jan., 1875.

BURLTON, HENRY MONTGOMERY BARTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 5th Native Infantry, Bengal, Aug., 1855; assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1870; cantonment magistrate, Mhow, 1881; cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1885.

BURNE, SIR OWEN T., Colonel, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Political Department, India Office.—Ensign, 20th foot, 15th April, 1855; served in the Crimea, and in the Indian Mutiny, 1858-59, and was promoted to a captaincy and brevet majority for services in the field; brigade-major at Gondah, Oudh, 1859-61; military secretary to commander-in-chief in India, 1861-62; A.D.C., and at times officiating military secretary to commander of the forces in Ireland, 1865-68; private secretary to viceroy of India, 1869-72; political A.D.C. to the secretary of state for India, 1872; assistant secretary, and subsequently secretary in the political and secret department, India Office, in 1874; on special duty in India as private secretary to the viceroy, 1876-78.

BURNEY, RICHARD THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1858; arrived in India, 14th Feb., 1858, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; superintendent, Chamba State, April, 1877; officiating additional sessions judge, Jan., 1880; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1880; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawul Pindi divisions, Dec., 1880; additional judge, chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Lahore.

BURROWS, LEONARD ROBERT, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Lincoln Diocesan School, St. Nicholas College, Lancing, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1865; president of municipal commission, Madras, June, 1875; sub-collector and joint magistrate, March, 1882; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Sept., 1883; collector and magistrate and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Sept., 1884.

BUSTED, HENRY ELMSLEY, Surgeon-Major; M.D., Mint Department, Calcutta.—First commission, Indian medical service (Madras establishment), Aug., 1855; arrived in India, March, 1856; civil surgeon, Cuddalore, Jan., 1861; assistant assay master, Madras mint, Feb., 1865; acted as assay master for various periods, and also as mint master and commissioner of paper currency; deputy assay master, Bombay, April, 1868; from Feb., 1869, served in the Calcutta mint as officiating assay master, and was appointed deputy assay master, Nov., 1870, and confirmed as assay master, Sept., 1872; also acted as mint master in 1873 and 1875.

BUTLER, JAMES, Captain B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 19th foot, Feb., 1866; arrived in India, 24th May, 1866; served in the Burma commission from Oct., 1868, as assistant commissioner and town magistrate; appointed a deputy commissioner, July, 1881, and promoted to 3rd grade, Sept., 1883.

BUTLER, WILLIAM G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Bradfield and Eton; junior clerk, store department, India office, 31st Jan., 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to secretary of state 1874-78.

BUTTS, HENRY HILL (Barrister-at-Law), Uoov.C.S., Oudh Commission.—Extra assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, 3rd June, 1863; from Nov., 1865, to Oct., 1873, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer, and from the latter date as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Hardoi, Oct., 1883.

BYATT, J., Store Department, India Office.—Assistant clerk, education department, May, 1869, to May, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, May, 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, Nov., 1880.

BYRNE, EDWARD SIMPSON, Financial Department, Government of India.—Head assistant to auditor-general of India, June, 1862; served in Hyderabad from Jan., 1865, to March, 1871, as deputy auditor and accountant-general, and was ordered on special duty to Calcutta in connection with Berar finance, Dec., 1867; from March, 1871, to Feb., 1874, served in the Punjab as deputy accountant-general and acting accountant-general, and trustee, Punjab University; served subsequently as deputy accountant-general in Assam, Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1879, and in Bombay 1879 to July, 1882, and acted as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, in 1879; from July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as deputy accountant-general, and acted as accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Allahabad, Sept.-Oct., 1882; deputy comptroller-general (afterwards designated deputy auditor-general) in 1st class of the financial department, July, 1883.

CADELL, ALAN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Guetersloh Gymnasium, Westphalia, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from July, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from April, 1867, to March, 1881, served in the settlement department in Allahabad, Mozaffarnagar, and Banda, and was placed on special duty, June, 1867, and again in March, 1869, to conduct the prosecution of the Munisif of Deoband; promoted to settlement officer, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1880; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1883;
magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1885.

CADELL, ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-General late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 13th June, 1845; joined the public works department, April, 1848; executive engineer, Rawul Pindi, 1850; executive engineer, Nagpore, April, 1856; executive engineer in Oude road department, Dec., 1858; superintendent of works, northern road, and Saugor division, 1863; superintending engineer, Punjab, 1864; from 1867 to 1878 served in Indore, first as superintending engineer, and then as chief engineer, and secretary to the governor-general's agent for Central India; also officiated as chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1874-75; chief engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, 1879-80; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1881; inspector-general, military works, 1881-82; retired 13th March, 1882.

CADELL, ARTHUR WILLIAM REES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1883.

CADELL, THOMAS, Colonel, V.C., B.S.C.—2nd lieutenant, 2nd European fusiliers, Bengal, Oct., 1854; deputy Bheel agent and assistant political agent, Nimar, Dec., 1860; political agent, Ulwar, 1871; political agent, Meywar, 1878; chief commissioner and superintendent, Port Blair and the Nicobars, from 1879.

CALL, C. F., Major, R.E., Store Department, India Office.—Entered the royal engineers, 16th July, 1866; served on the Indian establishment with the Bengal sappers and miners, and afterwards in the public works department, buildings and roads and railway branches, Feb., 1860, to Sept., 1881; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80; assistant superintendent, India store depot, Jan., 1883.

CALLAGHAN, T., Registry Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, 27th March, 1885.

CAMERON, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1850; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department 1860-66, and served in the Bhootan campaign; from April, 1866, served in the civil department in Oudh, as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Bahrach and Rae Bareli; rank of surgeon July, 1871; surgeon-major, Sept., 1875; served also as civil surgeon of Bara Banki and Gonda.

CAMERON, DUNCAN, M.A., Bengal, C.S.—Aberdeen University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

CAMPBELL, ARCHIBALD COLIN, Uncov. C.S., Assam.—Served in Assam from 27th April, 1861, as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to chief commissioner; superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Dhubri, Sept., 1875; promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883.

CAMPBELL, ARCHIBALD EDWARDES, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Jan., 1851; served in the Assam commission from 30th May, 1862, and was promoted to 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Aug., 1883; inspector of labourers, Sibsagar, Feb., 1882.

CAMPBELL, COLIN G., India Office.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; junior clerk, military department, 13th Jan., 1876; private secretary to permanent under-secretary of state from 1877.

CAMPBELL, DUNCAN JOHN ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1877, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, boundary officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, May, 1883.

CAMPBELL, SIR GEORGE, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at New Academy, Edinburgh, and St. Andrews; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1842; served in Rohilkund, 1843 to 1846, in usual grades of the revenue and judicial departments, and was in charge of several districts and political divisions of cis-Sutlej states, 1846-51; on furlough 1851 to 1854, during which he was associate of the court of Queen's Bench, and published 'Modern India,' and 'India as it may be;' magistrate and collector, Azimgurh, 1854; commissioner of customs, N.W. Provinces, 1855; commissioner of the cis-Sutlej states, 1855-1857; took an active part in the events following the mutiny, and was present at several engagements; personal assistant to governor-general, Lord Canning, 1857-58; judicial and financial commissioner of Oude 1858; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1862-66; president of the commission to enquire into the famine in Orissa, 1866-67; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1867-68; while on furlough, 1868-70, published a work on Irish land tenure; D.C.L., University of Oxford; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1871-74; retired 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1874-75; resigned on election as M.P. for Kirkcaldy burghs in 1875; presided over economy and trade department at the Social Science Congress at Glasgow, 1874; re-elected for the Kirkcaldy burghs in 1880 and again in 1885; is the author of numerous statistical, ethnological, and linguistic works on India, also of 'A Handy Book of the Eastern Question,' 1876, and of various publications on different countries visited by him.

CAMPBELL, FRANCIS JOHNSTONE GRAHAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 20th January, 1864; from Feb., 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1875, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, April, 1880.

CAMPBELL, GERALD EDWARD LYON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1884.

CAMPBELL, JAMES McNABB, M.A., C.I.E. Bombay C.S.—Educated at Glasgow Academ and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bor
bay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and compiler of the 'Gazetteer' and 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency'; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; acting municipal commissioner Bombay, April, 1880; acting under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1880; acted as collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery in 1881; 1st assistant collector, Bombay presidency, May, 1885.

CAMPBELL, JOHN McLEOD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Academy and University of Glasgow; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; on special duty, Poonah, March, 1869; from Oct., 1873, acted as judicial assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1878; acting judicial commissioner and judge of the Sadar court in Sind, May, 1883; and grade, judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Aug., 1883; 1st grade judge, Surat, Feb., 1885.

CANDY, EDWARD TOWNSHEND (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; on special duty, Poonah, March, 1869; from Oct., 1873, acted as judicial assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1878; acting judicial commissioner and judge of the Sadar court in Sind, May, 1883; and grade, judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Aug., 1883; 1st grade judge, Surat, Feb., 1885.

CANDY, RICHARD EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting educational inspector; acting director of public instruction, Berar, June, 1872, to Dec., 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate Oct., 1877; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1885.

CAPPEL, A. J. LEPPOC, Indian Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the telegraph department, 10th Feb., 1857; 1st grade superintendent and personal assistant to director-general, Dec., 1866; director of traffic, May, 1869; deputy director-general, Feb., 1879; director-general of telegraphs, June, 1883.

CAPPÉL, EDWARD LOUIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from May, 1882, served under the government of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; transferred permanently to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

CARD, H. C., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

CARDEW, ALEXANDER GORDON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy registrar high court, and acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments (July, 1885); on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1884.

CARDOZO, HENRY O'CONNELL, Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 21st March, 1859, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, 1st class, March, 1883.
CAREY, Arthur Douglas, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the City of London School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the salt department from May, 1872, to March, 1877, and from May, 1877, to Feb., 1882, as assistant collector of salt revenue, and acting deputy collector, and was appointed collector of salt revenue, Bombay, April, 1881; on special duty to Sambhar, Oct., 1881; from Feb., 1882, served under the government of India as officiating commissioner, inland customs; commissioner, salt revenue, Northern India, Dec., 1882.

CAREY, Lionel Slade, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the Central Provinces as supernumerary assistant commissioner; acting district superintendent of police, July, 1883; acting inspector of schools, May–July, 1884; acting deputy commissioner, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, June, 1885.

CARLYLE, Robert Warrand, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Glasgow University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

CARMICHAEL, Charles Paget, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and subsequently at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; arrived in India, March, 1849; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1854; officiating registrar of Sudder Dewany and Nizamat Adawlut, April, 1854; officiating civil auditor, Aug., 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1856; deputed as civil officer with the relieving force to Shahjahanpur, April, 1858; magistrate and collector, Budaun, Feb., 1862; officiating commissioner, Kumaun, May, 1867, to Jan., 1868; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1870; from April, 1873, acted as commissioner and agent to governor-general, Benares, and was confirmed in these appointments, March, 1877; also held the substantive appointment of district and sessions judge, Jan., 1877; officiated as member of the board of revenue in 1877–78–79, and was appointed permanently to the board in 1882; retired March, 1884.

CARMICHAEL, David Fremantle, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury, 1851; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1851; head assistant registrar, court of Sudr and Foujdaree Adawlut, Feb., 1855; deputy secretary to government, Oct., 1855; secretary to board of examiners, Oct., 1856; private secretary to governor of Madras, March, 1859; fellow of Madras University, Oct., 1859; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1863, to April, 1867, and afterwards at Ganjam; acting judge, high court, Madras, April to July, 1869; employed in preparation of Vizagapatam district; manual; acting member, board of revenue, Aug., 1871; president of committee for examination of assistants, July, 1871; Inam commissioner, Aug., 1871; on special duty as president of the committee for inquiring into the action of government officials during cyclone in 1872, May, 1872; secretary to government, revenue department, Nov., 1872; additional member of council for making laws and regulations Feb., 1874; on special duty with government at imperial assemblage, Delhi, Dec., 1876; chief secretary to government, June, 1877; ordinary member of council, Madras, Dec., 1878; on tour as special commissioner through Hill tracts of Ganjam, Vizagapatam, and Godavari, Feb., 1881.

CARNDUFF, Herbert William Cameron, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1883.

CARSTAIRS, Robert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and Edinburgh Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882.

CARTER, Albert M., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 4th Nov., 1861; junior clerk, March, 1866; senior clerk, Aug., 1882.

CARTER, Henry Vandyke, Brigade Surgeon, M.D. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 27th Jan., 1858; arrived in India, 29th March, 1858, and served on military duty and as professor of anatomy and physiology, and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital; also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Satara; on special duty in England, May, 1874, and in Bombay and Kathiawar, 1875; acting principal and professor of medicine and clinical medicinere, Grant Medical College, and acting first physician Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, April-Oct., 1877, and again in 1878–79, and 1882–84; appointed surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, Bombay, Nov., 1879; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1882.

CARTER, Thomas Tupper, Major, R.E. (Bengal), Survey of India.—First commission, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, Dec., 1859; served with the Sikkim Field Force, 1860–61, as survey officer; from May, 1861, to April, 1862, served as assistant engineer in the public works department, Punjab; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862, and served as assistant in the Kashmir and Kumaon and Garhwal surveys; surveyor, 3rd grade, April, 1866; in charge of the survey party with the Abyssinian expedition, Dec., 1867, to March, 1869; was subsequently in charge of survey parties on the Brahmaputra, in Madras, Guzerat, Kumaon, Gwalior, and Central India; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Jan., 1878.

CASEY, Arthur Edwin Comerford, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School and Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in
India, 23rd Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Kumaon, May, 1882.

CASPERZ, CHARLES PETER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and London University.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

CASSELS, ANDREW.—Member of the council of the secretary of state for India from April, 1874, to April, 1884.

CAVE-BROWNE, E. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the College School, Taunton; junior clerk in the treasury, East India House, 12th April, 1854, and from 1858 in the India Office; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant in the accounts branch of the financial department, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax 1872; deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1879.

CAYLEY, H., Brigade Surgeon, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1857; from April, 1872, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of royal botanical gardens, ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic surgery, Medical College, Calcutta (from 1876), superintendent of the eye infirmary, and marine surgeon; rank of brigade surgeon, April, 1884.

CENTER, WILLIAM, M.B., M.A., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1865; arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from March, 1871, served under the government of the Punjab as chemical examiner and professor of chemistry and surgery in the Lahore medical school; officiating meteorological reporter in addition to his other duties, May, 1872; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; served under the government of India, Aug.–Nov., 1882, as statistical officer in sanitary department; officiated as principal of the medical school in 1878, 1882, and 1883; civil surgeon, Lahore, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, 1885.

CHAMIER, FRANCIS EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Judicial Department, Oudh.—Arrived in India as ensign, 7th April, 1850; from March, 1858, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, officiating settlement officer, and officiating commissioner in various divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Bara Banki, April, 1873; district judge, 1st grade, Rae Bareli, Feb., 1882, and afterwards at Fyzabad.

CHANNING, FRANCIS CHORLEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; settlement secretary to financial commissioner Jan., 1878; senior secretary to the financial commissioner, March, 1882.

CHAPMAN, CHARLES, Uncov. C.S., Oudh Commission.—Assistant in the opium department, Bengal, 27th May, 1862; assistant conservator of Oudh forests, Sept., 1865; from Sept., 1866, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; superintendent of encumbered estates, Gonda and Fyzabad, 1875–76; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Rae Bareli, Oct., 1883.

CHAPMAN, CHARLES, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 6th Aug., 1884.

CHAPMAN, FRANCIS STEUART, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1849; served as assistant collector and magistrate, Belgaum, up to 1852, when he was appointed assistant to Inam commissioner, and was employed on special duty in connection with the settlement of claims to compensation on account of the abolition of transit and town duties; 1st assistant to collector and magistrate, Ahmednuggur, 1855; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, 1862, and subsequently of Sattara; chief secretary to government of Bombay and secretary in revenue and finance departments, 1865; additional member of council, Bombay, 1869, and again in 1871; retired 1877.

CHAPMAN, ROBERT BARCLAY, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary to government of India, home and financial departments, Jan., 1858, to April, 1860; called to the bar (Inner Temple) Jan., 1863; secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, June, 1863; acting commissioner, Presidency division, Nov., 1866, to Jan., 1869; served subsequently as secretary to government of India, financial department, and government director of Bank of Bengal; retired 1881.

CHARLES, FENDALL LOWIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Repton School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty, demarcation of forests in Nasik, July, 1875; forest settlement officer, Dharwar, Nov., 1881; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883.

CHARLES, JOHN GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 15th Dec., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1866; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1870; on special duty (member of cattle plague commission) June, 1870; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1871; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, March, 1876; officiating chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1880; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885.

CHARLTON, A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 8th April, 1882.

CHATFIELD, KYRLE MITFORD, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th March, 1866, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as educational inspector and as director of public instruction, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, Nov., 1874.

CHATTERTON, FRANK WILLIAM, Major, Gen. List, Infantry.—Arrived in India as ensign
4th Nov., 1859; employed under the military department till Feb., 1869, from which date he served in Jhansi and Kumaon as officiating assistant commissioner; from May, 1873, served as cantonment magistrate of Roorkee; also appointed a small cause court judge, Roorkee, March, 1879; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Agra, Dec., 1880.

CHESNEY, GEORGE TOMKYNS, Colonel, R.E., C.S.I.—Joined the service, 1848; served in the public works department from 1851, as executive engineer in the Lower Provinces, N.W. Provinces, and Punjab; assistant to principal of Thomason College, 1856; controller and examiner of accounts, public works department, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1860; inspector-general of public works accounts, Bengal, Jan., 1862; also ex-officio under secretary to government of India; accountant-general, public works department, May, 1864; on the institution of the Royal Indian Engineering College at Cooper's Hill in 1870, was appointed president of the college, and continued in that post till 1880, when he was appointed military secretary to the government of India; military member of governor-general's council, May, 1886.

CHIPPER, E., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Finchley, matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 3rd Dec., 1875.

CHIPPERFIELD, A. E., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th June, 1881.

CHISHOLM, JAMES WRIGHT, Uncov. C.S., Central Provinces.—Served in the Central Provinces from 24th Oct., 1856, as deputy collector, assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1871; inspector-general of police and jails, Oct., 1876; secretary to the chief commissioner, June, 1880; commissioner of the Chhattisgarh division, March, 1883.

CHITPAL SINGH, RAJA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a covenanted civilian under native civil service rules without probation, 12th Dec., 1881; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

CHOLMELEY, NORMAN GOODFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884.

CHRISTIE, ARCHIBALD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty, Kurram field force, Oct., 1878.

CHUNDER MADHUB GHOSE. — Member of the legislative council of Bengal, 1883 to 1885; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1885.

CHURCH, WILLIAM THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintendent, Dehra Dun, Jan., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Azamgarh, July, 1885.

CLARK, WILLIAM OVENS, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Portora School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty, Bengal, Feb., 1874; on special duty in the public works department March, 1882; officiating cantonment magistrate, Mooltan, April, 1883.

CLARKE, SIR ANDREW, Major-General, R.E., G.C.M.G., C.B., C.I.E.—Member of governor-general's council in charge of public works 15th June, 1875, to 1880; inspector-general of fortifications and director of works, ordnance department, War Office.

CLARKE, C. B., M.A., Educational Service, Assam.—Appointed to the Bengal educational department, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor at the Presidency College and as inspector of schools; officiating superintendent of the Calcutta botanical garden, May, 1869; 1st class of the education department, March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1879; transferred to Assam as inspector of schools, March, 1885.

CLARKE, ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant, and was in charge of the Jhelum settlement, Aug., 1878; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, May, 1881.

CLARKE, TREDWAY GEORGE, Colonel, M.S.C.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, 1853; served in the Mysore commission from Oct., 1857; deputy superintendent, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner, Mysore, 1873; from 1875 acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, and was confirmed in this appointment, 1877; commissioner, Nagar division, May, 1879; commissioner of Coorg, 1881; officiating chief commissioner, Dec., 1884.

CLARKE, WILLoughby CHARLES STANLEY, Colonel, B.S.C.—Commission as ensign, June, 1851; arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1851; was employed on military duty till 1862, also serving as superintendent of police and magistrate, governor-general's camp, Sept., 1859, to Jan., 1860; from June, 1862, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1885.

CLAY, ARTHUR LLOYD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cholmeley Grammar School, Highgate, at Cologne, and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 29th Nov., 1862; from Nov., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1874; from Sept., 1874, to June, 1877, served in Assam as deputy commissioner, 1st grade, and district and ses-
CLAY, WILLIAM MCKINLEY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating deputy commissioner (Ward's estate, Patna); on famine relief duty, 1873-74; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1881.

CLEGG, ROBERT BAILEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885.

CLEGHORN, JAMES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical department, March, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; served in Bengal, and held various military medical charges, and officiated as civil surgeon of Howrah and Moorshebdabad, 1867, and of Mooltan and Cawnpore, 1868-69; from Feb., 1870, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, Azimgarh, June, 1870; junior civil surgeon and superintendent, district jail, Allahabad, April, 1873; held medical charge of the camp of the lieutenant-governor on several occasions, including Imperial assemblage at Delhi, 1876; civil surgeon of Naini Tal, March, 1876; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; on special duty to Calcutta, Dec., 1880; in medical charge of Mirzapur, Nov., 1883; officiating surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, Calcutta, June, 1885.
