CLERK, SIR GEORGE RUSSELL, G.C.S.I., K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1816; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and judge, and was appointed 1st assistant to the secretary in the secret and political department in 1820; assistant resident, Rajputana, and officiating assistant superintendent, Ajmere, 1821; assistant resident, Nagpur, and afterwards at Delhi, and assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1827; officiated as political agent at Jeypore and in other districts, 1828-31; political agent, Umballah, 1831, and at Loodianah, 1839; agent to governor-general in the Punjab, 1840; envoy to the court of Maharajah Shere Singh at Lahore 1842; provisional member of council of governor-general, 1845; member of governor-general's council, 1846; governor of Bombay, 23rd Jan., 1847; retired from the civil service, May, 1847; appointed one of the secretaries to the board of control, 1856, and on the transfer of Indian affairs to the crown was made under secretary of state for India, 1859; again governor of Bombay, May, 1860, to April, 1862; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1864-76.

CLOETE, HENRY DANIEL, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Army, Dec., 1849; arrived, 27th April, 1850; served in the Madras police department from June, 1860, as superintendent, deputy inspector-general, acting commissioner and acting chief magistrate of police for the town of Madras; inspector-general of police, Madras, from Dec., 1881.

CLOGSTOUN, HERBERT FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting assistant superintendent of police, April, 1867, to April, 1868; acting deputy director of revenue settlement March, 1872; on special duty in connection with state relief works, Kurnool, Dec., 1876; acting principal assistant collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Vizagapatam, Jan., 1880; joint sessions judge in Rumpa cases, Jan., 1880; from March, 1880, served in the financial department as assistant accountant-general, Madras, officiating accountant-general, Bengal, assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and deputy accountant-general, Madras; member of board of examiners, Madras, June, 1882; accountant-general and commissioner of issue of state paper currency, Madras, July, 1882.

COATES, JOHN MARTIN, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Bengal Medical Department.—First commission, 1855; in medical charge of 1st Bengal military police battalion, Dec., 1856; civil assistant surgeon, April, 1859; superintendent of jails, Hazaribagh, Nov., 1866; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; civil surgeon, Dec., 1871; in joint medical charge, Simla, and in charge of commander-in-chief's staff, 1873; sanitary commissioner for Bengal, May, 1874, and again in 1878-79; officiating principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex officio 1st physician to the college hospital, March, 1877; confirmed in this appointment, April, 1880; also officiating as inspector-general of jails, Aug., 1879; brigade surgeon, May, 1881.

COBB, WILLIAM HEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces.

COCKERELL, FRANCIS RICHARD, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1850; arrived, April, 1850, served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments; appointed magistrate, 1857, and served in that capacity, and also as collector in various districts; temporarily inspector-general of jails in Bengal; judge of the special courts for the adjudication of rent suits in Nuddea and Jessore, 1863; temporarily secretary to the government of Bengal; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 1864; legislative council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal; on special duty conducting an inquiry into the causes of the distress in the Patna and Bhagalpore divisions; additional member of the governor-general's council, 1868, and again in 1870, 1872, and 1876-79; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Dacca division, 1874, and subsequently of Rajshahye; deputed in 1873-74 as special commissioner to inquire into certain cases of maladministration in the province of Assam; retired 1879.

COCKERELL, HORACE ABEL, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1853; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, also as superintendent of survey, Sept., 1859, and as officiating chairman, justices of the peace,
Calcutta, and commissioner of police, March, 1869, and Dec., 1872; commissioner of the Chittagong division, June, 1872, and subsequently of the Dacca and Burdwan divisions; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, April, 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, April, 1878, and again, March, 1880; board of revenue, March, 1883.

COCKS, WALTER CAREW, Auditor, India Office.—Appointed 1st Aug., 1874.

CODDINGTON, FITZHERBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 12th June, 1857; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1857; served under the military department till Jan., 1862, when he was appointed assistant surveyor in survey department; deputy superintendent of survey, July, 1867; was employed in the Central Provinces revenue survey, 1867, and in the Deccan, 1871; 2nd grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1878; Hissar and Ferozepore district survey, March, 1884.

CODRINGTON, GEORGE HENRY FORBES, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th May, 1857; served on military duty till Dec., 1865, and subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, April, 1883.

COGHLAN, ROBERT NESBIT, Customs Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd April, 1871; from March, 1872, served as general manager of the customs bonded warehouses, Bombay, and as acting assistant commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, in charge of the tobacco department, Bombay; from March, 1874, served as assistant collector of salt revenue; collector of sea customs, Karachi, and assistant commissioner of salt revenue in Sind, Sept., 1882.

COLDSTREAM, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Nov., 1876; officiating commissioner and sessions judge, Lahore, April, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1883; deputed to Calcutta to act as one of the representatives of the Punjab in the committee on museum and exhibition held there, Dec., 1883.

COLE, WILLIAM HAMMOND, M.A. Cantab., F.R.A.S., F.R.G.S.—Served in the education department, N.W. Provinces, April, 1862, to March, 1864, as professor of mathematics at the Government College, Agra; from Jan., 1867, served in the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor attached to the computing office, Dehra; assistant superintendent of surveys, Sept., 1869; deputy superintendent July, 1882; appointed to charge of head quarters office, Dehra Dun, and survey detachment in Kashmir, Jan., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

COLLEN, E.H. H., Major, B.S.C.—First commission, royal artillery, July, 1863; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, May, 1873; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, March, 1875; 2nd assistant secretary April, 1876; 1st assistant secretary, Dec., 1876; deputy secretary, military department, April, 1884.

COLLETT, CHARLES, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; subordinate judge of Calicut, 1862; judge of court of small causes, Cuddalore, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1866; retired in 1871.

COLLIER, FRANK ROBERT STANLEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, May, 1884.

COLLIER, GEORGE H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Uppingham School; junior clerk, India office, 17th Feb., 1876.

COLLIN, EDWARD WOODFIELD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; private secretary to financial member of governor-general's council, Jan., 1880; served under the government of India, foreign department, Feb. to July, 1881.

COLLINGWOOD, WILLIAM, Lieutenant, Accounts Department, India Office.—Served in the Indian navy from 1st June, 1846 to 1862, in the course of which period he was employed in the survey of Mesopotamia, and as transport agent during the Persian war; from 26th June, 1867, served as a writer in the India office, and employed in the financial department till 1877, and subsequently in the accountant-general's department; junior clerk, Dec., 1870; senior clerk, May, 1876.

COLLINS, ARTHUR HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1879; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

COLVIN, SIR AUCKLAND, K.C.M.G., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton; appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; officiating under secretary to the government of India in the home department, May, 1864, and in the foreign department, Jan., 1865; settlement officer, 2nd grade, July, 1869; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1870; on special duty to Naini Tal, in connection with the revision of settlement in the Allahabad district, June 1870; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, April, 1873, and again in 1875; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of
registration, June, 1873; member of commission for investigating disturbances in Poona and Ahmadnagar, Aug., 1875; magistrate and collector, Basti, Feb., 1877; officiating commissioner of inland customs under the government of India, Nov., 1877; transferred for employment in Egypt, Jan., 1879, and served as controller of Egyptian finance, and subsequently as finance minister to the Egyptian government; acted as consul-general in Sir E. Malet's absence; financial member of council of the governor-general of India, 11th Oct., 1883.

COLVIN, BAZETT WETENHALL, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; arrived in India, 29th June, 1850; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector till Jan., 1854, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1855, magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, July, 1865, and civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, July, 1873; officiated as commissioner of the Jhansi division, April, 1873, and of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1873; on special duty at Agra during the visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Feb., 1876; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1876; commissioner, Meerut division, Jan., 1877; additional member, governor-general's council, Jan., 1877, to May, 1881; board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; retired, April, 1885.

COLVIN, CLEMENT S., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, and by private tuition in England and on the continent; temporary clerk, 1865; junior clerk, military department, 1864; funds department, 1867; private secretary to secretary of state, 1873-74; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state, 1874-77, and accompanied Sir Louis Mallet on his deputation to India in 1875-76; senior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, 1877; resident clerk 1877; public works department, 1877; government director of Madras irrigation and canal company, 1880-82; assistant secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph department, Sept., 1882; assistant government director of Indian railway companies, 1882.

COLVIN, ELLIOT GRAHAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1883; transferred to Assam as personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1884; officiating assistant political agent, Rajputana, Dec., 1884.

CONDOR, JAMES, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Sept., 1870; executive engineer, Neemuch railway, Oct., 1873; Punjab northern state railway, 1874; personal assistant to engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, June, 1875; provisional assistant director of state railways, western system, 1877; traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, May, 1878; officiating manager, southern section, Western Rajputana railway, Aug., 1879; manager, Holkar, Sindia-Neemuch, and Neemuch-Nusseerabad railways, Feb., 1881; officiating manager, Nagpur-Chhattisgarh and Wardha coal railways, Nov., 1883; officiating traffic superintendent, Rajputana-Malwa railways, Sept., 1884.

CONDON, JAMES HUNT, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 25th July, 1859; served under the military department till Oct., 1861, when he was appointed civil assistant surgeon in Oudh; from April, 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to surgeon, Feb., 1871; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Cawnpore, April, 1872.

CONINGHAM, HENRY EVELYN, Col., M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 18th March, 1855; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1861, as assistant superintendent and superintendent, and acted as deputy inspector-general, Sept., 1883, to May, 1884; 1st grade superintendent, Nov., 1884.

CONNELL, CHARLES JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner; from May, 1874, to Feb., 1878, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer in Gonda and Fyzabad; first assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1878; officiating under secretary to government, May to Aug., 1878; officiating magistrate and collector, Benares, Aug., 1882; junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1882; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, April, 1883; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1884.

CONOLLY, EDWARD ROBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 9th April, 1858; from Sept., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; on special duty as assistant to Major Cavagnari, Feb., 1879, and again at Khyber, Feb., 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Sept.; 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Bannu, Nov., 1884; also district judge.

CONSTABLE, EDWIN T., M.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as mathematical professor, Bareilly College, 25th Feb., 1862; 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1870; inspector of public instruction, 1st circle, Aug., 1870; inspector of schools, Meerut division, Dec., 1877; Benares division, Dec., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1883; 1st grade of education officers, April, 1883.

CONWAY-GORDON, LEWIS, C.I.E., Major, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—1st commission, 1857; was employed on the trigonometrical survey, 1862 to 1866; joined the public works department, Oct., 1866, as assistant consulting engineer, railway department, and examiner of accounts, Punjab; deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary, railway branch, Punjab, Oct., 1866; executive engineer, 1st grade, Punjab, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer to government for guaranteed railways, 1871; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, March, 1874;
controller of accounts, Madras, 1875 to 1879; 1st class examiner, Jan., 1879; officiating manager, Indus Valley railway, April, 1881; deputy accountant-general, public works department, and ex officio under secretary to government of India, Sept., 1881; temporarily manager, Eastern Bengal state railway, 1884; manager, North-Western railway, 1885.

CONYBEARE, Henry Crawford Arthur, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Westminster School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; on special duty for preparation of provincial gazetteer, July, 1877; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1884.

COOK, Henry, Surgeon-Major, M.D. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 31st Aug., 1865, and served as civil surgeon at various stations, superintendent of vaccination, and superintendent of jail; acted as second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, 1879-80, and as senior surgeon and professor of surgery 1881-82; civil surgeon, Poona, with medical charge of the Deccan College and College of Science, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, April, 1883, also superintendent and teacher of medicine and therapeutics at the medical school; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner, Oct., 1884.

COOK, Henry, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., F.R.C.P. (Lon.), F.G.S., F.M.S., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 24th Jan., 1855; arrived in India, 28th July, 1855, and served under the military department up to 1859, also holding the civil surgeoncy of Karachi in 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force in 1857; appointed medical officer to political agency, Khelat, April, 1859; and accompanied H.H. the Khan of Khelat and Sir H. Green on a military expedition into Mekran; from April, 1861, served as civil surgeon in Ahmednagar and Satara, and as superintendent of Mahabaleshwar, and assistant collector and magistrate at that station; scientific officer, Abyssinian field force, Dec., 1867; from June, 1871, served in Bombay as acting second physician, Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and acting professor of physiology and of hygiene at the Grant Medical College, and was confirmed in these appointments, May, 1873; 1st physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, principal and professor of medicine and hygiene Grant Medical College, Sept., 1875; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879.

COOKE, Crawford Boyd, Major, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission as ensign, March, 1864; joined the Burma commission, 17th Jan., 1884, as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade.

COOKE, Henry Giraud, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1882.

COOKE, Henry Reade, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of General Administration Report of Bombay Presidency for 1879-80; first assistant collector, June, 1885.

COOKE, John Edward, Financial Department, North-Western Provinces.—From Oct., 1863, to April, 1868, served as assistant secretary to the government of India in the financial department; officiated as deputy accountant-general, first in Bengal and then in Hyderabad, and as accountant-general in Bengal, 1868-69; deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, Aug., 1870, and in Madras, Jan., 1874; officiating accountant-general, Madras, Aug.-Oct., 1874; assistant comptroller-general, May, 1875; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878, to July, 1883, and officiated as accountant-general in 1885, 1882, and 1883; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1883.

COOKE, Samuel, M.A., F.I.C., F.G.S., A.M.I.C.E., Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of chemistry and geology at the Engineering College, Poona, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, June, 1875.

COOKE, Theodore, M.A., M.I., LL.D. (Dub.), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, Nov., 1860; from June, 1865, served in the Bombay educational department as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Poona, and also officiated as lecturer on chemistry and geology; 1st grade of the educational department, March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Feb.-May, 1884.

COOKSON, Hugh Cecil, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Dec., 1883, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab.

COOPER, Charles Philip (Barrister-at-Law), Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1863; served from June, 1864, as examiner of the insolvent debtors' court, Bombay; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer in the high court; police magistrate, Bombay, from Oct., 1871; acting first judge of the small cause court, Sept., 1873; senior magistrate of police and revenue judge, Bombay, June, 1874.

COOPER, H. A., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, accountant-general's department, 3rd June, 1880; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1881.

COPLESTON, Frederick Selwyn, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd October, 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, as assistant commissioner, Sept., 1874; on special duty in Rangoon, Nov., 1879; on forest demarcation duty, Toungoo, Jan., 1880; deputy superintendent of census, Sept., 1880; judge under the Land Acquisition Act, March, 1881; officiating deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1885.

CORBYN, Edwin Colnett, Lieut.-Col.,
B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1857; from Nov., 1861, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, 1st class, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; 1st grade deputy commissioner, Dec., 1884; also district judge, Ferozepur.

CORDERY, John Graham, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1856; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; from Oct., 1864, to Sept., 1868, served in the Hyderabad Assigned Districts as deputy commissioner and assistant resident; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, Jan., 1872, to May, 1873; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1877; officiating secretary to government of Punjab, April-Aug., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, April, 1879; also acted as political agent and superintendent, Bahawalpur State, May-Nov., 1879; commissioner, Peshawur, April, 1881; resident, Hyderabad, April, 1883.

CORNISH, Robert, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Lancing College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine relief duty, May-Dec., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884.

CORNWALL, William Wolfran Gardner, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of Dehra Dün, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Fatehpur, March, 1881.

COTTON, Henry John Stedman, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College School, Brighton College, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 29th Oct., 1867; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed officiating small cause court judge, Sealdah, March, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1873; officiating registrar, high court, Dec., 1873; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1875; junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1876; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1878; officiating commissioner, Chittagong, Sept., 1879; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1882.

COURTENAY, Robert, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and political agent; compiler of the 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency for 1883-84'; from March, 1885, acted as assistant judge.

COUCHE, T. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

COUPER, Sir George E. W., Bart., K.C.S.I., C.B., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sandhurst, and served in H.M.'s 15th regiment for two years before joining the East India College, Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1846; served in Bengal and the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; undersecretary, government of India, home and finance department, 1853; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, 1854; secretary to chief commissioner of Oudh, 1855; served through the siege of Lucknow, and was present at several engagements during the mutiny as aide-de-camp to Sir H. Lawrence and Sir John Inglis, and afterwards to Sir James Outram; commissioner in Oudh, 1858; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; judicial commissioner of Oudh, 1863; chief commissioner of Oudh, 1874; lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces, 1876, as well as chief commissioner of Oudh; retired 1882.

COURT, Major Henry, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; compiled 'Statistical Report and History of the Budona District'; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, 1853, and subsequently at Allahabad; president of special commission on the police of India, 1860; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, 1861 to 1866; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1866, and subsequently of the Meerut division, 1866; retired 1872.

COWIE, Alexander John, Deputy Surgeon-General, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Bengal medical service, 1854; sanitary commissioner, British Burma, 1868-72; served subsequently with the 37th N.I.; principal medical storekeeper, presidency, 1878; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; civil surgeon, Moradabad, 1882; deputy surgeon-general, Presidency district, April, 1884; inspector-general of civil hospitals, Bengal, March, 1885.

COWIE, Henry George, B.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—From Nov., 1868, to April, 1876, served in the grades of assistant accountant-general and assistant comptroller-general, and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, in the N.W. Provinces and at Calcutta; from April, 1876, to March, 1883, served in the Central Provinces as deputy accountant-general and deputy commissioner paper currency; comptroller, Assam, March, 1883; class 3 of the financial department, Sept., 1883.

COWIE, Thomas Renny, Major, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 12th Aug., 1860; employed under the military department till Aug., 1869, from which date he served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate and officiating sub-judge; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1881.

COWLEY, Francis William Rice, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, and Dec., 1863; from April, 1864,
served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at the disposal of the public works department, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, Ward's estate, Patna, June, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1877; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and grade.

COX, ARTHUR FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled 'The North Arcot District Manual'; on special duty in connection with visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; from Sept., 1882, served in the financial department, and was appointed officiating assistant accountant-general first in Madras and afterwards in Bombay; assistant comptroller-general, 3rd class, July, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1885.

COX, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

COX, JOHN HANDS MORRELL, Revenue Settlement Department, Madras.—Served from 18th March, 1861, in the revenue settlement department, Madras, as assistant director and deputy director; special assistant to collectors of Cuddapah and Kurnool for survey and settlement purposes, May, 1867, to April, 1871, and again in North Arcot, May, 1882; acting special deputy collector for state relief works, Jan., 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882; 1st grade of deputy directors, June, 1883.

COXE, HENRY REYNAL HOLLED, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagulpore, Nov., 1884.

COXHEAD, THOMAS EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 8th Jan., 1864; from Nov., 1864, served in the revenue and judicial departments, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on famine duty, Tirhoot, April, 1874; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1876; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1884.

CRADDOCK, REGINALD HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Reading Grammar School, Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1884; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1884.

CRASTER, GEORGE AYTON, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th Dec., 1849; served under the military department till 1854; from 8th Dec., 1854, served as an executive engineer in Assam, Oudh, and the Punjab; promoted to executive engineer 1st grade, April, 1865; transferred to N.W. Provinces as officiating superintending engineer, March, 1866; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, public works department, April, 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; promoted to 1st class, March, 1881.

CRAWFORD, ARTHUR TRAVERS, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1855, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and special income tax officer; from Feb., 1862, to June, 1864, served as assistant judge and session judge, and acting judge and session judge; registrar-general of assurances, Jan., 1865; acting collector of Bombay, special income tax commissioner, collector of income tax, president of the income tax commission, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1865; municipal commissioner for Bombay, June, 1865, to Oct., 1871; member of the architecture improvement committee, Bombay, Sept., 1865; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1875; on special duty at Kolaba, June–July, 1876; on special duty as president of the G.I.P. railway commission in connection with the railway robberies, March–Aug., 1878; from May, 1879, acted as commissioner, southern division, and was confirmed as commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1881; British delegate for the Portuguese treaty, Goa, Sept., 1879, and was on special duty under the government of India in connection with customs arrangements with native states in Bombay, Nov., 1880, to March, 1881; also on special duty, Oct.–Nov., 1882, at Simla, and Jan.–Feb., 1884, and in Europe, Feb. to Aug., 1884.

CRAWFORD, CHARLES EDWARD GORDON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent; railway magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; also acted as district superintendent of police, Aug.–Oct., 1878; from Jan., 1879, acted in the judicial department as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; 2nd grade assistant judge, Aug., 1883; also acted as judge and sessions judge in various districts, and as judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Feb.–May, 1885.

CRAWFORD, JAMES ADAIR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1881, served in the political department, and acted as assistant to the governor-general's agent for Rajputana, and assistant to the resident at Hyderabad (May, 1882); attache, foreign department of government of India, May, 1882; in charge of office of press commissioner, June, 1882, to Nov., 1883; acting political agent, 3rd class, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1884; acting assistant secretary, foreign department, Jan., 1885.

CRAWFORD, JOHN THOMSON, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Perth Academy, Edinburgh University, and
Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1864; from Feb., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; from Nov., 1880, served as district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, and from Jan., 1882, as deputy commissioner, Partabgarh; magistrate and collector, and grade, Unao, March, 1885.

CRAWFORD, RICHMOND IRVINE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Oct., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1857; from Sept., 1864, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and (from April, 1867) as superintendent of police; from May, 1873, acted as political superintendent of Thar and Pârkâr, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1875; deputy commissioner, Thar and Pârkâr, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, Shikârpur, June, 1885.

CRAWFURD, JAMES, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Collegiate School and University of Glasgow, and Dublin University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector Rajshahye, Jan., 1869; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1875; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1876; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1877; registrar, high court, Nov., 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1885.

CRAWLEY-BOEVEY, ARTHUR WILLIAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special assistant to political agent, and acting political agent in Rewa Kânthâ; from May, 1873, to Dec., 1874, served in Baroda as acting assistant resident, and performed the duties of the cantonment and railway magistrate, and small cause court judge, May-Nov., 1873; in special charge of Sachin state, Dec., 1874; on special duty at Baroda, Feb., 1875; on famine duty at Kâldâgî, Aug., 1877; Tâlukdâri settlement officer, Gujerat, June, 1879; pro temp. special officer for the settlement of claims to Girâs and Watanas in Baroda territory, April, 1883, and again April, 1885.

CREGEEN, A. C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1859, as assistant engineer, Punjab; executive engineer, April, 1866; railway department, Central India, 1870; Holkar state railway, Oct., 1870; engineer-in-chief, provincial light railway survey extensions, Lucknow, June, 1878; Neemuch-Naseerabad survey, Nov., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Western Rajputana state railway, Aug., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Vizagapatam-Raipur railway survey, March, 1882; superintending engineer, 1st class, July, 1884; engineer-in-chief, construction establishment, Nagpur-Bengal railway, Oct., 1884.

CRESSWELL, CHARLES ARTHUR, Captain, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1866; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1867; joined the Burma commission, Feb., 1871, as officiating assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate at Toungoo; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Dec., 1875; boundary officer, Sandoway, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, March, 1885.

CROFT, A. W., M.A., C.I.E., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor, Presidency College, officiating principal, Dacca College, and Presidency College, inspector of schools, and officiating registrar, Calcutta University, and was promoted to 2nd class of the educational service, Feb., 1877; director of public instruction, Aug., 1878; on special duty with the government of India, home department, Jan., 1883.

CROFTON, JAMES, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 9th Dec., 1844; joined the public works department, Nov., 1847; assistant engineer, Punjab circle, Dec., 1849; superintendent, 1st division, Bari Doab canal, July, 1854; executive engineer, Punjab irrigation, 1858; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1862; superintendent, Sutlej canal surveys; officiating superintendent, Eastern Junna canals, 1863; chief engineer, irrigation, and under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1864; chief engineer, 1st class, April, 1872; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, April, 1874, to Jan., 1882, when he resigned the service.

CROLE, CHARLES STEWART, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh High School and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as sub-secretary board of revenue, July-Sept., 1866, and as collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants in 1879-80; compiled Chingleput district manual; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, Jan.-March, 1880; district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1881; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882, in the district of Kistna, and afterwards in Madura.

CROMBIE, ALEXANDER, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1872; officiating resident surgeon, Calcutta Medical College Hospital, 25th Jan., 1873; professor of surgery, Medical College, Oct., 1873; professor of materia medica, Sept., 1874; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1875, and appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and health officer to the port; from April, 1877, served in Bengal as civil surgeon, also at Simla as joint medical officer, March, 1880, to Feb., 1882; civil surgeon, Dacca, with charge of the jail, March, 1882; also superintendent of the lunatic asylum, medical school and Mitford Hospital; surgeon-major March, 1884.

CROMMELIN, WILLIAM ARDEN, Lieutenant-General, C.B., late R.E.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1841; assistant engineer, public works department, S.E. Provinces, Nov., 1843; assistant to civil engineer, Punjab, Feb., 1853; deputy consulting engineer, railway department Jan., 1856; chief engineer, Oudh, April, 1858; inspector-general of military works, Aug., 1865; also deputy secretary to the government of India; secretary to the government of India, public works department, Feb., 1877; retired 31st Dec., 1878.
CROOKE, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's Grammar School, Tipperary, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Oct., 1883.

CROOKSHANK, ARTHUR CHICHESTER WILLIAM, Colonel, B.S.C.—1st commission, Jan., 1859, 65th Foot; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1862; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, April, 1876; 1st assistant secretary, April, 1884.

CROSTHWAITE, CHARLES HAWKES TODD, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; from Nov., 1858, to March, 1877, served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and settlement officer, and acted as secretary to the board of revenue for two years from March, 1875; from April, 1877, served in the Central Provinces as commissioner of the Nagpur and Jubbulpur divisions, and was appointed judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881, and additional member of the governor-general's council for the purpose of making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881; acting chief commissioner, British Burma, March, 1883, to April, 1884; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1885.

CROSTHWAITE, ROBERT JOSEPH, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty on the revenue committee at Naini Tal, July, 1872; assistant superintendent, sub-judge, and registrar of Dehra Dun, Dec., 1873; small cause court judge, Allahabad, March, 1875; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1878, to Feb., 1881; acting secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March to May, 1881; district and sessions judge, Allahabad, May, 1881; additional secretary to government of India, legislative department, Jan., 1883; acted as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces, March, 1882, to Jan., 1883, and from March, 1883, to Jan., 1885, when he was confirmed in the appointment.

CROW, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, 23rd Oct., 1883.

CROWE, WILLIAM HENRY (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin Grammar School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of mental and moral philosophy and logic at the Deccan College, Poona, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and assistant judge and sessions judge; editor of the 'Bombay Gazetteer' Oct., 1868; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, March, 1882; on special duty at Káthiáwár, Nov., 1882; appointed and grade judge and session judge, Thana, Aug., 1883, and afterwards at Sátára.

CROZIER, ROBERT G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; temporary clerk, India Office, 30th Nov., 1865; junior clerk, Jan., 1867.

CRUICKSHANK, ALEXANDER, M.A., Madras C.S.—University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras from Oct., 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, principal assistant collector, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, special agent, French settlement, and political agent for Pondicherry, Sept., 1878.

CRUICKSHANK, ALEXANDER WALMSLY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1885.

CRUICKSHANK, JOHN, M.D., Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, Bombay.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 9th April, 1856; civil surgeon, Dharwar, Jan., 1865; from March, 1866, acted as surgeon to the governor of Bombay, also as private secretary, Oct., 1866; on special duty to Egypt as surgeon to Lord Mayo, Nov., 1868; superintendent of Mahá-baleshwar, Dec., 1870; from April, 1871, served as inspector-general of prisons, Bombay, and was a member of the prisons conference at Calcutta, Jan., 1877; rank of brigade surgeon Nov., 1879.

CRUMP, CHARLES GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Bal-liol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector N.W. Provinces.

CULLEN, PETER, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Medical Department (Central Provinces).—Joined the Bengal medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1860; from Feb., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; also superintendent of cotton affairs, May, 1865; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877.

CUMINE, ALEXANDER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1874, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting superintendent of police, railway magistrate, and acting junior collector and forest settlement officer; acting special assistant collector and settlement officer, Ratnagiri, Nov., 1884.

CUMMING, CHARLES LENNOX BRUCE, F.R.G.S., Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1867, and served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting
district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Nov., 1883.

CUMMING, WILLIAM GORDON, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Rajputana.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1860; joined the public works department, Feb., 1864, as assistant engineer, Port Blair; executive engineer, April, 1866; Hyderabad, May, 1870; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, March, 1874; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, June, 1881; tempy. superintending engineer, Rangoon, Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1884; officiating secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Oct., 1884.

CUNNINGHAM, WILLIAM JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and Clapham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1873, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner on special duty at Bangalore and Chitaldrug, acting deputy commissioner, additional secretary in the famine department (Aug., 1878), and secretary to the chief commissioner, general department (Jan., 1879); political agent, assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner, Coorg, April, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, and assistant to the resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1883; officiating under secretary, government of India, foreign department, March, 1885.

CUNNINGHAM, ALEXANDER FREDERICK DOUGLAS, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab (civil department), Sept., 1878; on special duty as political assistant to Major Cavagnari for employment in Afghanistan, Nov., 1878; political officer, Khyber, Oct., 1879; 1st assistant to chief political officer, Afghanistan (Kabul), Feb., 1880; under secretary to government, Punjab, Oct., 1880; officiating secretary to government, April-May, 1881.

CUNNINGHAM, DAVID DOUGLAS, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1868; from 19th Dec., 1874, served as special assistant to the sanitary commissioner with the government of India; professor of physiology, Calcutta Medical College, from Dec., 1879; also acted as government quinologist, and was in charge of the cinchona plantations, Sept., 1879; officiating superintendent of botanical gardens, Aug., 1880; appointed to conduct special cholera inquiries in immediate connection with the sanitary commissioner with the government of India; rank of surgeon-major, April, 1880; honorary surgeon to H.E. the Viceroy.

CUNNINGHAM, H. S.—Advocate-general, high court, Madras, and additional member of the governor's council, 1872-77; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1877.

CURRIE, BERTRAM WODEHOUSE, appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, Dec., 1880.

CURRIE, FENDALL, Lieutenant-Colonel (Barrister-at-Law).—Arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858, as cornet, 1st European light cavalry; assistant commissioner, Hazaribagh, June, 1863; from Sept., 1863, served in the Oudh commission, and was appointed small cause court judge, Sitapur, June, 1868, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1868; on special duty to collate laws and regulations in force in Oudh, May, 1869; on special duty for taking up lands for railway purposes, Oct., 1869; city magistrate, Lucknow, Feb., 1870; on special duty to review the Bara Banki forgery report, March, 1874; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1878; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli, Aug., 1882; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1883.

CURRIE, GEORGE MAINWARING, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; from Oct., 1863, served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1884.

CURSETJEE RUSTOMJEE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

CUSHING, THOMAS, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk to inspector of scientific instruments, store depot, Dec., 1867; inspector of scientific instruments, May, 1876.

CUTHBERTSON, CLIVE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's, Adelaide, Glenalmond School, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882.

CUTTLE, G., Store Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, India store depot, 5th April, 1882.

DALE, GEORGE SPENCE DESBOROUGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Aug., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1882.

DALLAS, A. M., Deputy Surgeon-General, C.I.E., Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India and was appointed assistant surgeon, June, 1856; superintendent, central jail, Oct., 1859; inspector-general of prisons, April, 1862; surgeon, Feb., 1868; special duty, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1882, deputy surgeon-general, Sept., 1884; surgeon-general, Punjab.

DALMAHOY, PATRICK CARFRAE, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign 1st Jan., 1857; adjutant of the Hazirpur district police, Oct., 1858, to Sept., 1860; commandant of the same, Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1862, served as district superintendent of police up to April, 1867, when he was appointed assistant inspector-general, government railway police; officiating commandant of the Mhairwara police battalion Sept., 1860, to April, 1871; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1882.

DALTON, GODFREY JOHN BECTIVE Tuite, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Columba's College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin;
appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 12th Jan., 1864; from May, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1877, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1879.

DALYELL, ROBERT ANSTRUTHER, C.S.I., LL.D., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1850; served in junior offices in the revenue and magisterial departments till 1861, when he was appointed sub-secretary to the board of revenue; member of the income tax commission, 1861-65, and officiating president, 1865; officiating Inam commissioner, 1866; secretary, board of revenue, 1867; acting secretary to government in the revenue department, 1868-70; on special duty in connection with the excise, 1872; additional member of the council of the governor-general for making laws and regulations, 1873 (reappointed in 1875, and again in 1877); board of revenue, Madras, 1873; government director of the bank of Madras, 1873-74; officiating chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, 1875-76; member of the council of the secretary of state for India, 1877; nominated a C.S.I., on retirement from the Indian civil service in 1879; vice-president of council, 1883-84; honorary LL.D. of the University of St. Andrew's, 1885; a royal commissioner for Indian and Colonial Exhibition, 1886; published a sketch of the land tenures of Madras in 1864, a revised official edition of the standing orders of the board of revenue in 1866, and in 1867 a history of the Madras famine of the previous year.

DAMES, MANSEL LONGWORTH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty with the Kabul troops Jan., 1879.

DAMPIER, HENRY LUCIUS, C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1849; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1860; junior secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1861, and secretary, Nov., 1861; commissioner, Nuddea division, July, 1863; on special duty in the famine districts, 1866; between April, 1867, and Nov., 1874, served as secretary to the government of Bengal in the revenue and general departments, and as officiating secretary to the government of India, home department, in 1872; special member of the Bengal legislative council, Dec., 1874; board of revenue, Oct., 1877; Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1879; president of commission for amendment of rent law in Bengal, 1881; retired, 26th July, 1884.

DANCE, GEORGE WHITMORE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

DANE, LOUIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty in the Punjab secretariat, Aug., 1870; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1870, to April, 1882.

DANE, RICHARD MORRIS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; served under the foreign department of the government of India, July, 1878, to April, 1879; secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1880; on special duty in public works department, Feb. 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March to Aug., 1882.

DANGERFIELD, H., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Jan., 1868, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad; Nizam's state railway, June, 1872; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; manager, Nizam's state railway, 1876; superintendent of way and works, Holkar and Neemuch state railway, Feb., 1878; manager, Holkar and Neemuch state railway, Nov., 1878; manager, Bhavnagar-Gondal railways, Dec., 1880; officiating manager, Rajputana-Malwa railways, Sept., 1883.

DANIEL, JOHN READ, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton Grammar School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, June, 1863; served in Bombay from Dec., 1864, to July, 1867, and subsequently in Madras, as assistant collector, small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, 1873-74, and afterwards of Cuddapah; and as district and sessions judge, Nellore, 1874-76; from Jan., 1877, served as district and sessions judge of Ganjam.

DANIELL, CAIRNES ANTHONY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1859, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant under the commissioner of Meerut, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1866; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1868; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, July, 1860; civil and session judge, Gorakhpur, April, 1877; commissioner, Benares division, and agent to the governor-general, March, 1881; member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1884.

DANIELL, CLARMONT JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, Aug., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, Aug., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Allahabad division, Aug., 1881, and of the Agra division, Oct., 1883; 1st grade judge, April, 1885, Farakhabad.

DANVERS, FREDERICK C., Registry and
Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and King's College, London, and after a special training preparatory for Addiscombe studied for two years for a civil and mechanical engineer; East India House writer, old establishment, 26th Jan., 1853; junior clerk, public and ecclesiastical department, India office, 1858; public works department, 1861; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant secretary in the public works department, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary in the revenue department, 1877; registrar and superintendent of records Jan., 1884; in 1855 designed a salt-weighing machine, of which a number were manufactured in this country for the use of the Madras government; in 1859 was deputed by the secretary of state to Liverpool and Manchester to report on traction engines, with a view to their being used in India; author of articles published in 'Engineering' relative to public works in India, 1866–75; of a design for crossing the East India Railway under the Hooghly from Howrah to Calcutta, transmitted to India by the secretary of state in 1868; of 'Statistical Papers relating to India' (printed parliamentary paper No. 308 of 1869); of memorandum on Indian coals, with reference to their employment as fuel for Indian railways and steamers, 1867; of memorandum on coal-washing and artificial fuel, 1869; of 'Coal Economy' (printed by order of the secretary of state, 1872); of 'Spon's Information for Colonial Engineers—India' (published by E. and F. Spon, London, 1877); of 'Agriculture in India,' a paper read before the Society of Arts, 1878 (Society's silver medal); and of 'Famines in India,' read before the Society of Arts in 1886.

DANVERS, Sir Juland, K.C.S.I., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; East India House writer, 22nd March, 1842; junior clerk, Feb., 1847; senior clerk, Feb., 1852; minuting branch, secretary's department, 1853; private secretary to chairman and deputy, 1848–53; assistant secretary in the railway and electric telegraph department, India office, and assistant director of Indian railway companies, Feb., 1858; secretary in the railway and telegraph department, Sept., 1858, to July, 1861; director of Indian railway companies, 1861; secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph departments, Aug., 1880, continuing to be director of Indian railway companies; visited India in his official capacity in 1875–76; author of the annual official reports on railways in India presented to Parliament from 1859 to 1882.

DARLINGTON, Edwin, Customs Department, Burma.—Joined the service as superintendent of the Burma secretariat, June, 1868; from March, 1872, served as collector of customs, Akyab; also in the Burma secretariat, on special duty, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1875; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1876; collector of customs, Rangoon, July, 1877.

DARRAH, Henry Zouch, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882; acting manager of the Awa estate, March, 1883; acting director of agriculture in Assam, June, 1884.

DAUKES, Frederick Clendon, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Downing College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive exam nation of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, April, 1872; officiating under secretary to government, Sept., 1873; assistant settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, Nov., 1873; attaché, foreign department, government of India, 1873; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1876–77; under secretary, government of India, home department, Dec., 1877.

DAUNT, John Charles Campbell, Colonel, V.C., B.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 20th July, 1852; served in the Bengal police department from April, 1862, as district superintendent; and was promoted to 1st grade, June, 1875.

DAVIDSON, James, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to Aug., 1878.

DAVIDSON, Robert, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1852; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts; sub-judge of Cuddapah, 1860; small cause court judge, Chittoor, 1862; civil and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, 1867; district and sessions judge of Cuddapah, Aug., 1873, and subsequently of Chingleput; acted as collector and magistrate of Kurnool during the famine, 1877–78; third member, board of revenue, March, 1878; chief secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1878; legislative council of Madras, 1880 to 1883; provisional member of the executive council May–July, 1881; 1st member, board of revenue, March, 1882; member of the special committee appointed to frame a famine code for Madras, Oct., 1882; retired, June 1884.

DAVIES, Arthur Matcham, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras; arrived in India 23rd Jan., 1849; served in the Madras police department from Sept., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; acting personal assistant to commissioner of police, Madras, Sept., 1866; deputy inspector-general, Nov., 1881.

DAVIES, J., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk in principal storekeeper's office, Tower of London, under the board of ordnance, May, 1842; inspector of stores, 1851; sub-inspector of stores, East India House, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant superintendent of the India store depot, March, 1877; superintendent, June, 1880.

DAVIES, James Acworth (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at Denmark Hill Grammar School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service
after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, March, 1880; assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, April, 1880; acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department, July, 1882; member of the board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting district and sessions judge, South Canara, June, 1882; under secretary in the revenue department, Oct., 1882; acting secretary to the board of revenue, June, 1883; from Oct., 1883, acted as registrar, high court, Madras, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Kistna, July, 1884.

DAVIES, Sir Robert Henry, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the N.W. Provinces and cis-Sutlej Territory as assistant commissioner; settlement officer, Baree Doab, 1851; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Azimgurh, 1858; secretary to government of Punjab, 1859; financial commissioner, Oudh, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1869; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 1871; retired 1878; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1885.

DAVIES, William George, C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 5th Jan., 1849; from April, 1854, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, May, 1862; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Nov., 1876, and subsequently in the Jullundur division; financial commissioner, Punjab, Dec., 1883.

DAVIS, Arthur William, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rossall and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

DAVIS, John Samuel Champion, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at College School 'Taunton, Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dün, April, 1882, and officiating superintendent Dec. 1882, to Feb., 1883.

DAWKINS, Clinton E., Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in June, 1883; junior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India office, 6th Feb., 1884; political department, 1885.

DAY, Arthur S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, Bedford Grammar School, and Clifton College; writer, India office, 26th Oct., 1874; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1878.

DAYARAM GIDUMAL, B.A., LL.B.; Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and joined the service as assistant collector, 3rd Jan., 1885.

DEANE, Thomas, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, March, 1862, 21st hussars; lieutenant, Bengal staff corps, March, 1863; adjutant, governor-general's body guard, Jan., 1871; 3rd assistant secretary to the government of India, military department, Jan., 1877; 2nd assistant secretary, April, 1884.

DEAS, Joseph, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1870, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Jan., 1883; officiating magistrate and collector, April, 1883.

DE BEAUREPAIRE, E.L., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 1885.

DE BOURBEL, Raoul, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 1850; joined the public works department, Nov., 1852; executive engineer, Lower Provinces, Dec., 1853; assistant to chief engineer, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1857; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1866; officiating consulting engineer and under secretary, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1862; superintending engineer, Gowhatta, June, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oudh, Feb., 1870; superintending engineer, 2nd grade, railway branch, Oudh, Sept., 1870; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, 1871; in temporary charge of public works department in Biluchistan, 1879-80; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, 1880; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884.

DE FABECK, William Frederick, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, Burma.—Entered the army medical department, June, 1855; joined the Madras medical department, June, 1857, and served under the military department from that date to May, 1871, also holding the civil surgeoncies of Kurnul, Chittur, Vellore, and Nagode (Central Provinces), during that period. From Nov., 1873, served in British Burma as acting garrison surgeon, Rangoon, and acting civil surgeon and superintendent of Lock Hospital, Moulmein (May, 1874), and was confirmed in the latter appointment, 1877; also health officer, Moulmein, Feb., 1878, and was in medical charge of the central jail for various periods.

DEIGHTON, Kenneth, B.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as professor, Agra College, 19th Feb., 1862; principal, Agra College, March, 1864; officiating inspector of schools, Meerut division, Dec., 1865, to Jan., 1866; 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1883; officiating principal, Benares College, July, 1883; inspector, Rohilkund division.

DENMAN, John, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

DENNISTON, James Lawson, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as
assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1882.

DE PALEZIEUX-FALCONNET, GRENVILLE PULTENEY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1852; joined the Madras public works department, Aug., 1854, as assistant engineer; from June, 1856, served in the Bengal public works department as executive engineer, Pegu; Mhow division, Rajputana, Nov., 1864; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, 1872; superintending engineer, Meerut, April, 1874, and afterwards at Moradabad and Rawalpindi; superintending engineer, 1st grade, June, 1879.

DE PREE, GEORGE CHARLES, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1848; lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, June, 1851; served with the Pegu field force, 1852-53; joined the survey department in Oct., 1854, as assistant surveyor, and was employed on the survey of the Cuttack tributary mehals; appointed to the charge of the Ganjam topographical survey, March, 1856; also ex-officio assistant commissioner, Cuttack division; was afterwards in charge of the Chota Nagpur survey, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Chota Nagpur division, and during a long period decided many boundary disputes between the estates of the rajahs of the tributary mehals; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, topographical survey, Oct., 1866; was subsequently employed on the survey of the Central Provinces and Rewah, and on the Rajputana and Simla surveys; deputy surveyor-general in charge of topographical surveys, Jan., 1883; surveyor-general, Jan., 1884.

DEY, GEORGE GOODAIR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1869; served in the revenue and judicial department, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1882; also served in Assam, in 1880, as officiating judge of Sylhet and Cachar.

DIACK, ALEXANDER HENDERSON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1882, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Punjab; served in the settlement department, Dec., 1882, to March, 1883.

DICK, ROBERT, M.A., Educational Department, Punjab.—From 31st July, 1870, served in the Punjab as professor at the Delhi and Lahore Colleges, and officiating inspector of schools, and was appointed principal of the Lahore Training College, Dec., 1881; on special duty, April, 1877; promoted to 3rd grade of the educational department, Nov., 1880.

DICKENS, CRAVEN HILDESLEY, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., late R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1838; adjutant and quartermaster, 1846; captain, March, 1853; assistant to secretary, government of India, public works department, June, 1855; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, April, 1864; secretary to government of India, public works department, March, 1865, to Feb., 1877; retired 31st Dec., 1878.

DICKINSON, RICHARD, Financial Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1851; junior clerk, minuting branch, secretary's department, 1853; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1855-58; senior clerk, financial department, India office, 1858; assistant secretary in the financial department, June, 1867.

DILLON, JOHN, Postal Department.—Served in the post office department, Punjab, from 3rd Oct., 1857, as deputy postmaster, inspector, and superintendent; also served in the N.W.
