Provinces and in Bengal; chief inspector of post offices, Oudh, March, 1874; compiler of postal accounts of India, July, 1878, subsequently designated as accountant-general of the post office, and afterwards as comptroller, post office; acting deputy director-general of the post office of India, March, 1879; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, Jan., 1880, and again in 1883.

DOBIE, WILLIAM HERBERT, Financial Department.—Joined the financial department, 23rd May, 1872; on famine duty as district grain accountant, Chumparun, July, 1874, and at Purneah, Jan., 1875; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1875; from Jan., 1876, served in Bengal, as acting deputy accountant-general, and as assistant comptroller-general; served in Madras, 1878-83, and in the Punjab, Oct., 1883, to Nov., 1884; assistant accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, in 3rd class of the financial department, Dec., 1884; assistant accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1885.

DODD, CHARLES ALBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Royal Welsh Fusiliers, 12th Nov., 1857; from Feb., 1860, served in the police department, and was employed on special duty at Lucknow, 1860; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, March, 1861; district superintendent, Aug., 1861; secretary to committee at Calcutta for revising forms of police statistics, Feb., 1869; honorary magistrate, April, 1870; superintendent, government press, and curator of government books, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1871; also superintendent of emigration, Jan., 1883.

DODERET, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883.

DODGSON, CYRIL GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

DONALD, WILLIAM, Financial Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1856; from 23rd May, 1859, served in the central public works office, and the civil paymaster's office, Madras, and was appointed to 5th class of financial department, Aug., 1862; examiner of claims, July, 1865; secretary to committee for examination of assistants, June, 1868; assistant accountant-general, Madras, 1870; director of incorporated bank of Madras, March, 1871; 3rd class of financial department, Feb., 1874; served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general, Nov., 1874,
to Jan., 1876, and subsequently in Madras, and acted on several occasions as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; member of board of examiners, May, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Dec., 1884.

DONOVAN, Charles, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; from Feb., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty at Cawnpore, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; transferred to Assam, Sept., 1879, as deputy commissioner, 1st grade; judge, 3rd grade, Benares, Jan., 1885.

DOSABHAI FRAMJI, C.S.I., Presidency Magistrate, Bombay.—Served from 6th Oct., 1860, as income tax assessor; police magistrate, July, 1866; special officer for the Imperial licence tax, May, 1867; collector of income tax and certificate tax, May, 1866; sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1871; member of the town council, Sept., 1873; from June, 1874, served as second magistrate of police, Bombay, and also held the posts of chairman of the municipal corporation (Sept., 1875, to Dec., 1876), chairman of the justices of the peace, additional member of the governor's council for making laws and regulations (Sept., 1877), special officer to hear appeals against the licence tax assessment (Aug. 1878), special collector of licence tax, and acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery (Aug.–Sept., 1882).

DOUGLAS, Edward Ronald, C.I.E.—Served in the postal department, Punjab, from 14th Oct., 1854, as postmaster and superintendent of mail cart and bullock train; also in Bengal as postmaster and inspector; officiating chief inspector of post offices, Central Provinces, March, 1869; confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1871; personal assistant to director-general, May, 1871; compiler of postal accounts, April, 1875; assistant director-general, July, 1878; officiating postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces, Jan.–April, 1879; deputy director-general of the post office of India, July, 1880; officiating postmaster-general, Madras, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883; on special duty under the director-general, Aug., 1883; in charge of railway mail service, May, 1884.

DOUGLAS, Sholto James, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, Jan., 1878; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and inspector of labourers; assistant magistrate and collector of Chittagong, April, 1885.

DOUIE, James McCrone, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the High School, Edinburgh, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab, 7th Dec., 1876; secretary to financial commissioner, Jan., 1881; assistant settlement officer, Dec., 1882.

DOVETON, John Chadwick, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Oct., 1858; assistant conservator of forests, 1st grade, Central Provinces, 8th April, 1864; deputy conservator May, 1865; conservator, 1st grade, Sept., 1882.

DOWDEN, Thomas F., Colonel, R.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Lieutenant Bombay engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the Bombay public works department, Aug., 1859; acting under secretary to government, Feb., 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, 1872; manager, Dhond and Mummad state railway, officiating as manager Rajputana state railway, Nov., 1878; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Oct., 1879; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Beluchistan, April, 1880; acting senior deputy consulting engineer, and under secretary to government, Bombay, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1884; assistant to director-general of railways, 1884.

DOWING, S. F., M.A., M.I.C.E., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 15th July, 1869; assistant professor, Presidency College, 16th Sept., 1869; professor, April, 1877; 3rd class, education department, Aug., 1878; principal, government engineering college, Howrah, April, 1880.

D'OYLY, Warren Hastings, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 28th May, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; inspector-general of jails, May, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1876; officiating opium agent, Behar, March–Dec., 1878.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, Edward Forster, Surgeon-Major, F.R.C.S., L.R.C.P.L., Madras Medical Dept.—Assistant-surgeon, 1st Oct., 1866; arrived, 23rd April, 1867, and served under the military department, Madras, and also as acting civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish liver oil factory, Calicut; was also in medical charge of lock hospital, Madras, and central cholera hospital, Vepery, 1869–70; resident assistant surgeon, general hospital, and professor of pathology in medical college, Madras, Oct., 1870, to Feb., 1875; also acting professor of medical jurisprudence, Sept., 1872; ophthalmic surgeon, general hospital, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology March, 1875; surgeon-major, Oct., 1878; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885.

DREW, William Wilson, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; from May, 1882, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

DRUITT, George, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Wimborne Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1868; and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate and cantonment magistrate, assistant judge and acting judge and sessions judge; attached to political department of secretariat, Oct., 1877–Jan., 1878; 2nd grade senior assistant judge, Oct., 1883.

DRUMMOND, Hon. Edmund, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury Col-
lege; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1831; arrived in India, March, 1833; assistant collector and magistrate, Monghyr, Jan., 1834; on special resumption and settlement duty, Dec., 1835, to Sept., 1839; magistrate of Behar, Sept., 1839; collector of Burdwan, July, 1850; collector, magistrate, and salt agent, Pooree, 1852; accountant, government of Bengal, military accountant, deputy accountant-general, government of India, member of mint committee, and director of bank of Bengal, 1854; accountant-general, government of India, 1856; auditor-general, government of India, president of board of audit, government director of bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1860; financial secretary, government of India, 1862; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, March, 1863; retired 1868; member of council of secretary of state 1875-85.

DRUMMOND, JAMES RAMSAY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, University of Glasgow, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner.

DRYSDALE, ALEXANDER TOVEY, Forest Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, Dec., 1864; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as head master of government school and officiating inspector of schools; from June, 1868, served in the forest department, Berar, as assistant conservator, deputy conservator, and conservator (3rd grade, Sept., 1882).

DRYSDALE, THEODORE, Central Provinces Commission.—Assistant master, government school, Saugor, April, 1861; served in the Central Provinces commission from 19th Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of the judicial commissioner's office, June, 1864; registrar of the judicial commissioner's court May, 1869; deputy superintendent of census operations in the Central Provinces April, 1880; was also in executive charge of the jail, Saugor, 1877; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 4th class, April, 1885.

DUFF, ALAN COLQUHOUN, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1881, and served in the Central Provinces as supernumerary assistant commissioner; acting deputy commissioner, Raipur, Nov., 1884.

DUKE, CHARLES JOHN ASHETON, Burma Commission.—Arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1866; served in the Burma commission from March, 1867, as assistant commissioner; town magistrate, Akyab, July, 1876; superintendent of Arakan Hill Tracts, March, 1880; deputy commissioner, March, 1882.

DUKE, FREDERICK WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Hooghly, Dec., 1884.

DUMERGUE, JOHN WILLOUGHBY FRANCIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant resident and acting resident in Travancore; Malayan translator to government, March, 1884; head assistant collector and magistrate, Nilgiris, Feb., 1885.

DUNCAN, DAVID, M.A., D.Sc. (Edinburgh), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 20th May, 1870, as professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Presidency College, and was registrar of the Madras University from April, 1875, to March, 1879, and again in 1881; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1877; 3rd class of the education department, April, 1880; principal and professor, Presidency College, from March, 1884; also acted as director of public instruction and as commissioner for the uncov. civil service examinations, from May, 1885.

DURAND, HENRY MORTIMER, C.S.I. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal, C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, March, 1873; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, March, 1873; on famine duty, Nov., 1873; from June, 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed officiating 1st assistant to the governor-general's agent, Rajputana, July, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, Nov., 1877; political assistant, 1st class, Dec., 1877; on special duty with the British force, Kabul, Sept., 1879; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, March, 1880; officiating secretary, government of India, foreign department, March, 1880; officiating private secretary to the Viceroy, June, 1880; secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1885.

DURRANT, WILLIAM S., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Whitgift and Lycée St. Omer; junior clerk, India office, 18th Sept., 1879.

DUTHOIT, WILLIAM, D.C.L., Bengal, C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1857; served from Sept., 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed deputy superintendent, family domains, Maháraja of Benares, May, 1862; officiating inspector-general of registration and commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1875; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1877; on special duty under the government of India, financial department, Dec., 1879; on special duty under the orders of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1881; officiating puisne judge, high court, June, 1881; district and sessions judge, and grade, Aug., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Oudh, May, 1882; employed on the opium commission, under government of Bengal, March to Oct., 1883; judicial commissioner of Oudh, March, 1884.

DYSON, JOHN, Oudh Commission.—Joined the service, 8th June, 1858, as deputy magistrate and deputy, collector in Bengal; from Dec., 1861, served in Oudh as assistant com-
missioner; officiating city magistrate of Lucknow, Sept., 1866; also officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Aug.–Oct., 1867; small cause court judge, Lucknow, 1869; on special duty on committee for compiling the laws and regulations in force in Oudh previous to 1861, Jan., 1870; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sitapur, April, 1883.

EADES, F. T., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

EALES, CHARLES LINDSTEDT MODELLIER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

EALÉS, HERBERT LOVELY, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India 30th Oct., 1879; served in British Burma as assistant commissioner.

EARLE, ARCHDALE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882.

EAST, WILLIAM ALBERT, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 26th Nov., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar and deputy registrar and sealer of the high court, assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; superintendent of Panchgani, Nov., 1870; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Dharwar, June, 1881; senior collector, June, 1885.

EBDEN, EDWARD JAMES, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen Elizabeth's School, Ipswich, and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1872, served in the forest department as acting deputy conservator in the Kanara district; employed on famine duty, Dharwar, April, 1877, and in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to July, 1878; from July, 1878, served as assistant collector, railway magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, Aug., 1881.

EDEN, HON. SIR ASHLEY, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Haileybury, and appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1852; arrived in India, April, 1852; assistant magistrate and collector of Rajshahiye 1854; assistant special commissioner in the Sonthal insurrection, 1855; deputy commissioner of the Sonthal Pergunnahs, 1856; magistrate and collector of Baraset, 1856; junior secretary, board of revenue, 1859; special envoy to Sikhim, 1861; special envoy to Bostan, 1864; secretary to the government of Bengal, 1862–71, and member of council of the lieutenant-governor for making laws and regulations, 1868; chief commissioner of British Burma, 1871 to 1877; officiating member of the governor-general's council, 1875; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1877–82; retired in 1882; member of council of secretary of state 1882.

EDGAR, JOHN WARE, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector July, 1863; served in Cachar from Dec., 1863, as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on special duty with the Lushai expeditionary force, Oct., 1871; officiating junior secretary to the government of Bengal, June, 1872; magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Feb., 1873; officiated as commissioner in various divisions in Bengal, 1880–83; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Nov., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1885.

EDGELL, W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; writer, India office, 31st July, 1869; temporarily employed as shipping inspector of railway stores, Jan., 1872; receiver of wharf stores, Jan., 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, March, 1877.

EDGERLEY, STEYNING WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and officiating cantonment magistrate; from May, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, and acting Sindhi translator to government; 3rd assistant collector in Sind, March, 1885.

EDIS, FREDERICK, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India Office, 29th July, 1872; clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, March, 1876.

EDWARDS, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1837; assistant commissioner, Cuttack, 1838; assistant registrar, Sudder court, Calcutta, 1839; deputy secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1840; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, 1842, and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces in all departments, and in attendance on the governor-general; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1843, and attended the governor-general in his tour to the N.W. Provinces; superintendent of the Hill states, and magistrate and collector, Simla, 1848; civil and sessions judge, Futtehpore, 1858; judge, Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlat, N.W. Provinces 1862; judge, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1866; retired 1867; author of a book of Indian treaties (reprinted by order of the House of Lords, 1853), and of several other works relating to India.

EGERTON, SIR ROBERT EYLES, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and Exeter College, Oxford, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from the East India College, Haileybury, in 1850; served in the Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to the charge of the settlement of the Lahore district, 1854–58; deputy commissioner, 1856; officiating commissioner, Lahore, 1863; additional commissioner, Peshawur, Nov., 1863, to Feb., 1864; commissioner, Nagpur, Central
Provinces, March, 1864; officiated as judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, at various times from 1865 to 1867; financial commissioner of the Punjab, March, 1868; additional member governor-general's council, July, 1871, and again in 1872 and 1877; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, April, 1877, to April, 1882, when he resigned the service.

ELIAS, NEY, Political Department.—Appointed joint commissioner of Ladakh, Oct., 1877; political assistant, 1st class, June, 1879.

ELIOT, JOHN, M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, June, 1869; from 27th Dec., 1869, to Feb., 1876, served in the N.W. Provinces as professor of mathematics, Thomason College, and also at Muir College; superintendent of the Meteorological Observatory, Allahabad, and meteorological reporter to government; from Feb., 1876, served in Bengal, as professor, Presidency College, and meteorological reporter, also as officiating meteorological reporter to government of India, April, 1878, and Dec., 1881; 2nd class, Bengal education department, March, 1881; officiating principal, Presidency College, Jan., 1883.

ELLENOR, T. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

ELLERCAMP, H. McD., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 10th Oct., 1879.

ELLIOT, FREDERICK AUGUSTUS HUGH, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Berar as educational inspector, and acting director of public instruction; principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar, Baroda, Dec., 1875; on special duty, Baroda, April, 1882.

ELLIOT, FREDERICK EDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 16th March, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, April, 1877, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1881.

ELLIOT, SIR WALTER, K.C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1820; served under the commissioner in the Deccan, and was present in the Kittoo insurrection, 1824, during which he was captured by the rebels; private secretary to the governor, Canarese translator to government, member of the college board and mint committee, and member of the board of revenue, 1837; also acted as Persian translator to government; was placed on special duty to examine and report upon condition of district of Guntoor, 1845, and was deputed as special commissioner for the whole of the Circars in 1849 for the same purpose; member of Madras council, and president of the revenue and marine boards, Dec., 1854; resigned the service 27th Dec., 1859; author of various articles on the zoology, botany, and antiquities of Southern India, including a paper on the 'History of the Deccan' ('Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society,' 1836), Descriptive Catalogue of the Mammalia of the Southern Maratha Country' ('Madras Journal of Literature and Science,' 1839), and 'Coins of Southern India' ('International Numismata Orientalia,' 1886).

ELLIOTT, CHARLES ALFRED, LL.B., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from April, 1858, to May, 1861, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner, and from Feb., 1863, to Oct., 1866, in the Central Provinces as settlement officer, Hoshangabad; served subsequently as settlement officer, Farakhabad, and as secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1870-1877; commissioner, Meerut, Oct., 1877; famine commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1877; additional secretary to government of India, famine branch, May, 1878; secretary to famine commission, June, 1878; census commissioner, Oct., 1880; chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1881.

ELLIS, SIR BARROW HELBERT, K.C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School and University College, London; matriculated in 1839 at the University of London with scholarship and honours in classics; appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 26th July, 1843; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1843; 3rd assistant collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, 1844; 2nd assistant, 1847; commissioner for investigating certain claims on the Nizam's government, 1848; assistant commissioner in Sind, 1851 to 1855; in charge of office of commissioner in Sind, afterwards acting revenue commissioner for alienations, and in charge of office of revenue commissioner, Southern Division, 1857; special commissioner for jaghirs in Sind; afterwards acting secretary to government in revenue, finance, and general departments, director of bank of Bombay, and member of mint committee, 1858; collector and magistrate, Broach, continuing to act as secretary to government, Nov., 1859; confirmed as secretary to government, &c., April, 1860; acting chief secretary to government, additional member of Bombay legislative council, revenue commissioner, Northern Division, 1862; re-appointed member of legislative council, 1864; ordinary member of Bombay council, 1865; member of governor-general's council, 2nd May, 1870; retired, 27th April, 1875; member of council of secretary of state, July, 1875, to 1885.

ELLIS, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.A., M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 16th June, 1859, and was employed under the military department up to 1861; from April, 1861, served in Oudh as civil assistant surgeon; officiating superintendent, central jail, Lucknow, Oct., 1866; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Unao, June, 1872; transferred to Sitapur, Oct., 1872.

ELLISON, THOMAS EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1864; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Delhi, Aug., 1865;
transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1868; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1881; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884.

ELPHINSTON, John, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 5th Feb., 1855, and served in Bombay and Sind as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and collector and magistrate (Jan., 1873); senior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, Oct., 1876; collector and magistrate and political agent, Kolaba, Sept., 1880.

ELSMIE, GEORGE ROBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab; officiating judge small cause court, Lahore, Nov., 1863; on special duty at Lahore, July, 1867; officiating under secretary to government of India, Oct., 1868; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; from 1871 to 1877 officiated as additional commissioner of Jullundur and Amritsar, and of Peshawur; civil and session judge, March, 1877; officiating judge, chief court, 1878-79; commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Nov., 1880, and again in 1885; judge, chief court, Punjab, Jan., 1882.

ELWIN, EDGAR ALFRED, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dover College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1883, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

ERSKINE, CLAUDIUS JAMES, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; private secretary to governor of Bombay, 1844; oriental translator to government, 1847; also deputy secretary to government of Bombay, Persian department, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay in the general and judicial departments 1854; civil auditor, 1854; director of public instruction, 1855; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Konkan, 1857; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, 1859; member of legislative council of India, 1860; also puisne judge of court of Sudder Dewani, Bombay, 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 31st Oct., 1865; retired in 1867.

ERSKINE, GEORGE ELPHINSTONE, Lieutenant-Colonel, North-Western Provinces (Oudh).—Arrived in India as cornet, Bombay light cavalry, 9th Dec., 1857; served under the military department till Feb., 1863, when he joined the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner; from May, 1865, to July, 1871, served as assistant settlement officer, and acting settlement officer; also officiated as personal assistant to financial commissioner in 1867-69, and as superintendent of excise and stamps in 1868, and was confirmed in the former appointment, July, 1871; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, May to Aug., 1876; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, in forest branch, and Oudh revenue department, 7th April, 1878; commissioner, Sitapur division, Jan., 1882.

ERSKINE, HENRY NAPIER BRUCE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Sept., 1853, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special officer for income tax, assistant-commissioner and acting educational inspector in Sind, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1869; from June, 1879, served as commissioner in Sind, and was confirmed in this appointment, Oct., 1882; on special duty at Bombay, Dec., 1880; 1st grade commissioner July, 1881.

ETESON, A., M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, Assam.—Joined the Indian medical department as assistant surgeon, May, 1854; arrived in India, 30th June, 1854; held various military medical charges, and was promoted to surgeon-major, May 1874; secretary to surgeon-general, Indian medical department, March, 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Eastern frontier district, and sanitary commissioner, Assam, Jan., 1884.

EUAN-SMITH, CHARLES BEAN, Colonel, C.S.I., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, March, 1859; on special duty in Seistan, 1871-72; on special duty in Zanzibar, 1872-73; attaché, secretariat, foreign department, government of India, during visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, 1875; officiating 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, 1876; officiating political agent, Muscat, 1879; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, Rajputana, 1882; political agent, Bhurtapore and Kerowlee, 1883; officiating resident in Meywar, 1884; graded as additional political agent, 2nd class.

EVANS, HENRY FARRINGTON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from May, 1870, to Sept., 1879, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1880; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1881; special judge, Jhansi, July, 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Oct., 1882.

EVANS, LOFTUS GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner.

EVERETT, STEPHEN H., Audit Department, India Office.—Educated at Dulwich College; writer, India office, May, 1872; junior examiner, audit department, Dec., 1873.

EWART, CHARLES HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 20th Feb., 1857; arrived in India, and April, 1857; from Feb., 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, May, 1881.

EWBANK, A., M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived, 28th Feb., 1868; served as professor, Dacca College, and as officiating inspector of schools; principal, Dacca College, March, 1876;
2nd class, education department, Oct., 1879; principal, Patna College, Oct., 1881.

FAGAN, WILLIAM TURTON, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission 23rd July, 1847; commandant, 4th Bengal police battalion, April, 1862; district superintendent July, 1862; officiating personal assistant to inspector-general of police, July, 1882; deputy inspector-general, Dec., 1882.

FAICHNIE, A. G., Post Office Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the post office department, Jan., 1858; served for some time as superintendent of the Rawal Pindi military horse van, and bullock train; deputy postmaster-general, Central Provinces and Berar, 8th Nov., 1879.

FAIRRIE, J. S., Registry Department, India office.—Educated at Clapham Grammar School and King's College, London; writer, India Office, 1st Jan., 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

FAIRWEATHER, JAMES, M.D., Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 20th March, 1856; in civil charge of Rawal Pindi and its jail, April, 1869; civil surgeon at Gurdaspur, April, 1874, and subsequently at various other stations in the Punjab; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; officiated as sanitary commissioner in 1870, 1879, and 1883.

FANSHAWE, ARTHUR UPTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps and inspector-general of registration; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July, 1880, and acted as secretary in 1880 and 1881; in charge of model farm, Nagpur, July, 1880, to Jan., 1881; from April, 1881, served in the postal department as officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1882; also officiated as director-general of the post office in India, Aug., 1884.

FANSHAWE, HERBERT CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bedford, Tonbridge, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1873, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab; served temporarily in Bengal on famine duty Feb.-Nov., 1874; officiating settlement officer, Rohtak, Aug., 1875, to Feb., 1876, and again in 1877; under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, March, 1879; assistant to the officer on special duty in Kashmir, June, 1879; officiating junior secretary to government, Oct. to Dec., 1882.

FARMER, HENRY RICHARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Loughborough, Bromsgrove, and Uppingham Grammar Schools; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acted as Tamil translator to government, Feb., 1880, to Sept., 1881; on special duty completing treatise on Madras Act viii of 1865, July, 1882.

FARQUHAR, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 28th May, 1858; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858, and served under the military department in Madras, Burma, and the Straits Settlements; also held civil medical charge, Toungoo, in 1859; medical officer, Ootacamund, from Nov., 1882; promoted to brigade surgeon, April, 1885; deputy surgeon-general, July, 1885.

FARRAN, G. H., M.A. (Dublin), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 17th May, 1866, as head assistant in the prothonotary's office, high court, Bombay, acting prothonotary, ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, acting official assignee of the insolvent debtors' court, and acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court; deputy registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits, and judge's clerk, Nov., 1873; assistant commissioner for taking accounts and assistant taxing master, July, 1876; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer.

FARRER, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Heversham Grammar School and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

FASSON, HERBERT JOHN HAMILTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School, Quebec, and Bray College, Wicklow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Nov., 1872; on famine relief duty at Dinapore, March, 1874; assistant settlement officer, Chittagong, June, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, March, 1883.

FAULDER, CECIL JOSEPH SALKELD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

FAWCETT, GEORGE WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, deputy commissioner of salt revenue, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector and magistrate, Malabar, July, 1883.

FAYRER, SIR JOSEPH, Surgeon-General, K.C.S.I., LL.D., M.D., F.R.S.S. (London and Edinburgh), F.R.C.P., F.R.C.S., Medical Board, India Office.—Acting assistant surgeon, R.N., Aug., 1847; assistant surgeon, royal artillery, 1849; joined the East India Company's service April, 1850, and served under the military department, also holding civil surgeoncy of Cheera Poonjee, Nov., 1850; served in the Burma campaign, and officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, Feb., 1853; appointed residency surgeon, Lucknow, by Lord Dalhousie, for services during war in Burma; honorary assistant resident at Lucknow, Sept., 1854; civil surgeon, Lucknow, March, 1856; brevet rank of surgeon for services in defence of Lucknow residency during the siege, Sept., 1858; officiating professor of surgery and ex-officio 1st surgeon of Medical Col-
lege Hospital, Calcutta, May, 1859; confirmed in these appointments, June, 1860; medical charge of Mysore princes, June, 1860; fellow of University of Calcutta and member of the senate March, 1861; served for two years as president of the medical faculty, and received the public thanks of the faculty; surgeon, July, 1863; consulting surgeon to Howrah General Hospital Nov., 1865; president of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, 1867; J.P. for Calcutta, Feb., 1868; government trustee for India Museum 1868; officiating surgeon to viceroy Jan.–Feb., 1869; accompanied H.R.H. the Duke of Edinburgh in his tour through India, Jan.–March, 1870; surgeon-major, June, 1870; honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1871; accompanied H.R.H. the Prince of Wales to India, 1875–76, in medical charge of his party; retired, 1874; president of medical board, India Office, Dec., 1874; member of army sanitary commission; member of senate of Army Medical School at Netley; consulting physician to Charing Cross Hospital; author of 'Clinical Surgery in India'; 'Clinical and Pathological Observations in India'; 'Thanatophobia of India' (presented to the Indian government, by whom it was published in 1872); and other works; has also published numerous papers, monographs, and addresses, on medical and scientific subjects.

FENTON, MICHAEL WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1883, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab.

FENTON, T. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd May, 1873; attached to the store department till Aug., 1879, and subsequently to the registry department.

FERET, C. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

FERRAR, MICHAEL LOYD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Belfast Academical Institution and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from Jan., 1864, to Sept., 1865, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Sept., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner; from July, 1868, to July, 1873, served in the settlement department, and was appointed to take up lands for railway purposes in Lucknow, Aug., 1870; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, in 1882 and 1883; deputy commissioner, and grade, April, 1883; magistrate and collector, Etah, March, 1884.

FFINCH, B. T., Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, 5th Nov., 1857; director of the Persian Gulf section, from April, 1875.

FIDDIAN, JAMES PAULL, Madras C.S.—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Bellary, Dec., 1884.

FIDDIAN, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Huddersfield College, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine duty, May, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1881.

FIELD, CHARLES DICKENSON, M.A., LL.D. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1850; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating judge of the principal court of small causes, Kishnagurh and Jessore, officiating magistrate and collector, and registrar, high court (July, 1867); from Dec., 1870, served in the judicial department and was placed on special duty in connection with a commission to consider the question of amending the rent law of Bengal, May, 1879; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1879; judge, high court, Oct., 1880.

FIELD, GEORGE A., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; supernumerary writer, 30th May, 1859; copying clerk, Sept., 1860; assistant to registrar, March, 1882.

FILGATE, ALEXANDER JEROME, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—First commission, 1857; joined the Madras public works department, Sept., 1863, as assistant engineer, South Canara; deputy controller, public works accounts, Sept., 1865; from March, 1867, served in the public works department of the government of India, as assistant accountant-general; deputy accountant-general, and ex-officio under secretary to government, March, 1872; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary, March, 1879; accountant-general, and deputy secretary, Sept., 1881.

FILGATE, TOWNLEY P. H. MACARTNEY, Registration Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 1st March, 1867, and served as military secretary to governor of Bombay, and registrar-general of assurances, Bombay Presidency (from Aug., 1870); from July, 1871, served as inspector-general of registration, and stamps (Nov., 1874); on special duty, Nov.–Dec., 1876, engaged in selecting prisoners for release from the jails of the Bombay Presidency on the occasion of the proclamation of the Empress of India, 1st Jan., 1877; on special duty, Dec., 1879, as member of the committee on the registration law, at Calcutta.

FINCH, C. T., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

FINK, W. R., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Assistant to the taxing officer and registrar, high court, Calcutta, 1878; chief clerk, high court of judicature, 1885.

FINLAY, JAMES FAIRBAIRN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty in the public works department, Oct., 1880; transferred to finance department...
of government of India, Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, as officiating assistant accountant-general and officiating deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general in 4th class of financial department, July, 1882; officiating under secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, Aug., 1883.

FINLAY, HERBERT BLAKEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, Dec., 1865; from May, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Oct., 1873, to April, 1880, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, July, 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1880; officiating magistrate and collector, Agra, March, 1882; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, July, 1885.

FINUCANE, MICHAEL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Munchin's College, Limerick, Limerick Collegiate Academy, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1872; manager, Raj Durbhunga, Sept., 1879; settlement officer, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Jan., 1882; on special duty, Midnapore, May, 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1884; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, and director of agriculture in Bengal, Dec., 1884.

FIREBRACE, FREDERICK, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1865; officiating assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, May, 1868; executive engineer, railway branch, Central India, Sept., 1870; Neemuch railway survey, Feb., 1871; assistant director of state railways, March, 1875; manager, Rajputana state railway, Nov., 1876; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, April, 1877; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1880; supervising engineer, 2nd class, May, 1884.

FISHER, FREDERICK HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Boston Grammar School and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause judge of Dehra Dun, March, 1879; officiating civil and sessions judge, Saharanpur, Oct., 1881; on special duty in connection with the preparation of the 'Provincial Gazetteer,' Dec., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1885.

FISHER, JOHN HADDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1861; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Jan., 1872, to April, 1879, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner; from April, 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Meerut; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1883.

FITZMAURICE, JOHN DAY STOKES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Jan., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884.

FITZGERALD, EDWARD AMBROSE, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India 27th Jan., 1860, and was employed under the military department, 1860-68; from Feb., 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Jaunpur; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1874; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Shahjahanpur, Mirzapur, Agra, Moradabad, and Aligarh, and was promoted to senior surgeon-major, July, 1879.

FITZGERALD, JAMES RICHARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Jan., 1882, served in Hyderabad as political assistant, acting political agent, and first assistant to the resident, and held charge of the office of resident, May, 1882; from July, 1882, served in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner, and acted as commissioner, Aug.-Oct., 1882; magistrate of the district of Ajmere, Oct., 1882; first assistant, governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, May, 1883.

FITZGERALD, JAMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Berar Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; arrived in India, Sept., 1856; from Aug., 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, railway magistrate, and deputy commissioner.

FITZGERALD, W. G. S. V., India Office.—Educated at Harrow and Oriel College, Oxford; political aide-de-camp to the secretary of state for India, 14th Aug., 1874.

FITZPATRICK, DENNIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department, 1874; secretary in the legislative department from 1877; is also secretary to the governor-general's council.

FLEET, JOHN FAITHFUL, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, educational inspector, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector, Dec., 1878; on special duty in England, Jan.-May, 1879, and again in 1884 and 1885; epigraphist to the government of India, Jan., 1883.

FLEMING, ALLAN STOPFORD, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Harrow, and
King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1882, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner.

FLETCHER, WILLIAM MORRIS, Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India 2nd June, 1865, and served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, acting assistant settlement officer, and acting deputy superintendent of survey; on special duty in connection with the famine, Nov., 1876; superintendent of survey, Sept., 1879.

FOORD, EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—Second lieutenant, Madras Engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; arrived in India, July, 1844; assistant civil engineer, Oct., 1846; adjutant of engineers, 1850-52; assistant to secretary board of revenue, public works department, Madras, Aug., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in South Arcot and Tanjore, Dec., 1856, to May, 1863; superintending engineer, Tanjore and Trichinopoly, May, 1863; inspecting engineer for civil and military buildings, Madras, Dec., 1872; superintending engineer, Kistna and Nellore, June, 1874; deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1875; chief engineer, 2nd class, and joint secretary to government, buildings and roads branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, April, 1877; resigned the public works department and retired from the army, 31st Dec., 1878.

FOOTE, ROBERT BRUCE, F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined 23rd Sept., 1888; served in various districts of the Madras Presidency, the Nizam's territory, and Bombay; deputed to Vienna Exhibition in joint charge of the survey collections, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1876; deputy superintendent, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University and member of the faculty of engineering, 1834.

FORBES, ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1867; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Sept., 1873; secretary to the central relief committee, Jan., 1874; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1874, to May, 1876; on special duty at Sibsaugor, Jan., 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1880; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882.

FORBES, GEORGE FOREST GREENLAW, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

FORBES, GEORGE STUART, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue; from Sept., 1880, to Jan., 1883, was employed in the Madras secretariat as acting under secretary in the revenue department, assistant secretary, judicial and legislative department, and under secretary in the departments under the chief secretary, and also served on the board of examiners from Jan., 1882; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of India in the home department as officiating under secretary, also in the foreign department, on special duty, Dec., 1884, and as junior under secretary, Jan., 1885; also press commissioner, March, 1885.

FORBES, JOHN GREENLAW, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 9th Dec., 1854; served under the military department till 1858; served in the public works department, Punjab, from 21st June, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and from July, 1863, in the N.W. Provinces; on special duty in the Madras Presidency, Feb., 1867, reporting on the Kaveri, Krishna, and Godavari canals; superintendent of irrigation works, Oudh, Dec., 1867; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, July to Nov., 1872; from Nov., 1872, served as superintending engineer in the irrigation branch in the N.W. Provinces, in the Punjab (Bari Doab canal), and in Bengal (Sone circle), and officiated as chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Bengal, May to July, 1877; on special duty under the government of India to prepare a revised scheme for the Sardah canal, June, 1878; on special duty on the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi, and Indus valley railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary, N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch, April, 1881, and in the irrigation branch from Nov., 1881; chief engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1883.

FORBES, WILLIAM A., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1847; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Oude; served as political officer throughout the mutiny; medal with clasp for Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Jaunpore, 1862; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1872; officiating member board of revenue, N.W. Provinces; retired 1875.

FORBES, WALTER ERNEST, Major, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as lieutenant Bengal artillery 13th April, 1859; served from Oct., 1860, in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1876; commissioner, Lucknow division, July, 1883; Fyzabad division, Oct., 1883.

FORD, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1842; arrived in India, 7th July, 1842; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty in the Sikh states, April, 1846; assistant to the governor-general's agent, N.W. Frontier, May, 1846; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and superintendent, cissutele territory, and officiating deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Goorgaon, 1850; deputy commissioner, 1st class, 1858; deputed on special duty to Cashmeer, March-
Nov., 1860; commissioner and superintendent, Hissar division, Oct., 1864; Mooltan division, March, 1865; placed in charge of the state of Bhowalpoor, 1866; retired 1869; author of a report on native government as contrasted with the English system.

FORMAN, WILLIAM SCOTT (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Loretto School, Musselburgh, Edinburgh Academy, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting conservator of forests in Scinde; acting collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; 2nd grade judge Jan., 1884.

FORSYTH, Sir THOMAS DOUGLAS, K.C.S.I., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1848; served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Umballa, 1857; secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, 1858; officiating commissioner in Punjab 1860; C.B. for services in mutiny; commissioner of Lahore, 1863, and subsequently of Jullundur, 1865; deputed on special mission to Yarkand, 1870; commissioner of Umballa, 1871; transferred to Oudh, 1872; envoy on mission to Kashgar, 1873; K.C.S.I., 1874; additional member of governor-general's council, 1874; envoy on special mission to Burma, 1875; retired 1878.

FORTEY, Henry, M.A. (Cambridge), Education Department, Madras.—Headmaster, Government School, Kumbakonam, 9th Sept., 1854; professor and acting principal, Presidency College, March, 1856; from Dec., 1857, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 2nd class of education department, April, 1880; fellow of Madras University, Feb., 1872.

FOSTER, CHARLES J., Lieutenant-General, C.B.—Served with the 16th Lancers during the campaign in Afghanistan under Lord Keane, including the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); served also at the battle of Maharajpore, 9th Dec., 1843 (bronze star); and in the campaign on the Sutlej in 1846, including the battles of Buddiwal, Aliwal (as aide-de-camp to Brigadier Cureton), and Sobraon (medal and clasp); appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, July, 1878.

FOSTER, HERBERT WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Liverpool Institute and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate.

FOSTER, WILLIAM SHIRBOLE, M.A., Madras C.S.—St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras from Nov., 1861, as assistant magistrate and collector and sub-collector; fellow of University of Madras, April, 1873; collector and magistrate and political agent, Godavari, April, 1875.

FOSTER, W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 2nd Sept., 1882.

FOWLER, JAMES TOWNSEND, F.R.G.S., F.S.A., Education Department, Madras.—Principal, Government Normal School, Madras, 2nd Dec., 1855; fellow of Madras University, Sept., 1857; on special duty superintending formation of normal schools, May, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 1st class of educational department April, 1880; on special duty to Calcutta as member of the educational committee, Feb., 1882, and again, Aug., 1882, to March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Madras, April-June, 1883.

FOX, CHARLES EDWARD, M.A. (Cantab), (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 9th Jan., 1866, as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts and local investigations, and taxing officer, high court, Bombay.

FOX, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Independent College, Taunton, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the Central Provinces, and from March, 1877, in Burma, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of central jail, Moulmein, in 1877 and 1878; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1883, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, May, 1885.

FOX, G. J. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1877.

FOX-STRANGWAYS, MAURICE WALTER, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1882; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nagpur, Nov., 1882.

FOXTON, WILLIAM, B.A. (Oxon), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Aug., 1857; from Oct., 1857, served in the educational department as acting professor at the Poona and Elphinstone College, and headmaster of the English school, Ahmednagar, and was appointed tutor to ex-Ameers of Hyderabad, Sind, July, 1860; from Oct., 1860, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, deputy collector of income tax, acting judge and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; appointed judge of the court of small causes, cantonment magistrate, and superintendent of jail, Karachi, also Sindi translator to government, May 1876.

FRANCIS, EDWARD BELCHAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, Feb. to Nov., 1874; officiating superintendent of Chamba, April-Aug., 1879; officiating secretary to financial commissioner Aug., 1879; officiating judicial assistant in various districts, 1880-83; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, June, 1883.

FRANKS, CHARLES N. B., Public Works Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 19th Nov., 1856; junior clerk, railway department, India office, 1860; senior clerk, Feb., 1875.

FRANKS, EDWARD, Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1858; junior clerk financial department, India office, Dec., 1866;
funds department, 1867; senior clerk, military department, Aug., 1881.

FRASER, ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-General, C.B., R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 8th Dec., 1843; joined the public works department, Sept., 1850, as executive engineer, Lower Provinces; executive engineer, Arran, 1853, and subsequently at Rangoon; garrison engineer, presidency, Feb., 1856; under secretary to government of India, public works department, 1859; superintendent, Algoona Reet and other lighthouses, 1860; chief engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1862; officiating secretary to government of Bengal, and chief engineer, 1862; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Aug., 1867; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1873; chief engineer and secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1871, to Jan., 1879; secretary to government of India in the public works department, Jan., 1879, to Feb., 1882.

FRASER, ANDREW HENDERSON LEITH, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at the Academy, Institution, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1871; served in Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, Jan., 1877; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1877; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881; junior secretary to the chief commissioner, and director of agriculture, Feb., 1882; acting secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1882, and again in 1883-84; acting deputy commissioner, Wardha, March, 1884.

FRASER, HUGH, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1885.

FRASER, STUART MITFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

FRAZER, ROBERT WATSON, B.A., LL.B., M.R.I.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, engineer and manager of the Parla Kinded estate (Jan.-Feb., 1882), acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy director of revenue settlement.

FRENCH, JOHN GAY, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission 1860; civil assistant surgeon, May, 1865; superintendent of jails, Hazaribagh, Dec., 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1872; civil surgeon, Dec., 1873; 1st resident surgeon of the Presidency General Hospital, March, 1875; also in charge of marine surgery, Aug., 1875; health officer of port of Calcutta, Sept., 1875, and again, July, 1878; also medical inspector of emigrants, April, 1876, and officiating superintendent of the Campbell medical school and Sealdah hospital, Oct., 1877; civil surgeon, Dacca, March, 1880, and at Patna, Dec., 1882; also superintendent of the Temple medical school, and in charge of the jail and lunatic asylum.

FRENCH, T. LOUIS VALPY, Right Rev., D.D., Bishop of Lahore, 8th Feb., 1878.

FRIZELLE, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Punjab, May, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, Ferozepore, April, 1877; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

FROST, CHARLES EVITT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Kensington Grammar School and foreign schools; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate and political agent, acting railway magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1884.

FRY, HENRY J. W., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 18th Aug., 1873.

FRYER, GEORGE EDWARD, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1853; assistant superintendent of police in Madras presidency, June, 1861; officiating assistant engineer, Madras public works department, May, 1862; from Jan., 1864, served in Burma as officiating assistant superintendent of police, and joined the commission, Jan., 1865, as assistant commissioner and assistant secretary to the chief commissioner; cantonment magistrate, Thayetmyo, Nov., 1883.

FRYER, FREDERICK WILLIAM RICHARD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at foreign schools and at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, Oct., 1875; on special duty with the Quetta field force, Oct., 1878, and again, Feb., 1879; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1882; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, May, 1883; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884.

FULLER, JOSEPH BAMFFYLD, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875; from Nov., 1875, to July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and acting joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty as assistant director of agriculture and commerce, Feb., 1878; transferred to Central Provinces, July, 1882, and appointed acting director of agriculture and commerce, and junior secretary to the chief commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1882.
FULTON, EDMUND McGILDDOWNY HOPE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate; acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind; acting judge and session judge, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed registrar of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1881.

FURLONG, MALCOLM, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 10th Feb., 1857; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, British Burma, June, 1865; served in the Burma commission from Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (1st July, 1869, to Feb., 1871), and town magistrate of Prome; from Jan., 1880, acted as deputy commissioner of Moulinem, also officiating as judge from June, 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1884.

FURNELL, MICHAEL CUDMORE, Surgeon-General, C.I.E., M.D., M.R.C.S., F.A.S.L., F.R.C.S., Medical Department, Madras.—Joined the Indian medical service as assistant surgeon, 7th Feb., 1855; arrived in India, 28th April, 1855, and served under the military department till Dec., 1861; served subsequently as civil surgeon in various districts, and also as professor at the Medical College, and ophthalmic surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; surgeon to H.E. the governor, March, 1871, to Dec., 1873; fellow of Madras University, April, 1872; acting superintendent, government central museum, June, 1874; surgeon-major, Feb., 1875; senior physician, General Hospital, and principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, March, 1875; sanitary commissioner, April, 1880; brigade surgeon, May, 1880; deputy surgeon-general, Feb., 1881; surgeon-general, Madras, April, 1885.

FURNIVALL, W. C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, May, 1869, as superintending engineer on the Delhi and Rewari railway; 1st grade superintending engineer, Rajputana railway, March, 1874; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873, in charge of Rajputana railway as engineer-in-chief; officiating director of railways, central system, and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1877; joint secretary and officiating chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1879; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Oct., 1880; services lent to the Bengal Central, and Bengal and N.W. railway companies, 1883; Nizam's guaranteed railway company, March, 1884; chief engineer, and 2nd class (supernumerary), March, 1882.

GAIT, EDWARD ALBERT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884, and served as assistant commissioner in Assam.

GALBRAITH, EDGAR, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1885.

GALTON, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley, Magdalen Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Aug., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), acting under secretary to government in the revenue department (March, 1872, to March, 1873), secretary to the board of revenue (Oct., 1879), and acting collector of sea customs at Madras, and protector of emigrants; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Oct., 1884.

GAMBLE, JAMES SYKES, M.A., F.L.S., Madras Forest Department.—Appointed assistant conservator of forests, Oct., 1871; arrived in India 27th Dec., 1871, and served in British Burma; transferred to Bengal, Aug., 1872; served under the government of India as assistant to the inspector-general of forests, April, 1877, to Jan., 1879; deputy conservator, Bengal, July, 1880; conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882; transferred to Madras, Dec., 1882; conservator, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884.

GAMBLE, REGINALD ARTHUR, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884.

GANPATRAO BHASKAR, RAO BAHADUR, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as acting 4th judge of the court of small causes, Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, Dec., 1874.

GANPATRAO DAMODHAR PANSE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant collector and magistrate, 13th Dec., 1881; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1884.

GARBETT, COLIN HUBERT, Major, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 27th June, 1859; from 4th Dec., 1866, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Jan., 1880.

GARBETT, H., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department Nov., 1854; executive engineer, Bari Doab canal, Feb., 1860; Western Jumna canal, Aug., 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, on the inundation canals, Punjab, Feb., 1870; superintendent of works, Derajet circle, Punjab, 1870; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1878; superintending engineer, Bari Doab circle, Jan., 1880.
