GARDEN, ALEXANDER, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical department, March, 1855; arrived in India, June, 1855, and served under the military department up to 1859; from Sept., 1859, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon of Ghazipur, Oct., 1859, and was subsequently in medical charge of Saharanpur and Mussoorie; rank of surgeon, March, 1867; officiating sanitary commissioner and inspector-general of jails, Oudh, Feb., 1876; transferred to Assam, and officiated as civil surgeon of Tezpur, Feb., 1877; from March, 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces
and was appointed a civil surgeon, 2nd class, April, 1882; posted to Ghazipur, March, 1883, and Saharanpur, Dec., 1883.

GARDINER, JOHN WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Lycée Impérial Bonaparte, Paris; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty under financial department of government of India, Sept.–Nov., 1873; again on special duty, Nov., 1880; promoted to judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1880, and to deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1883.

GARDNER, EDWARD BARTON, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1865; civil assistant surgeon, Bijnor, May, 1866; from Jan., 1869, to April, 1876, served under the military department, and subsequently under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877, and appointed a civil surgeon, 2nd class, Bijnor, June, 1878.

GARRETT, CHARLES BAZETT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, and March, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating registrar of assurances, district and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector; judge of the principal court of small causes in Nudda and Jessore, Dec., 1882; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, April, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, 26th Nov., 1884.

GARRETT, H. W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the King's School, Ely; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 12th April, 1882.

GARSTIN, JOHN HENRY, C.S.I., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from Sept., 1859, and was appointed private secretary to H.E. Lord Napier, March, 1866, acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants Jan., 1871, and collector and magistrate and political agent, Pondicherry, May, 1871; acting secretary to government, revenue department, Dec., 1876; compiled South Arcot district manual; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, March, 1880, to April, 1881; board of revenue, July, 1882; appointed to revise the establishments of collectors and divisional officers in Madras Presidency, Feb., 1883.

GARTH, SIR RICHARD, Knight, M.A., Q.C.—Educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford; called to the bar in Lincoln's Inn in 1847, and went the home circuit; represented Guildford in Parliament, 1866-68; nominated chief justice of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, March, 1875.

GARTHWAITE, LISTON, B.A. (London), Education Department, Madras.—Served from 8th April, 1857, as head master of Zillah School, Cuddalore, Provincial School, Calicut, and normal school, Cananore, and as deputy inspector of schools; also acted as Malayan translator, and Canarese translator to government; from Sept., 1869, served as inspector of schools; compiled Canarese and Malayan Arzis for the secretary of state, and also various text-books; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; 2nd class, education department, May, 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of a scheme for development of technical and scientific education, Nov., 1884.

GATES, FRANK CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S., Burma.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant commissioner, 4th grade, British Burma Aug., 1884.

GAY, EDWARD, M.A. (Oxon), Financial Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state as assistant in the finance department, Sept., 1865; assistant comptroller-general of accounts and acting assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, June, 1867; acting deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1868; deputy comptroller-general, Calcutta, Sept., 1869; 1st class of the financial department, Jan., 1871; on special duty in England, March, 1872, to Dec., 1873; acting accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1874, to Jan., 1875; accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of paper currency, April, 1879; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, April, 1885.

GEIDT, BERNARD GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, Oct., 1877, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, Jan., 1882.

GELL, FREDERICK, Right Rev., D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Fellow of Christ College, Cambridge; nominated lord bishop of Madras, 16th May, 1861; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1861; acting metropolitan bishop, Calcutta, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877.

GEOGHEGAN, H. T., B.A., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab Northern state railway; superintending engineer, Indus valley railway, June, 1877; officiating consulting engineer to government of India for state railways, Feb., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bhopal railway, June, 1879; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1881.

GIBB, MALCOLM COUPER, LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883.

GIBBS, JAMES, C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1846; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1846; served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed assistant judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, May, 1851, and afterwards at Surat; judicial assistant to commissioner in Sind, Aug., 1854; also political assistant; appointed special commissioner for income tax, Bombay, Sept., 1860, and (in addition) president of the income tax commission for the town and island of Bombay, March, 1861, and collector of the tax, June, 1861; while
on furlough was called to the bar at the Inner Temple, June, 1864; judge and session judge of Khandeish, March, 1865, and afterwards at Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan; judge of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1866; provisional member of council, Oct., 1872; member of council, April, 1874; vice-chancellor of the University of Bombay, 1870 to 1879; retired in 1879; member of the governor-general's council, 10th May, 1880 to 1885, and was president of the council in 1884.

GIBSON, EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Albans Grammar School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in Madras revenue and judicial department from Feb., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and was on special duty, Jan., 1868, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot, and on famine duty in Kurnool, Nov., 1876, to March, 1878; acting under secretary to government, chief secretary's department, Feb., 1880; private secretary to governor of Madras, Dec., 1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1882; secretary to the board of revenue, Jan., 1884.

GIBSON, FREDERICK EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, London University, and Edinburgh University.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1883.

GIBSON, HENRY WILLIAM (Barrister-at-Law), Oudh Commission.—Volunteer in the Meerut light horse 1857-58; served subsequently in the military police 1858-61; assistant district superintendent of police, Oudh, June, 1861; district superintendent, 4th grade, April, 1865; from July, 1864, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; acted as superintendent of encumbered estates, Sitapur, July to Oct., 1874; deputy commissioner, Sultanpur, Nov., 1877; 1st grade, July, 1883.

GILES, ARTHUR HENRY, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 14th Feb., 1863; district superintendent, Jan., 1866; officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, March, 1866; officiating deputy commissioner of police and justice of the peace for the town of Calcutta May, 1870; 1st grade superintendent, April, 1885.

GILES, EDWARD, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 14th May, 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of history and political economy, Elphinstone College, Bombay; from May, 1875, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of the department, March, 1883.

GILES, FRANK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, March, 1885.

GILL, JOHN EDWARD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

GILLAN, G. G., Rev., M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Assistant chaplain of the Church of Scotland, 4th Jan., 1866; served under the military department with the 91st Highlanders at Dum Dum, 1866, and with the 72nd Highlanders at Umballa, 1871; chaplain, Jan., 1876; senior chaplain of the church of Scotland in Bengal, and of St. Andrew's Church, March, 1880.

GILLON, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1871; officiating first inspector of registration offices Jan., 1876; on famine relief duty, Cuddapah, Feb., 1877, and in North Arcot, May, 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

GIRDLESTONE CHARLES EDWARD RIDGWAY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse School and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputy commissioner, Nagpore, 1871, and in Jubbulpore 1872; resident in Nipal, 1873; on special duty with Maharaja Sir Jung Bahadour, 1874; officiating resident in Mysore, and chief commissioner of Coorg, 1885; graded as resident, 2nd class.

GIRINDRA NARAIN DEB KUMAR, Bengal C.S.—Officiating deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Burdwan, Aug., 1878; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, and served as assistant magistrate and collector from Dec., 1880.

GLADSTONE, CECIL ERNEST, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Delhi in the Imperial assemblage, Dec., 1876, and again, in the foreign department of the government of India, Feb., 1877.

GLAZIER, EDWARD GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; from April, 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1879.

GLEESON, EDWARD JAMES HARRY ORMOND, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at London University and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement and demarcation officer.

GLENNY, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry Collegiate School, Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dub-
lin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras from June, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, Jan., 1868, enquiring into the condition of the poorer classes, South Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool April, 1880.

GODFREY, CHARLES WILLIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1853, and served in the Bombay artillery; from Aug., 1854, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and acting deputy superintendent, and was promoted to superintendent of survey, Jan., 1855.

GODFREY, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Oct., 1873; on famine duty, May, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July to Oct., 1877; from Jan., 1880, served in Bengal as officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; again transferred to Assam, Oct., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Lakhipur; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Jan., 1885.

GODLEY, JOHN A., C.B., Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; Hertford scholar, 1868; Ireland scholar, 1870; Eldon law scholar, 1874; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, 1876; private secretary to the first lord of the treasury, 1872-74, and again, 1880-82; commissioner of inland revenue, 1882-83; permanent under secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1883.

GODELL, WILLIAM, Audit Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 30th Sept., 1860; senior examiner, June, 1863; junior inspector Dec., 1868.

GOLDINGHAM, JOHN DALRYMPLE, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from April, 1855, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-judge, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from July, 1862, to July, 1865, served as judge of the court of small causes, Madura, and from Oct., 1868, to Oct., 1872, as civil and sessions judge at the same place; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Nov., 1872, to Feb., 1881, and afterwards at Bellary.

GONNE, CHARLES, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; arrived in India 10th March, 1854; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, May, 1861; joint judge and sessions judge, Thana, March, 1863, and acted as judge and sessions judge June, 1863, to March, 1864; acting judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, April-June, 1864; acting registrar, high court, Bombay, June-Oct., 1864; from Oct., 1864, served as secretary to government of Bombay in the judicial and political departments; chief secretary to government in the political, secret, judicial, and separate departments, April, 1879; temporary member of council, Bombay, March-April, 1884; retired in 1885.

GOODFELLOW, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Col., R.E., V.C., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, July, 1853; 2nd lieutenant June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; joined the public works department as special assistant engineer, harbour defences, Bombay, April, 1860; executive engineer, Bombay and Agra road, Feb., 1862; joined the Abyssinian Expedition, Dec., 1867; executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1877; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1884.

GOODFELLOW, GEORGE RISTO, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, Oct., 1854, and was employed on military duty till Jan., 1863, also serving as personal assistant to inspector-general of prisons, Poona, Oct., 1859, to March, 1860; from Jan., 1863, to April, 1870, served in the political department, at Aden, as Arabic interpreter to the resident, and as assistant resident and officiating resident; acting special assistant political agent in charge of Rajkot and Gondal states, Kathiawar, April, 1870; from March, 1871, to Feb., 1872, served in Central India as officiating political agent, Baghelkhand; from May, 1872, served under the government of Bombay as acting political agent, Cutch, acting political superintendent, Akalkot, and assistant resident and acting resident at Aden; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sept., 1880; political agent and collector of stamp revenue, Cutch, Sept., 1881; 2nd grade political agent, Feb., 1885.

GOODFELLOW, WILLIAM WEST, Major-General, C.B., R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, Oct., 1853; served from July, 1854, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was on field service with the Persian and Abyssinian expeditionary forces; executive engineer, Bombay defences, Jan., 1869, to May, 1870; acting controller of public works accounts, June-July, 1870; served subsequently as executive engineer at Aden and in the Poona districts; from June, 1876, served as superintending engineer, and was promoted to 1st class, March, 1882; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1885.

GOODRICH, HARRY ST. AUBYN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Eton and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from July, 1865, as assistant collector, and magistrate, deputy director of revenue settlement, acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, Nellore, Feb.-Sept., 1881; appointed collector and magistrate, March, 1882, in South Canara, and subsequently in the districts of Ganjam and Vizagapatam; on duty to Calcutta as additional member of governor-general's legislative council Dec., 1884, to March, 1885; on special duty at Madras conferring upon proposals for legislating on relation of landlord and tenant in Malabar, March, 1885.

GOODRICKE, G. M., Bengal Customs Department.—Served from 30th Nov., 1859, as preventive officer and appraiser, Calcutta custom house, and was appointed assistant collector of
customs, 24th July, 1871, and deputy collector of Calcutta, March, 1880; is also superintendent of excise revenue, collector of stamp revenue, and a collector under the Licence Tax Act.

GOODRIDGE, JOHN PERCH, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1869; from Dec., 1869, served as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces, and held acting appointments at various dates as district superintendent of police, inspector of schools, cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and was deputed on famine duty to Madras, Sept., 1877; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884.

GOPAL LAL MITTER.—Vice-chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, Sept., 1884.

GOPENDRA KRISHNA, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S.—Served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, from Jan., 1877, and officiated as registrar of Calcutta and inspector of registration offices; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, Nov., 1882, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

GORDON, D. C., Public Works Department, Madras.—Joined the public works department Feb., 1868, as assistant controller of accounts, N.W. Provinces; served subsequently as deputy controller in the Punjab; controller, 3rd class, on the Indus Valley state railway, July, 1874, and afterwards on the Punjab northern railway; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1877-79, and afterwards in Madras.

GORDON, HAMILTON WINKUP, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1866, officiating inspector of schools, July, 1872, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1881.

GORDON, HUNTLY PRYSE, Madras C.S.—Educated at New College, London, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from Aug., 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), and acting district and sessions judge; appointed collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Dec., 1878, and afterwards at Bellary, April, 1880.

GORDON, SIR JAMES DAVIDSON, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and at Trinity College, Glen Almond, Perthshire; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1854; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed junior secretary to government of Bengal, 1861, and magistrate and collector of Maldah, 1863, and subsequently at Monghyr; mutiny medal; officiating civil and sessions judge of Puneah, April, 1865, and subsequently of Dinagepore, and Moorshedabad; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, June, 1865; private secretary to the governor-general of India, Jan., 1866; judicial commissioner, Mysore, 1869; president of the famine relief committee, 1874; chief commissioner, Mysore and Coorg, and guardian to H.H. the Maharaja, 1878; resident, Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, 1881; retired 1883.

GOUGH, A. E., B.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the department, 6th July, 1868, and served as Anglo-Sanskrit professor, Benares College, and as professor of English literature and professor of history and philosophy at the Muir College, Allahabad, and also officiated for various periods between 1872 and 1878 as principal, Benares College, with charge of the meteorological observatory; 3rd class, Bengal educational department, April, 1878; professor, Presidency College, June, 1878; also principal, Calcutta Madrassa, Aug., 1878.

GOVAN, GEORGE MONCRIEFF, Surgeon-Major, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P.E., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, and Feb., 1852, and served under the military department up to 1883, in Bengal, Burma, and Assam, and throughout the Bhootan campaign, 1864-1866; rank of surgeon, June, 1864; surgeon-major, Dec., 1871; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, 2nd class, Fatehgarh, and posted to Zamgarh; officiating deputy sanitary commissioner, Aug., 1883; superintendent of Pilgrim Hospitals in Kumaun and Garhwai in addition to other duties, Aug., 1883; in medical charge of Almora, Nov., 1883.

GRACE, CHARLES HALLYBURTON, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, March, 1854; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1883, at Jubbulpore; acted as commissioner of the Jubbulpore division, May-June, 1882.

GRAHAM, JAMES, Store Department, India Office.—Served in the Bombay artillery and ordnance department, 1834 to 1844; also in auditor-general's office, and in charge of Mul-ligau depot, and in grand arsenal, Bombay; examiner of stores, India store depot, London, 25th May, 1866; sub-inspector of stores, Dec., 1866; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877.

GRAHAME, WILLIAM FRANCIS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, and was placed on special duty in July, 1868, with Dr. Janssen in connection with the solar eclipse; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, June, 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1882, in North Tanjore, and afterwards in Kurnool.

GRANT, SIR CHARLES, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity College, Cambridge, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the revenue and settlement departments; transferred to Central Provinces, Nov., 1863, and served as settlement officer and acting deputy commissioner; in charge of settlement commissioner's office, Jubbulpore, Jan., 1868; secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov.,
1861; compiled the 'Provincial Gazetteer'; commissioner of Chattisgarh division, Nov., 1870, and subsequently of the Jubbulpore and Narbala divisions; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; acting chief commissioner, April to Nov., 1879; additional member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1879; acting secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural departments, May, 1880; foreign secretary, government of India, Sept., 1881; retired, Feb., 1885.

GRANT, GREGORY COLQUHOUN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1853, and served on military duty till Nov., 1860, and subsequently as deputy collector and magistrate in Sind; judge and sessions judge, March, 1865; also acted as judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the Sadar court.

GRANT, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 11th July, 1859, and served under the military department till 1860; from June, 1860, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Bijnor, and was in medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp, Nov., 1861; civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Farakhabad, March, 1862; on special deputation to Calcutta to give evidence in a criminal case at the high court, Jan., 1864; officiating superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, and chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces, Oudh and Central Provinces, Aug., 1866; superintendent of new central prison, Farakhabad, Dec., 1866; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; representative of N.W. Provinces at the prison committee, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; officiating inspector-general of prisons and civil hospitals, N.W. Provinces, in 1877, 1879, and 1882; superintendent, central and district jails, Bareilly, Dec., 1877; deputy sanitary commissioner, 1st circle, Dec., 1883.

GRANT, GEORGE FRANCIS MYTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton and Brighton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch registrar-general, education inspector in Sind, and acting talukdari settlement officer; in charge of the Sachim state, May, 1879; junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Nov., 1883; acting collector of customs, Bombay, May, 1884; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Thana, March, 1885.

GRANT, JOHN ANDREW, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; served under the foreign department, government of India, at Kurram, May-Aug., 1880.

GRANT, JOHN HAY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 6th Feb., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, assistant revenue and police commissioner, acting collector and magistrate, and acting commissioner of customs, salt, and opium; junior collector, Kaladgi, Sept., 1877; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1877 to Feb., 1881; collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Aug., 1883; special commissioner for Bombay for purpose of international exhibition at Calcutta, Nov.-Dec., 1883.

GRANT, SIR JOHN PETER, K.C.M.G., K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1826; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; deputy collector of Sarun, 1833; officiated as secretary, Sudder board of revenue, Calcutta, and as assistant secretary and deputy secretary to government, 1834; deputy accountant and civil auditor, Agra; deputy secretary to governments of India and Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, and officiating superintendent of the botanical gardens, 1835; junior member and secretary, prison discipline committee, 1836; officiating secretary, Indian law committee, 1837; officiating secretary to government of India, legislative, judicial, and revenue departments, 1838; private secretary to governor-general, and deputy secretary, general and financial departments, 1839; deputy accountant-general, ex-officio director of bank of Bengal, and junior secretary, financial branch, 1840; commissioner for payment of Mysore debts 1844-47; commissioner for enquiry into proceedings regarding Meriah sacrifices in Ganjam, 1847; secretary to Indian law commission, 1848; secretary to government of Bengal, 1849; secretary to government of India, home department and foreign department, 1852-54; governor-general's council, 1854 to 1857; temporarily lieutenant-governor of Central Provinces during mutiny, 1857-58; governor-general's council, 1858-59; lieutenant-governor of Bengal 1859 to 1862, when he resigned the service; governor of Jamaica, 1866 to 1874.

GRANT, JOHN PETER, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1855; assistant magistrate and collector, Jessore, June, 1857; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Sept., 1862; officiating comptroller of government salt chowkies, Nov., 1862; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1863; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1863; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1867; small cause court judge, Kishnaghur, April 1874; district and sessions judge, March, 1875; 1st grade, district judge, Jan., 1878; officiating judge, high court, April, 1885.

GRANT, JOHN PYNE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Revenue Survey of Mysore.—First commission as ensign, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1856; joined the revenue survey, 1860; superintendent of revenue survey, Mysore, Jan., 1868.

GRANT, J. G. GARROW, Dr., Emigration Department, Bengal.—Served in the emigration department from 22nd May, 1863, as medical inspector and protector of labourers, Kooshtea; on special duty at the Presidency, Oct., 1870; protector of emigrants and superintendent of labour transports, Calcutta, Feb., 1871; superintendent of emigration, Calcutta, Jan., 1874.

GRANT, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Bengal
C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1874, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1878.

GRANT, T., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk 2nd class, India office, 28th May, 1875.

GRAY, EVELYN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Nasik, March, 1884.

GRAY, PERCY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 30th December, 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Roorkee, Oct., 1883.

GRAY, R., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 11th March, 1860; civil assistant surgeon, Gujranwala, Feb., 1863; superintendent, central jail, Jan., 1864; civil surgeon, Mooltan, May, 1868; officiated as inspector-general of prisons, March, 1869, to March, 1871, and again in 1877; in medical charge of lieutenant-governor's camp, Nov., 1877; served afterwards as civil surgeon of Murree, Mooltan, and Lahore; inspector-general of prisons, Punjab, July, 1884.

GRAY, WELLINGTON, Surgeon-Major, L.M., L.Ch. (Dub.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1866; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1866, and was appointed professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and 2nd surgeon at the Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Bombay; also served as professor of botany, professor of surgery, curator of the Victoria and Albert Museum, professor of chemistry and medical jurisprudence, and chemical analyser to government; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department, June, 1878; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical Hospital, May, 1883.

GREAVES, RICHARD HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 19th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884.

GREENE, WALTER JAMES, Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 1st July, 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; attached to the financial department; clerk for examination of army non-effective accounts.

GREENSHIELDS, ROBERT SCOTT, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Birkenhead School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Patna, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, March, 1882, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner.

GREENSTREET, WILLIAM LEE, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works branch 1872; executive engineer, Nov., 1874; supervising engineer, Presidency and Oudh command, Lucknow, Aug., 1884.

GREER, RICHARD TOWNSEND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Erasmus College, Drogheda, and Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1877, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty Oct., 1878; forest settlement officer, Jan., 1880; officiating deputy commissioner Sept., 1881; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1884.

GREIG, G., Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th Sept., 1857, as a lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland Highlanders; retired from the army, June, 1865; joined the forest department, Dec., 1868, and was appointed assistant conservator, Aug., 1869, deputy conservator, March, 1871, and conservator Nov., 1876; promoted to 1st grade of conservators, April, 1883.

GREIG, IRWIN MONTGOMERY, Colonel, R.E., A.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1855; served in the Bombay public works department from Oct., 1855, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; deputy consulting engineer for railways, B.B. and C.I. railway, April, 1863; served subsequently as executive engineer in Ahmedabad, Khandesh, Kanara, Lower and Central Sind, and Dharwar, and with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867; from April, 1879, served as superintending engineer, and was promoted to 1st class, Oct., 1882.

GREY, CHARLES, Political Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1864; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, April, July, 1866; financial department, 1866; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1872; political department, 1874; reading clerk to council from 1875; senior clerk, April, 1877.

GREY, LEOPOLD JOHN HERBERT, C.S.I., Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; assistant commissioner in Assam, Feb., 1865; officiating civil officer with Bhootan Dover field force, Dec., 1865; from April, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, but was employed under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1868, to June, 1869; on special duty, Oct., 1869, to March, 1870; political agent, Bahawalpur State, March, 1871, to Jan., 1873, and again in 1877; judicial assistant, 1st grade, July, 1876; on special duty in connection with imperial assemblage, Sept., 1876, to Jan., 1877; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1876; officiating civil and session judge, Pesha wur, Aug., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; secretary to board of examiners (under government of India), March, 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Hissar division, Dec., 1882.

GRIERSON, GEORGE ABRAHAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Bees, Shrewsbury, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1873; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine
duty, March, 1874; officiating inspector of schools Oct., 1880; on special duty in the revenue department, Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Feb., 1885.

**GRiffin, Sir Lepel Henry, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.**—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; under secretary to government of Punjab, 1871; superintendent of Kapurthala state, 1877; deputy commissioner, Lahore, 1878; secretary to government of Punjab, civil department, 1879; agent to governor-general, Central India, 1882.

**Griffith, Hugh, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Burma.**—Joined the Indian medical department (Madras establishment), 1859; served under the military department from 1859 to 1871, and also held civil surgeoncies of Thayetmyo and Hoshungabad during that period; civil surgeon and health officer, Rangoon, April, 1871; also superintendent of lunatic asylum, and in charge of state prisons and lock hospital, June, 1871; in medical charge of Rangoon jail, Nov., 1871; superintendent of vaccination May, 1875.

**Griffith, Ralph Thomas Hotchkin, M.A., C.I.E., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.**—Arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1853, and served as professor and head master, Benares College, also as officiating inspector of public instruction, 3rd circle; principal, Benares College, Jan., 1861; superintendent of observatory, Benares, May, 1866; promoted to 1st grade April, 1873; on special committee under government of India, for selection of text-books, May, 1877; inspector-general of schools, N.W. Provinces, March, 1878; director of public instruction, Feb., 1879.

**Griffiths, W., M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Education Department, Bengal.**—Appointed to the education department, 1st July, 1869; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1870, and served as assistant professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College; professor, Presidency College, Feb., 1876; principal, Hooghly College, April, 1880; 2nd class, education department, July, 1883.

**Grigg, Edward Evans, Major, Gen. List Inf., Oudh Commission.**—Arrived in India as ensign, Dec., 1861; served under the military department till Jan., 1864, and subsequently as assistant commissioner of Goalpara up to March, 1867, when he was transferred to the Oudh commission, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner in various districts; officiating cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, May-June, 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Sultanpur, May, 1885.

**Grigg, Henry Bidewell, M.A., Madras C.S.**—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1866; acting inspector of schools Feb., 1867; from March, 1872, to Feb., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and acting commissioner, Nilgiris; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Feb., 1876, and acting secretary, March, 1877; on special duty, preparing Annual Administration Report, Oct., 1877; under secretary, public department, Oct., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1880; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1880; director of public instruction and commissioner for the uncov. civil service examinations, July, 1880; compiled the 'Nilgiri District Manual'; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882.

**Grimes, Henry Robert, Jail Department, Madras.**—Assistant deputy commissioner of paper currency, Vizagapatam, 29th Nov., 1864; from April, 1866, served as superintendent of the central jail, Coimbatore; inspector-general of jails, Madras, July, 1884.

**Grimley, William Henry, B.A., Bengal C.S.**—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India 12th Dec., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiated as superintendent of surveys, Feb., 1870, and as inspector of schools Aug., 1870; on special duty in connection with the examination of candidates for the native civil service, Jan., 1874; from 1874 to 1879 served as officiating secretary and junior secretary to the board of revenue; magistrate and collector, and grade, March, 1879; officiating collector of customs and ex officio shipping master, Calcutta, April, 1881; officiating secretary, board of revenue, from Feb., 1883.

**Grimwood, Frank St. Clair, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).**—Educated at Winchester and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1876; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, inspector of labourers, and officiating deputy commissioner.

**Grindlay, Walter, Bengal C.S.**—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

**Grose, James, M.A., Madras C.S.**—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras from Aug., 1861, as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, secretary to commissioner for uncov. civil service examinations, secretary to the central committee for the examination of assistants, and sub-secretary board of revenue; fellow of the Madras University, May, 1868; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, March, 1870; secretary to board of revenue, 1870 to 1877; collector and magistrate, Nellore, March, 1877.

**Groves, Frederick W., Accounts Department, India Office.**—Associate of King's College, London; M.A. and LL.B., University of London; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; temporary clerk, India Office, 1st Aug., 1863; junior clerk May, 1864; senior clerk, Aug., 1879.

**Growse, Edward Frederick, Bengal C.S.**—Educated at Charterhouse and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879;
arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

GROWSE, FREDERICK SALMON, M.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oriel and Queen's Colleges, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; from Dec., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Bulandshahr, Jan., 1879.

GUBBINS, FREDERICK BEBB, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1835; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, Delhi division; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Moradabad, 1842, and subsequently in Rohutk and Banda; magistrate and collector of Benares, 1852; civil and sessions judge, Benares, 1857; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Benares, agent to governor-general, and superintendent of ex-rajah of Coorg, 1858; retired 1863.

GUN, WILLIAM HENRY MAFFETT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Greenock Academy and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884.

GUPTA KRISHNA GOVINDA (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mymensingh Zilla School and Pogose School, Dacca, and matriculated at Calcutta University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884.

GURBACHAN SINGH, SIRDAR SINDHAWALIA, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra assistant commissioner, 27th Jan., 1880; probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1882; assistant commissioner, Pind Dadan Khan, Jan., 1884.

GURDIAL SINGH, SIRDAR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 26th Jan., 1880; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1882.

GURDON, EVELYN PULTENEY, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 2nd April, 1852; from Aug., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsar divisions, Nov.-Dec., 1881, and subsequently in the Lahore and Rawul Pindi divisions; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Nov., 1882; divisional judge, and grade, Lahore, Nov., 1884.

GÜTERSLOH, F. N., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1874, as assistant engineer on the Indus Valley state railway; in charge of locomotive and carriage department, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1875; officiating manager and locomotive superintendent, Holkar state railway, 1877; assistant manager, Warora colliery, March, 1879; locomotive superintendent, Rajputana railways, March, 1880; 1st class, 2nd grade, locomotive department, state railways, Jan., 1882.

GUTHRIE, THOMAS KEY, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India 11th July, 1855; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; deputy inspector-general, Dec., 1881; commissioner of police, Madras, July, 1883; acting inspector-general Sept., 1883, to Nov., 1884.

GUTHRIE, WILLIAM JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Glasgow Academy, University of Glasgow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HAIG, CHARLES THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Obtained his first commission from Addiscombe, June, 1854; lieutenant, Bombay engineers, May, 1856; arrived at Bombay July, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856–57, and with the Rajputana field force, 1857; assistant executive engineer at Neemuch, Sept., 1859; appointed as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, Sept., 1859; served with the Okhamandal field force in 1859, and was subsequently variously employed in the survey department in Cutch, Kattywar, Guzerat, Meywar, Malwa, the Deccan, and Kanara; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; on deputation as commissioner, Venice geographical exhibition; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; officiating deputy surveyor-general in charge of trigonometrical survey branch, Oct., 1884.

HAINES, HERMANN A., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Wellington College and Keble College, Oxford; junior clerk, financial department, India Office, 15th Nov., 1881.

HALL, CHARLES FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of jail, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Bareilly, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Budaun, Feb., 1883.

HALL, M. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 21st Jan., 1875; clerk, 2nd class, Oct., 1878.

HALL, WILLIAM THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Rossall, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1878, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer.

HALLETT, HENRY HONEYWOOD HUGHES, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Jail Department, Central Provinces.—First commission as ensign July, 1858; arrived in India, 11th Aug., 1858; from Dec., 1868, served in the Central Provinces
as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and was appointed superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1878; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, 1883.

HALLETT, JOHN REVANS, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 17th Oct., 1864; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, May, 1865; inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; second inspector of registration offices, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1880.

HALLIDAY, SIR FREDERICK JAMES, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1824; arrived in India, 8th June, 1825; served in Bengal as assistant to the agent in the Saugur division and assistant registrar of the Sudder court; joint magistrate and deputy collector in Bundelcund, and afterwards in Noacolly and Bulloobah, 1831-35; magistrate and collector of the Zillah Court at Dacca, Feb., 1835; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, Feb., 1836; secretary to the Sudder board of revenue April, 1836; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, May, 1838; member of the general committee of public instruction, June, 1838; junior secretary to the government of India, revenue, judicial, and legislative departments, in addition to his other duties, March, 1840, to 1843; secretary to the government of India, home department, 1849; member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1853; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1st May, 1854; retired in 1859; member of council of secretary of state for India 30th Sept., 1863.

HALLIDAY, FREDERICK MYTON, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived, 30th Oct., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating civil and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, May, 1871); officiated as opium agent, Benares, in 1876 and 1877; commissioner, Presidency division, April, 1878, and Patna division, June, 1878.

HAMBLIN, RICHARD EBB, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School and Christ College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HAMILTON, RICHARD ERRIS, Financial Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the financial department, 1st Aug., 1868; served as assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1869, also in British Burma, May, 1870; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1872; from July, 1873, to March, 1876, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, and subsequently in Calcutta, March, 1876, to Dec., 1877; reposted to Bombay, March, 1878; officiated as deputy accountant-general in Bombay, the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, the Punjab, and Madras, 1879-81; officiating assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, March, 1882; controller and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; 3rd class of the financial department, Feb., 1883.

HAMILTON, SIR ROBERT N. C., Bart., K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1816; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1821; served in the revenue and judicial departments, N.W. Provinces; assistant to the governor-general's agent, and magistrate to the city court, Benares, Nov., 1827; judge of Benares, March, 1829; magistrate and collector of Suhaswan, Feb., 1834; civil and sessions judge, Delhi, March, 1837; commissioner, Agra division, June, 1839; agent to the lieutenant-governor, Agra, July, 1840; secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, March, 1842; resident at Indore, 1844; political agent to the governor-general for Central India 1854; retired 1860.

HAMILTON, THOMAS SHARP, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, the College, Chester, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; promoted to and assistant collector, Feb., 1883; also acted as superintendent of police, June, 1876; and as cantonment magistrate, June, 1878.

HAMMICK, MURRAY, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from Jan. to June, 1882, served in Coorg as acting 1st assistant commissioner and district magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served in the Madras secretariat as assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments and acting under secretary in the revenue department; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Canara, April, 1885.

HAMMICK, STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant educational inspector, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; assistant political agent, and tutor to the Mahárája of Kolhapur Feb., 1873; on famine duty, Kaládgi, Sept., 1877; judicial assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, Aug., 1883; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Feb., 1885; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1885.

HAMNETT, FREDERICK HARPER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and was on special duty, Sept., 1882, preparing the Madras administration report; from March, 1885, served in the financial department as assistant accountant-general, Madras.

HAMNETT, GEORGE, C.I.E., Registration Department, Madras.—Served from 11th March, 1843, in the public works department as writer, head clerk, and manager and surveyor in office of consulting engineer for railways; unco-
venanted assistant to the consulting engineer Jan., 1859; receiver of the Carnatic property Feb., 1865; marriage registrar for town of Madras, Jan., 1866; first uncov. assistant, chief secretary's office, Feb., 1867; inspector-general of registration, Nov., 1880.

HANCOCK, GEORGE EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay Staff Corps, Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1859, and served under the military department till Nov., 1863; from Nov., 1863, to March, 1868, served as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, and assessment, Gujarat; from March, 1868, acted as political and personal assistant to the political agent, Káthiáwar, and also as superintendent of the Rajkot and Limbdi states, Aug., 1869, and as assistant resident at Aden, May, 1870, and at Baroda, May, 1871; assistant general superintendent for thuggee and dacoity, Oct., 1871; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, Oct., 1871; assistant political agent, Mahi Kántha, July, 1872; from Oct., 1873, served as superintendent of surveys under Rajasthání court, Káthiáwar, and acted on various occasions as president of the court; on special duty at Delhi, Nov., 1876, to Jan., 1877; acting joint administrator of Gondal state, Nov., 1881; on special duty with the Thákór Sáheb of Gondal on tour in Europe, April, 1883; on special duty to inquire into administration of Rajpípla state, Nov., 1883; third assistant political agent, Káthiáwar, Feb., 1885, continuing to be superintendent of surveys.

HANCOCK, HENRY FRANCIS, Major-General, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 30th July, 1854; assistant superintendent, roads and tanks department, Bombay, March, 1855; assistant engineer, Poona district, Dec., 1859; assistant superintendent, harbour defences, Bombay, Jan., 1860; from May, 1860, to June, 1874, served as deputy consulting engineer for railways at Surat, Nagpur (Nov., 1861) and Bombay (March, 1863), and officiated as consulting engineer for Véhar waterworks, Bombay, Feb.–Sept., 1865; also acted as consulting engineer for railways and under secretary to government; superintending engineer, Sept., 1871; appointed consulting engineer for railways and reclamations, and under secretary to government, railway branch, with rank of chief engineer, 3rd class, Bombay, June, 1874; joint secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, from Feb., 1881; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884; on special duty under government of India, Jan.–March, 1884.

HANDLEY, FRANCIS FREDERICK (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sydenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating inspector-general of registration, and senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Dec., 1880; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1881.

HANDLEY, JAMES WILLIAM, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in Madras as government pleader from 29th Oct., 1868, to July, 1881; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, July, 1881; officiating judge of the high court, July, 1885.

HANKEY, HERBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; served in the Punjab till 1862, and subsequently in the Lower Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Malda, 1867, and subsequently at Chittagong; superintendent of transport during famine of 1874; inspector-general of police, Lower Provinces, 1876; retired 1878.

HANKIN, EDWARD LEWIS, Colonel, M.S.C., Ensign Indian army, Dec., 1847; arrived in India 16th June, 1848; served in the public works department, Madras, from Aug., 1853, to July, 1859; served subsequently in the police department as superintendent of police and acting deputy inspector-general, and temporarily in the department of the deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Jan.–June, 1861; acting magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1870; joint magistrate, Ootacamund, Nov., 1870, to Sept., 1876; superintendent of family payments and pensions, Oct., 1876; secretary to government, military department, Madras, Dec., 1882.

HANNYNGTON, JOHN CHILD, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in Madras from Oct., 1859, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate; judge of the court of small causes, Tellicherry, April, 1867; district and sessions judge, Salem, Nov., 1873; on special duty, Dec., 1880, as arbitrator of boundary disputes between states of Travancore and Cochin; on tour with H.H. the Maharajah of Travancore to Benares Jan., 1882; resident of Travancore and Cochin April, 1882.

HAPPELL, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Crosshill School, Maybole, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1879; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1880; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, April, 1881; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, Kistna, Nov., 1883.

HARCOURT, ALFRED FREDERICK POLLOCK, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1855; from Sept., 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating small cause court judge; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1877; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Montgomery, Feb., 1881.

HARDING, FRANCIS HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885.

HARDING, HERBERT W., Audit Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; writer, India office, 27th April, 1868; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1873.

HARDINGE, HON. ARTHUR EDWARD, Lieut.-General, C.B.—Esquerry to the Queen; commander-in-chief and member of council, Bombay, 30th March, 1881.

HARDY, RICHARD GILLIES, Bengal C.S.
HARRIS, ROBERT LISTON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; deputed to settlement department, Dec., 1883.

HARRISON, CHARLES WILLIAM INGLEBY, Major, R.E., Public Works department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, irrigation branch, North-Western Provinces, from 10th April, 1863, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and assistant to chief engineer, and was employed on the Eastern Jamuna, Rohilkund, and Ganges canals; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1881.

HARRISON, EDWARD FRANCIS, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1849; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent of survey; assistant accountant-general, and accountant to government of Bengal, 1854; civil auditor, Madras, 1859; sub-treasurer, Madras, 1860; civil paymaster, Madras, 1862; deputy auditor and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, 1864; accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, 1865; comptroller-general of accounts, Calcutta, and government director of bank of Bengal, 1867; also head commissioner of paper currency, Sept., 1870; retired, 1879.

HARRISON, FRANCIS CAPEL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, 24 Pergunnahs, Dec., 1884.

HARRISON, HENRY ANTHONY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College 1855; arrived in India, 3rd April, 1855; served from May, 1856, to Sept., 1858, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, Cuttack, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1862; assistant, settlement department, Feb., 1864; magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, March, 1872; officiating commissioner, Jhansi division, Sept., 1875; civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, March, 1878; 1st grade judge, March, 1884.

HARRISON, HENRY LELAND, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; inspector of schools, July, 1865; junior secretary, government of Bengal, 1867-71; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1868; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1871; superintendent of survey, Oct., 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1878; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1879; commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, Jan., 1882.

HARRISON, JOHN HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's School and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1872;
arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, Nov., 1876; officiating assistant director of department of agriculture and commerce, Nov., 1880; acting junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1881.

HARRISON, RICHARD PRYCE, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1834; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and officiating collector, Moorshedabad, 1849; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Bograh, 1850; officiating abkari commissioner, Dacca division, 1851; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1853-56; civil and sessions judge, 1856; accountant-general, government of Madras, and a government director of the Madras bank, 1859; accountant-general and auditor-general to government of India, and a government director of the bank of Bengal, 1860; also first member and president of the board of audit; comptroller-general, 1863-67; resigned, April, 1867.

HARRISON, WILLIAM PRINGLE, Major, Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 10th Feb., 1861; employed under the military department till Oct., 1867, from which date he served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating district superintendent of police, officiating superintendent of encumbered estates in Sultanpur, officiating deputy commissioner, and sub-judge; cantonment magistrate of Fyzabad, July, 1881, and subsequently of Lucknow, April, 1883.

HART, G. H. R., Financial Department, Government of India.—Probationer in financial department, 20th July, 1869; from Dec., 1870, served as assistant to comptroller-general; on special duty in Behar, Jan.-March, 1874; assistant to private secretary to viceroy, April, 1874, to April, 1876; assistant to accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1877; from Feb., 1878, acted as private secretary to governor of Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1880.

HART, JOHN HENRY EUSTACE, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854; joined the Bombay public works department, Jan., 1855, and served as civil engineer at Sátára, Násik, and Dáhrwár; acting executive engineer for reclamations, Bombay, May, 1869; architectural executive engineer and surveyor, Bombay, May, 1871; acting superintendent, harbour works, Karachi, Nov., 1874; acting superintending engineer in Sind, April, 1876; acting chief engineer for irrigation, Sept., 1877; superintending engineer 1st class, March, 1880; joint secretary to government of Bombay for irrigation, March, 1880; chief engineer, 3rd class, Oct., 1881.

HART, WILLIAM, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; commissioner for enquiring into claims &c., South Mahratta country, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay, in the general and ecclesiastical departments, 1855, also in the public works department, and railway branch, 1856; puisne judge of the court of Sudder Dewani, 1860; revenue and police commissioner, southern division, 1862; additional member of Bombay council for making laws and regulations, 1864; retired in 1865.

HART, WILLIAM ELLERTHER, B.A. (Cantab), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acting professor of English literature, Elphinstone College, Bombay, March, 1872, to Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the Bombay judicial department as acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court, and reporter to the high court; first judge of the small cause court, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as judge of the high court, July to Oct., 1884.

HART-DAVIES, THOMAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1876, served in Sind as educational inspector, acting judge and session judge, and acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, Oct., 1879.

HARTNOLL, HENRY SULLIVAN, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1883.

HARVEY, ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission 1865; officiating civil surgeon, Sept. to Dec., 1865; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1878; member of committee to report on management of the medical institutions, and on medical expenditure in Bengal, March, 1878; civil surgeon, Bankoora, May, 1878; officiating professor of midwifery, Medical College, Calcutta, and superintendent-general of vaccination, Aug., 1878; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Nov., 1878; also in medical charge of the Alipore and Russa jails, May, 1879; superintendent of emigration, July, 1879; officiating professor of midwifery, medical college, and obstetric physician to the college hospital, Sept., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1882; also officiating principal of the college, May to July, 1882; honorary surgeon on personal staff of H.E. the viceroy, May, 1883.

HARVEY, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1884.

HASTED, JOHN ORD, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—Arrived in India and Dec., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from 30th Jan., 1856, as assistant engineer, and was promoted to executive engineer, April, 1865, and superintending engineer, Feb., 1877; officiated as chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government for various periods between 1875 and 1884; and was confirmed in this appointment and promoted to chief engineer, 2nd class, April, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883.

HASTINGS, F. T. C., Political and Secret Department, India Office.—Educated at Haileybury College; admiralty writer, 8th Oct., 1868,
to Jan., 1874; civil service copyist from Jan., 1874, to Feb., 1877; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, India office, 7th March, 1877.

HASTINGS, HOLLOWAY WALROUD, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C. (Oudh Commission).—Arrived in India as lieutenant, Madras artillery, 3rd May, 1858; from March, 1866, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate and officiating city magistrate of Lucknow, officiating assistant superintendent of settlement and survey, and officiating settlement officer; superintendent of encumbered estates in Sultanpur and Parabgarh, June, 1873, to 1876; on special duty at Naini Tal, March, 1881; district judge, 3rd grade, sub pro tem., Jan., 1882; sub-judge, 1st grade, May, 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1883; 2nd grade, March, 1884.

HATCHELL, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 30th Sept., 1858; served in N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon from Dec., 1859, to Oct., 1864, and was subsequently employed under the military department, and served in the Bhootan expedition; served again under government of N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1869, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Bulandshahr; rank of surgeon, July, 1870; civil surgeon, 2nd class, and superintendent of jail, Muzaffarnagar, Dec., 1877; senior surgeon-major, July, 1878.

HATHORNTHWAITE, J. T., M.A. (Cambridge), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1872, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of mathematics at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, Dec., 1877.

HAWES, ARTHUR B., Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; ensign, Bengal army, 12th Dec., 1849; chief executive officer of telegraph from Bagdad to Constantinople, 1857-58; captain, May, 1858; retired, Oct., 1858; assistant auditor, India office, March, 1859; member of committee for valuation of military equipments, April, 1863; author of a work on small arms ammunition.

HAWKINS, CESAR RICHARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow School and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862; served in Bengal as assistant collector and magistrate, and from Feb., 1865, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Peshawar, March, 1870; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, 1876; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

HEATON, JOSEPH JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bradford Grammar School, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

HEAVISIDE, WILLIAM JAMES, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1857; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, Nov., 1861; served in the public works department as assistant engineer from Sept., 1862, to Feb., 1865; joined the great trigonometrical survey, as 2nd grade assistant, Jan., 1866; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1872; served with the Southern Afghanistan field force in 1878-79, on special survey duty; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

HEBBERT, HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1832; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1833; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed deputy secretary to government in the Persian department, Jan., 1835; deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1849; collector and magistrate of Broach, March, 1852; from March, 1853, served in the judicial department and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, July, 1853; judge and sessions judge, and agent for the governor, Surat, March, 1856; judge of the court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, 1857, and again in 1860; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, June, 1862; retired May, 1863.

HENDERSON, EDWARD PIERCY (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; from Feb., 1878, served as government advocate, chief court, Punjab.

HENDERSON, GEORGE, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 20th November, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Shahpur, May, 1862; officiating professor of medicine and surgery, April, 1865, to Jan., 1867; superintendent of Lahore central jail, April, 1868; officiating superintendent, botanical gardens in Bengal, Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Gujranwala, Dec., 1875, and subsequently at other stations in the Punjab.
