HENDERSON, PHILIP DURHAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, C.S.I., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, Feb., 1857; under secretary to the government of India, foreign department, 1873-74; resident, 3rd class, on special duty in Cashmere, 1874; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity, 1878; graded as resident, 2nd class.

HENRY, CHARLES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the French College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1885.

HENRY, EDWARD RICHARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived, Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1882; on famine duty, Tirhoot, Dec., 1873; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July, 1879, to 1882.

HENVEY, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Edu-
cated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, officiating secretary, board of revenue, and officiating junior secretary to government, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; placed on special duty for purpose of compiling a narrative of the famine of 1869-70, April, 1871; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1877-79; resident, 3rd class, on special duty, Kashmir, 1879-82; commissioner, Hyderabad Assigned Districts, Jan., 1883.

HERALD, JOHN LUMGAR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884.

HERBERT, PATRICK C. H., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; junior clerk, accounts branch, India Office, 11th March, 1872; judicial and public departments, 1877; resident clerk 1885.

HERSCHEL, JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, F.R.S., R.E., Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1855; first commission, Dec., 1856; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1859; served in the great trigonometrical survey from Nov., 1859, in the grades of assistant surveyor and deputy superintendent; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Jan., 1884.

HEWAT, RICHARD A., Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 18th Aug., 1888; junior clerk, military department, India office, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1875.

HEWETSON, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

HEWETT, JOHN PRESCOTT, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Winchester and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner; in charge of provincial gazetteer, Aug., 1883.

HEWISH, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 1st Feb., 1869; senior clerk (supernumerary) Sept., 1883.

HEWITT, JAMES FRANCIS KATHERINUS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived, 12th Feb., 1859; assistant magistrate and collector Feb., 1860; officiating deputy commissioner, Lohardugga, July, 1863; settlement officer, Chuttergurh, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, wards' estate in Behar, Feb., 1873; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1878; commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, March, 1879.

HEWLETT, THOMAS GILLHAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, C.I.E., M.R.C.S., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 20th Jan., 1854; arrived in India, 21st Feb., 1854, and served in the military department, and as civil surgeon and superintendent of vaccination; acting deputy assay master, Bombay mint, May, 1863; sanitary officer, Bombay, May, 1863, to June, 1865; coroner of Bombay, Oct., 1865; health officer, Bombay, Aug., 1865, to Oct., 1873; municipal commissioner, Oct.–Dec., 1872; sheriff of Bombay, and superintendent of common jail, Dec., 1872; member of municipal corporation of the city of Bombay and member of the town council, March, 1874; from April, 1874, served as surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejpal native general hospital, and was appointed a member of the standing medical committee, Nov., 1874; deputy surgeon-general (in Sind) Nov., 1879; sanitary commissioner for the government of Bombay, May, 1883.

HEWSON, FRANCIS THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; transferred to foreign department, government of India, Oct., 1878, and appointed assistant agent to the governor-general in Rajputana (magistrate of Abu and assistant to the general superintendent of operations for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity in Lower Rajputana).

HEYWOOD, JOHN MAGEE, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; arrived in India, April, 1858; served in the public works department from April, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; on special duty Oct., 1866; deputed to examine reservoirs in France and Spain while on leave in 1867; ordered to report on arrangements connected with towing in inland rivers in Belgium; special survey duty, Sept., 1870; deputed on special duty to the Punjab, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1881; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, April, 1883; superintending engineer, 1st class, sub. pro tem., Jan., 1884.

HIGGINS, ALFRED WILLIAM BUCKLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; on special duty as secretary to the draft forest bill committee, April–Nov., 1882; deputy conservator of forests, 1st grade, Cuddapah, Dec., 1882.

HIGGINS, JOHN JAMES, Police Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed acting adjutant military police, Narsinghpur, for services rendered during the mutiny under Sir Henry Havelock, Dec., 1858; from March, 1861, served in the police department of the Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st class, June, 1879; on special duty at Kalahandi, June, 1882.

HILDEBRAND, ARTHUR HEDDING, Burma Commission.—From Feb., 1868, to March, 1872, served in the Burma police department as assistant superintendent and acting superintendent; from March, 1872, served in the Burma commiss-
HILL, F. G., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 6th July, 1882; attached to the funds department.

HILL, Henry, Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and Edinburgh University; India office writer, old establishment, 1859; junior clerk, financial department, 1860; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1867-74; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; assistant secretary in the revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Sept., 1877; compiled the Annual Official Reports on Sanitary Measures in India from 1873-74 to 1877-78, and the Moral and Material Progress Reports from 1873-74 to 1875-76.

HILL, John, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, June, 1862; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1865; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1866, and was employed in Kumaon and Garhwal and afterwards in Bombay, and on the eastern frontier; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1870; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; attached to Afghan boundary commission, Sept., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1884; in charge of Konkan topographical survey, Oct., 1884.

HILL, T. C., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Aug., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1867; superintendent, British Burma, Feb., 1879; 1st grade superintendent, March, 1885.

HILL, William, Colonel, M.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Aug., 1853; junior assistant to the commissioner of Mysore, Jan., 1861; deputy superintendent, 3rd class, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; 1st class deputy commissioner in Mysore, April, 1877; acting commissioner of Coorg, 1881-85; appointed civil and sessions judge of the civil and military station of Bangalore, 1883.

HILSON, Archibald Hamilton, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the army medical department from Dec., 1855, to Oct., 1856; appointed assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 29th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 3rd June, 1857, and served under the military department in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, and in the Bhootan campaign, also temporarily holding the civil surgeoncies of Moradabad, 1860, and Aligarh, 1863, and serving as civil assistant surgeon, Gorakhpur, 1864; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1869; from April, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Naini Tal, and officiating civil surgeon at Bijnor and Moradabad; also held charge of the jails at Bijnor and Moradabad, and of the lock hospital at the latter place; civil surgeon, Naini Tal, Oct., 1874; civil surgeon, 1st class, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, and principal, medical school, Agra, March, 1876.

HOBART, Robert Thompson, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; deputy inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1873; officiating inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1881; inspector-general of prisons, Oct., 1882.

HOBHOUSE, Arthur F., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Royal College, Boulogne; junior clerk, India board, political and secret department, 30th Oct., 1849; private secretary to the president 1849-52; public secretary, 1852; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, 1858-60; senior clerk, public department, 1860; assistant secretary in the public department, June, 1867.

HOBHOUSE, Sir Charles P., Bart., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1844; arrived in India, 22nd July, 1844, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and in the financial department, government of India, as assistant to the sub-treasurer, and assistant to accountant-general; collector of Burdwan, 1857-59; magistrate and collector, 1859; officiating civil and sessions judge, 1859-60; deputed on special duty in 1860 to adjudicate on suits arising out of the indigo disturbances, Nudda and Jessore; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, and government advocate, 1862, and also member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal for making laws and regulations, 1863-64; civil and sessions judge, 1864-66; on special duty in Calcutta to revise law relating to stamp duties; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; on special duty as chairman of the Orissa famine and orphan relief fund, 1867; judge of the high court of judicature, 1868 to 1871; retired 1872.

HODGKINSON, George James Spence, Bengal C.S., British Burma.—Educated at Middle School, York, and Louth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived 25th Nov., 1864; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Nov., 1865; manager of the Hutwa estates, Jan., 1872; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1877; from March, 1877, to Dec., 1878, acted as magistrate and collector of Moorshedabad, and was in charge of office of agent to governor-general, June, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1878; transferred to British Burma as officiating commissioner, Arakan division, Dec., 1878; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1879; specially appointed a judge under the Land Acquisition Act, June, 1881; on special duty at Rangoon, June, 1881; commissioner, Irrawaddy, July, 1881.

HODGSON, J., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 19th Aug., 1878.

HOEY, William, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 18th Oct., 1872, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Sept., 1879; assistant commissioner, and grade, Jan., 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, March, 1885.
HOGG, ADAM GEORGE FORBES, Brigadier-General, C.B., Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1854; served with the Persian expedition, 1857, in the Indian mutiny, the China war, 1860, the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, as deputy adjutant quarter-master-general, and in the Afghan war, 1879-80, as director of transport with Bombay reserve and brigade on Kandahar line, and subsequently with the Kabul field force; appointed political resident and collector of stamp revenue with charge of the Vice-Admiralty court, Aden, May, 1885.

HOGG, FREDERIC RUSSELL, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India 12th Feb., 1857; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; postmaster-general, Punjab and Sind, July, 1863; officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, April, 1867; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1868; officiating deputy director-general of post office of India, March, 1870; officiating director-general, 1871-72, and again, 1873-76; representative of the government of India at the postal congress, Paris, 1878; confirmed as director-general of post office of India, March, 1882.

HOGG, STAPLETON C., Financial Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 25th July, 1861; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, 1862; financial department, 1863; senior clerk Dec., 1875.

HOGG, SIR STUART S., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; arrived in India, Jan., 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner till 1859, and afterwards in Oudh as deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Bengal, 1861; chairman, justices of the peace, Calcutta, 1866; commissioner of police, Calcutta, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1874; retired 1878.

HOGG, THEODORE WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1858; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner from Aug., 1867, and acted as cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, 1874-80, also acting at various times as small cause court judge at the same place; small cause court judge, Nagpur, and deputy commissioner, 4th class, 1885.

HOJEL, ABRAHAM NICKSON, M.K. and O.C.P., L.R.C.S. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 16th Feb., 1860, and served under the military department till Feb., 1865; professor of anatomy and physiology, and curator of the museum, Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Feb., 1865; also acted as surgeon to coroner of Bombay, and professor of medicine at the Grant Medical College; from July, 1866, to Nov., 1871; served in the Persian Gulf as civil surgeon, Bushire, and assistant to the resident; served subsequently under the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; appointed professor of physiology, Grant Medical College, and second physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Sept., 1876; also acted as 1st physician of the hospital and principal of the college, March-April, 1878, as surgeon of the Gokuldas Tejpal Native General Hospital, Oct., 1883, to May, 1884, and as physician of the European General Hospital from March, 1885.

HOLDERNESS, THOMAS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 17th Feb., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, March, 1877; junior secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1878, and officiated as secretary in 1879 and 1881; under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Sept., 1881, to 1885; joint magistrate, N.W. Provinces, April, 1885.

HOLDICH, THOMAS HUNGERFORD, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, Dec., 1862; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1865; served on special survey duty in the Bhutan campaign, 1865; joined the topographical survey as assistant superintendent, July, 1866; on special survey duty with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68; served subsequently in the Gwalior and Central India topographical survey, and was appointed to the charge of the Vizagapatam agency and Central Provinces survey Dec., 1873; joined the Afghanistan field force in 1879, and was in charge of survey operations in Northern Afghanistan during second period of the campaign; in charge of Kohat topographical survey, Feb., 1881; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1883; in charge of Biluchistan topographical survey, Oct., 1883; attached to the Afghan boundary commission, 1884.

HOLIDAY, FREDERICK C., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 17th June, 1861; junior examiner, June, 1863; senior examiner, Dec., 1868.

HOLLOWAY, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1848; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate till 1857, when he was appointed subordinate judge of Calicut; civil and sessions judge, Tellicherry, 1861; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1862; retired in 1877.

HOLMES, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Windermere College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating superintendent of Dehra Dun; appointed to take charge of H.H. Amir Yakub Khan, March, 1880; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, April, 1881; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Dec., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, June, 1884.

HOLMES, WILLIAM CUTHBERT, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, to Aug., 1882, served in Bombay as officiating assistant accountant-general; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Dec., 1884.

HOLMS, JOHN MITCHEL, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol Col-
lege, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOLMWOOD, HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1879; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

HOLROYD, WILLIAM RICE MORLAND, Col., B.S.C., Educational Department, Punjab.—First commission as ensign, Dec., 1853; served from 11th Aug., 1858, in the Punjab educational department as inspector of schools, and was appointed director of public instruction, Punjab, Feb., 1868; 1st grade, education department, April, 1870; under secretary to government of Punjab, educational department, Oct., 1884.

HOLT, JAMES RICHARD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Beective College and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1880, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOME, A. L., Bengal Forest Department.—From 1st March, 1864, served in the Forest Department in the Punjab, Central Provinces, and Bengal, and was appointed deputy conservator, 1st grade, and assistant comptroller-general of forests, Sept., 1882, and conservator of forests, 3rd grade, Bengal, April, 1883; 2nd grade, Feb., 1885.

HOME, FREDERICK JERVIS, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, N.W. Provinces, irrigation branch, from Feb., 1861, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Ganges, Eastern Jamna, and Agra canals, and other works; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1883; officiating chief engineer, irrigation branch, and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1885.

HOME, ROBERT, Colonel, C.I.E., R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1853; assistant engineer, irrigation department, N.W. Provinces, April, 1858; executive engineer, Punjab, 1859; deputy superintendent, Eastern Jamna canal, 1860; executive engineer, Bari Doab canal, Jan., 1862; superintendent of works, Sutlej canal, Nov., 1867, and afterwards on the Sirhind canal, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, Sirhind canal circle, March, 1872; officiating chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government of Punjab, Dec., 1876, to Jan., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, 1882; officiating inspector-general of irrigation, and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, 1884.

HOOKER, W. H., Store Department, India Office.—Supervisor, and 2nd grade, India store depot, Aug., 1877.

HOOPER, JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1881; settlement officer, 3rd grade, Basti, Nov., 1884.

HOOPER, WILLIAM ROE, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1850; arrived in India, Aug., 1859, and served in Bengal, holding various military medical charges; from July, 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and was appointed superintendent of central prison, Benares, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; civil surgeon of Benares, Sept., 1874; senior surgeon-major, Feb., 1879.

HOPE, JAMES, B.A., Madras C.S.—Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1863; served in Bombay from Oct., 1864, to July, 1867, and subsequently in Madras, and was appointed principal assistant collector, Ganjam, Sept., 1870; acted as collector and magistrate and political agent in the districts of Ganjam, Kurnool, and Godavari, 1870-77; from Jan., 1877, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge of Chingleput, and from Dec., 1882, in South Arcot.

HOPE, SIR THEODORE CRACRAFT, K.C.S.I., C.I.E. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay, C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 5th June, 1853, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and educational inspector; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1860; president of committee on finances of educational department, March, 1861; joint commissioner with the secretary in the public works department to receive North Kanara from the Madras government, Feb., 1862; deputy commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, Oct., 1862; collector and magistrate, Kaira, Jan., 1867; collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Surat, March, 1867; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1871; acting commissioner of customs and opium, Nov., 1874; member of tariff committee at Calcutta, Dec., 1874; from July, 1875, served as additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, also acting as secretary to the government of India in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed additional secretary for famine, Dec., 1876; commissioner, northern division, and agent to governor, Surat, Jan., 1878; on special political duty in England Oct.-Nov., 1878; provisional member of council of governor of Bombay, Oct., 1880; commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1881; from April, 1881, acted as secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1881; ordinary member of governor-general's council in charge of public works department, July, 1882.

HOPKINS, E. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 14th Nov., 1883.

HOPKINS, JOHN ARTHUR, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Oct., 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magis-
trate and collector; also served as officiating district superintendent of police, March, 1872, inspector of schools, 1872-76, and officiating inspector-general of registration, July, 1875, to March, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1884.

HOPKINSON, WILLIAM, Major, Gen. List Inf., Bengal.—First commission, 1859; from 28th Nov., 1867, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, as assistant commissioner, and sub-registrar of assurances; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, March, 1874, and subsequently of Barrackpore, and small cause court judge Nov., 1875.

HORDERN, PETER, B.A., Educational Department, Burma.—Appointed to the education department, 19th Nov., 1861; arrived in India, March, 1862; assistant professor of English literature, Presidency College, Calcutta, March, 1862; director of public instruction, British Burma, Nov., 1867; fellow of Calcutta University, April, 1876.

HORNE, WILLIAM OGLIVIE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

HORSFALL, JEREMIAH GARNETT, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from Aug., 1864, and was appointed district and sessions judge, South Malabar, April, 1878, and collector and magistrate, Kistna, Jan., 1879, and afterwards in Vizagapatam and Ganjam.

HORSFALL, THOMAS MENDELSSOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Educated at the Wilhelms-Gymnasium, Berlin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1880, and again, Sept., 1881; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Madura, Dec., 1884.

HORSFORD, NORMAN MACLEOD THOMAS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 27th regiment Native Infantry, 29th Dec., 1857, and served under the military department till 1861; from Aug., 1861, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department, N.W. Provinces, as assistant inspector-general, and district superintendent; from Dec., 1867, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, junior secretary, and officiating personal assistant to chief commissioner, and officiating director of public instruction; superintendent of encumbered estates, Rae Bareli, 1874-76; officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, April, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, March, 1878; city magistrate and Wasika officer, Lucknow, April, 1883.

HORSLEY, WILLIAM HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Canterbury, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and was in charge of the forests in Khandaish, Oct., 1872, to Feb., 1874; employed from March to Oct., 1874, on famine relief operations in Dinapore, in Bengal, and subsequently on forest demarcation work in Khandaish; on famine duty, Kaladgi, Aug., 1877; forest settlement officer, Nov., 1878; second assistant collector and acting junior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; from June, 1884, acted as assistant judge and sessions judge.

HORSPOOL, W. P., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Educated at the Newark Collegiate School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Aug., 1878.

HÖRST, HENRY, Survey Department, Burma.—Librarian and accountant, Thomason College, Roorkee, Jan., 1853; sub-assistant, great trigonometrical survey, Sept., 1854; transferred to topographical survey, senior department, April, 1868; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1866; deputy superintendent, Burma topographical survey, Sept., 1882.

HOSKING, EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and registrar of the high court; judge and sessions judge, Khandaish, Jan., 1884.

HOSKING, W. H., Store Department, India Office.—Assistant to supervisor of stamps, 1st Aug., 1861; superintendent of stamps, June, 1869.

HOSKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 7th Sept., 1858; served in Madras police department from May, 1863, as assistant superintendent and superintendent (1st grade, Feb., 1885).

HOUGHTON, BERNARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at All Saints', Bloxham, Wellingborough Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1885.

HOUSE, HENRY FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bristol Grammar School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOUSLEY, ARTHUR W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

HOUSTON, JOHN, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Appointed, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1856, and served in Mysore in various military charges, and also as civil surgeon, chemical examiner, and superintendent of jail; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; from July, 1871, served as surgeon to the Mysore commission; brigade surgeon, June, 1881; officiating residency surgeon, May, 1883; surgeon to the Mysore government.

HOWE, WILLIAM ARTHUR, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St.
Edmund's College, Ware; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1873, to Oct., 1874, for service in connection with Behar famine; on famine relief duty in Madras, Feb., 1877, to Nov., 1878; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Etawah, June, 1880.

HOWELL, Arthur Pearse, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; from May, 1859, to April, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, assistant secretary, and acting under secretary to the government; from April, 1864, to March, 1878, served in the secretariat of the government of India, first as under secretary, financial department, and then as under secretary and acting secretary, home department, also as acting deputy secretary, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was placed on special duty March, 1869; commissioner, Jubbulpore division, Central Provinces, April, 1877; secretary, famine commission, March, 1878; on special duty, June, 1878; commissioner, Nerbudda division, Sept., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1879, to Feb., 1880, and again in 1885; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, June to Dec., 1882; member of education commission under the government of India, Dec., 1882, to Sept., 1883.

HOWELL, Mortimer Sloper, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating inspector of public instruction, April, 1867; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1868; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1871; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; from March, 1880, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, May, 1880.

HUDLESTON, William, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; assistant collector and magistrate, Canara, July, 1847; head assistant, Chingleput, May, 1854; head assistant and acting deputy registrar, court of Sudder Adawlut, Sept., 1854; deputy secretary to government in the departments under the chief secretary, Feb., 1855; secretary to board of examiners, March, 1855; acting deputy secretary in the revenue and public works department, Dec., 1857; acting deputy collector of sea customs, Madras, May, 1858; sub-secretary, board of revenue, July, 1858; secretary, board of revenue, April, 1861; secretary to government, revenue department, Jan., 1867; chief secretary to government, Nov., 1872; member of council, June, 1877; acted as governor of Madras, May to Nov., 1881; retired June, 1882.

HUDSON, William Hebard, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875, served under the government of Bengal on famine duty in Behar; from May, 1880, served in the judicial department, N.W. Provinces, as district and sessions judge, Bijnor-Budaun division, and additional (civil) judge, Moradabad.

HUGHES, E. W. M., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, April, 1871, as assistant engineer, Punjab, irrigation, and was employed on the Sirhind canal; locomotive superintendent, Dhond-Mamad state railway, May, 1879; locomotive superintendent, Indus valley railway, Feb., 1881.

HUGHES, George, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

HUGHES, Herbert Alfred, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Institute and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

HUGHES, Theodore William Hughes, A.R.S.M., F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 11th Nov., 1862; was employed chiefly in the Central Provinces, Central India, and Bengal, in connection with coal and iron deposits; 1st grade officer, April, 1883; superintended Rewah coal explorations from March, 1883; served under the public works department from Dec., 1884.

HUGHES, William Gwynne, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission as ensign, June, 1858; arrived in India, 11th Sept., 1858; was employed on military duty and in the police department Burma, till June, 1864; transferred to the Burma commission, June, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner in the Amherst district, cantonment magistrate of Rangoon, town magistrate of Akyab, superintendent of the Hill Tracts Arakan (Nov., 1871), and deputy commissioner of Tavoy (2nd grade, July, 1881).

HUGHESDON, Joseph Charles, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Sutton Valence Grammar School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in various districts of Madras from March, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877; appointed district and sessions judge, Tinnevelly, March, 1880.

HUME, Allan Octavian, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1849; arrived in India, 7th March, 1849; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Etawah, March,
1858; officiating civil and sessions judge, Bareilly, May, 1867; commissioner of customs, N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Central Provinces, July, 1867; officiating secretary to government of India, home department, 1870-71; secretary to government of India in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, June, 1871; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1879; retired 1882.

HUMPHREYS, I. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin (exhibitor and prizeman); clerk, 2nd class, 5th July, 1872; junior clerk, Feb., 1876.

HUNT, SAMUEL, Funds Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, East India House, examiner's office, 18th June, 1851; revenue department, India office, 1858; senior clerk, Aug., 1860; financial department, 1867; funds department, 1882.

HUNT, SAMUEL BRADSHAW, Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Service.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1865; arrived, 10th Dec., 1865, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon at Coimbatore and at Vizagapatanam with charge of the jail and lunatic asylum; from May, 1875, served as surgeon in the 4th, and subsequently in the 3rd district, Madras, also as medical officer of Coonoor and Kotagiri, Feb., 1881, to April, 1883; surgeon-major, March, 1877.

HUNTER, GEORGE YEATES, Surgeon-Major, M.R.C.S. (Lond.), L.S.A., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 23rd July, 1883; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1858, and served in the military department, and as civil surgeon in various stations; acting second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, acting professor of anatomy, Grant Medical College, and curator of the museum, Bombay, April-Oct., 1872; acting superintendent of lunatic asylum, Colaba, Nov.-Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Karachi, Feb., 1882; presidency surgeon, Bombay, in medical charge of jail, house of correction, Byculla Schools and Elphinstone College, May, 1884.

HUNTER, WILLIAM WILSON, C.S.I., C.I.E., B.A., and LL.D., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy and University of Glasgow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1863; superintendent of labour transport, Kooshtea, July, 1865; on deputation for compiling a history of Beerbhoom, March, 1866; officiating inspector of schools, May, 1866; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1868; compiler of 'Bengal Gazetteers,' and on deputation in home department, government of India, July, 1869; compiler of 'Gazetteers of India,' Jan., 1871; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871; director-general of statistics, government of India, Sept., 1871; on special duty to England for purpose of compiling statistical account of Bengal, and 'Imperial Gazetteer,' March, 1875, and March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1877, to Nov., 1881; director-general of gazetteers, Oct., 1877; additional member, governor-general's council, Dec., 1881, and again Dec., 1883; author of 'The Annals of Rural Bengal,' 1883; 'A Dictionary of the Non-Aryan Languages of India and High Asia,' 1866; 'Orissa, an Indian Province,' 1869; 'The Indian Mussulmans,' 1877; 'A System of Famine Warnings,' 1878; 'A Life of Lord Mayo,' 2 vols., 1874; editor of 'The Imperial Gazetteer of India,' 9 vols., 1881; 'The Statistical Account of Bengal,' 20 vols., 1876.

HURRY, ARNOLD EARDLEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at City of London School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

HUTCHINGS, F. S., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 23rd June, 1879.

HUTCHINS, PHILIP PERCEVAL (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as deputy secretary to government in the revenue department in 1862 and 1863, as secretary to board of examiners in 1863, and as judge of the court of small causes, Chittoor, Sept., 1863; private secretary to governor of Madras, Nov., 1863; registrar, high court, March, 1865; from Feb., 1869, acted as civil and sessions judge in various places, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Madura, April, 1873; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; acting secretary, revenue department, Dec., 1882; on special duty in connection with reorganization of judicial establishments, March, 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; judge of the high court, Madras, Nov., 1883; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1884.

HUTCHINSON, CHARLES WATERLOO, General, R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 9th June, 1843; joined the public works department, Nov., 1844; assistant engineer, Benares road, Jan., 1845; executive engineer, Ganges canal, 1850; superintendent, 6th division, Ganges canal, 1852; assistant to chief engineer, Lahore, Feb., 1856, superintending engineer, Lahore, July, 1859; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, Feb., 1865 to 1868; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1870; inspector-general of military works, 1871-81; also officiating deputy secretary government of India, buildings and roads, 1871-73; chief engineer, 1st class, April, 1872.

HUTCHINSON, CHARLES WEBBER, Post Office Department, Madras.—Superintendent, mail and bullock train, Indore and Goona road, May, 1860; from Feb., 1866, to Aug., 1868, served as chief inspector of public offices, Central Provinces; from Aug., 1868, to March, 1869, acted as postmaster-general first in Madras and then in Bengal; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1869, to June, 1881, from which date he served as postmaster-general in Madras.

HUTCHINSON, JAMES BIRD, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th May, 1864; from March, 1868, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Dec., 1884.

HYDE, HENRY, Major-General, R.E., Inspector-general of Railway Stores, India Office.—Arrived in India, 8th June, 1846, and from that date up to 1859 served under the military depart-
ment, and also as executive engineer in the public works department; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, N.W. Provinces, 1859; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Bengal, 1860; inspector-general of public works accounts, 1860; officiating consulting engineer and secretary in the railway department to government of Bengal, July, 1861; officiating master of the mint, 1861; mint master and head commissioner of paper currency, Jan., 1862; organized and superintended the paper currency department, 1862 to 1870; fellow of the University of Calcutta and member of the senate; president of the Asiatic Society; president of the committee for the defence of the River Hooghly by torpedoes, and government director of the bank of Bengal, 1870 to 1876; continued master of the mint till his retirement in 1876; appointed to the India Office, Jan., 1876.

HYNES, G. J., Post Office Department.—Entered the post office department, 4th May, 1868; assistant director-general of the post office of India, Oct., 1880.

IBBETSON, DENZIL CHARLES JELF, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Collegiate School, Adelaide (South Australia), and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; deputy superintendent, census, Punjab, Aug., 1881; compiler, 'Punjab Gazetteer,' March, 1883; officiating director of public instruction, March, 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1885.

ILBERT, COURTENAY PEREGRINE, C.I.E., C.S.I.—Took his seat as legal member of the council of the governor-general of India, May, 1882.

IMPEY, WILLIAM HENRY LOCKINGTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

INCH, G. F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

INGLIS, JOHN FORBES DAVID, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed junior under-secretary to the government of India, foreign department, in 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847; deputy commissioner in the Punjab, 1849; magistrate and collector of Bareilly, 1858; judge of Moradabad, 1862; commissioner of Rohilkund 1864; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, 1867; additional member of governor-general's council, 1870, and was reappointed in 1873 and 1875; temporarily finance member of governor-general's council, April to Dec., 1874; officiating chief commissioner of Oudh, March-Nov., 1875, and again in July, 1876; retired Feb., 1877.

INGLIS, THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

INNES, JAMES JOHN McLEOD, Colonel, V.C., R.E., Public Works Department, India.—First commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; served under the civil engineer, Punjab, from 1852; assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal, 1854; assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, Jan., 1857; executive engineer, Cawnpore, Dec., 1857; garrison engineer, Presidency, April, 1858; controller and examiner of accounts, Lahore, Feb., 1861; officiating accountant-general, public works department, May, 1867, to 1869; superintending engineer, Punjab, Oct., 1869; accountant-general and deputy secretary, public works department, June, 1870; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1884, and deputy inspector-general, military works; inspector-general of military works, 1882.

INNES, LEWIS CHARLES, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1844; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts till Jan., 1855, and afterwards in the judicial department, and was appointed sub-judge of Combaconum, Feb., 1856, and civil and sessions judge of Nundial, July, 1858; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, Feb., 1865, to Sept., 1883, and officiated on several occasions as chief justice; fellow of the University of Madras 1865 to 1883, and was on the syndicate, 1873-83; vice-chancellor of the university, 1874 to 1880.

IRELAND, WILLIAM DE COURCY, B.A., LL.D., Burma Commission.—Joined the service as accountant in office of commissioner of Pegu, April, 1859; assistant superintendent of forests, Toungoo, April, 1860; collector of customs, Nov., 1860; from April, 1861, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, town magistrate, and deputy commissioner (1st grade, June, 1879) on special duty, Aug., 1878; also acted as inspector-general of police, June, 1875, and March, 1881; and as commissioner of Arakan, June-Sept., 1880; boundary officer, Akyab district, Sept., 1880.

IRVINE, GEORGE DUNCAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs at Madras and protector of emigrants, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Kurnool, July, 1882, and afterwards in Trichinopoly.

IRVINE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Anne's School, Brixton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty under the board of revenue, Jan. to April, 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Ghazipur, Dec., 1881.

IRVING, L.A., Surgeon-Major, Army Medical
Department.—Medical officer on the personal staff of the governor of Bombay (Rt. Hon. D. J. M. Lord Reay, LL.D., C.I.E.), 31st March, 1885.

IRWIN, ALFRED MACDONALD BULTEEL, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab till June, 1877, and subsequently in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner.

IRWIN, GEORGE ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Uppingham and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow.

IRWIN, HENRY CROSSLY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, St. Edmund's Hall, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Jan., 1881.

ISAACSON, S. H. H., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 15th April, 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878.

ISMAY, STANLEY (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1871; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting inspector of schools, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the Kalahandi State, Jan., 1882; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, May, 1884; officiating inspector-general of police and jails, May, 1885.

IZAT, ALEXANDER, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad; executive engineer, March, 1868; transferred to railway branch, 1870, as executive engineer, Nizam's state railway; Holkar state railway, Oct., 1874; transferred to Dhoondh and Manmar railway, Bombay, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Bombay Eastern Deccan state railway, Aug., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Kathiawar state railways, 1879; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1880; services lent to Bengal and N.W. railway company, 1883.

IZON, CLARENCE BOVILL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1860, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and session judge, acting registrar, high court, and joint judge and session judge; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Feb., 1877; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Ratnagiri, Dec., 1880.

JACKSON, CHARLES JULIAN, Brigade Surgeon, Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1855; served in Bengal from Aug., 1859, as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon at various stations; also officiated as sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1872, and as medical inspector of emigrants, Calcutta, 1880, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, Feb., 1883; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail and lunatic asylum, Moorsshedabad, 1883; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; brigade surgeon, Jan., 1881.

JACKSON, SIR LOUIS S., Knight, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Castleknock, Waterford, and Enniskillen (Royal) Schools; matriculated at Trinity College, Dublin, 1839 (exhibitioner); appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1843; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; from 1847 to 1850, was employed in the Straits Settlements as under governor, Prince of Wales' Island, and officiated as superintendent of Province Wellesley, 1847-48; assistant resident and superintendent of police, Singapore, and chairman of municipal commissioners, 1848; acting collector of stamps and abkari revenue, Calcutta, 1850; magistrate of Patna, 1852; collector of Moorshedabad, 1856; civil and sessions judge, Rajshahi, 1859, and Nuddea, 1861; officiating judge of the Sudder court, May, 1862; judge of the high court, Calcutta, July, 1862 (in the English department); officiating chief justice, 1878; retired, June, 1880.

JACKSON, WILLIAM GRIERSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Manchester Grammar School and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Feb., 1877, to Jan., 1880, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, 4th grade; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1882.

JACOB, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; in charge of forest settlement and demarcation officer's office, Khandesh, Oct., 1881, to Feb., 1882; from May, 1883, acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for sardars in the Deccan.

JACOB, HERBERT BRUCE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bo.S.C., Educational Department, Central Pro-
vinces.—First commission, Dec., 1857; served from 26th June, 1869, in the educational department, Central Provinces, and was appointed inspector of schools, 3rd grade, April, 1871; acting inspector-general of education, 1882-84.

JACOB, STEPHEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating registrar in the judicial commissioner's court, and officiating deputy commissioner, till Dec., 1878, when he was transferred to Bengal; on special duty, legislative department, government of India, April, 1879; officiated as under secretary and as assistant secretary in department of finance and commerce, government of India, in 1880 and 1881; assistant comptroller-general, Nov., 1880; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1881, and in 1882; on special duty with the government of India in department of finance and commerce, Jan. and Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, June, 1882; under secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, July, 1882; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, July, 1883; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oude, Feb., 1885.

JAMES, HENRY EVAN MURCHISON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Cathedral School, Carlisle, and Durham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and as acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind; from May, 1873, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1875; also acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, from Nov., 1875; and grade, postmaster-general, Punjab, Nov., 1877; postmaster-general, Bengal, March, 1882; from Feb., 1884, acted as director-general of the post office in India.

JAMES, STEPHEN HARVEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Probus Grammar School and Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1875, and officiated as secretary, 1877; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, and officiating junior secretary, Aug., 1877; on special duty under the orders of the high court Feb., 1881, and again in 1882 and 1883; registrar, high court, May, 1881; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March, 1885.

JAQUET, ROBERT G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 11th May, 1877.

JARDINE, JOHN, Bombay C.S. (Burma).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 30th October, 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1869, to May, 1871; from May, 1871, to Oct., 1873, served in Káthiáwár as political assistant, and was in charge of the agency in Sept., Oct., and Dec., 1871; also appointed judicial assistant in Káthiáwár, June, 1873; acting registrar of the high court, Bombay, Oct., 1873; secretary to the Baroda commission for the trial of the Gáekwár, Feb.–May, 1875; acting judge and sessions judge at Ratnagiri, Tanna, and Khan-deish, Oct., 1875, to Feb., 1877; secretary to the delegates of the government of India in the negotiations for a commercial treaty with Portugal, March to Sept., 1877, also acting as deputy secretary to government of India, legislative department, April, 1877; acting secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Nov., 1877, to Jan., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served in British Burma as judicial commissioner, and also presided in court of recorder of Rangoon, Oct.–Nov., 1881; president of the educational syndicate, Sept., 1881; president of the Pougndeh reformatory committee, Nov., 1881.

JARRETT, HENRY SULLIVAN, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, Dec., 1856, 3rd European Infantry, Bengal; secretary to board of examiners, Fort William, 1871; assistant secretary, legislative department, government of India, from 1875.

JEFFERY, JOHN EDWARD BEVOR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grammar School, Worcester, and Worcester Cathedral School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in revenue and judicial departments; and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, July, 1880.

JEFFREYS, WILLIAM, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 8th June, 1854; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1856; served in the irrigation branch, N.W. Provinces, from May, 1857, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent, Western Jamna canal; also officiated as assistant principal, Roorkee College; temporarily transferred to P.W. secretariat, government of India, Nov., 1864, to April, 1865; transferred to Bengal, and specially deputed to investigate a project of irrigation and navigation for the river Gandák, Oct., 1867, to April, 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1869; officiating assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1869; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; 1st class, Jan., 1880.

JENKINS, JOHN LEWIS, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bristol Grammar School and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector, and acting city magistrate, Karáchi; 3rd assistant collector in Sind, June, 1885.

JENKINS, THOMAS LOWTEN LAYTON (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875;
arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam (in 1882) as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

JENKYNS, EDWARD S., Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 25th Feb., 1846; junior clerk, audit department, India office, Sept., 1853; accountant-general's department, 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1868.

JERVOISE, ALAN ARTHUR CLARKE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 23rd March, 1857, and served in various districts of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, political agent and collector of stamp revenue, and acting deputy commissioner of customs and opium; junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1877; senior collector and magistrate, March, 1879.

JODU NATH ROY, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 13th July, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, June, 1873; judge of the court of small causes at Kooshtea, Chooodanga, and Meherpore, May, 1883; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

JOHNSON, ALLEN B., Major-General, C.B., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; joined the service (infantry), July, 1846; appointed to 4th Sikhs as volunteer for service in Burma; in civil employ in Punjab, 1854; Indian Mutiny in 1858; brevet for Lucknow; assistant adjutant-general, 1861; assistant secretary to government of India in the military department, 1875; deputy military secretary, 1876; secretary in the military department, India Office, from 18th Jan., 1877; temporarily employed as military secretary to the government of India, 1879-1881.

JOHNSON, EDWARD RALPH, Right Rev., D.D.—Appointed Bishop of Calcutta, 14th Dec., 1876.

JOHNSON, SIR EDWIN BEAUMONT, General, K.C.B., C.I.E., R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, June, 1842; deputy judge advocate-general, Sirhind division, April, 1849; assistant adjutant-general of artillery, Jan., 1856-63; assistant military secretary, Horse Guards, 1865-72; quartermaster-general, Bengal, July, 1873; adjutant-general, March, 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1st Sept., 1874, to Feb., 1877; military member of council of governor-general of India, March, 1877-80; director-general of military education, War Office, Dec., 1884.

JOHNSON, EVANS CHARLES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Jan., 1868, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), acting sub-collector, and acting district and sessions judge; sub-collector and joint magistrate, South Arcot, Jan., 1883; from Feb., 1883, acted as principal assistant in Vizagapatam, and as collector, magistrate, and agent in the same district, and afterwards in Kurnool; acting district and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, May, 1884, to April, 1885.

JOHNSON, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

JOHNSTON, JOHN LEECH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Akalkot, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; and grade judge and sessions judge, Kanara, Jan., 1884.

JOHNSTONE, DONALD CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; transferred to Bombay, May, 1882, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

JOHNSTONE, FREDERICK JOHN, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Assam.—Served in the public works department, Central Provinces, from July, 1861, and was appointed executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; assistant to the chief engineer, Aug., 1873; officiating controller of public works accounts, April to Nov., 1875; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; promoted to superintending engineer, Nov., 1880, and posted to British Burma; transferred to Assam as superintending engineer, 2nd class, and secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department, Jan., 1884.

JOHNSTONE, HUGH, Surgeon-Major, A.M., M.D., Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical service, 30th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 2nd May, 1868, and served in Calcutta at the General Hospital and as house surgeon at the Medical College Hospital; in medical charge of the British residency, Mandalay, Upper Burma, July, 1869; civil surgeon of Akyab, March, 1877; from April, 1878, officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, and was appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, April, 1880; also port health officer and in charge of the lock hospital and meteorological observatory.

JOHNSTONE, JAMES, Colonel, C.S.I., Bengal Infantry, Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, 1838; assistant superintendent of police, 1864; in charge of Keddahs in the Gurjat Mehals of Cuttack, 1868-74; assistant commissioner in Assam, 1874; political agent, Manipur, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1884.

JOHNSTONE, JAMES WILLIAM HOPE, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1853; from March, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; officiated as commissioner and superintendent, Peshawur, in 1880 and 1883, also in the Jullundur division, Sept., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Rawal Pindi, Feb., 1881; civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, Sept., 1881; 1st grade divisional judge, Nov., 1884.

JOLLIFFE, E. W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 2nd April, 1885.

JONES - BATEMAN, HERBERT BURLTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Oct.,
1876, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Aug.–Nov., 1883.

JONES, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived, 14th March, 1859, and was appointed magistrate and collector of Dacca, May, 1860; from Sept., 1860, to March, 1875, served in the survey department, and was appointed senior superintendent of survey, April, 1873; magistrate and collector, Tipperah, Jan., 1878; 1st grade magistrate and collector, March, 1879.

JONES, SAMUEL SIMPSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fauconberge Grammar School, Beccles, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, Kandi, April, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Oct., 1884.

JONES, THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Department.—Assistant secretary, government of Bengal, 7th April, 1866; clerk and officiating 5th judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1873; registrar and chief ministerial officer of the court, June, 1882; officiated as 4th judge from March, 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, Oct., 1884.

JONES, WILLIAM BRITTAIN, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 15th Sept., 1856; from March, 1857, to April, 1865, served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and assistant commissioner; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner, acting superintendent of cotton affairs, secretary to the chief commissioner, and acting commissioner in the Jubbulpore, Nerbudda, and Nagpore divisions; on special duty as commissioner for drawing up land revenue and tenancy bills for Central Provinces, Sept., 1874; on special duty in the home department, Calcutta, Nov., 1876, also in April, 1877, and at Simla, May, 1877; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; resident, Hyderabad, June, 1882; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1st May, 1883; retired, 27th Jan., 1885.

JONES, W. R. S., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Sept., 1873, as executive engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation; transferred to the locomotive department, Rajputana state railways, April, 1879, as deputy locomotive superintendent; carriage and wagon superintendent, Ajmere, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, April, 1880.

JOPP, A. ABERCROMBIE, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and Royal Indian Military College, Addiscombe; entered the Royal Engineers, 19th Dec., 1860; retired Feb., 1879; secretary, office of agent-general for government of New South Wales, London, Feb., 1874, to March, 1879; director-general of stores, India office, April, 1879.

JOPP, CHARLES HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

JOSEPH, HUGH GORE, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate.

KAVASJEE JAMASJEE BADSHAHI, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elphinstone High School, Bombay University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, Oct., 1882.

KAYE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Bareilly, April, 1877, officiating civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, March, 1880, and commissioner of the Jhansi division, Dec., 1881; commissioner of the Agra division, July, 1885.

KEAN, HENRY FITZMAURICE JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1857; from March, 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, April, 1877.

KEEFER, WILLIAM NAPIER, Surgeon-Major, Indian Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, Bengal Medical Establishment, 1st Oct., 1869; served under the military department up to 1884, when he was appointed senior medical officer, Port Blair and the Nicobars.

KEEGAN, D. F., Surgeon-Major, M.D., Indian Medical Service.—Joined the Bengal medical service in 1866; in medical charge of 2nd regiment, Central India horse, Nov., 1868; in medical charge of Augur agency, Central India, 1874; officiating residency surgeon, Indore, 1877–78; residency surgeon, Indore, superintendent of Malwa dispensaries, and superintendent of central jail, Indore, 1881.

KEELAN, BERNARD CALLAN, Surgeon-Major, L.K. and Q.C.P., M.R.C.S., L.M.K. and Q.C.P. (Ir.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations; civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, lunatic asylum, and medical school, Hyderbad, April, 1884.

KEENE, HENRY G., C.I.E., M.R.A.S., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1847; arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1847; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent
Dehra Dün, May, 1856; magistrate and collector, April, 1860; civil and sessions judge April, 1867; officiated as commissioner of the Agra division in 1872 and 1875, and of the Allahabad division in 1874; retired 1883; fellow of the Calcutta University; member of committee of the Muhamadan College of Aligurh; medal from the zoological society; medal and diploma from the Austrian Exhibition of 1863; author of 'Indian Administration,' 1867; 'History of Hindustan,' 1885; and numerous contributions to the periodical press.

KEEES, JAMES, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., M.R.C.P.L., Madras Medical Department.—Served in the subordinate medical department as warrant officer from 11th Sept., 1848, to May, 1855; assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived 11th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department up to May, 1862, and subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of district jail, Kurnool, and was placed on special duty experimenting on alkaloids in Gudalur and Wynnaad, June, 1866; fort surgeon, Madras, and professor of anatomy in the Medical College, April, 1867; medical inspector of seamen, Aug., 1868; acting principal medical storekeeper and inspector of emigrants, May, 1869; acting health officer and superintendent, lock hospital, Madras, April, 1880; fellow of Madras University, May, 1882; principal and professor of medicine in the Medical College, and senior physician, General Hospital, Aug., 1883.

KEITH, STANLEY, Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Lancing College; writer, India Office, 6th June, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, April, 1879; attached to financial department.

KEITH, THOMAS W., Accountant-General, India Office.—Educated at Cholmeley School, Highgate; East India House writer, old establishment, 20th Aug., 1845; junior clerk, Treasury, 1848; senior clerk, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; accountant, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax, 1872; accountant-general, Feb., 1879.

KELLAKKA COVILAGOM MANAVEDAN RAJA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 4th June, 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1882.

KELLEHER, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the Catholic University of Ireland; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1866; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1882; transferred to Assam as district and sessions judge of Sylhet, March, 1884.

KELLEY, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India Office, 9th Oct., 1879.
