KELLNER, EDWIN WELSH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department as assistant comptroller-general, 29th April, 1870; acted as deputy accountant-general, and, for a short period, as accountant-general, Bengal, 1874-76; officiating deputy comptroller-general, Jan., 1877; confirmed as deputy accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1877; officiating assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Oct., 1878; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, April, 1879.

KELLY, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, June, 1868; also served as assistant-superintendent of survey, 1863-64, and officiating inspector of schools, 1869; appointed small cause judge, Bhagulpore, Jan., 1876, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1879.

KELSALL, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; from March, 1865, to Jan., 1867, served as probationary assistant-superintendent of police, and subsequently, in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled the Bellary 'District Manual'; appointed district and sessions judge, Aug., 1880, in the Godavari district, and afterwards in South Malabar and Vizagapatam.

KEMBALL, CHARLES GURDON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1850; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, judicial assistant commissioner (in Sind), and deputy magistrate; collector and magistrate, Karachi, Nov., 1861; served as judge and sessions judge, Surat, from Jan., 1866, to June, 1870, and from the latter date acted as judge of the high court, Bombay, in which appointment he was confirmed in Aug., 1871; acted as member of council, Bombay, in 1880, and again in 1881; retired in 1885.

KEMBLE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 8th April, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Oct., 1873; inspector-general of jails, July, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; officiating opium agent, Benares, April, 1881; opium agent, Behar, May, 1884.

KEMP, FRANCIS BARING, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at foreign schools and at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 1831; served in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Bengal; collector, Tirhoot, 1851; civil and sessions judge, Backergunge and Jessore, 1855 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1862 to 1878; retired, 1878.

KENNEDY, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade,
KENNEDY, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty, Madras, July, 1878; transferred to Assam, Nov., 1883, as assistant commissioner, 1st class.

KENNEDY, Sir MICHAEL KAVANAGH, General, K.C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th June, 1841; arrived in India, Nov., 1842; assistant engineer, roads and tanks, June, 1843; executive engineer at Surat, Aden, and Satara, 1848-50; on special duty, Ceylon, Madras, and Calcutta, Oct., 1860, to April, 1861; superintending engineer, southern division, April, 1862; secretary to government of Bombay, public works and railway departments, July, 1863; resigned the public works department in 1880; controller-general of supply, Kabul expedition; additional secretary to government of India for supply and transport, 1880.

KENNEDY, ROBERT MUIRHEAD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1877; and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate.

KENNEDY, THOMAS JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, Balliol College, Oxford, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1880, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on deputation in the settlement department, 27th Nov., 1883.

KENSINGTON, ALFRED, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Marlborough and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; on special duty in civil secretariat, Oct., 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1882; settlement officer, in charge of Northern Umballa settlement, April, 1884.

KERNAN, JAMES, M.A., Q.C., Judicial Department, Madras.—Judge of the high court, Madras, 3rd May, 1870; fellow of the Madras University, Feb., 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, June, 1885; officiating chief justice, July, 1885.

KERR, T. COULTER, Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Surveyor of shipping, 1st April, 1881.

KETTLEWELL, G., B.A., Inspecting Veterinary Surgeon, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1854; served under the military department till Dec., 1881, when he was appointed principal, Veterinary School, Lahore.

KEYS, ARTHUR INNES, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed clerk, London office, 1880.

KEYSER, ALFRED, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School and Royal Academy, Gosport; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant-collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Surat, Dec., 1884.

KHARSEDJI MANEKJI, KHAN BAHADUR, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th May, 1874, as judge of the court of small causes, Ahmednagar, and subsequently at Ahmedabad (Sept., 1879).

KHARSEDJI RATANJI BAMANJI, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882; confirmed as member of the Bombay Civil Service, Jan., 1885.

KIERNANDER, CHARLES ROBERT CAMPBELL, Financial Department, Government of India.—Assistant accountant-general, British Burma, 5th Aug., 1864; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, April, 1870; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1870; from Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1876, served as deputy accountant-general in the Punjab, and subsequently in Bombay, N.W. Provinces, British Burma, and Bengal; officiated as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1878 and 1879; inspector of local offices of account, Oct., 1878; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, Nov., 1884.

KILBY, G. C. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Service.—Deputy superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 28th Feb., 1876.

KILBY, SANDFORD JAMES, Bengal Preventive Service.—Assistant collector of customs, Chittagong, 30th June, 1865; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1866; from Aug., 1868, to Dec., 1876, served in the police department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 1st grade, May, 1874; on famine relief duty, Dec., 1873, and March, 1876; on special duty in Chumparum, April, 1874; from Dec., 1876, served in the customs preventive service, and was appointed superintendent, Jan., 1877; also in charge of the Sulkea salt golas, April, 1880.

KINCAIRD, WILLIAM, Colonel, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Indian Army, March, 1849; magistrate, Nowgong, 1867; assistant political agent in Bundelkund, 1869; second in command, Malwa Bhel corps, Nov., 1870; political agent, Bhopawur, 1877; political agent, Bhopal, 1882.

KINDERSLEY, JOHN ROBERT, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1847; served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector till 1857, when he was appointed assistant judge of Mangalore; subordinate judge, Bellary, 1859; civil and sessions judge, Rajahmundry, March, 1865; and subsequently at Bellary; officiating judicial commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1866, and again 1868; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, June, 1877; retired in 1884.

KING, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; house surgeon, Medical College Hospital, from 9th May to 25th Aug., 1866, when his services were placed at disposal of government of India, military department; superintendent of Royal Botanical Gardens and ex-officio professor of botany in Calcutta Medical College, and ex-
officio superintendent of cinchona plantation in British Sikkhim, from July, 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; also officiating quinologist, Dec., 1879.

KING, JOSHUA, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 26th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate and acting assistant judge and session judge; in charge of the small cause court, Ahmedabad, April-May, 1864; acting under secretary to Government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1866; acting collector and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bombay, July, 1869, to Jan., 1870; Talukdari settlement officer, Dec., 1874, to Feb., 1876, and again, Feb., 1876, to Nov., 1877, for carrying Bombay Act VI of 1862 into effect, and manager under Act XV of 1871; on special duty, Baroda, Nov., 1877, to June, 1879; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, May, 1879; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, May, 1884.

KING, LUCAS BLACKER BURNET, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 11th Oct., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue, survey, and judicial departments, and was appointed superintendent of survey, Aug., 1866, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1880.

KING, LUCAS WHITE, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Ennis College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Sept., 1882; deputed to settlement department, Dec., 1882.

KING, WILLIAM, D.Sc., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined the service, 4th March, 1857; served in various districts of the Madras presidency, and was appointed deputy superintendent for Madras, Nov., 1868; served subsequently in the Godavari district and the Nizam's territories, and discovered the Singareni coalfield, 1871-72; deputed to Vienna in joint charge of the survey collections at the Exhibition, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1875; fellow of the Madras University and member of the Faculty of Engineering, 1884; officiated as superintendent of the geological survey, May-Nov., 1884.

KIPLING, JOHN LOCKWOOD, Education Department, Punjab.—Joined the government service as architectural sculptor, Bombay, May, 1865; from April, 1875, served in the Punjab as principal of Mayo School of Industrial Art, and curator, Lahore Museum.

KIRKHAM, T. B., Barrister-at-Law, Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational department, 1st Jan., 1862; arrived in India, 21st June, 1862, and served as headmaster of the Poona High School, principal of the Elphinstone High School, Bombay, and professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College; was also a member of the first municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug., 1873; from April, 1878, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, April, 1885.

KIRKWOOD, TOWNSEND MOLLOY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 2nd Dec., 1863; from Feb., 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1876, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1880; served temporarily under the public works department, Oct., 1869, to Oct., 1872, and was employed on famine duty, Bhagulpore, March, 1874.

KISCH, HERMANN MICHAEL, M.A. (Barrister-at Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Nov., 1873; on famine duty, Patna, March, 1874, and at Bellary, Feb., 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, May, 1878; under secretary, judicial and political departments, Jan., 1880; on deputation as under secretary in the financial department, Nov., 1883; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Dec., 1883; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, Feb., 1884.

KITTS, EUSTACE JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Berar, Aug., 1875, and served as assistant commissioner and also as small cause court judge of Akola; on special (famine) duty, Madura, 1877-78; assistant commissioner, Ajmir, May, 1883; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, N.W. Provinces, May, 1885.

KNIGHT, RAYMONT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's College, Stoney Stratford, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector, April, 1885.

KNOX, GEORGE EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from June, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from March, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed small cause court judge, Allahabad, Aug., 1877; judge, 3rd grade, March, 1884; officiating legal remembrancer, Feb., 1885.

KNOX, GEORGE, Punjab Administration.—Assistant engineer, May, 1854; from June, 1856, served in the Punjab commission, and was appointed personal assistant to commissioner of Jullundur, April, 1864, assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1864, and deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1877; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Rawul Pindi, Nov., 1878, to April, 1879.
KNOX, Hubert Thomas, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, acting principal assistant, joint sessions judge for trying Rumpa cases, and assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); acted as district and sessions judge, Ganjam, April–Sept., 1884, and afterwards in North Arcot; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Malabar, Oct., 1884.

KNYVETT, William Leycester Nathaniel, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th June, 1854; served in the Bengal police department from June, 1863, as district superintendent (1st grade, April, 1875); officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, July, 1875; deputy inspector-general, April, 1885.

KOUGH, Charles, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1867, and served in various districts of Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, head assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; forest settlement officer, March, 1884; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate in the districts of Madura, Cuddapah, and North Arcot.

KRISHNA CHUNDER CHATTERJEE, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 19th Dec., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, May, 1877; small cause court judge, Backergunge, Dec., 1877; subordinate judge, 1st grade, 24 Pergunnahs, May, 1884.

KRISHNA MOHUN MOOKERJI, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, from 28th March, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, Chittagong, Dec., 1884.

KUNWAR BHARAT SINGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

KUNWAR SHIAM SINGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 12th Jan., 1881.

KUNWAR JWÁLA PRASÁD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1884; probationary assistant magistrate, Allahabad.

LAFFAN, Edward Sidney, Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimbledon School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, 1877–78; from June, 1882, served in the Madras secretariat as acting secretary in the revenue department, acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department (June, 1884, and April, 1885), assistant secretary in judicial and legislative departments (July, 1884), and under secretary in revenue department (Jan., 1885); on special duty, preparing Madras administration report, Nov., 1882; acting Canarese translator to government, April, 1885.

LAIDMAN, George John, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Liverpool Collegiate Institution and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and officiating magistrate and collector; small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Nov., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1883.

LAING, James Anderson, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1870, and served in the Madras medical department as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acting resident surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; deputy sanitary commissioner and inspector of vaccination, Feb., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882.

LAKSHMAN GOPAL DESHMUKH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, 16th April, 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

LAMB, Richard Amphlett, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Khandesh, March, 1885.

LAMBE, William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1881; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Jan., 1883.

LAMBERT, John, C.I.E., Police Department, Bengal.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1863, as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and officiating personal assistant to the inspector-general; on special duty, March, 1872; visitor of the presidency jail, and of the lunatic asylums, July, 1872; deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, Feb., 1874; served under the government of India, foreign department, from March, 1882, to March, 1884, as officiating political resident, 2nd class, and general superintendent of the operations for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity.

LAMBERT, Parry, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1857; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, 8th Jan., 1858, and served in Oudh, and the Punjab; executive engineer, Dec., 1863; officiating controller of Punjab northern state railway accounts, Sept., 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, May, 1876; examiner, 3rd class, Oct., 1878; transferred to the office of examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1879; transferred to Bombay, as officiating examiner, public works accounts, Dec., 1879; from Dec., 1881,
served in the N.W. Provinces as examiner, public works accounts, and officiated in Bengal, Feb.-Dec., 1882; examiner, 2nd class, Feb., 1884; transferred to Bombay, May, 1884.

LANE, CLAYTON TURNER, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Ensign Bengal army, 11th Dec., 1858; from March, 1863, served in the Punjab as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent of police; transferred to Berar police, Sept., 1865; inspector-general of police and jails, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; is also inspector-general of registration and stamps, and registrar of joint stock companies.

LANE, J. H., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Feb., 1857; superintendent, 1st grade, Bombay, Aug., 1870; officiating deputy director-general, March, 1872; director of traffic, Feb., 1879.

LANE, J. M., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 22nd Sept., 1862; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Bengal, Oct., 1869; served subsequently in the Malabar Coast and Nagpur divisions; 1st grade superintendent, British Burma, Sept., 1883, and afterwards in Bombay.

LANE, WILLIAM MOORE, Colonel, M.S.C., Postal Department, Punjab.—Ensign in the Madras Army, 20th Jan., 1851; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1851; from July, 1856, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab, March, 1866; postmaster-general, Punjab, Feb., 1869; officiating director-general, post office of India, Nov., 1879, to Feb., 1880.

LANE, WILMOT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 13th January, 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Aug., 1863 to March, 1866, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Moradabad, Aug., 1877; commissioner, Rae Bareli Division, Sept., 1880, and subsequently of the Agra and Meerut divisions; officiating member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1883.

LANG, ARTHUR MOFFATT, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Burma.—Arrived in India, July, 1854; assistant engineer, Punjab, Nov., 1855; superintendent, civil buildings, Lahore, Aug., 1856; executive engineer, March, 1857; assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, April, 1858; assistant secretary, public works department, to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1865; principal, Thomason Engineering College, March, 1871, to May, 1877; superintending engineer, 1st grade, deputy inspector-general military works, and secretary, defence committee, Feb., 1879; secretary to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, public works department, Feb., 1881; chief engineer, 3rd class, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, public works department, Jan., 1883.

LANG, GEORGE LUKIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, March, 1858; from Nov., 1858, to Nov., 1866, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; from Nov., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Aligarh, April, 1877; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1880; officiating commissioner, Agra Division, Aug., 1882.

LANG, RICHARD TICKELL MONTGOMERY, Major, Gen. List, B.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1859; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, Mooltan, April, 1877; officiating additional civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, April-Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, March, 1881, and subsequently in the Rawalpindi Division; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Jan., 1882.

LANGLEY, EDWARD HARTLEY RAYNSFORD, Brigade-Surgeon, B.A. (Dub.), M.R.C.S. (Lon.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1858; and served in the military department, and as acting civil surgeon in various stations; appointed presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay, Oct., 1876; also in medical charge of the European General Hospital, May-June, 1882; brigade-surgeon, March, 1885.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 2nd Aug., 1873.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM REA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 28th Dec., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; officiating commissioner, Orissa division, and superintendent of Tributary Mehals, Cuttack, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Dacca, April, 1885.

LARPENT, FREDERIC DE HOCHFIED, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 19th Feb., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant accountant-general, officiating deputy accountant-general, and assistant comptroller-general; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nov., 1875; served in Madras, Nov., 1876, to April, 1878, as assistant accountant-general; officiating deputy accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1878; examiner of local accounts in Bengal, March, 1880; assistant accountant-general, Punjab, in 4th class of financial department, Nov., 1884.

LATHAM, F. L., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Service, Bombay.—Served as acting remembrancer of legal affairs, 23rd May, 1872, to 1st Jan., 1873; also acted as advocate-general, and as judge of the high court, Bombay, for various periods between 1st Jan., 1880, and 5th March, 1884; advocate-general, Bombay, 6th March, 1884.

LA TOUCHE, CECIL D'URBAN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Ensign, 20th July, 1850; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1850, and served on military duty up to Nov., 1883, and subsequently as cantonment magistrate, Poona.
LA TOUCHE, H. C. D., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab northern state railway; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; engineer-in-chief Sindia state railway, construction division, Nov., 1879; Bundelkund railway surveys, 1881; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Feb., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Jhansi-Manikpur state railway, Sept., 1883.

LATTOUCHE, JAMES JOHN DIGGES, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, till Dec., 1871, when he was transferred as settlement officer to Ajmir; also served as officiating assistant commissioner of Bewar and officiating deputy commissioner, Ajmir; returned to N.W. Provinces, 1875, and was appointed district superintendent of police, 1st grade, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1875; served subsequently in various districts in officiating appointments as settlement officer, magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge, and was promoted to joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1882; settlement officer, 1st grade, Gorakhpur, Nov., 1883.

LATTOUCHE, WILLIAM PAGET, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Salt Department, Bombay.—1st commission, Bombay army, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1855; was employed on military duty till June, 1867, and was also appointed assistant magistrate, Dec., 1859, and assistant district superintendent of police, Jan., 1865; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, June-Nov., 1867; from Dec., 1867, served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent (1st grade, May, 1882), and also acted as superintendent of the Bombay, Baroda, and C. I. railway company's police, Nov., 1868, to Nov., 1869; on special duty, June, 1879, to Feb., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as deputy collector of salt revenue.

LAUGHTON, DANIEL WILSON, Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission in the army, Jan., 1854; arrived in Madras, April, 1854; from Jan., 1865, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate; acted as inspector-general of registration, Jan., 1873; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Feb., 1885.

LAURIE, LEWIS KOSSUTH, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting district superintendent of police; acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1880, to March, 1883, and as small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1881 and 1882; acting assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1883; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, July-Oct., 1883, and again, March, 1885; acting director of agriculture, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept.-Oct., 1884.

LAW, VICTOR EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, April, 1859; in civil employ from 1872; served in Rajputana as superintendent of railway police; officiating political agent, Jeypoor, 1877, and afterwards in Ulwar, 1877-1882; officiating political agent, Charkhari, 1883; appointed to the political charge of ex-Amir Muhammad Yakub Khan of Kabul, 1884; graded as political agent, 3rd class.

LAWRENCE, ALEXANDER JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1856; served from March, 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1864, served in the Central Provinces as settlement officer of Bhandara; re-attached to N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1869, and served as settlement officer and officiating magistrate and collector; member of the commission under the military department on the Lawrence asylums, June, 1872; on special duty with the Government of India, home department, Dec., 1872; officiating civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, June, 1874; magistrate and collector, Etawah, Oct., 1874; officiating commissioner, Agra division, May, 1877; commissioner of the Allahabad division, April, 1885.

LAWRENCE, EDWARD, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant to the political resident at Aden, March, 1882, and forest settlement officer; acting under secretary to Government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, April, 1882.

LAWRENCE, HENRY JOHN, Major, Gen. List B.I., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th February, 1862; from Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884, Amritsar.

LAWRENCE, WALTER ROPER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 5th December, 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Sept., 1881, served in Ajmere and Merwara as officiating political assistant and assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; in charge Ajmere treasury and office of registrar of assurances, May, 1882; under-secretary to government, Punjab, Feb., 1885.

LEARY, A.S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the Moravian Colleges of Fulneck in Yorkshire and Neuwind on the Rhine; temporary clerk, India Office, 15th Nov., 1860; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

LE BRETON, WILLIAM INGLIS, Major, Bombay S.C., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined the royal artillery, Dec., 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; joined the public works department, Nov., 1866, and served as assistant engineer in the Bombay presidency till Nov., 1869, and subsequently as assistant controller and deputy controller of accounts in the Punjab, N.W. Provinces, and Bombay; controller,
3rd class, and examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, Sept., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; from Dec., 1879, served as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, and was promoted to 3rd class, Jan., 1882; also officiated as examiner of public works accounts, Sept.-Dec., 1883, and port storekeeper, state railways, March-June, 1884.

LEE, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Yarmouth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1876.

LEE, J., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Caius School, Cambridge; writer, India Office, 24th Aug., 1868; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

LEEDS, ROBERT JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, 3rd grade.

LEE-WARNER, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from April, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting cantonment magistrate; on special duty, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot and Salem, Jan., 1868; boundary arbitrator between the Kalastri Zemindari and Madras district, Sept., 1868; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1882; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, Dec., 1884.

LEE-WARNER, WILLIAM, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th November, 1869; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1870; officiating director of public instruction, Berar, Feb., 1872; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May-Nov., 1872, and Jan.-Dec., 1876; on special duty in the secretariat, Nov., 1874; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and acting secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, Nov., 1874; from Dec., 1876, to Aug., 1878, served in Sind as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, acting educational inspector, and acting commissioner; acting junior collector and magistrate, Satara, March, 1881; on special duty as member of the education commission, Calcutta, Feb., 1882; on special duty at the Nira canal, April, 1882; from Jan.-Oct., 1884, acted as junior under secretary to government of India, foreign department, and as private secretary to the president in council of the governor-general (Jan.-Feb.), and was on special duty in the foreign department, March-June, 1884; acting press commissioner, Sept., 1884; acting under secretary to government of India, foreign department, Oct., 1884; from March, 1885, served under the government of Bombay as first assistant collector and acting director of public instruction.

LE FANU, WILLIAM JOSEPH HENRY, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School, Tipperary Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; served in Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Salem district manual.

LEGEYT, PHILIP HARRISON, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 27th March, 1851, and served in the military department till May, 1863, also officiating as assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha (April, 1858); from May, 1863, served in the political department as assistant political agent, Káthiáwar and Cutch, and magistrate of the district of Bhávnagar; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Oct., 1874; political superintendent, Palanpur, Sept., 1880; 1st grade, political agent, Feb., 1885.

LEGGÄTT, EDWARD OWEN EVERY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; attached to the N.W. Provinces.

LEITNER, GOTTLIEB WILLIAM, Dr., M.A., Ph.D., LL.D., D.C.L., Barrister-at-Law, Education Department, Punjab.—Served in education department as principal of the Lahore College from 12th Nov., 1864, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, Nov., 1880; in July, 1867, was deputed to Kashmir for a philological examination of the Kashmiri and Chilasi dialects; on special duty in connection with the school text-book committee at Simla, May, 1877; attended the congress of Orientalists at Florence, Oct., 1878; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, July, 1879; on special duty with education commission, May, 1882.

LELY, FREDERIC STYLES PHILPIN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th December, 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting city survey and inquiry officer at Ahmedabad, acting Talukdari settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; in charge of the Sadim state, Oct., 1881; first assistant collector, Surat, Dec., 1884.

LEMAN, GEORGE DOWNTON, Madras C.S., appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from Feb., 1859, and was appointed principal assistant to the collector and magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Dec., 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Gunturo, July, 1867, and afterwards at Tellicherry; acted as collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, in 1868, and again in 1875 and 1881-82, and as Inam commiss-
sioner in 1869; from Feb., 1872, to Nov., 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Kistna, and subsequently in Ganjam and Coimbatore.

LE MESSURIER, AUGUSTUS, Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Mysore.—Lieutenant, Bombay engineers, Dec., 1856; joined the public works department, June, 1860, and served under the superintendent of harbour defences, Bombay, to 1863; served subsequently as assistant to the garrison engineer, Bombay; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Nagpur, 1869; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Kurrachee, March, 1872; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, May, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Mysore state railway, and joint secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, 1st class (supernumerary), Jan., 1883, acting as consulting engineer to the Mysore government.

LE MESURIER, JOHN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; second lieutenant, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1855; served in the public works department in Sind from June, 1856, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Nara works and the Rohri canal, Hyderabad; on special duty, Karachi, Jan., 1867; acting superintending engineer for irrigation in Sind, April, 1871, to Dec., 1873, and for various periods between 1875 and 1880; superintendent of works, Western Indus, Karachi, Dec., 1873; superintending engineer, Jan., 1879; officiating chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, June-Aug., 1883; (temporary) chief engineer, 3rd class, and chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, public works department (irrigation), March, 1884; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1884.

LETHBRIDGE, ALFRED SWAINE, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1867; served from March, 1872, as superintendent of central jail and officiating civil surgeon, Bhagulpore; officiating inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner, and superintendent of vaccination, British Burma, July, 1876; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, May, 1877; inspector-general of jails, Bengal, Jan., 1878; rank of surgeon-major, Sept., 1879.

LETHHEREN, S. K., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877.

LEUPOLT, JOHN CUNNINGHAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Aug., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Allahabad, Oct., 1882.

LEWIS, E. M.—Superintendent, Bengal secretariat press, April, 1869; superintendent of government printing, Bengal, Sept., 1877.

LIDDERDALE, ROBERT, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; superintendent of vaccination, 8th November, 1869; in medical charge, Julipigoree, June, 1872; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, April, 1880; professor of hygiene, Medical College; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; deputy surgeon-general, Bengal, March, 1884.

LILLINGSTON, EDWARD GORDON, Major, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 30th Aug., 1859; from 5th Feb., 1864, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1867, officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1874, superintendent of the central jail and the European penitentiary at Hazaribagh, May, 1875, and deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1879.

LIMOND, DAVID, Colonel, C.B., R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1850; assistant engineer, public works department, Bengal, Feb., 1853; executive engineer, Cawnpore, 1858; officiating superintending engineer, Allahabad, April, 1867, and in Bengal, western circle, from March, 1868; transferred to Rawal Pindee, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, military works, Rawal Pindee, April, 1872; chief engineer, 3rd class, military works, April, 1887; chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, 1882.

LINCOLN, FREDERICK, Judicial Department, North-Western Provinces.—From Oct., 1846, to March, 1860, served in various capacities in the offices of the commissioner of the cis-Sutlej states, the Punjab board of administration, the judicial commissioners of the Punjab and Oudh, and the secretariat at Allahabad; appointed, for special services during siege of Lucknow, extra assistant commissioner in Oudh, March, 1860; assistant civil judge, Lucknow, Jan., 1861; small cause court judge, Lucknow, March, 1866; civil judge, Lucknow, Aug., 1869; district judge, 3rd grade, Sitapur, Aug., 1879.

LINDSAY, CHARLES ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Woolwich and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1844; arrived in India, 1845; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Farakhabad, 1858; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, 1862; extra judge of the Sudder court, Agra, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Mynpoorie, 1865, and subsequently of Goruckpore and Moradabad; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1869; retired, 1880.

LINDSAY, JAMES GAVIN, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department.—Lieutenant, Madras engineers, Aug., 1855; joined the Madras public works department as assistant engineer, Dec., 1857; assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, 1861; acting deputy consulting engineer for railways, Madras, Dec., 1867; executive engineer, 1st grade, railway survey, Mysore, April, 1870; officiating superintending engineer, and engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal railway, 1872; engineer-in-chief, Sukkur-Quettah railway, Sept., 1879; superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1881; engineer-in-chief, southern Mahratta railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class (supernumerary), April, 1881; services lent to South Mahratta Railway Company.

LINDSAY, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; junior clerk, India Office, 31st Jan., 1867; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1877-81; senior clerk, Jan., 1882.

LINGHAM, ALFRED FRASER, Judicial Department, Burma.—Solicitor, supreme court, Cal-
cutta, March, 1854; small cause court judge, first at Magurah and then at Jhenida, 1860-61; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, Nov., 1868; advocate, high court, Calcutta, Feb., 1869; first judge of court of small causes, Rangoon, April, 1876.

LISTER, ALLEN LINDSAY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in the grades of assistant and sub-collector, and was placed on special duty in connection with the relief of the poorer classes, South Arcot, Jan., 1868; on famine duty, Sept. to Dec., 1877; on special duty, Irrigation and Canal Company, Jan., 1878; collector and magistrate, South Canara, July, 1882; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1882, in Vizagapatam, and afterwards in the Godavari district.

LISTON, JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 29th May, 1856; from Aug., 1863, served in Jhansi and Kumaon as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Lalitpur, Dec., 1879; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, Aug. to Nov., 1882.

LITTLE, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.C., L.R.C.S., L.M., Madras Medical Service.—Arrived in Madras, 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department; civil surgeon, Akola, Jan., 1877; sanitary commissioner, inspector-general of dispensaries, superintendent of vaccination, and administrative medical officer of the Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884.

LITTLE, F. A., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acted as government solicitor and public prosecutor, Bombay, Oct.-Nov., 1879, and May to Nov., 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1884.

LIVESAY, JOHN JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, and grade, Oct., 1878; employed on famine relief duty, March to Oct., 1874.

LOYD, ERNEST THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Shrewsbury, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, and Feb., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1832.

LOYD, FRANCIS, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the College School, Gloucester; appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and session judge; judicial assistant to magistrate, Satara, 1860; judge and session judge, Dharwar, 1861; judge and session judge, Poona, and agent for sirdars in the Deccan, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1869; retired in 1873.

LOYD, R. A., B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served in the education department, from 1st March, 1864, as professor and officiating principal, Agra College; inspector of schools, Agra circle, Oct., 1867; 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1870; officiating principal, Bareilly College, July, 1875; inspector, Benares division, Oct., 1876, and in the Oudh division, 1877 to 1879; re-appointed to the Agra division, May, 1881.

LOCH, JAMES HENRY, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; served under the military department till Aug., 1859, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in various stations, and superintendent of jail, and held medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp in 1869-70, and again, 1872 and 1873; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1884.

LOCH, WILLIAM, Captain, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, March, 1866; served in the 14th Foot; joined the Bombay staff corps, May, 1868, and served subsequently in the Sind horse; officiating assistant to general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, 1878; 2nd assistant to governor-general's agent, Indore, 1879; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, 1880; assistant resident, Western Rajputana, and boundary settlement officer in Marwar, 1882; graded as additional political agent, 3rd class.

LOCH, WILLIE WALKER, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting principal of the Raja's school, and tutor; and governor of the Gaekwär, Baroda, April-Nov., 1880; first assistant collector and railway magistrate, Thana, Oct., 1882.

LOGAN, ALEXANDER COCHRANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

LOGAN, ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, and University College, London; matriculated at the London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1866; served in the Central Provinces from 1869 to 1881, in the grade of assistant commissioner, and officiated as district superintendent of police, March, 1872; inspector of schools, Dec., 1873, to March, 1874, and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, April, 1874, to Dec., 1876; from April to Nov., 1881, served in the financial department in Bengal as officiating deputy accountant-general and officiating accountant-general; appointed assistant comptroller-general in Class III of the financial department, Sept., 1881; acted as under secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, from Nov., 1881, and was confirmed in this appointment, July, 1883; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Aug.-Oct., 1883, and as deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1884;
deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, March, 1885.

LOGAN, WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at Musselburgh Grammar School and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from Aug., 1863, and was appointed acting district and sessions judge, June, 1873, and collector and magistrate of Malabar, March, 1876; on special duty, Feb., 1881, as commissioner for inquiring into certain important matters in the Moplah districts; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1881; member of Forest Draft Bill Committee, March, 1882; acting member, board of revenue, Nov., 1882; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, May, 1883; on special duty at Madras in connection with Report on Land Tenures of Malabar, Feb., 1884, and again in connection with the Attipadi Valley suit, July, 1884.

LORD, WALTER FREWEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

LOVETT, SACKVILLE HALTON HARRINGTON VERNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sherborne and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LOWIS, EDMOND ELLIOT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1861; deputy commissioner, Western Doors, Oct., 1867; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Oct., 1867; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Aug., 1868; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1872; commissioner, Chittagong division, March, 1875; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1879; officiating opium agent, Behar, Jan. to Nov., 1879.

LOWNDES, THOMAS, Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Burma.—Joined the Madras army, and arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1854; served in the Burma police department from March, 1861, as superintendent; on special mission to Chiengme, March–May, 1871; political agent, Bamo, May, 1872, to Oct., 1873; 1st grade, superintendent, May, 1875; inspector-general of police, British Burma, Jan., 1876.

LUARD, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1857; deputy superintendent, Western Junna canal, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1859; assistant principal, Thomason College, 1864; assistant secretary, government of India, public works department, officiating as deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, March, 1865; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bengal, Oct., 1867; officiating under secretary, government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873, to 1875; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1874; officiating mint master, Calcutta, 1876; officiating consulting engineer, Lucknow, 1877; chief engineer, 3rd class, July, 1884; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1884.

LUCAS, ARTHUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884.

LUDLAM, JOSEPH T., Registry Department, India Office.—Served under the India Board from 1838; registrar at India Board, 1859, and continued in charge of the records till 1867, when he was transferred to the registry department, India Office, as extra assistant to registrar.

LUFKIN, GEORGE, India Office.—Clerk to the clerk of the works, India office, 21st June, 1860; clerk of the works, Aug., 1874; surveyor and clerk of the works, April, 1882.

LUGARD, HENRY IBBETSON, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1853; assistant superintendent of police, Nellore, June, 1860; from Jan., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry, Jubbulpore, May to Sept., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, April, 1882.

LUMSDEN, JOHN JAMES FOOTE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, July, 1874; on special duty to Naini Tal, July, 1875; commissioner, Fyzabad division, Dec., 1879, and subsequently of the Benares division.

LUMSDEN, SIR PETER S., Major-General, G.C.B., C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal army, Dec., 1847; assistant executive engineer, 1849; deputy assistant quartermaster-general, April, 1853; assistant political agent, Afghanistan, Jan., 1857, to June, 1858; assistant quartermaster-general, Sept., 1858; deputy quartermaster-general, April, 1863; quartermaster-general, May, 1868; officiating resident, Hyderabad, 1872; adjutant-general, Sept., 1874; chief of the staff, 1879; member of council of secretary of state for India, Dec., 1883; Afghan boundary commissioner, 1884.

LUSHINGTON, EDWARD HARBORD, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1841; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate of Chittagong in 1847, and afterwards of Patna; deputy collector of government sea customs, Calcutta, 1855; collector, Nuddea, 1856; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, 1857; acting commissioner of the Burdwan, Manbboom, and Singbhoom district, 1857–58; Mutiny medal; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Nuddea, 1861; secretary to government of Bengal, 1861; secretary to government of India in the financial department, government director of bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1863; retired, 1871.

LUSON, HEWLING, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Edu-
cated at St. Olave's, Southwark, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Nuddea, Jan., 1885.

**LUTTMAN-JOHNSON, HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Assam).**—Educated at Winchester and Christchurch, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1872; acting under secretary, government of Bengal, department of scarcity and relief, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1874; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1874, as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, and secretary to chief commissioner; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, July, 1879.

**LYALL, SIR ALFRED COMYNS, K.C.B., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).**—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Central Provinces, April, 1864, and served as deputy commissioner, officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating commissioner of the Nagpur division; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1867, and appointed commissioner, West Berrar, Aug., 1867; secretary to the government of India, home department, March, 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and chief commissioner of Ajmere; on special duty in England, Aug., 1876; secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1878; on special political duty in Kabul, March, 1880, and again in Sept., 1880; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, 17th April, 1882.

**LYALL, CHARLES JAMES, M.A., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Assam).**—Educated at King's College School, King's College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiated at various times as under secretary to government, and as junior secretary, Oct., 1872; assistant under secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1872; from April, 1873, served under the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed under secretary to government, Sept., 1873, and again, July, 1879, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1878; transferred to Assam as officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1880; officiating judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, Jan. to May, 1883; secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1883.

**LYALL, DAVID ROBERT, Bengal C.S.**—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating commissioner, Dacca division, March, 1878, and Presidency division, Feb., 1882; inspector-general of police, March, 1883.

**LYALL, JAMES BROADWOOD, Bengal C.S.**—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and deputy commissioner; settlement commissioner, Mooltan and Derajat, 1875; financial commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1883; also judicial commissioner of Coorg; graded in the political department as resident, 1st class.

**LYNCH, SIDNEY S., Medical Department (Uncovd.), Bengal.**—From 16th Nov., 1858, served in Assam as civil medical officer, and inspector of landing of native labourers, and from Jan., 1866, in Bengal, as superintendent, presidency jail; superintendent of the Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1871; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, May, 1879; confirmed in this appointment, April, 1882.

**LYON, GEORGE KENNETH, Bengal C.S.**—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

**LYON, ISIDORE BERNADETTE, Surgeon-Major, F.C.S., M.R.C.S., L.S.A., F.I.C., Medical Department, Bombay.**—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1855; arrived in India, 1st March, 1866; acting professor of anatomy and curator of museum, Grant Medical College, March, 1866; professor of chemistry, Grant Medical College, and chemical analyser to government, Jan., 1867; in addition to these appointments was also third physician at the Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, July, 1867, to Oct., 1872; professor of medical jurisprudence, Grant Medical College, from July, 1868, and professor of chemistry at the Elphinstone College from Dec., 1875; on special duty conducting petroleum experiments, Oct.–Nov., 1882.

**LYON, PERCY COMYN, Bengal C.S. (Assam).**—Educated at King's School, Bruton, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1884; assistant commissioner, Sylhet, Jan., 1884.

**LYTTELTON, HON. N. G., Lieutenant-Colonel, Rifle Brigade.**—Military secretary on the personal staff of the governor of Bombay (Rt. Hon. D. J. M. Lord Reay), 31st March, 1885.

**MACAULIFFE, MICHAEL, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).**—Educated at Newcastle School (Limerick), Springfield College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1882; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

**MACAULAY, COLMAN PATRICK LOUIS, M.A., Bengal C.S.**—Educated at Ratcliffe College, Loughborough, Queen's College, Galway, and at Liège; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1870; assistant ma-
gistrate and collector, in Bengal, Nov., 1870; district superintendent of police, June, 1873; on famine duty at Bankoora, July, 1874; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1875; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Oct., 1875; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, Nov., 1875, and July, 1876; officiating under secretary, government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, April, 1876; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, Oct., 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, Feb., 1879; junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1879; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Aug., 1879; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1882.

MACCARTIE, CHARLES FALKINER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served in Bombay till Nov., 1872, and subsequently in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting principal assistant, additional sessions judge, and acting collector, magistrate, and agent, and was placed on special settlement duty, Nov., 1882; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Jan., 1882; officiating postmaster-general, Madras, April-Dec., 1883; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, May, 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Feb., 1885.

MACDONALD, DONALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal army, Oct., 1853; arrived in India, Dec., 1853; appointed to the survey department, revenue branch, Dec., 1860; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1865; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1866; promoted to 2nd grade, Jan., 1878.

MACDONALD, JOHN CRAWFORD, Kumaun Commission, North-Western Provinces—Previous to employment in India was engaged in the railway survey department at Melbourne, 1855 to 1858; from 5th Sept., 1858, served in Kumaun as assistant to the superintendent of Kheddas, and was appointed assistant superintendent, Tarai, April, 1861; superintendent, Tarai, May, 1871.

MACDONALD, R. G., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1864, as accountant, 3rd grade, in the accountant-general's office; examiner of railway accounts, Oudh, Dec., 1867; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkund railway accounts; examiner, railway accounts, Madras, 1875; Tirhoot state railway, 1876; W. Rajputana railway, 1876; assistant accountant-general, Calcutta, Dec., 1879; examiner of accounts, Punjab, 1881; N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1882; examiner of military works accounts, 1883; inspector of public works accounts, 1884; examiner, 3rd class, in the accounts establishment, June, 1884.

MACDONNELL, ANTHONY PATRICK, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1876; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Sept., 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, May, 1884; secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, July, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, Nov., 1884.

MACDOUGALL, H. R. L., Brigade Surgeon, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.M. (Ed.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1858; appointed civil surgeon, Rajkot, Oct., 1878; also acted as superintendent of vaccination, Oct.-Nov., 1882; brigade surgeon, May, 1883; superintendent of Matheran, March, 1884.

MACDOUGALL, JAMES WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1853; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1853; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted at various times as cantonment magistrate of Kamptee, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur, April, 1871, to March, 1873; held charge of the model farm, Nagpur, in addition to other duties, 1873-79; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1883.

MACEWEN, ROBERT SUTHERLAND TAYLOR (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Department.—Sub-assistant commissioner, Sonthal commission, Sept., 1862; officiating assistant commissioner, May, 1863; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, July, 1866; served from Dec., 1870, as judge, Calcutta court of small causes, and was promoted to 2nd judge, Oct., 1884; temporary additional recorder of Rangoon, April, 1884.

MACFARLAN, JOHN, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1857; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, Satara, till 1860; deputy collector and magistrate, in Sind, 1860-61; second assistant collector and magistrate at Poona and Dharwar, 1862 to 1864; acting collector and magistrate, Kanara, April, 1866; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1869; acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, 1870-72, and from Feb., 1873, and was appointed postmaster-general, Madras, in 1875; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, April, 1877, to Dec., 1878; retired, Dec., 1878.

MACGEORGE, HENRY JOHN, Uncov, C.S. Central Provinces.—Joined the service as deputy superintendent of Jhansi, 10th June, 1854; deputy collector, Betul, Nov., 1856; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Dec., 1860; in charge of settlement duties, Wardha and Chanda, Dec., 1862, to April, 1863; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877.

MACKIE, ANDREW WALLACE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Universities of Edinburgh and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874, and again, in Nellore, March, 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1884.

MACKAY, DUNCAN LACHLAN MACPHERSON, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Madras College, and University, St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in
India, 8th Nov., 1875, and was appointed assistant commissioner at Jubulpore; transferred to Burma, July, 1876; 3rd grade assistant commissioner, June, 1882.

MACKENZIE, ALEXANDER, B.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward VI's Grammar School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Sept., 1863; from Feb., 1866, to Dec., 1873, served as under secretary, junior secretary, and officiating secretary to government of Bengal; on famine duty, Dec., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1875; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Moorshedabad, July, 1876; also in charge of office of agent to governor-general; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, July, 1877; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Oct., 1877; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1879; secretary, government of India, home department, April, 1882.

MACKENZIE, GORDON THOMSON, Madras C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; assistant commissioner, Nilgiris, Aug., 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Kistna, Sept., 1881; head assistant collector, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; acting registrar, high court, July, 1883; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883, and acting secretary, Nov., 1884; president of the municipal commission, Jan., 1885.

MACKENZIE, JOHN, M.D., Brigade Surgeon, Madras.—Assistant surgeon, army medical department, 5th Aug., 1853; served through the campaign in north of China in 1860; surgeon, March, 1873; surgeon-major, April, 1873; medical officer to His Grace the Duke of Buckingham and Chandos, governor of Madras, April, 1877, and to the Right Hon. M. E. Grant-Duff, Nov., 1881; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1884.

MACKENZIE, JOHN ANDREW SHAW, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Reading Grammar School and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1817; served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant collector of customs, and assistant accountant-general, Bombay; deputy collector of customs and town duties, Bombay, 1827; sub-collector of Sholapur, 1829; judge and sessions judge of Tannah, 1835, and afterwards of Concan and Dharwar; postmaster-general, Bombay, 1842; resigned, 1844.

MACKENZIE, KENNETH JAMES LOCH, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Berar Commission.—Joined Madras artillery from Addiscombe, 11th June, 1858; from April, 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts, as assistant commissioner, assistant conservator of forests, and deputy commissioner (2nd class, Feb., 1885).

MACKENZIE, STEPHEN COULL, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; served from 15th Oct., 1869, as professor of hygiene, Calcutta Medical College, also officiating as assistant surgeon at the Presidency General Hospital; superintendent, presidency jail, Jan., 1871; junior surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, Dec., 1873; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, Feb., 1877; superintendent of Campbell Medical School and Hospital, Sealdah, professor of medical jurisprudence, Calcutta Medical College, and police surgeon, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; superintendent of lock hospitals in Calcutta, Nov., 1879, and of lunatic asylums, Dec., 1880, also coroner's surgeon; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1878.

MACKENZIE, THOMAS DUNCAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate; secretary, Baroda inquiry commission, Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1875, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1877; member of civil and military examination committee, April-Oct., 1879; from Nov., 1879, served as acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty at Baroda, March-Aug., 1880, in connection with the settlement of the affairs of Mir Zulfiqar Ali; acting junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Nov., 1880; junior collector and magistrate, Broach, May, 1884.

MACKINTOSH, JAMES SIMON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, Edinburgh University, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant secretary, and officiating under secretary to government, and was appointed private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb., 1874; junior secretary to government, July, 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1877.
