MACLEAN, ALEXANDER THOMAS, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1856; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1857; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector of Pooree, Oct., 1866; from July, 1869, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge and district judge in various districts of Bengal, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs in 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1880; retired, 1885.

MACLEAN, CHARLES DONALD, Mus. Doc., M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; acting inspector of schools, Oct., 1866; assistant collector, Dec., 1867; acting cantonment magistrate, Sept., 1868; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, 1871; on special duty in preparing annual administration report, Nov., 1876, and again, Sept., 1878; on special duty revising standing orders of the board of revenue, Oct., 1877; under secretary to government in chief secretary's department, July, 1880; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1881; Canarese translator to government, April, 1881; member of board of examiners, Jan., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate (acting as collector and magistrate), Jan., 1883; on special duty at Madras
in connection with preparation of 'Manual of Administration,' Nov., 1883, and again, Aug., 1884; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Feb., 1884; acting Tamil translator to government, April, 1885.

MACLEOD, BANNATYNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, Edinburgh University, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector.

MACLEOD, DONALD GRANT, M.A., LL.M. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Burma.—Trinity College, Cambridge, and Inner Temple; judge of the court of small causes, Rangoon, Sept., 1869; judge of Moulmein, March, 1876.

MACLEOD, Roderick Henry, Bengal C.S. (North-West Provinces).—Educated at University College, London, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate.

MACMILLAN, ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Aldenham Grammar School and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; from Aug., 1874, to Aug., 1876, officiated as assistant secretary, and under secretary to government of N.W. Provinces; deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1883.

MACNABB, DONALD CAMPBELL, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Peshawur, 1865; commissioner, Hisar division, 1872, and subsequently in the Lahore, Rawalpindi, and Peshawur divisions; retired, 1881.

MACNABB, JAMES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1852, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Aug., 1861; commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Nov., 1875, and afterwards in the Hissar and Delhi divisions.

MACNAGHTEN, CHESTER, M.A. (Cantab.), Educational Department, Bombay.—From July, 1866, to Dec., 1870, held the appointment of tutor to the minor Mahárájah of Durbhunga under the court of wards, Bengal; joined the Bombay educational service, 19th Dec., 1870, and served from that date as principal of the Rajkumar College, Káthiáwar.

MACONACHIE, GEORGE ARCHIBALD, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; served in the military department till Jan., 1872, and subsequently as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and comparative anatomy at the Grant Medical College, Bombay; also presidency surgeon from June, 1880.

MACONACHIE, JAMES ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 9th Jan., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1880.

MACONACHIE, ALEXANDER FRANCIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883.

MACPHERSON, ARTHUR G., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at University and King's College, Aberdeen, and University of Edinburgh; called to the bar, 1852; 1st judge of Calcutta small cause court, 1859; secretary to the government of Bengal, legislative department, 1862; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India in the home department (legislative), 1863; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1865; retired, 1877; legal adviser to the secretary of state, Nov., 1879; secretary in the judicial and public department, India Office, Feb., 1882; author of 'Law of Mortgage in Bengal,' and joint author with Mr. W. Morgan of 'The Indian Penal Code (Act xlv of 1860).'

MACPHERSON, ANDREW KENNEDY, Captain, B.S.C.—First commission, 19th Dec., 1865; arrived in India, 9th March, 1866; from April, 1871, served as cantonment magistrate at various stations in the Punjab, and was promoted to the 1st class, Dec., 1879.

MACPHERSON, CHARLES GORDON WELLS, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and superintendent of police; supernumerary, under secretary to government of Bombay in the public works department for relief purposes, Nov., 1876; on famine relief duty in Madras, as secretary to personal assistant to the governor, Sept., 1877, to Jan., 1879; from April, 1879, acted as under secretary to government of Bombay, political and judicial departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; acting private secretary to governor of Bombay, Dec., 1880, to March, 1881; acted as secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, in 1884 and 1885; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, April–July, 1885.

MACPHERSON, DUNCAN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882.

MACPHERSON, GEORGE MORISON, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at
University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, small cause court judge, and judge and sessions judge in various districts; 1st grade judge, Jan., 1881; judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the Sadar court, Feb., 1885.

MACPHERSON, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; on special duty under board of revenue, July, 1875; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1884.

MACPHERSON, J. M. (Barrister-at-Law), Legislative Department, Government of India.—Advocate of the high court, Calcutta; served from 1873 as deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department.

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating civil and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1872, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1878; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 10th Jan., 1885.

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector, Patna, Jan., 1878; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating inspector of schools; transferred to Bengal in 1884; officiating under secretary to government of Bengal, May, 1885.

MACRAE, JOHN KENNETH, Burma Commission.—Joined the Burma commission as officiating assistant commissioner, 20th July, 1860; registrar to the court of the recorder, and judge of the court of small causes, Moulmein, May, 1864; deputy commissioner, July, 1869; town magistrate, Akyab, Nov., 1874; boundary officer, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883.

MAGUIRE, HUGH FITZJOHN TYRREL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

MAHADEO GOVIND RANADE, RAOBAHURDUR, M.A., LL.B. (Bombay), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 28th May, 1866, in the educational department, and was appointed assistant professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, Oct., 1868; also served in the judicial department as assistant reporter to the high court, Bombay, acting magistrate of police, acting small cause court judge, and subordinate judge (June, 1872); acting presidency magistrate, Bombay, Jan.-March, 1881; appointed under the Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act to inspect and supervise the lower courts in districts of Poona and Satara, Aug., 1881; judge of the court of small causes, Poona, Feb., 1884, and was in charge of duties of law lecturer, Deccan College, Jan.-April, 1885.

MAINE, SIR HENRY JAMES SUMNER, K.C.S.I., LL.D., D.C.L., F.R.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Cambridge; Craven scholar; graduated B.A. in 1844 (senior classic and senior chancellor's classical medallist); tutor of Trinity Hall; regius professor of civil law, 1847-1854; called to the bar in 1850; reader on jurisprudence, Middle Temple, 1854; law member of the supreme council, government of India, 1852-1859; Corpus professor of jurisprudence, Oxford, 1870-1878; member of council of secretary of state for India, Nov., 1871; elected to the mastership of Trinity Hall, Cambridge, Dec., 1877; a foreign associate of the Institute of France; author of 'Ancient Law: its Connection with the Early History of Society, and its Relation to Modern Ideas,' 1861, 'Village Communities in the East and West,' 1871, 'The Early History of Institutions,' 1875, 'Early Law and Custom,' 1882, and 'Popular Government,' 1885.

MAITLAND, FREDERICK HENRY, Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, 4th Hussars, Feb., 1861; served in Central India on civil employ from 1869 as boundary officer and political assistant; 2nd assistant agent, Indore, 1877; 1st assistant agent, Indore, 1878; additional political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, 1880.

MAITLAND, WILLIAM J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and abroad; temporary clerk, 3rd Nov., 1866; junior clerk, July, 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1878; private secretary to the secretary of state, August, 1886.

MALET, ARTHUR, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Addiscombe, and finally at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1824; arrived at Bombay, May, 1826; served first as assistant collector and magistrate, Khandesh, and then as assistant to the resident of Baroda; political agent and resident, Kutch, 1842; political agent, Kathiawar, 1843; secretary to government of Bombay, political and secret departments, 1846; chief secretary to government, 1847; legislative council of India, 1854; Bombay council, April, 1855; also chief judge of the court of Sudder Dewannee and Sudder Foujdarree Adawlut, 1857; retired, 1860.

MALLET, FREDERICK RICHARD, F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 12th Feb., 1859; was employed in various districts of Bengal, the Central Provinces, Assam, Sikkim, and Bhutan; keeper of the mineral collections in the museum, Oct., 1875; 1st grade officer, Jan., 1883; deputy superintendent, April, 1883.

MALLET, RIGHT HON. SIR LOUIS, C.B.—Clerk in the audit office, 1839; transferred to board of trade, 1847; private secretary to president of the board of trade, 1848 to 1852, and again 1855 to 1857; accompanied Mr. Cobden to Paris in April, 1860, as assistant commissioner for the purpose of making a tariff; English
member of mixed commission at Vienna for the purpose of examining into an Austrian tariff, 1865; C.B., 1866; knighted, Dec., 1868; retired from the board of trade, and was nominated to the council of the secretary of state for India, 1872; permanent under secretary of state for India, Feb., 1874-1883; privy councillor; author of a treatise on 'Reciprocity,' printed for the Cobden Club in 1879.

MALLETT, R. T., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Jan., 1868, as executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway; superintendent of works, Ravvee section, March, 1873; temporary superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, Jan., 1877; superintending engineer, Mooltan, Aug., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley railway, May, 1879; director of stores, railway branch, Oct., 1880; engineer-in-chief, Rewari Ferozepur railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883.

MALLOCK, HENRY ARCHIBALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Indian Telegraph Department.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1853; joined the telegraph department, Jan., 1861; superintending, 1st grade, and storekeeper, Dec., 1866; director of construction, April, 1868; deputy director-general, June, 1883.

MALTBY, EDWARD, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Haileybury; appointed to the Madras civil service in 1828; served in the revenue and judicial departments; appointed civil and sessions judge, Cuddapah, 1848; collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, 1849, and in the south division of Arcot, 1851; member of board of revenue, 1854; was temporarily chief secretary to government; provisional member of council of governor of Madras, June, 1858; member of council, 16th Dec., 1859; also president of the board of revenue; acted as governor of the presidency for a few months in 1864; retired in 1864.

MALTBY, EDWARD PENNYCUCK, Major, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Jan., 1861; served in civil employ in the Mysore commission from Jan., 1864; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1877; small cause court judge, and town and cantonment magistrate, Bangalore, March, 1879; district magistrate and collector, and president, municipal commission, in the civil and military station of Bangalore from March, 1881.

MANSE, SIR HENRY CHRISTOPHER, C.I.E., Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, July, 1863; superintendent, Kurrachee, Persian Gulf section, Sept., 1866; engineer and electrician, Sept., 1879; C.I.E., Jan., 1883.

MANCHERJI PESTANJ KHAREGHAT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Xavier's College, Calcutta, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884; assistant collector, June, 1885.

MANDERSON, THOMAS CLARIDGE, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, July, 1860, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Punjab, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, Rawal Pindi, Oct., 1880; superintending engineer, Lahore, April, 1882.

MANISTY, GEORGE ELDON (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ruabon Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1873; served in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884.

MANN, GUSTAV, Forest Department, Assam.—Assistant in government cinchona plantations, Darjeeling, Nov., 1863; assistant conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1864; from Nov., 1868, served in the Assam forest department, and was promoted to conservator, 3rd grade, April, 1880.

MANSFIELD, SAMUEL, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts, and was appointed political agent, Rewa Kantha, 1847; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1852; revenue commissioner, northern division, 1859; commissioner, Sind, 1862; member of council, Bombay, 14th May, 1867; retired in 1872.

MANSON, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; from Sept., 1865, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, March, 1883; also served as second inspector of registration offices, Aug., 1876.

MARINDIN, CHARLES RANDAL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, Tirhoot, Feb., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1884.

MARKHAM, ALEXANDER MACAULAY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Down and Connor Diocesan School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating postmaster-general, officiating cantonment magistrate, settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Allahabad, Nov., 1880; member of committee for considering revised rules for Patwâris and Kanungos, Nov., 1880; member of grass supply committee under military department of government of India, Oct., 1881; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli division, March, 1882.

MARRIOTT, CHARLES RICHARDSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

MARYAT, ERNEST LINDSAY, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—First com-
mission, 1859; probationary assistant engineer, Mhow, Bombay, Nov., 1862; assistant engineer, Central Provinces, Oct., 1864; executive engineer, Bombay public works department, Jan., 1866; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1874; acted as deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, from Nov., 1875, and was confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1879; acting manager, Dhond and Manmad state railway, Dec., 1878; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; manager, Punjab northern state railway, in 1st class of the state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1880.

MARSDEN, F. J.—Clerk of the crown, 14th May, 1873; officiating magistrate, Calcutta police, and coroner, Oct., 1874; presidency magistrate and coroner, Dec., 1877; chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1878; also judge of the court for the trial of pilots, and of the court of survey, port of Calcutta.

MARSHALL, CHARLES HENRY TILSON, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from July, 1865, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1878; superintendent, Chamba state, Oct., 1879.

MARSHALL, HERBERT, Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough College; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 19th March, 1869; senior clerk, Jan., 1884.

MARTELLI, N. C., Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Oct., 1864, 11th foot; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1870; served in civil employ from 1873 as assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, and political assistant in Rajputana; magistrate of Aboo, and assistant in the thuggee and dacoity department, 1876; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, and superintendent of operations for control of Moghias, 1881; officiating political agent, Baghelcund, 1882; political agent, Bhopawur, 1885.

MARTIN, C. A., LL.D., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 22nd Nov., 1864; served as professor at the Dacca College and at the Krishnaghur College; inspector of schools, Aug., 1877; 2nd class, educational service, Aug., 1877.

MARTIN, CHARLES WILLIAM WALL, B.A., LL.D., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Nov., 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1883, in Cuddapah, and afterwards in Salem.

MARTIN, EDWARD JAMES, M.I.C.E., and F.R.I.B.A., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, May, 1859; arrived in India, 6th Sept., 1859; served in the Punjab in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer and executive engineer till 1869-70, when he was transferred to the N.W. Provinces, and posted to the Rajputana state railway; officiated as engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, April, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, May, 1877; also ex-officio manager of the line, April, 1878; transferred to Bengal, railway branch, and appointed engineer-in-chief of the Central Bengal system of state railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal provincial branch, Jan., 1880; on special duty under the chief engineer, Bengal, as government architect, April, 1881; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1882; deputed to Indore on special duty, Jan., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, sub pro. tem., May, 1884.

MARTIN, GERALD WARD, Captain, Bo. S.C., Assay Master, Bombay Mint.—Ensign, 88th Foot, 22nd June, 1867; joined Roorkee College, Nov., 1869, and obtained certificate as civil engineer; from March, 1871, to July, 1878, served as assistant superintendent of survey in Assam, in the Deccan topographical survey, and in the Soane irrigation survey; transferred to the financial department for employment in the assay department, July, 1878, and acted as deputy assay master in the Calcutta and Bombay mints; appointed assay master, Bombay mint, May, 1884; also served with the Afghan expeditionary force as assistant superintendent of survey, Feb., 1879, and with the Waziri expeditionary field force.

MARTIN, WILLIAM THOMAS (Barrister-at-Law) Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Regent's Park College and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865; from July, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1881; judge, 3rd grade, Aligarh, April, 1885.

MARTINDALE, ARTHUR HENRY TEMPLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the foreign department of the government of India from Oct., 1877, to Oct., 1879, and from June, 1881, to May, 1882, as attaché, officiating political agent, 3rd class, and assistant secretary to government, and was placed on special duty Dec., 1881; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, May-Aug., 1882; from Aug., 1882, served again under the foreign department of the government of India as political agent at Kotah, and assistant secretary to government; junior under secretary, Oct., 1884; officiating assistant to resident in Mysore and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg, Feb., 1885; officiating resident and chief commissioner, May-June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, July, 1885.

MASTER, CHARLES GILBERT (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate from Sept., 1855; deputy secretary to government in revenue department, Dec., 1859; commissioner of income tax, 1860-1865; secretary to the board of examiners, April, 1861, to Jan., 1866; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue for various periods between 1862 and 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Calicut,
May, 1869; on special duty in Godavari and Kistna on irrigation works, May to Nov., 1869; from Nov., 1869, to May, 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Nellore, and other districts; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1877; chief secretary to government, June, 1882; additional member of the legislative council, June, 1882; ordinary member of council, Madras, Jan., 1884.

MATHEW, GEORGE FELTON, C.I.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1876, as assistant to the manager, Rajputana state railway; officiating traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, June, 1879; 2nd class, traffic department, Jan., 1880; officiating manager, Nizam's railway, March, 1882.

MATHEWS, HENRY MONTAGU, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed 4th grade executive engineer, 8th Oct., 1868; arrived in India, Dec., 1868; served in British Burma, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, Oct., 1877; employed in examining, repairing, and reporting on lighthouses, British Burma, Jan.-March, 1878; transferred to railway branch as engineer-in-chief and manager of the Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; officiated as chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner, public works department, Oct., 1880; 1st class, 1st grade, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1882; also chairman, Rangoon port trust.

MATHIAS, HENRY VINCENT, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Central Provinces.—Ensign Bengal infantry, Dec., 1849; in command, Nagode divisional military police, Oct., 1862; from 1st July, 1865, served in the police department, Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent of police, 1st class, April, 1875.

MATTHEW, HENRY JAMES, Ven., M.A., Ecclesiastical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 15th Feb., 1867, and served in N.W. Provinces and Bengal as chaplain of Allahabad and Fort William, and as domestic chaplain to the Lord Bishop; from Jan., 1877, served in Punjab as senior chaplain, and was appointed archdeacon, Aug., 1878, and bishop's commissary, March, 1883.

MATTHEWS, HAROLD FRANCIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1871; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam; officiating superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Sept., 1878; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1885.

MAUDE, HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; under secretary to government, Punjab, revenue department, April, 1885.

MAUDE, WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1883.

MAUNSELL, JOHN RICHARDSON, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, 1851; 2nd lieutenant, June, 1853; arrived in India, 6th July, 1855; served in the Bombay public works department from March, 1856, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, June, 1858; on special duty investigating irregularities in local fund system, Nov., 1871; superintending engineer (temporary), May, 1879; superintending engineer, 1st class, May, 1884.

MAYHEW, ALFRED HERCULES, Major, Bombay S.C.—First commission as ensign, Madras army, June, 1861; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1862; from July, 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Thar and Pârkar, head assistant collector, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in the military department, March, 1882; in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Jacobabad, May-Aug., 1883, and March-May, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1884.

MAYNE, JASPER OTWAY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, Feb., 1852, and served under the military department till March, 1855, when he was appointed to Madras public works department; promoted to 1st class executive engineer, Feb., 1858; chief engineer, Straits Settlements, March, 1862, to Oct., 1866; transferred to Bengal as superintending engineer, irrigation department, July, 1868; transferred to Hyderabad, Jan., 1870, as secretary to resident, and superintending engineer, and promoted to 1st class, 1st grade, March, 1871; transferred to Central Provinces as temporary chief engineer and secretary, Sept., 1874; secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, Dec., 1876; officiating chief engineer and secretary, Central Provinces, April, 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, Feb., 1883; transferred to N.W. Provinces and Oudh, as chief engineer and secretary to government, Feb., 1883.

MAYO, JOHN H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; East India House writer, old establishment, 28th Feb., 1855; junior clerk, administrator general's department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; military department, 1875; assistant secretary in the military department, Dec., 1882.

McANDREW, JOHN, Police Department, Punjab.—From 8th Nov., 1860, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, July, 1886; deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, March, 1885.

McCABE, ROBERT BLAIR, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Oct., 1884.

McCALLUM, EDWIN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, May, 1884.

McCarthy, SAMUEL TRANT, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Patrick's College, Carlow;
appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments, from Nov., 1865, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Oct., 1877; acted as collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Sept., 1879, to March, 1881; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1882, in the district of Vizagapatam, and afterwards in Kistna and Madura.

McCONAGHEY, MATTHEW ALLEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, and Feb., 1862; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Banda, March, 1879; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli division, Feb., 1883; commissioner, Sitapur division, Nov., 1883.

McCONNELL, JAMES FREDERICK PARRY, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1870; house-surgeon to the Calcutta Medical College Hospital, Oct., 1871; professor of pathology in the medical college, and resident physician to the College Hospital, March, 1872; also officiated as professor of the comparative anatomy section of the college museum, in July, 1873; officiating civil surgeon and medical inspector of emigrants, Sept.–Nov., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; superintendent of vaccination, Feb., 1883; officiating professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, Medical College, and medical inspector of emigrants, April, 1883; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, medical officer, Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, 1885.

McCORKELL, GILMOUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Foyle College, Londonderry, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting educational inspector, acting district superintendent of police, and acting assistant judge and sessions judge.

McDONELL, WILLIAM FRASER, V.C., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, June, 1849; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1850; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, April, 1864); on special duty, May, 1858; settlement officer, Shahabad, July, 1859; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1863; civil and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1868; commissioner, Bhagulpore division, April, 1874; judge, high court, Calcutta, Aug., 1878.

McKEON, GEORGE, Store Department, India Office.—Served in the Bombay ordnance department, Sept., 1831, to May, 1859; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, July, 1860; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877.

McLAUGHLIN, FREDERICK HUBERT, LL.M., B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalene College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, 1877; from May, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1884.

McLEAN, JOHN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the International College, Ealing, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate, Jhansi.

McLEOD, KENNETH, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; civil surgeon, Jessore, 20th February, 1866; on special duty as member, cattle plague commission, Dec., 1869; secretary to inspector-general of hospitals, Jan., 1871; officiating professor of surgical and descriptive anatomy, Calcutta Medical College, and ex officio 2nd surgeon, College Hospital, April, 1874; also officiating medical inspector of emigrants, Calcutta, and officiating marine surgeon, Jan., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; professor of surgery, Medical College, and ex officio 1st surgeon at the hospital, Jan., 1880; health officer for town of Calcutta, Feb., 1880.

McMINN, CHARLES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from July, 1864, to Feb., 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty for completion of Oudh gazetteer, July, 1872, also at Simla, July, 1873; from March, 1879, served in the Central Provinces and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1884.

McNALLY, CHRISTOPHER JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 30th March, 1872; arrived 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department till July, 1879, also holding charge of the jail at Secunderabad in 1873 and 1878, and acting as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Mangalore, March–Sept., 1878; from 1879, served as assistant physician at the General Hospital, Madras, and professor of materia medica, pharmacy, and hygiene in the Medical College, and was also in charge of the principal medical storekeeper's office, May, 1880, and acted as professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology, July–August, 1880; on special duty in Egypt in connection with outbreak of cholera, July–Oct., 1883; surgeon-major, March, 1884; from April to July, 1884, acted as fort surgeon, medical inspector of seamen, Madras, and professor of anatomy in the Medical College, also acting as surgeon, General Hospital, and professor of clinical surgery, April, 1884; chemical examiner and professor of chemistry, July, 1884.

McNEILE, CHARLES, Lieutenant-Colonel B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1858; from Dec., 1861, served in the Punjab police department as assistant superintendent and officiating district superintendent; from May, 1865, served in the commission as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and judicial assistant; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.
McNEILE, JOHN MAGEE, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined at Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; arrived in India, 10th April, 1858; from May, 1858, served in the public works department as assistant engineer and executive engineer in British Burmah and Bengal, and in Rajputana as officiating superintendent of works, Ajmere and Mairwara, 1874-1876; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1879; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, public works department, Jan., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1882; chief engineer, 3rd class, special, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, Jan., 1884; chief engineer for irrigation.

McQUEEN, J. W., Colonel, C.B., B.S.C.—Arrived in India, 15th May, 1854; employed in military department up to 31st Dec., 1882; military secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; aide-de-camp to the Queen.

McRAE, JOHN GRAHAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C.—Arrived in India, 10th July, 1858, and served in the Bombay Presidency on military duty till March, 1867, and subsequently in the revenue survey department as assistant superintendent; on military duty, Nov., 1867, to July, 1868 (field service in Abyssinia), and again Dec., 1870, to Nov., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Bombay forest department as deputy conservator, and conservator of forests in Sind (from Dec., 1876).

McWATTERS, GEORGE, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry Collegiate School and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting under secretary to government of Madras, May, 1872; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1879; district and sessions judge, Salem, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, Salem, Jan., 1884.

McWILLIAM, ORMISTON GALLOWAY REID, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 22nd Nov., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, Tipperah, Jan., 1865; from March, 1868, to Dec., 1883, served in district of Cachar, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 4th grade, and political agent, Naga Hills, April, 1871.

MEAD, HENRY ROBERT, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as Lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857, and served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer (4th grade, Jan., 1866), and was placed on special duty on the Neringipeth Anicut project, March, 1871; superintending engineer, Oct., 1878; on special duty in Travancore, Feb., 1882; 2nd class superintending engineer, Jan., 1883.

MEDLICOTT, HENRY BENEDICT, M.A., F.R.S., F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—Engaged for service in India from the geological survey of Great Britain; joined appointment in India, March, 1854; professor of geology, Roorkee College, Aug., 1854, to Oct., 1862, when he rejoined the geological survey as deputy superintendent for Bengal, was variously employed in Bengal, Assam, Central India, Rajputana, Central Provinces, &c.; superintendent of the geological survey, April, 1876; fellow of Calcutta University, and member of the faculty of arts and engineering, April, 1876.

MEIKLEJOHN, DAVID OGILVY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector, Hoogly, Dec., 1870; from Oct., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Dec., 1882; judge, small cause court, Jubbulpore, April, 1885.

MELITUS, PAUL GREGORY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Marylebone and All Saints Grammar School, Marlborough, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

MELLOR, CHARLES WARREN, Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Province as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1882.

MELVILL, MAXWELL, C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1855, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant registrar of Sadar Divani, assistant judge and session judge, and judicial assistant commissioner in Sind; registrar-general of assurances, Feb., 1866; judicial commissioner, Sind, July, 1866; judge of the Sadar court in Sind, Aug., 1866; one of the commissioners to inquire into the failure of the Bank of Bombay, June, 1868, to May, 1869; judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1871; member of governor's council, April, 1884.

MELVILL, PHILIP SANDYS, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1846; arrived in India, 4th Oct., 1846; attached to the Punjab, and served as assistant to the resident at Lahore, and assistant commissioner; settlement officer in the Hoshiarpur and Amballa districts, 1850-54; deputy commissioner, Amballa, Jan., 1854; commissioner, Hissar division, 1860 to 1862, and subsequently of the Delhi and Rawul Pindi divisions; officiated as financial commissioner of the Punjab in 1869, and again in 1873, and as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces in 1870-71; commissioner, Jullundur division, 1872 to 1875, and officiated as judge of the chief court of the Punjab in 1873 and 1874; member of commission for investigating the charges brought against the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1875; agent to the governor-general and resident, 1st class, at Baroda, Oct., 1875; retired, Jan., 1882.

MENZIES, HUGH CHRISTIAN, Colonel, M.S.C.,
Berar Commission.—Arrived in India, 7th June, 1850; served in Burmah from Aug., 1859, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Oct., 1860, served as superintendent of police in Madras, and was engaged in the organisation of the police in the South Malabar districts, and in the Hyderabad assigned districts from Oct., 1862; from Dec., 1864, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, and small cause court judge at Amraoti; inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1871; deputy commissioner, April, 1878.

MENZIES, OSWALD, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 26th Aug., 1854; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1854; from March, 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, July, 1880; inspector-general of police in the Punjab, and under secretary to government, March, 1885.

MEREDITH, ARTHUR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

MERES, WILLIAM FITZPATRICK, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 29th Nov., 1864; from Sept., 1865, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and in Assam (March-Dec., 1881), and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1883; acting judicial commissioner, British Burma, Feb., 1885.

MERK, WALTER HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Christ's Hospital and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

MERK, WILLIAM RUDOLPH HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kornthal, Wurtemberg, the Grammar School, Old Aberdeen, and the University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty, Jhelum, March, 1877, and in the Khyber Pass, 1879, and again as assistant political agent, Sept., 1879; assistant resident, Kandhar, Nov., 1880; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1882; on special duty with the boundary commission.

MERRIMAN, CHARLES JAMES, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, June, 1850; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1852; assistant engineer, Sept., 1853; field engineer, Persia, Nov., 1856; executive engineer, Hyderabad, Sept., 1857, and subsequently at Kurrachee and at Aden, 1866; supervising engineer in Sind, May, 1868; in N.W. Provinces to examine irrigation works, Sept.-Nov., 1869; acting chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, 1871, and again in 1873 and 1877-79; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bombay, general, and buildings, and roads branches, March, 1880; retired from the public works department in 1885.

METCALFE, CHARLES THEOPHILUS, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1857; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; deputy commissioner and civil officer, Bhutan field force, Oct., 1864; senior superintendent of survey, May, 1869; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, June, 1871; additional commissioner, Patna division, March, 1874; officiating inspector-general of police, Oct., 1876; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, Nov., 1876; officiated as commissioner in various divisions between 1876 and 1884, and was appointed commissioner of the Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary Mehals, Cuttack, Sept., 1884.

MEYER, WILLIAM STEVENSON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Missionary School, University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate.

MICHELL, THOMAS BERNARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Assam Commission.—First commission as ensign, Feb., 1858; arrived in India, 29th Jan., 1866; from March, 1866, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885; also served temporarily in Bengal as cantonment magistrate, Dum-Dum, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878.

MIDDLETON, JAMES RUSSELL, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Aug., 1883.

MIDWINTER, WILLIAM COLPOYS, Uncov. C.S., Burma Commission.—Assistant conservator of forests, June, 1868; from Sept., 1869, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, officiating judge of the small cause court at Rangoon, settlement and boundary officer in the Tharrawaddy district, and cantonment magistrate of Thyetmyo (July, 1883); deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883.

MILES, SAMUEL BARRETT, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1857; assistant political agent, Makran coast, 1871; political agent, Muscat, 1874; officiating political agent, Turkish Arabia, 1879-80; political agent, Zanzibar, 1882; returned to agency of Muscat, 1883; graded as political agent, 1st class.

MILLER, A., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 11th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, March, 1880; attached to library.

MILLER, JOHN ANDREW ERASMUS, Punjab Administration.—Joined the Punjab commission, Jan., 1863, as extra assistant commissioner; personal assistant to the financial commissioner, Oct., 1865; secretary to the financial commissioner, May, 1866, to 1881; officiating registrar, chiefcourt, Punjab, 1871-72; officiating inspector-
general of registration and superintendent of stamps, Aug., 1879, and again in 1882; also officiated in the grades of judicial assistant and deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Dec., 1884, Kangra.

MILLER, JOHN ONTARIO, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, and assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1883; under secretary to government, May, 1884.

MILLER, LESLIE CREERY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

MILLETT, ARTHUR FENNING, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; served in N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1864, as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and from April, 1866, as assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, June, 1881, but served in the judicial department, from Aug., 1879, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, N.W. Provinces, March, 1883.

MILLETT, H. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal Judicial Service.—Professor of English law, Presidency College, Calcutta, April, 1870; officiating and judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Oct., 1871; receiver, high court, April, 1873; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, legislative department, Dec., 1873, to April, 1875; first judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1876.

MILLETT, MONTAGUE, Colonel, Bengal Inf., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1857; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1857; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, June, 1884.

MILNER, J. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 26th April, 1860; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878; attached to funds department, estates and administrator-general's branch.

MITCHELL, HORACE, Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Paul's School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 27th March, 1885.

MITCHELL, THOMAS CANDY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal; from May, 1876, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and boundary and settlement officer; on special forest demarcation duty, Nov., 1880; on special duty in connection with waste land grants in Arakan division, March, 1882; officiating deputy commissioner, Akyab, July, 1883.

MOBERLY, CHARLES MORRIS, Colonel, M.S.C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 2nd European regiment, Madras, May, 1855; joined the public works department, May, 1867, as examiner of railway accounts, Madras; controller of accounts, Calcutta, 1873; officiating deputy accountant-general, March, 1876; Rajputana railway accounts, 1879; examiner, 1st class, in the accounts establishment, July, 1884.

MOBERLY, HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradfield, and King's College School, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

MOCKLER, EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, Gen. List Bo. Int., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1859; on civil employ, Mekran coast, from 1873; assistant to the governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, 1879; assistant agent, Busreh, Turkish Arabia, 1882; acted as political agent, Muscat, 1883; graded as political agent, 3rd class.

MOHENDRO NATH BOSE, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 26th Feb., 1859, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, Sept., 1868; small cause court judge, Midnapore, Feb., 1872; 1st grade subordinate judge, May, 1877; officiating judge, high court, Jan., 1882; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, Oct., 1884.

MOIR, WILLIAM, M.A., M.B., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 20th Jan., 1866; arrived in India, 27th April, 1860, and was employed in various military medical charges; from June, 1861; served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail at Mainpur, and afterwards at Meerut, and was placed in medical charge of the lock hospital at the latter place; held medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, 1863-64; superintendent, meteorological observatory, Meerut, June, 1868; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1872; surgeon-major, Jan., 1875; officiating chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878.

MOLESWORTH, GUILDFORD LINDSAY, C.I.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at the College of Civil Engineers, Putney; in 1852 was chief assistant engineer on the London, Brighton, and South Coast railway, which he left in order to superintend the construction of buildings and machinery in the Royal Arsenal at Woolwich during the Crimean war; afterwards practised as a consulting engineer in London for some years; was awarded the 'Watt' medal and the 'Mainby' premium by the Institution of Civil Engineers in 1858, for a paper read before the institution on the 'Conversion of Wood Machinery;' engineer on the Ceylon railway, 1859; chief engineer, Ceylon government railway, 1862; director-general of the railways, 1865; director of public works in 1867; consulting engineer for state railways to the government of India, April, 1871; fellow of the University of Calcutta; is the author of many publications on engineering, moneta, and other subjects, including a 'Pocket-book of Engineering Formulae' which has passed through
twenty-one editions; 'Proposals for the Establishment of Decimal Coinage' in Ceylon, 1865, and in India, 1871; Reports on the Public Works of Ceylon, 1869, Light Railways in Ceylon, 1870, the Festiniog Railway, 1871, State Railways in India, 1872, the Madras Harbour, 1882; 'Iron Manufacture in India,' 1884; 'Suggestions for the Establishment of an Engineer Volunteer Corps for India,' 1885; 'Imperialism for India,' 1885; 'Text-book of Bi-metallism,' 1886, &c., &c.

MONAHAN, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881.

MONEY, ALONZO, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1843; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Backergunge, 1846; superintendent of survey, Monghyr, 1850; magistrate and collector, Behar, 1857, and afterwards of Shahabad and Tirhoot; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Pooroor, 1859; controller of government salt-chowkies, 1860; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Bhaugulpore, 1863; commissioner of Patna, and member of council of the lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1869; member of revenue board, Lower Provinces, 1869; district and sessions judge, Bareilly, and member of revenue board, 1875; retired, 1878.

MONEY, ROBERT COTTON, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission in army, 20th March, 1855; from 1st March, 1861, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed deputy commissioner, and grade, April, 1877; manager of the Durbhunga Raj estate, April, 1876, to Jan., 1878, and again Jan., 1880.

MONEY, WILLIAM JAMES, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; served in the revenue and survey departments in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent of survey, and was employed as civil officer with the troops in the Sonthal insurrection, 1855-56; private secretary to Sir James Outram, chief commissioner of Oudh, Aug., 1857; during the mutiny was present at several engagements, and was a member of the garrison of Lucknow; mutiny medal; served subsequently in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of revenue survey, 1866, in Jessore, and afterwards in other districts; magistrate and collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1861; officiated as district and sessions judge, Mymensingh, from 1869, and was confirmed in that appointment, Sept., 1873; retired, 1879.

MONTAGU, FRANCIS WARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's School, Ely, Winchester, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; attached to the N.W. Provinces.

MONTEATH, ALEXANDER M., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Edinburgh University, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; arrived in India, 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Allahabad, 1858; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; under secretary to government of India, financial and home departments, 1861; director-general of the post office of India from 1867 till his retirement in 1881, during which period he was placed for about two years on postal duty in England, including the representation of India at the postal conference at Berne in 1876.

MONTEATH, JAMES, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay in connexion with the Kânara land assessment case, Nov., 1873; also acted as under secretary to government of Bombay in the revenue, financial, and general departments, under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the Bombay legislative council, assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for sardars in the Deccan; appointed under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1884, and acted as secretary, Sept.-Dec., 1884.

MONTGOMERIE, PATRICK, Lieut.-Col., R.E., A.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, June, 1856; arrived in India, 7th June, 1858; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, 23rd Nov., 1860; transferred to Central Provinces, June, 1864, and appointed executive engineer, Nov., 1864; returned to Madras, Dec., 1868, and served as district engineer, Trichinopoly and Tanjore; under secretary to government, public works department, March, 1873; on military duty, Dec., 1873, to Feb., 1874; officiating district engineer, Presidency, and consulting architect to government, March, 1876; officiating deputy chief engineer, and under secretary to government, Sept., 1877, to March, 1879; on special duty in the Tanjore Delta, July, 1880; on special duty in connection with the tank maintenance scheme, and promoted to superintending engineer, 3rd class, Feb., 1883.

MONTGOMERY, JAMES ALEXANDER LAWRENCE, Captain, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1868; from Nov., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; temporarily director of settlement and revenue records.

MONTGOMERY, SIR ROBERT, G.C.S.I., K.C.B.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1827; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1828; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector of Allahabad, June, 1839, and subsequently of Mirzapore; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, 1846; commissioner, Punjab, 1849; 3rd member of the board of administration, Punjab, 1852; judicial commissioner, Punjab, 1853; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1858; provisional member of governor-general's council, Sept., 1858; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 1859; retired, 1865; member of council of secretary of state, 1868.

MOORE, ADOLPHUS W., C.B.—Educated at Harrow; junior clerk, East India House, secretariat department, Aug., 1858; financial department, India office, 1860; senior clerk, June, 1867; reading clerk to council, 1871-75; attached to funds department, 1873; political and secret department, 1874; assistant secretary from Feb.,
1875; acting political secretary, 1876-78; retired, 1885; private secretary to secretary of state for India (Rt. Hon. Lord Randolph Churchill), 1885, and to the chancellor of the exchequer, 1886.

MOORE, GEORGE MONTGOMERY J., Major, R.A.—Military secretary on personal staff of the governor of Madras (Rt. Hon. M. E. Grant Duff, C.I.E.), 1st April, 1884.

MOORE, JOHN GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; served in Sind from Dec., 1862, to Nov., 1870, as assistant commissioner, educational inspector, branch registrar-general, and acting commissioner; senior collector and magistrate, Sátára, Sept., 1877; on special duty as president of the jail commission, July-Sept., 1878; was subsequently collector and magistrate of Poona, and acted on several occasions as commissioner of the southern and central divisions, Bombay, and as commissioner of customs, salt and opium, Feb., 1885.

MOORE, LEWIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate (Dec., 1884), and acting collector and magistrate; compiled 'Trichinopoly District Manual.'

MOORE, PIERCE WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 18th Oct., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Tanjore, Dec., 1884.

MOORE, ROSS ARTHUR LESLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883.

MOORE, WILLIAM JAMES, Surgeon-General, C.I.E., Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1852; served for some time in Rajputana as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination; acting deputy surgeon-general, Bombay, 1877; deputy surgeon-general, Oct., 1877; surgeon-general with the government of Bombay, 1st April, 1885; hon. surgeon to the Viceroy.

MORGAN, CHARLES, Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd April, 1857; assistant to registrar, Oct., 1874.

MORGAN, WILLIAM HENRY, Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, Madras.—Appointed to the Indian medical department, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1856, and served in various military medical charges in Madras, Bengal, and N.W. Provinces; also held the civil surgeoncy of Etawah, June to Nov., 1858; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; from May, 1878, served as civil surgeon, Cochin; brigade surgeon, Aug., 1882.

MORIARTY, ARTHUR STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

MORISON, WILLIAM THOMSON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

MORRIESEN, EDWARD CURRIE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1878, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, assistant magistrate of Rangoon town, and in charge of Toungoo jail; from Dec., 1881, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and cantonment magistrate, and was transferred permanently to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

MORRIS, SIR JOHN H., K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1847; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1848; served in the Punjab as assistant resident, Lahore, assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer in the Trans-Sutlej division; settlement officer, Mooltan, 1854; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, May, 1862; settlement commissioner, Central Provinces, Sept., 1863; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1868; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, May, 1870; retired, 1883.

MORRIS, ROBERT, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885.

MORTON, BOYCE WILLIAM DUNLOP, Colonel, B.S.C., Non-regulation commission, Bengal.—First commission, 6th June, 1848; served in Assam from June, 1854, as junior assistant and principal assistant to the commissioner; deputy commissioner, Goalpara, April, 1861; superintendent of Darjeeling, Dec., 1866; on special duty for conducting the prosecution of Captain Playfair, Aug., 1876; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1870.

MOSCARDI, EDWARD HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, and Worcester College, Bath; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty compiling the general administration report of the Bombay Presidency, Aug., 1881; from Dec., 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed and grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883.

MOSLEY, HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bishop's Stortford Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from April, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1884.
MOSS, T., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1858; assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1860, to 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, Nov., 1863; officiating controller, central office of account, Rangoon, Oct., 1869; assistant accountant-general in the public works department, government of India, April, 1872; officiating controller, Madras, March, 1873; controller of accounts, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; transferred to Central Provinces as controller, Nagpur, Sept., 1875; examiner of accounts, Rangoon, April, 1878; transferred to Punjab, 1879; examiner, 2nd class, Sept., 1881.

MOULE, HORACE FREDERICK D'OYLEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty in 1872 to conduct the prosecution of the sub-judge of Mirzapur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, June, 1884.

MOUNSEY, CHARLES HERBERT, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant sessions judge.

MOWAT, M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Professor, Presidency College, June, 1876; Dacca College, Jan., 1878; officiating inspector of schools, Nov., 1879; professor, Patna College, Feb., 1880; officiating principal, Patna College, May, 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1883; officiating principal, Hooghly College, 1885.

MUHAMMAD ABABAS MIRZA, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, C.S.I., Lieutenant-Colonel, Sirdar, Political Department, Punjab.—Appointed British agent at the court of H.H. the Amir of Kabul, March, 1882.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, Sirdar, Khan Bahadur, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 3rd March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Kohat, March, 1883.

MUHAMMAD ASLAM KHAN KAZI, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra assistant commissioner, 10th Sept., 1881; on special duty in civil secretariat, Dec., 1881; probationer under native civil service rules, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

MUHAMMAD ISHAK KHAN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1884.

MUHAMMAD RAZA KHAN SAHIB, Madras C.S.—Served from Jan., 1874, in Madras revenue and educational departments, and in Hyderabad as attaché to the resident; appointed by the government of India to be a member of the Madras civil service, 3rd Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1883.

MUIR, JOHN FAIRLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1869, to April, 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting assistant secretary and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; from April, 1874, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector, May, 1880.

MUIR, JULIUS WOOD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dumfries Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, July, 1883.

MUIR, SIR WILLIAM, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., LL.D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kilmar-nock Grammar School and Edinburgh and Glasgow Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1837; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1837; settlement officer in Cawnpore and Bundelkund, 1840–1843; officiating collector, Futtehapore, 1844–1845; secretary, Sudder board of revenue, 1847; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; member, board of revenue, 1856; in charge of intelligence department at Agra during mutiny, 1857; secretary with Lord Canning at Allahabad for N.W. Provinces, 1858; reverted to board of revenue, 1859; member of legislative council of governor-general, 1864; foreign secretary, government of India, 1865; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1868–1874; financial member of governor-general's council, 1874–76; member of council of secretary of state, 1876–85; principal, Edinburgh University, 1883; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Glasgow and Edinburgh; author of 'Life of Mahomet and History of Islam to the Era of the Hegira,' 1858; 'Annals of the Early Caliphate,' 1883, and other works on the same subject; pamphlet on indigenous education in Futtehapore, 1845; papers on revenue settlement in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, &c.

MUTR, WILLIAM JAMES WEMYSS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1858; assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1864; officiated for some time as agent of Haraoti and Tonk; political agent, Morshedabad, 1876; political agent, Neemuch, 1879; Haraoti and Tonk, 1880; graded as political agent, 1st class.

MUIR-MACKENZIE, JOHN WILLIAM PITT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877.

MULLALY, CHARLES MYLNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Southampton Grammar School,
Hartley Institution, Southampton, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1883.

MULLINS, John, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, 8th Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1850; assistant civil engineer, Feb., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in Nellore and Tanjore, 1858-64; consulting engineer for the irrigation and canal company, Madras, May, 1864, to Aug., 1866; under secretary to government, public works department, Feb., 1869; chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government of Madras, public works department, Nov., 1870; acted as chief engineer and secretary to government in 1875 and 1877; president, irrigation committee, famine commission, Oct., 1878, to Jan., 1879; on special duty for drawing up the Bangalore water supply scheme, Oct., 1883; services replaced at disposal of military department, in 1884.

MULOCK, Francis Berry, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W.
