Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty as assistant private secretary to lieutenant-governor on occasion of visit of H.R.H. Prince of Wales, Dec., 1875, to March, 1876; on special duty for arrangements connected with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, Nov., 1876; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Oct., 1883.

MULOCK, Henry Pilkington, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; from Feb., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and acted as deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, March, 1871; transferred temporarily to Bengal for employment on Behar famine relief works, Dec., 1873, to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885.

MULOCK, William Bury, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar of the high court, and assistant collector and magistrate; from April, 1873, to Nov., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of assurances in Sind, also as inspector of education, May-Nov., 1873, and was on various occasions in charge of the office of the commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Jan., 1880; acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, June, 1883; senior collector and magistrate, Nasik, March, 1885.

MUNRO, W. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1861; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

MURDOCH, David Doig, Madras C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate.

MURRAY, Thomas James, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1869; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1869; on famine relief work, Patna, May, 1874; served in Assam from Dec., 1875, as assistant commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, May, 1876; officiating inspector of schools, March-July, 1877; officiating secretary to the chief commissioner, July-Oct., 1877; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Jan., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1882; registrar of joint stock companies and inspector of registration offices, July, 1882; inspector-general of police and jails, superintendent of stamps, inspector-general of registration, and commissioner of excise, March, 1883.

MYLNE, Right Rev. Louis George, M.A., D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Arrived in July, 1876; installed as Bishop of Bombay, 6th July, 1876.

NANABHAI HARIDAS, LL.B. (Madras), Judicial Department, Bombay.—From May, 1873, served in the Bombay judicial department as acting judge of the high court, and government pleader; also acted as professor of law in the government law school, July to Dec., 1880, and in Feb., 1881; confirmed as judge of the high court, June, 1884.

NAPIER, Hon. George Campbell, C.I.E., Major, Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1861; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; on special duty, March, 1874, in Persia, and again, Feb., 1881, at Kandahar; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882, to Sept., 1883; judicial assistant, Feb., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; superintendent, Kapurthala State, April, 1885.

NARSINGRAO BHOLONATH DIVATIA, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, Jan., 1844, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

NASH, A. M., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th Jan., 1875; arrived, 31st March, 1875; served as professor, Presidency College, and as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 2nd class of the education department, April, 1883.

NAYLOR, James Richard, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Kaladgi, June, 1875; remembrancer of legal affairs, July, 1876; acting chief secretary to government, judicial, educational, political, secret, and sep-
rate departments, Oct., 1879, to March, 1880; additional member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1884; on special duty in connection with the Bombay municipal bill, June, 1885.

NEALE, WALTER ERSKINE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from Nov., 1867, to April, 1880, as settlement officer; district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1881; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Allahabad, Dec., 1881.

NEATHAM, A. H. J., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Feb., 1879.

NEEL, EDMUND, Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; India office writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, military department, 1860; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1868-1871; military department, 1871; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; funds department, 1874; assistant secretary in the military department, Aug., 1881; assistant secretary in the political and secret department, 1885.

NEILL, JOHN WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London, and Edinburgh University; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1864; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Jan., 1866; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Central Provinces, July, 1866; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, May, 1870, and acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, from June, 1870, to March, 1877, when he was confirmed in the appointment; also acted as inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise in 1872, and as inspector-general of education in 1873; commissioner, Nagpur Division, June, 1880; acting judicial commissioner, June, 1881, to March, 1882; fellow of the University of Calcutta, June, 1883; commissioner, Jubbulpore division, Oct., 1883.

NEILL, LINDSAY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools, King's College, London, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1867; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector-general of education in 1874, and as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Oct., 1874, to Oct., 1876; under secretary to government of India, home department, April, 1877; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Dec., 1877; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, June, 1880; acting inspector-general of police and prisons, June-Aug., 1881; acting commissioner, Nagpur division, April, 1882; additional commissioner, Jan., 1883; secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1883.

NELSON, JAMES HENRY, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1863; acted as small cause court judge of Madura, 1865-67; acting registrar of the high court, Madras, April, 1867; small cause court judge, Kumbakonam, Dec., 1867, to June, 1872; prepared the Madura district manual; from June, 1872, served as civil and sessions judge in Tanjore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, July, 1876, to March, 1880, and afterwards in South Arcot and Chingleput.

NESFIELD, JOHN C., M.A., Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—From 22nd Jan., 1867, to May, 1872, served in Bengal as professor, Krishnagarh College, and at the Presidency College; from May, 1872, served in British Burma as director of public instruction, and inspector of schools; transferred to Oudh, March, 1874, and served in the 2nd grade of education officers as director of public instruction; principal, Benares College, May, 1878; inspector of schools, Oudh division, Nov., 1879.

NETHERSOLE, WILLIAM, B.A., LL.M., Barrister-at-law, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Sutton Valence Grammar School and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1878, and served in the Central Provinces as supernumerary assistant commissioner; acted as cantonment magistrate in 1882, and as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1883; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1884; acting director of agriculture, July, 1884; acting junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1884; from Dec., 1884, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer of Sambalpur, March, 1885.

NEWBERY, FRANCIS MONRO, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 58th native infantry, 13th April, 1859; from February, 1867, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; city magistrate, Lucknow, March, 1874; on special duty in connection with agricultural meeting and exhibition at Lucknow, Dec., 1881; district judge, 3rd grade, sub. permanent, March, 1883; sub-judge, 1st grade, April, 1883; district judge, 2nd grade, Lucknow, May, 1885.

NEWBERY, HENRY JAMES, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1879.

NEWMAN, J. H., Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bengal Medical Establishment.—First commission in the Indian medical service, 1867; served in civil employ, in the political agency, Joudpore, from Sept., 1868; civil surgeon, Ajmere, May, 1879; officiated as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination, and administrative medical officer in Rajputana in 1884; is also superintendent of jail at Ajmere, and medical officer of the Mhairwarra battalion.

NEWMARCH, FRANCIS W., Military Department, India Office.—Matriculated at Balliol College, Oxford, Jan., 1873; scholar of Corpus Christi College, Oxford, 1873-8; 1st class in classics, moderations, May, 1874, and 1st class
in classics, final schools, Dec., 1876; B.A., Feb., 1877; junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1877; resident clerk, 1885.

NEWMARCH, Oliver Richardson, Colonel, B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, March, 1855; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, July, 1857; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, 1871; deputy accountant-general, military department, 1875; accountant-general, military department, April, 1878; is also ex officio deputy secretary to the government of India.

NEWTON, Henry, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury School, and afterwards at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; judicial assistant to commissioner, Satara, 1854; joint judge and sessions judge, Poona, 1858; and afterwards of the Konkan; acting sub-treasurer, Bombay, July, 1859; acting civil auditor, Aug., 1859; registrar, court of Sudder Dewani, Nov., 1859; acting puisne judge of the Sudder Court, Jan., 1860; member of commission to frame a code of laws for the Parsees, Dec., 1861; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1863; acted as chief justice, Bombay, 1868; retired in 1871.

NEWTON, J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

NICHOLLS, George Jasper, LL.B. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and was transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, May, 1874; acting secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1877; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, Dec., 1877; acting inspector-general of police, July, 1880; small cause court judge, Jubbulpur, Sept., 1880; deputy commissioner, 4th class, March, 1883; from July, 1883, served in the N.W. Provinces as officiating magistrate and collector, 1st grade, and was appointed manager of the Awa State, Oct., 1883; judge, 3rd grade, Ghazipur, April, 1885.

NICHOLSON, Frederick Augustus, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Medical College, Epsom, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty with the selection of forest reserves, Nov., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, July, 1883; principal assistant to the collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1883.

NICHOLSON, William Gustavus, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1872, as assistant engineer, Sirhind canal; transferred to military works branch, 1873; executive engineer, March, 1876; fortification branch of inspector-general's office, April, 1882; secretary to defence committee; superintending engineer, Aug., 1884.

NISBET, Robert Parry, C.I.E., Major, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from Aug., 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Nov., 1876; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, April, 1885, Rawalpindi.

NOBLE, Charles Simeon, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bengal native infantry, 14th Nov., 1858; from April, 1862, to June, 1866, served in the police department, Oudh, as assistant district superintendent, officiating assistant inspector-general, and district superintendent; from June, 1866, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate of Fyzabad, officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, and officiating deputy commissioner; secretary to committee appointed to conduct the agricultural meeting, Lucknow, Aug., 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Bara Banki, Oct., 1883.

NOLAN, Philip, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Stonyhurst School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; on special duty at Darjeeling, Aug., 1875, and again, in the stamp and stationery office, Nov., 1879; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Shahabad, Sept., 1884; officiating secretary, board of revenue, March, 1885.

NORMAN, Sir Henry Wylie, K.C.B., C.I.E., B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal Army, March, 1844; deputy assistant adjutant-general, Pesha-wur, Aug., 1853; assistant adjutant-general of the army, May, 1856; deputy adjutant-general, Dec., 1857; secretary to government of India in the military department, 1862-70; military member of governor-general's council, Jun., 1870-76; member of council of secretary of state for India, Feb., 1878, to Nov., 1883; governor of Jamaica, 1883.

NORMAN, Thomas, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, April, 1881.

NORRIS, J. F.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1882.

NORTON, David, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

NUGENT, John, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Institution School, Liverpool, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant educational
inspector; appointed under secretary to government of Bombay in the judicial, political, and educational departments, and secretary to the legislative council, Feb., 1875; also acted on several occasions as secretary in the revenue, financial, and general departments, as collector of salt revenue, July, 1878, and as secretary in the political, secret, judicial, educational, and Persian departments, Feb.-March, 1879; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Feb., 1881; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Satara, May-June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as secretary to government in revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Dec., 1882; also acted as chief secretary to government in 1884 and 1885; president of the central committee for vernacular departmental examinations.

NUGENT, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Stonyhurst College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872, and served in Bengal, and from Jan., 1880, in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector.

NUNDA KRISHNA BOSE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Employed in the education department from Aug., 1878; appointed under the native civil service rules, and served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, from Jan., 1880, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, Sept., 1881.

NURSEY, J. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 26th July, 1871; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878; attached to financial department.

OAKESHOTT, JONATHAN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at City of London School and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

OBARD, ROBERT, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces Commission).—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1873; from 7th Jan., 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; transferred for special famine duty in the Madras presidency, Sept., 1877, to July, 1878; acted as judge of the small cause court, and superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubbulpore, in 1882.

O'BRIEN, EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Colomba's College, Winchester College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, March-Dec., 1871; promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

O'BRIEN, PETER HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Malvern College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1882.

O'CALLAGHAN, FRANCIS L., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, June, 1862, as assistant engineer, Central Provinces; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to the railway branch, 1870; Nagpur and Raepur railway survey, March, 1871; engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, June, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, Pindi-Peshawur section, Nov., 1879; superintending-engineer, Jan., 1880.

O'CALLAGHAN, I., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1873; traffic superintendent Rajputana state railway, Dec., 1874.

O'CONNOR, J. E., Financial Department, Government of India.—Registrar, department of agricultural and commerce, June, 1873; assistant secretary in statistical branch of department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary, department of finance and commerce, and in 2nd class of financial department, Dec., 1879; deputed on special duty in connection with the International Exhibition at Melbourne, July, 1880, to Feb., 1881.

O'DONNELL, CHARLES JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Ignatius' College and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, June, 1874; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, July, 1884.

O'FARRELL, HORACE HANDLEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, and acting additional sessions judge.

OGILVIE, GEORGE MACARTNEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1883.

O'KINEALY, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Nov., 1862, to Sept., 1874, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of survey, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector; appointed additional sessions judge of Bhagulpore, Sept., 1874, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, May, 1875; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, Dec., 1877; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan., 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, Feb., 1880; judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, Feb., 1883; president of the board of examiners, April, 1885.
OLDFIELD, RICHARD CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1848; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed in charge of the office of assistant superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1855, and appointed assistant secretary to government, and assistant accountant, N.W. Provinces, March, 1856; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, March, 1864; on special duty at Cawnpore for enquiring into the case of the Dewan of Chirkhari, Feb., 1866; on special duty under the public works department, Feb., 1866; on special duty for investigating the charges brought against Mir Badshah, Munshi of Deoband, March, 1869; from May, 1869, served in the judicial department, and was appointed civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872, and subsequently of Allahabad; additional judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1874.

OLDHAM, FRANCIS GEORGE, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1873, as officiating deputy controller of accounts, Calcutta; controller of accounts, Hyderabad, Aug., 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, March, 1878, and subsequently at Calcutta, 1879; Central India, 1882; telegraph accounts, Calcutta, 1883; examiner, 3rd class, in the accounts establishment, June, 1884.

OLDHAM, WILLIAM BENJAMIN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1879, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; on famine relief duty, Oct., 1866, and again March, 1874, and at Bellary, March, 1877, to Feb., 1879.

OLIPHANT, HENRY LAURENCE, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; from July, 1859, served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner; judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, April, 1877.

OLIPHANT, JOHN S., Funds Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd June, 1853; junior clerk, minuting branch, 1855; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1857–58; India office, secretariat department, 1859; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1863 to 1865; senior clerk, funds department, April, 1866; assistant secretary, military department, 1872, but continued doing duty in funds department; also agent to administrators-general of India, 1877; acting judicial and public secretary for four months, 1879; director of funds, 22nd July, 1879.

OLLIVANT, ALFRED, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department (North-Western Provinces).—Arrived in India as ensign, 20th April, 1857; appointed to Jhansi military police, July, 1858; from May, 1861, served as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, July, 1882; deputy inspector-general, June, 1885.

OLLIVANT, EDWARD CHARLES KAYLL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant agent in special charge of Sachin state, and was in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Sept.–Oct., 1875; acting junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Surat, April, 1878; on special duty at Baroda in connection with estate of Mir Zulfikar Ali, Jan., 1879; assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration in Sind, and Sindhi translator to government, Sept., 1880; also deputy superintendent of census in Sind, Jan., 1881; municipal commissioner for Bombay, May, 1881; on special duty in England in connection with the municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug-Nov., 1883.

OMMANNEY, EDWARD LACON, Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 12th June, 1855; assistant to commissioner in charge of ex-king of Delhi and state prisoners, Sept., 1857; took ex-king of Delhi and family to Rangoon, and served in Pegu commission, Oct., 1858, to April, 1859; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to commissioners of Derajat and Pesha-wur, and deputy commissioner; on special duty in Bengal, March, 1871, and again, April, 1871, at Patna, to give evidence in case of Queen v. Amir Khan; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Dera Ghazi Khan, Dec., 1883.

OMMANNEY, HENRY TRAVERS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, cantonment magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, acting political agent, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Oct., 1882.

OPPERT, GUSTAV, Ph.D. (Halle), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 14th Nov., 1872, as professor of Sanscrit, Presidency College, and curator of Government Oriental Manuscript Library; fellow of Madras University, April, 1873; Telugu translator to government, Sept., 1878; 3rd class of education department, March, 1882; officiating principal of Presidency College from May, 1885.

ORR, J. W., M.A. (Dublin), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 7th May, 1860, as acting deputy clerk of the crown, clerk to the chief justice, acting prothonotary and ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits and sealer of the high court, registrar of joint stock companies, and clerk of insolvent court; confirmed in appointment of prothonotary and ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, from Feb., 1866.

O'SULLIVAN, PATRICK (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in judicial department, Madras, from Oct., 1864, as law reporter, high court, acting clerk of the crown and crown prosecutor, and as professor of law, Presidency College, Jan., 1867, to Sept., 1870; assistant secretary to government, legislative
department, Feb., 1872; additional member of legislative council, Jan., 1877; fellow of Madras University, March, 1877; advocate-general, Madras, Jan., 1878; member of forest draft bill committee, May, 1882.

OTTLEY, JOHN WALTER, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, Feb., 1870, as assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal; assistant to chief engineer for irrigation, Punjab, March, 1872; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; personal assistant to superintending engineer, Bari Doab canal, Oct., 1872; assistant to chief engineer for irrigation, Bengal, Feb., 1874; executive engineer, Western Jumna canal, Jan., 1876; and subsequently on the inundation canals, Oct., 1876; attached to chief engineer's office, July, 1878; assistant secretary, irrigation branch, Punjab, Nov., 1878; superintendent of works, Bari Doab circle, April, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1884.

OWEN, E., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

OWEN, H. P., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 16th June, 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Rajputana, Feb., 1871; served also in Bangalore and Bellary; 2nd grade superintendent, Nagpur, April, 1880.

OWENS, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Aug., 1873.

OXENHAM, ROBERT G., M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1863, and served till Nov., 1874, as professor of English literature at the Deccan College, Poona, and subsequently as principal of the college, and professor of moral philosophy; also held acting appointments for various periods at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, as professor of English literature and history, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy, and as professor of history and political economy.

OZANNE, EDWARD CHARLES, M.R.A.C., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; on famine relief duty in Tirhoot, March-Oct., 1874, in Mysore, Oct., 1877, and in Káthiáwar, March, 1879; on duty in England at the Royal Agricultural College at Cirencester, Sept., 1882; director of agriculture in the Bombay Presidency, July, 1883.

PAGE, WILLIAM HUMPHREY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Nottingham Grammar School, and Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1882.

PAKEMAN, THOS. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 16th Oct., 1851; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, July, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872.

PALLE CHENTSAL RAO PANTULU, Superintendent of Stamps and Stationery, Madras.—Served from Feb., 1851, in various subordinate posts in the judicial and revenue departments, Madras; from July, 1859, to May, 1872, served as deputy collector, and as special assistant to the Inam commissioner, also as deputy collector of salt revenue, and was on special duty under the collector of Godavari, Aug.-Dec., 1870; Sheristadar, board of revenue, May, 1872; fellow of the Madras University, Nov., 1875; superintendent of stamps and stationery, July, 1882.

PALMER, ELWIN MITTFORD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, Nov., 1871; assistant to accountant-general, British Burma, Dec., 1873; transferred to Bombay, April, 1876; assistant to comptroller-general, Oct., 1878; served under the Egyptian government, Dec., 1878, to April, 1879; from Jan., 1880, served in Madras as officiating assistant accountant-general, and officiating deputy accountant-general; comptroller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1882; 4th class of financial department, Dec., 1882; assistant accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, Nov., 1884; assistant comptroller-general, Dec., 1884.

PARGITER, FREDERICK EDEN, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at College School, Taunton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1875; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, settlement officer in Chittagong, and commissioner of the Sunderbuns.

PARKER, ELWIN WOODDALL, Punjab Administration.—From 20th Oct., 1863, served in the Punjab as extra assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and officiating judicial assistant; extra judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Lahore, officiating as district judge.

PARKER, GEORGE ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Uppingham School and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Madura, March, 1878, and district and sessions judge, April, 1882, in the district of Kurnool, and subsequently in South Tanjore; officiating judge of the high court, Madras, July, 1885.

PARKER, JOSEPH, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; East India House writer, old establishment, 9th July, 1851; junior clerk, marine department, Aug., 1858; store department, 1860; senior clerk, Nov., 1866.

PARKER, WILLIAM HENRY, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed as temporary assistant engineer, 24th Aug., 1860, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, April, 1872; from Nov., 1873, served in the railway branch, and was employed on the Western Rajputana and Indus Valley state railways; transferred to Bengal, June, 1881, and employed temporarily on Central Bengal railway as superintending engineer, and subsequently on Singapore railway surveys as engineer-in-chief; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884.

PARKER, WILLIAM JACKSON, Lieutenant-
Colonel B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1858; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty with H.H. the Raja of Sirmoor, Dec., 1875, at Calcutta, and again, Dec., 1876, at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

PARRATT, CHARLES, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Clerk, London office, 1881.

PARRY, R., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 14th Jan., 1865; served as head-master, Krishnagur College and Hooghly College, professor at Hooghly College (March, 1868), and at Presidency College (Sept., 1874), inspector of schools (temporary), and officiating principal, Dacca College; 3rd class, education department, Aug., 1877; professor, Patna College, June, 1884.

PARSONS, HENRY JAMES (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1867, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant judge, and judge and sessions judge, and acted as judicial commissioner and judge of the Sadar court in Sind, in 1881-82; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Thana, Jan., 1884.

PARSONS, JAMES EDMUND BACON, Colonel, B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1849; from Feb., 1856, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 1st class, May, 1876.

PARTIDGE, WILLIAM REGINALD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, Sherborne School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1883, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

PATEKI SRINIVASA RAO, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in the judicial department from 16th Dec., 1844, as gumastab, Foudari translator, district munisif, and principal sudr amin; magistrate of police, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of Madras University, Nov., 1875; small cause court judge, Madras, April, 1880; board of examiners, 11th Jan., 1882.

PATTERSON, ALEXANDER BLEAKLEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Belfast Royal Academical Institute and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant magistrate and collector; from June, 1869, to April, 1883, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1882; on special duty in the settlement department, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Allahabad, Dec., 1883; acting commissioner of Northern India salt revenue, Agra, June, 1885.

PATTLE, A. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

PAUL, ALFRED WALLIS, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; on special settlement and survey duty, Aug., 1878, and again, Nov., 1881; services placed temporarily at the disposal of the public works department, Nov., 1883; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1884.

PAUL, GREGORY CHARLES, B.A., C.I.E.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1862-78; advocate-general, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1878; legislative council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, March, 1885.

PEACOCK, FREDERICK BARNES (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed registrar, high court, May, 1864; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1870; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1873; commissioner, Dacca division, April, 1878, and of the Presidency division, May, 1881; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointments departments, March, 1883.

PEACOCK, HENRY PHIPSON, Lieutenant-Colonel, Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal cavalry, Sept., 1856; adjutant, governor-general's body guard, 1860; commandant of the body guard, 1875; political agent, Moorshedabad, 1879; political agent, Ulwar, Rajputana, 1882; graded as political agent, 2nd class.

PEARSE, HERBERT GEORGE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1883.

PEARSON, CHARLES, M.A., Educational Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab educational department from March, 1861, as professor and principal, Agra College; inspector of schools, Rawal Pindi circle, Nov., 1865; 2nd grade, educational department, April, 1870; officiating director of public instruction in 1873, 1876, and 1883; on special duty with education commission, 1882.

PEARSON, FRANCIS BOYLE, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; attached to the N.W. Provinces; served in various districts in the grades of assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector and civil and sessions judge; also as settlement officer, Jullundur, 1849-50, and as registrar to the court of Sudder Dewanni and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1850-53; judge of Sudder Dewanni and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1862-66; puisne judge, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1866-81; retired March, 1881.

PEDDER, WILLIAM GEORGE, C.S.I., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Departments, India Office.—B.A. of Exeter College, Oxford, 1854; appointed to Bombay civil service after open
competitive examination, 1855; arrived in India, 8th Oct., 1856, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; on special duty under the revenue commissioner for alienation, Feb., 1859; assistant settlement officer, March, 1860; on special duty as president, Guzerat Wutun commission, Sept., 1864; superintendent, revenue survey, and assessment, Jan., 1867; on special duty to reorganise the salt department, Dec., 1869; officiating commissioner, Nagpur, Central Provinces, Sept., 1871, to Dec., 1872; municipal commissioner, Bombay, June, 1873; acting secretary to government of Bombay in the revenue, general, and financial departments, May, 1875; junior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1877; on special duty to organise the licence tax, April, 1878; commissioner of customs, salt, and opium; retired, 1879; appointed secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India Office, June, 1879.

PEDLER, A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed to the education department, 22nd Jan., 1873; arrived 8th May, 1873, and served in the 3rd class of the department as professor of agricultural chemistry, Presidency College; on special duty, eclipse expedition, March, 1875; officiating principal, Presidency College, July, 1883; is also officiating meteorological reporter to government of Bengal, and officiating secretary to the central committee for management of the Economic Museum.

PEET, HENRY JOHN, Major, General List Infantry, Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1866; arrived in India, 2nd Oct., 1866; served under the military department till Oct., 1866, from which date he served in the Assam commission, and was appointed officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1875, and officiating secretary, Jan., 1876; acting inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, and commissioner of excise, and superintendent of stamps, June, 1881, to Feb., 1882; promoted to deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1883.

PEILE, JAMES BRAITHWAITE, M.A., C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 8th Oct., 1856, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty, alienation department, Nov., 1858; on special duty for inquiry into claims of Thakurs of Bhavnagar on account of land and sea customs, May, 1859; especially appointed to inquire into condition of Talukdars, Ahmedabad, Jan., 1860; alienation settlement officer, Gujarat, April, 1861; assistant to revenue commissioner, Dec., 1861; under secretary to government of Bombay, revenue department, April, 1862; on special duty for carrying out provisions of bill for relief of the Talukdars, Ahmedabad, Dec., 1862; commissioner for revising subordinate civil establishments, April, 1866; registrar-general of assurances, July, 1866; director of public instruction, April, 1869; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, May-Oct., 1872; acting political agent, Kathiawar, Jan., 1873; on duty at Delhi in connection with Imperial assemblage, Dec., 1876; acting commissioner in Sind, June, 1878; on special duty as member of famine commission, Aug., 1878, to March, 1879; acting secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, March, 1879; from April, 1879, served as secretary in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and acted as chief secretary; on special duty on famine commission in England, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; on special duty in India, Nov.-Dec., 1880, and in June, 1881, at Simla; member of council, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acted as governor and president in council in March, 1885.

PEMBERTON, ROBERT CHARLES BOILEAU, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 1853; joined the public works department, May, 1857, and served in the road department, Oudh, as executive engineer; assistant secretary to government of India, public works department, March, 1865; officiating superintending engineer, railway branch, Hyderabad, Sept., 1879; director of stores, railway branch, May, 1877; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, 1880; chief engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1884.

PEMBERTON, WILLIAM WALKER, Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, July, 1853; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1853; served in the Burma commission from Dec., 1859, as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner (May, 1873), small cause court judge, and boundary officer; 1st grade deputy commissioner, Jan., 1882.

PENNINGTON, HENRY FRANCIS DUMARESQ, Bengal C.S. (Oudh).—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; officiating sub-judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, April-July, 1881.

PENNINGTON, JAMES BURN, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Sedburgh Grammar School and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from May, 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, sub-secretary and acting secretary to the board of revenue, and acting collector of sea customs at Madras and protector of emigrants; on special duty at Madras with the public works committee, Feb., 1869; acted as collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, Aug., 1872, to April, 1875; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, July, 1875; member of commission of special inquiry on emigration matters, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate and political agent, Tanjore, Sept., 1884.

PENNY, JAMES CHAMPION, M.D., Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 3rd June, 1857; from Feb., 1863, served in the Punjab at various stations as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1869; brigade-surgeon, April, 1884.

PERKINS, ÆNEAS, Colonel, C.B., R.E., Public Works Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, 1851; served in the Bengal local public works department, April, 1861, to Aug., 1863, and subsequently in the Imperial public works department as executive engineer and acting superintending engineer, in Berhampore, Darjeeling, and Behar; commanding and field engineer with the Doora force, Jan., 1865; chief engineer, Bhootan field force, Aug., 1865; acting superintending engineer, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1870; from April, 1872, served in the military works branch as superintending engineer, and was posted to the Meerut command in Jan., 1879, and to the Rawal Pindi
command in March, 1881; was also on active service, Oct., 1878, as commanding engineer field force, Cabul, and in Oct., 1879, Kuram division; made C.B., 1879; aide-de-camp to the Queen, March, 1881; acting deputy inspector-general of military works, April-July, 1881; chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner, Central Provinces, public works department, Feb., 1883; chief engineer, 2nd class, July, 1884.

PERKINS, HENRY EDMUND, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856, and served in the Punjab, and temporarily in Oudh, as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, Dec., 1864; promoted to deputy commissioner, April, 1866; commissioner and superintendent, Amritsar, April, 1877, and afterwards in the Mooltan and Rawul Pindi divisions.

PERROTT, FINCH, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 24th Dec., 1880.

PETERSON, F. W., F.C.S., Mint Department, Calcutta.—Assistant in the bullion office, Calcutta mint; between Jan., 1869, and Oct., 1881, acted for various periods as deputy assay master at the Calcutta mint, and at the Bombay mint, and also as assay master at the latter mint; appointed deputy assay master, Calcutta mint, Oct., 1881; acting assay master, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883, and again in 1884.

PETERSON, FREDERICK WILLIAM VOYSEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Leicester Collegiate School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 7th Dec., 1863; from April, 1864, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Dec., 1877; from May, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1880.

PETERSON, HERBERT PARSONS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Loughborough Grammar School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

PETERSON, PETER, M.A. (Ed.), Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of oriental languages, Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as professor in the Deccan College, Poona, Oct., 1875-Nov. 1876; university registrar, Bombay, Jan., 1878; promoted to 3rd grade of the educational department, July, 1879; on leave to attend international oriental congress at Leyden, Aug.-Nov., 1883.

PETHERAM, SIR W. COMER, Kt., Q.C.—Took his seat as chief justice of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, 1st Nov., 1884.

PETLEY, E. W., Lieutenant, R.N.—Deputy conservator of the port of Calcutta, and river surveyor.

PETRE, FRANCIS LORAIN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oscott College and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Bareilly, April-Nov., 1880; junior secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1881; officiating under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Aug. to Nov., 1882; acting political agent 3rd class, Central India, 1885.

PETTY, A. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 16th July, 1883.

PEYTON, WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, March, 1851, and served in Madras on military duty till Jan., 1866, and subsequently as deputy conservator of forests; from Oct., 1870, served in the Bombay presidency as conservator of forests (2nd grade, Dec., 1883).

PHAYRE, ROBERT, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in Rangoon, 19th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating political assistant, and assistant resident at Mandalay; on special forest demarcation duty, Feb., 1881; on special duty at Rangoon, May, 1881; officiating deputy commissioner, April, 1883.

PHELPS, W. E., Store Department, India Office.—Supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, 17th June, 1884.

PHILIPPS, HERBERT REES, Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Trinity College, Cambridge; Porson (Greek) University prizeman, 1871 and 1872; B.A., 1873; M.A., 1877; junior clerk, General Post Office, 1867; junior clerk, correspondence department, India office, estates and will branch, 1868; transferred to public works department, 1869; statistics and commerce department, 1874; attached in 1876 to select committee on the depreciation of silver, and edited report of committee; transferred to military department, 1883; senior clerk, July, 1883; compiled Parliamentary papers, Nos. 8 to 16 of statistical abstract relating to British India, Nos. 13 to 16 of statement exhibiting the moral and material progress of India.

PHILLIPS, A. (Barrister-at-Law).—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, from 1871; standing counsel, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1880.

PHILLIPS, AUGUSTUS MARSHALL, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, June, 1855; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1855; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57; from March, 1863, served as assistant political superintendent, Savantvadi; assistant political agent, Mahi Kántha, Sádra, Gujarát, Feb., 1867; special assistant political agent in charge of estate of Gondal, Kathiáwar, July, 1872; acting superintendent of the Gaékwár's contingent, assistant in charge of Amreli Mahals, and superintendent, stud department, Kathiáwar, June, 1881; first assistant political agent, Kathiáwar, Sept., 1881; also acted as political agent, Kathiáwar, Cutch, and Mahi Kántha.

PHILLIPS, FRANCIS ANGELO THEODORE, Ben-
gal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1880, and served in the Central Provinces as supernumerary assistant commissioner, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; acting judge, small cause court, Nagpur, June, 1883; acting deputy commissioner, Sambalpur, June, 1884.

PHILLIPS, HENRY ARTHUR DEUTEROS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1874; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, Bellary, Aug., 1878.

PHILLIPS, HENRY DOMINIC, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service in 1829; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge, and was appointed junior deputy secretary, board of revenue, 1837; acted as registrar, Sudder Dewani and Foujdari Adawlut, 1842-43; sub-judge, Madura, 1846; agent to governor of Madras, at Kurnool, 1847; collector and magistrate, Salem, 1850; civil and sessions judge at Mangalore, and at Madura, 1857; collector and magistrate and resident commissioner at Tanjore, 1858; puisne judge, Sudder Dewani and Foujdari Adawlut, 1858; president of the board of examiners; commissioner for the affairs of the late Raja of Tanjore, 1859; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1862; provisional member of council of governor of Fort St. George, 1864; member of Madras council, 16th Dec., 1864; resigned the service, 12th Nov., 1869.

PIGOT, J. Q., B.A.—Advocate, high court, Bombay, 1870-82; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Bengal, 1882.

PIKE, HERBERT WATSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Honiton Grammar School, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; attached to the N.W. Provinces.

PILCHER, JESSE GRIGGS, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1860; officiating sanitary commissioner for Bengal, 26th April, 1875; officiating health officer for the port of Calcutta, April, 1876, to Feb., 1877; civil surgeon, Burdwan, June, 1876, and at Howrah, from Feb., 1877, with medical charge of the government engineering college, from April, 1880.

PILCHER, ROBERT HOPE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Boston Grammar School, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 14th Sept., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner till April, 1873, and subsequently in Burma as assistant commissioner, assistant resident at Mandalay (Nov., 1875), junior secretary to chief commissioner (June, 1877), and deputy commissioner (3rd grade, Jan., 1883); on special duty at Rangoon, Dec., 1881, and again Dec., 1882; on special duty with the Burmese embassy, April-Sept., 1882.

PINHEY, ARTHUR FRANCIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

PINHEY, ROBERT HILL (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Feb., 1851, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, joint judge and sessions judge, and registrar of the high court, Bombay; judge and sessions judge, Thana, Sept., 1863; acting judicial commissioner, and judge of the Sadar court in Sind, Nov., 1869, to June, 1871; judge and sessions judge, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, Poona, April, 1873; judge of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1875.

PITCHER, DUNCAN GEORGE, Major, B.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as cornet, Bombay light cavalry, 3rd Sept., 1859, having previously served in the royal marine light infantry and artillery, 1856-59; served under the military department till Aug., 1868, from which date he was employed in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow; small cause court judge, Lucknow, April, 1873, to March, 1882, also serving as officiating registrar, Lucknow, from Sept., 1873; member of commission appointed to inquire into the rights and privileges in Oudh forests, 1876; on special duty at Naini Tal, July, 1878; deputed to inquire into mortality statistics of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1878; on special duty under the government of India, revenue and agricultural department, March, 1882; assistant director of agriculture and commerce for Oudh, June, 1882.

PITTAR, CHARLES WILLIAM ERSKINE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dacca, Nov., 1884.

PLACE, GEORGE WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner.

PLANCK, CHARLES, F.R.C.S., F.S.S., Deputy Surgeon-General, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 21st Feb., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Fatehgarh, July, 1859; superintendent, central prison, Agra, Feb., 1862; inspector-general of prisons, British Burma, Oct., 1864; sanitary commissioner and compiler of mortuary returns, N.W. Provinces, April, 1868, also in Oudh, April, 1877; also superintendent-general of vaccination, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Aug., 1881.

PLANT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Colonel, M.S.C.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 9th June, 1855; served in the British Burma commission from March, 1860, as assistant magistrate of Rangoon, assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and officiated at various times as commissioner in the Arakan,
Pegu, Tenasserim, and Irrawaddy divisions; appointed commissioner, Tenasserim, Sept., 1883.

PLAYFAIR, ARCHIBALD LEWIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 7th native infantry, Bengal, Oct., 1856; superintendent of central jail and penitentiary, Hazareebagh, March, 1874; officiating cantonment magistrate, Necmuch, 1878; cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1879-84, and subsequently at Mhow.

PLOWDEN, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Feb., 1854; arrived in India, 28th April, 1854; served from May, 1860, in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, in 1867-68, and was appointed commissioner of excise, inspector-general of registration, and superintendent of stamps, Sept., 1880, and deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Nov., 1884.

PLOWDEN, GEORGE WARD CHICHELE, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Arrived in India, as cornet, Bengal light cavalry, 4th April, 1854; employed under the military department till Sept., 1874, from which date he served in the N.W. Provinces as cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, and subsequently of Meerut; promoted to 1st class cantonment magistrate, March, 1876.

PLOWDEN, H. M. (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Punjab.—Served in the Punjab from 17th March, 1871, as government advocate and officiating judge of the chief court; confirmed as judge, chief court, Jan., 1878.

PLOWDEN, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Nov., 1868; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, March, 1872, and Jan., 1873; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1873; inspector-general of police, Assam, Nov., 1876; on special duty as secretary to the prison conference, Jan., 1877; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Dec., 1878; resident, 2nd class, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, March, 1880; consul-general, Baghdad, June, 1880; commissioner of Ajmeer, sub pro tem.

PLOWDEN, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, C.I.E., Major, Gen. List B.I., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1859; from May, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; in attendance upon the Peshawur Darbaris to visit the Prince of Wales at Lahore, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; also district judge.

PLOWDEN, SIR WILLIAM CHICHELE, K.C.S.I., F.S.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1852; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1852; from Nov., 1853, served in the revenue and judicial department in the N.W. Provinces, Oudh, and Punjab, and was appointed deputy commissioner, Aug., 1858, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1863; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, July, 1864; on special duty in connection with the census report, April, 1866, and again, May, 1872; magistrate and collector, March, 1870; civil and sessions judge, March, 1877; on special duty at Calcutta as president of census committee, Jan., 1878; commissioner, Meerut division, Sept., 1879; officiating member, board of revenue, Aug., 1880; census commissioner for India, March, 1881; additional member, governor-general's council, Dec., 1881; retired, July, 1885.

POLLEN, ARTHUR DANIEL, B.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting remembrancer of legal affairs; on special duty as joint sessions judge at Surat, Aug., 1878; special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, Jan., 1880; and grade judge and sessions judge, Jan., 1884.

POLLEN, JOHN, B.A., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting railway magistrate; on famine relief duty, Dinagapore, Bengal, March, 1874; on special settlement duty, March, 1879; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, Dec., 1880; assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration and stamps in Sind, April, 1881; also Sind translator to government, Nov., 1881.

POLLOCK, GEORGE D., Store Department, India Office.—Examiner of surgical instruments, store depot, Oct., 1857.

PONTIFEX, CHARLES, Legal Adviser, India Office.—B.A., Trinity College, Cambridge, 1845; called to the bar, May, 1854; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, May, 1872; retired in 1882 on appointment as legal adviser to secretary of state for India.

POPE, J. VAN SOMEREN, M.A. (Cantab), Education Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 17th June, 1876, and served as professor at the Patna and Presidency Colleges, and as principal, Dacca College, Oct., 1881, and was promoted to 3rd class, education department, July, 1883; inspector of schools, April, 1884.

POPE, RICHARD RODNEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, April, 1885.

PORCH, REGINALD, LL.M., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 29th Nov., 1861; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1879.

PORTEOUS, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to
the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1879; and served in Assam as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner.

PORTEOUS, CHARLES ARKCOLL, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived, 26th Nov., 1856; served in the Madras police department from May, 1860, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; in charge of the Madras police at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Dec., 1876; deputy inspector-general, July, 1883.

PORTEOUS, WILLIAM, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and political agent; from Jan., 1874, to April, 1878, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner, acting town and cantonment magistrate, acting deputy commissioner, acting deputy inspector-general of police, July–Oct., 1876, and assistant sessions judge, Oct., 1877–March, 1878; from April, 1878, served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1879; acting collector of salt revenue, Bombay, July to Nov., 1881, and Feb.–Nov., 1882.

PORTER, ALEXANDER, Surgeon-Major, M.D., F.R.C.S.I., M.R.I.A., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1865, and served under the military department in the Central Provinces, also holding the civil surgeoncy of Akola, with charge of the jail, from May, 1866, to April, 1874, and acting as sanitary commissioner, Berar, 1870–71; from April, 1874, served in Madras, and acted as fort surgeon and professor of anatomy and physiology in the Medical College, and as chemical examiner to government, and professor of chemistry and hygiene, March, 1876, to Jan., 1877; surgeon-major, March, 1877; from Jan., 1877, served as surgeon, 4th district, Madras, and also as professor of medical jurisprudence in the Medical College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883.

PORTER, FORTESCUE WILLOUGHBY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Felstead Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1869, served in the settlement department, and was promoted to settlement officer, 3rd grade, April, 1877; officiating magistrate and collector, Benares, April, 1880; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1881.

PORTER, GEORGE EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Felstead Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; from June, 1863, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1874; also served as inspector of schools, Feb., 1866, to Nov., 1868, and deputy commissioner, wards' estate, Patna, May, 1874, to April, 1875; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge; and was promoted to 1st grade, Sept., 1884; officiated as judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, from March, 1884.

PORTER, JOHN SINCLAIR, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from June, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputy commissioner, Lalitpur, Oct., 1874; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Jhansi, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, April, 1877; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1879.

PORTER, LESLIE ALEXANDER SELIM, M.A., LL.D., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1878, to Jan., 1883.

PORTMAN, AUGUSTUS BERKELEY, Major, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 11th April, 1860, and was employed on military duties till May, 1866, and subsequently served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and superintendent of railway police on the Bombay, Baroda and C.I. and Great Indian Peninsula Railways; on special duty, Bombay, Feb.–March, 1874; acting inspector-general of registration and stamps, March to June, 1879, and March, 1880, to Sept., 1883; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, Jan., 1885.

POSFORD, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1883.

POULTON, HENRY D., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 26th Dec., 1873.

POWER, AMBROSE WILLIAM BUSHE (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated in Germany and at Kingstown School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, deputy commissioner and political agent, Hill Tipperah; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Lohardugga, January, 1880.

POWER, GUY FRANCIS THOMAS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting principal assistant; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Oct., 1884; additional sessions judge in the agency tracts of Vizagapatam, May, 1885.

POWLETT, PERCY WILLIAM, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—
Ensign, 58th native infantry, Bengal, April, 1855; assistant commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1858; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Berar, 1865; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1868; political agent, 2nd class, and settlement officer, Ulwar, 1874; additional political agent, Kota, 1876; political agent for the Western Rajputana states, 1880; resident, Western Rajputana, 1882.

PRATT, JAMES, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen and London Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Oct., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, January, 1883.

PRENDERGAST, HEW LINDSAY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—1st commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1853, and served in Burma on military duty, and as executive engineer, Bassein, till Nov., 1854, and subsequently in Madras as assistant engineer; on military duty, Feb., 1855, to Nov., 1857; from Nov., 1857, served in the public works department as garrison engineer, Madras, district engineer, and acting deputy consulting engineer for railways, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, July, 1863; acting controller and auditor, public works accounts, Madras, Jan., 1864; acting consulting engineer for railways, April, 1870; on military duty, May, 1874, to May, 1876; superintending engineer, Oct., 1878; superintendent of works, presidency, July to Oct., 1880, and again in 1881; in charge of Buckingham canal, 1880; superintending engineer, 1st class, April, 1884.

PRENTIS, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, M.R.C.S., L.R.C.S., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th Jan., 1853; arrived in India, 25th June, 1853, and served under the military department; from March, 1864, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Mainpuri, June, 1864; officiating superintendent of Central Prison and Lunatic Asylum, Bareilly, 1866; transferred to Gorakhpur, March, 1869; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1870; superintendent of government observatory, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1873.

PRICE, JAMES CATARALL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; settlement officer, Midnapore, Dec., 1871; superintendent of survey, March, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, April, 1881.

PRICE, JOHN FREDERICK, Madras, C.S.—University of Melbourne; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from Oct., 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, and political agent for Pondicherry, April, 1878; collector and magistrate, Chingleput, Sept., 1878; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Madras, April, 1885.

PRIDEAUX, WILLIAM FRANCIS, Major, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1860; assistant political resident, Aden, 1866; officiated as political agent, Zanzibar, 1873-75; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1875; officiating political resident, Persian Gulf, 1876-79; political agent, Bhopal, 1879; officiating agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, Nov., 1880; officiating resident, Eastern Rajputana states, Feb., 1882; agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent, political pensions, Calcutta, Jan., 1883.

PRIEST, HENRY HALSTED, Bengal C.S.
