(Central Provinces).—Educated at the Real-Schule, Marburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd December, 1879, and served in the Central Provinces as supernumerary assistant commissioner, and acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1883, to May, 1884; acting political agent, Bhownani Patna, June-Sept., 1884; acting deputy commissioner, Bhandara, Sept., 1884; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1885.

PRIMROSE, ARTHUR JOHN, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1875; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Nov., 1879, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner.

PRINGLE, ROBERT KEITH, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1820; arrived in India, 1821, and served in the Bombay revenue department; superintendent of revenue survey and assessment of the Deccan, 1826; first assistant to collector of Ahmednugger, 1831; sub-collector and magistrate, Sholapur, 1831; acting deputy civil auditor and deputy mint-master, 1838; collector and magistrate, and political agent, Khandeish, Dec., 1840; secretary to government, Bombay, general department, June, 1843; revenue commissioner, July, 1843; chief secretary to government, Bombay, revenue and finance departments, government director of the bank of Bombay, and master of the mint, April, 1846; acting member of council, Bombay, April, 1846; chief commissioner of Sind, July, 1847; resigned, Feb., 1851.

PRINSEP, CHARLES C., Statistics and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Warfield and Wimbledon; with a mercantile firm in Calcutta, 1843 to 1846; assistant traffic manager on the Great Western Railway, 1846-49; appointed a writer in the East India House, 16th Jan., 1853; junior clerk, treasury department, 1850; examiner's office, 1854; statistical department, 1855; assistant secretary, July, 1857; statistics and commerce department, 1874; statistical reporter and keeper of the records, 1879 (the latter office being transferred to the registrar, Jan., 1884); compiler of the annual statistical abstract from 1867-74, and again from 1880, also of the annual trade and
navigation statement for India, commencing 1869-70; author of the moral and material progress report of India for the years 1866-67 and 1867-68; compiled the record of services of Madras civilians, 1741-1858.

PRINSEPE, HENRY THOBY, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Nov., 1856; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1860; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1861; registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, February, 1862, and subsequently of the high court, Nov., 1863; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1866; officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, May, 1866; served in the judicial department from April, 1873, as district and sessions judge, and officiated as judicial commissioner of Mysore, March, 1875, to July, 1876; 1st grade district judge, Sept., 1875; judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, Aug., 1878.

PRITCHARD, CHARLES BRADLEY, C.S.I., Bombay, C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 24th Jan., 1858, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty at Poona for investigating frauds committed by subordinates in the public works department, Oct., 1870, to Oct., 1871; collector of salt revenue, Bombay presidency, Feb., 1873; on special duty in Madras as president of the salt commission, Jan.-Sept., 1876; on special duty to submit a scheme for the working of the abkari system, May, 1877, to March, 1878; commissioner of customs, opium, abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, April, 1881; 1st grade commissioner and commissioner of salt revenue, Oct., 1882.

PROPERT, WILLIAM HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate and political agent; from Feb., 1876, served as collector and magistrate and political agent, Khandaipur; senior collector, Sept., 1877; also acted as commissioner, northern division, April, 1883; and was on special duty, Poona, July-Oct., 1883.

PUCKLE, RICHARD KAYE, C.I.E., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School and Haileybury College; entered the Madras civil service in 1851, and was appointed deputy director of revenue settlement in 1859; collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, 1866; director of revenue settlement, 1874, and member of board of revenue, 1879; was engaged for 22 years in preparing data for the reassessment of the lands and for the revision of government establishments in the ryotwari villages of Madras; published a handbook on revenue matters and the duties of village officers; was specially employed in the distressed districts in famine of 1877; C.I.E., 1878; retired in 1881.

PULFER, J. W., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 3rd Aug., 1865; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; India store depot.

PULLAN, AVTON, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Arrived in India, 29th April, 1856; first commission as ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; served under the military department till April, 1862; officiating assistant political agent and bazar master, Morar, April-June, 1862; joined the great trigonometrical survey as 2nd assistant, Jan., 1863; acted as deputy superintendent from Dec., 1871, and was appointed to the charge of the Kathiawar survey, April, 1873; deputy superintendent, and grade, Nov., 1884.

PUNNETT, HENRY BEATSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Falmouth Grammar School and Boston Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun.

PURSER, WILLIAM EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at various schools and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was placed on special duty, May and Dec., 1879; senior settlement officer and deputy commissioner of settlement, Jullundur, Sept., 1880.

PUTNAM, P., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 28th July, 1881.

PYCROFT, SIR THOMAS, K.C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School and Trinity College, Oxford, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1828; served in various offices in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from 1829 to 1830; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, Madras, 1843-44; secretary to the board of revenue, 1845-50; secretary to government of Madras in the revenue and judicial departments, 1850-55; chief secretary to government of Madras, 1855-62; member of Madras council, 1862 to 1867, in which year he retired from the service.

QUINN, CHARLES CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 8th Jan., 1864; from Nov., 1864, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1884.

QUINN, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from April, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate, and was appointed deputy commissioner, Oudh, April, 1877, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Ballia, Dec., 1881; commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1884.

QUINTON, JAMES WALLACE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces from Oct., 1857, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; served in Oudh from March, 1865, to April, 1875, as deputy commissioner, and officiated as commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1869; officiating judicial commissioner, British Burma, April, 1875, to March, 1877; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, April, 1877; officiating civil and sessions...
judge, April, 1878; on special duty at Naini Tal as member of N.W. Provinces famine commission, July, 1878; commissioner, Jhansi division, April, 1880, and Lucknow division, Feb., 1882; additional member of governor-general's council, Feb., 1883.

RAIKES, CHARLES, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, Sept., 1831; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner; settlement officer of the unsettled estates in Benares, June, 1839; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Farakhabad, 1843, and afterwards of Mainpuri; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, 1849; commissioner, Lahore division, 1854; judge of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, 1858; retired in 1860.

RAJANINATH RAY, M.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, and was attached to the office of the comptroller-general, Nov., 1872; served in the Central Provinces, May, 1874, to Jan., 1876, and afterwards in Bombay as assistant to the commissioner of paper currency, and assistant to the accountant-general; officiating assistant comptroller-general, Nov., 1882.

RAJENDRA CHANDRA CHANDRA, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; from July, 1863, served as civil assistant surgeon, also officiating as sub-assistant commissioner, Deogurh, from July, 1864; surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; officiating civil surgeon, July, 1874; professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex-officio 2nd physician to the College Hospital, Feb., 1875; in charge of duties of surgeon to the mint and officers of the customs preventive service, Jan., 1878; also medical inspector of emigrants, May, 1881.

RAMESHAWARA SING KUMAR, Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal from March, 1878; confirmed in his appointment in the Bengal civil service, March, 1881.

RAMPINI, ROBERT FULTON, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy, Institution, and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 28th Nov., 1864; from July, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1880, district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, July, 1880, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, April, 1883; also served as officiating inspector of schools, Sept., 1873.

RAND, WALTER CHARLES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884.

RATTON, JAMES JOSEPH LOUIS, Surgeon-Major, M.D., M.C., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 16th April, 1868; served in the Abyssinian expedition, and in various military medical charges, also as civil surgeon, Central Provinces, 1869-70; on special duty for the board of revenue, Madras, in connection with salt manufacture, from Jan., 1872, to Nov., 1876 (including one month in South of France); in medical charge of east coast canal, famine relief works, Dec., 1876; Zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail, Chittoor, April, 1877; surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; acting president, board of medical examiners, Oct., 1884; surgeon, General Hospital, Madras, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery in the Medical College, Feb., 1885.

RAVENCROFT, EDWARD W., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at King Henry VIIith Grammar School, Ottery St. Mary, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1851; arrived in India, 25th May, 1851; served as assistant collector and magistrate at Surat and Ahmedabad, and was placed on special duty under the settlement officer in Guzerat to inquire into alienations, Oct., 1855; was specially appointed acting collector and magistrate of Surat in 1860, to carry out provisions of income tax law; inspector-in-chief under the Cotton Frauds Act, Bombay, Feb., 1864; president of the municipal commission, Bombay, June, 1864; officiating chief secretary to the government of Bombay, in the revenue, financial, and general departments, 1864, and acted in that appointment at intervals till 1877, when he was confirmed in the same; collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, March, 1868; additional member of council, Bombay, March, 1871, and again, March, 1873; collector of salt revenue, Oct., 1871; senior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, Dec., 1871, and subsequently of Colaba; on special duty as member of the Baroda commission to investigate the charges brought against the Gaekwar; member of governor's council, Bombay, April, 1879; retired, March, 1884.

RAWLINS, THOMAS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; from Jan., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; small cause court judge and subordinate judge, Allahabad, Nov., 1872; from March, 1877, served under the government of India in the financial department as officiating accountant-general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1880; also held substantively, while officiating in the Punjab, the posts of assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, and deputy accountant-general, Madras; officiated as accountant-general, 1st grade, and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, from March, 1885.

RAWLINSON, SIR HENRY CRESWICKE, Major-General, K.C.B., F.R.S.—Educated at Ealing School; served in the Bombay army, 1827 to 1833 and in Persia from Nov., 1833, to Dec., 1839; major in Persia, 1836; political agent at Kandahar, June, 1840; political agent in Turkish Arabia, 1843; consul, Bagdad, March, 1844; military C.B and K.L.S., 1st class, 1844; consul-general 1851-55; lieutenant-colonel in Turkey, 1851; director of the East India Company and civil K.C.B., 1856; retired from Indian service as lieutenant-colonel, 1856; member of the council of India, Sept., 1858, to April, 1859, when he was sent as envoy to the court of Teheran with local rank of major-general; member for Reigate in the liberal interest, Feb.-Sept., 1858, and for Frome, 1865-68; reappointed to the council
of the secretary of state for India, 1868; is hon. D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Cambridge and Edinburgh, a chevalier of the 'Order of Merit' in Prussia, and corresponding member of the French institute, and academy of Munich, &c.; author of various papers on the antiquities of the east, and on the interpretation of the cuneiform inscriptions of Persia, Assyria, and Babylonia, in the journals of the Geographical and Asiatic Societies; also of 'England and Russia in the East; a series of papers on the Political and Geographical Condition of Central Asia,' 1875; appointed a trustee of the British Museum, March, 1878.

RAWSON, EDWARD CRESWELL, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate.

RAYE, DANIEL O'CONNELL, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1866; from 1st Sept., 1875, served as first resident surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, also acting as civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, and as surgeon-superintendent of the General Hospital, Jan., 1877, and held temporary medical charge of the Alipore and Russa jails, Nov., 1879; officiating professor of surgical and descriptive anatomy, Medical College, and ex officio surgeon to the College Hospital, Jan., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, May, 1881; also medical examiner of candidates for the public service, Feb., 1880; officiating professor of surgery, Medical College, and ex officio surgeon, College Hospital, May, 1884.

REDFERN, THOMAS ROBERT, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 2nd Oct., 1870; served in Oudh, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1870; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1872; officiating settlement officer, Kheri, Oct., 1875; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1881; also served as officiating district and sessions judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate, 1st grade, May, 1885.

REED, J. H. F., Accounts Department, India Office.—B.A., London University; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

REES, FREDERICK WILLIAM JOSEPH, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Jan., 1863; from Oct., 1863, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, July, 1869; officiating collector of income tax, Sept., 1871; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, April, 1878; from Dec., 1882, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge; 1st grade, Jan., 1885.

REES, JOHN DAVID, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy registrar of the high court, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from April, 1882, to Dec., 1884, served in the Madras secretariat as assistant secretary in the judicial and legislative departments, under secretary in the revenue department, Telugu and Tamil translator to government, acting private secretary to the governor (July-Oct., 1884), and acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department; from Dec., 1884, to March, 1885, served in Mysore as acting civil and sessions judge; served subsequently in Madras as under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department.

REEVES, HENRY NICHOLAS, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 6th Feb., 1857; from Jan., 1861, served as assistant political agent, Cutch; on special duty, Mahi Kantha, Oct., 1862; assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha, Jan., 1863; acting railway magistrate, Poona, Sept., 1865; assistant resident, Baroda, Aug., 1866; on special duty for settlement of boundary disputes on Khandeish and Gaekwar's frontiers, March, 1867; in charge of Amreli, and acting superintendent of Gaekwar's contingent, and acting remount agent, Baroda, June, 1867; between May, 1871, and April, 1879, acted as political superintendent of Savantvadi, assistant political agent in Kolhapur and Southern Maharrata country and in Kathiawar in charge of the Gondal state, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Cutch, and Mahi Kantha, and was on special duty at Delhi, Nov., 1876; appointed political agent, Cutch, April, 1879; political agent, Kolhapur and Southern Maharrata country, Sept., 1881.

REID, GEORGE BOILEAU, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to take up land for the Khadakvasla lake, Oct., 1866; first assistant collector, July, 1878; on special duty as settlement officer at Baroda, June, 1879, and Sept., 1882.

REID, JAMES ROBERT, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1860; from Aug., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating deputy commissioner in Oudh; from Aug., 1868, to April, 1877, served as assistant settlement officer, and settlement officer, Azamgarh; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1878; member of committee for considering revised rules for Patwaris and Kanungos, Nov., 1880; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1883.

REID, JOHN WILLIAM (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served from July, 1856, in the revenue and judicial department, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; from June, 1869, served in the judicial department in the district of Malabar as civil and sessions judge; district and sessions judge, Coimbatore, Oct., 1884.

REILY, C. H. (Barrister-at-Law).—Advocate of high court, Calcutta; assistant secretary,
legislative department; sub pro tem. chief presidency magistrate, Calcutta, judge of the court for the trial of pilots, and judge of the court of survey for the port of Calcutta, in 1885.

REILLY, HENRY MAXWELL, Police Department, Bengal.—From May, 1858, to July, 1863, served as deputy magistrate and deputy collector; from July, 1863, served in the police department, and was appointed district superintendent, 1st grade, Dec., 1882; on special duty, Garo Hills expedition, Nov., 1872.

RENDELL, ALAN WOOD, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, March, 1874; joined the department as locomotive superintendent, Northern Bengal state railway, 8th Nov., 1877; surveyor of government steamers of the Northern Bengal and Tirhoot railways; locomotive superintendent of north-eastern system of state railways, June, 1881; class I, grade 3, of state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1882; locomotive superintendent, Eastern Bengal state railway, July, 1884.

RENNICK, ALBERT DE CLANCY, Major, B.S.C.—First commission, 6th July, 1864; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1866; from Oct., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating cantonment and camp magistrate; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, Dec., 1880.

RENNIE, JOHN GEORGE MACKWORTH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1881, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and also in the settlement department.

REPTON, HERBERT MILLS, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd June, 1854; from May, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on famine duty, 1870; from July, 1877, served in the Central Provinces, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1883.

REYNOLDS, EDWARD SWATMAN, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department.—Joined the service (Bombay infantry), Oct., 1859; served with the Scinde horse, 1863-77; assistant to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, 1877; political agent in Pishin, 1882; political agent at Jacobabad, 1883.

REYNOLDS, HERBERT JOHN, C.S.I., B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1856; from March, 1857, to July, 1874, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, superintendent of survey, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, June, 1872); between 1874 and 1880 served as secretary to the government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, and as secretary to the board of revenue; additional member, governor-general's council, Jan., 1880, and again in 1882 and 1884; officiating member, board of revenue, June, 1880; officiating president, board of examiners, Dec., 1880; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1881; and again January, 1883; board of revenue, July, 1884.

REYNOLDS, HERBERT WILLIAM WARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; second assistant secretary to Government, July, 1880; junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883.

RHIND, ROBERT HUNTER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationer by the secretary of state, June, 1862; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1862; served as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent of works on the Upper Godavary works till Aug., 1872, when he was transferred to Bengal, and served in the Orissa, Sone, and South-Western circles; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1873; superintending engineer, class III, special, May, 1882.

RIBBENTROP, B., Forest Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state for India as an assistant conservator of forests, Dec., 1866; conservator of forests, Burma, Oct., 1876; 2nd grade conservator, Sept., 1882; transferred to Punjab, 1883; officiating inspector-general of forests, Feb., 1885.

RICE, WILLIAM GEORGE LEWIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oscott College, and Jesus College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

RICE, WILLIAM ROCHE, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Nov., 1856; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; civil assistant surgeon, Central Provinces, June, 1859; civil surgeon, Jubbulpore, May, 1871; acting assistant to sanitary commission, Central Provinces, July, 1872; superintendent, central jail, Jubbulpore, April, 1873; surgeon-major, Nov., 1876; civil surgeon and in medical charge of central jail, school of industry, and lunatic asylum, and superintendent, meteorological observatory, Jubbulpore, July, 1879; brigade surgeon, April, 1884.

RICHARDSON, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.B., B.A., Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 23rd Feb., 1860, and was employed under the military department up to 1866; from April, 1866, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and officiated as superintendent of the central and district jails at Agra, Farakhabad, and Allahabad; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1874; deputy sanitary commissioner and superintendent of vaccination, 3rd circle, Jan., 1879.

RICHEY, JAMES BELLOT, C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived 7th Dec., 1856, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, educational inspector, assistant revenue commissioner, officiating under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, talukdari settlement officer, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant to the agent and special commissioner at Baroda; on special duty in connection with the disturbances in the Ahmednagar and Poona districts, July, 1875; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, Jan., 1879; senior collector, May, 1880; on special duty at Khárághoda, Dec., 1883, and Feb., 1884, and at Baroda, Jan., 1884; acting and grade commissioner of customs, March,
1884; acting member of council, Bombay, March, 1885; chief secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, educational, and separate departments, May, 1885.

RICKETTS, GEORGE H. M., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1847; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and as assistant to the governor-general's agent, S.W. frontier; from 1853, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and from 1858 in the N.W. Provinces as magistrate and collector, and civil and sessions judge; C.B. for service in the Punjab in 1857, and medal for service with the troops; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1873; junior member, board of revenue, 1878; retired 1879.

RICKETTS, MONTAGUE POYNTZ, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, 22nd March, 1855; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1862; deputy commissioner, May, 1867; acting inspector-general of police, Nagpur, in 1876-77; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1880; acting commissioner of the Jubbulpore and Nagpur divisions successively, Dec., 1882, to Nov., 1883; additional commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1883; acting commissioner, Narbudda division, Aug., 1884.

RIDDELL, HENRY P. A. BUCHANAN, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1839; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces, 1845; director-general of the post office of India, 1854; during the mutiny organised the transport of European troops from Rangaeungee to Allahabad; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; retired 1867.

RIDDELL, HENRY VANSITTART, Colonel, Bengal infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1858; from July, 1865, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Lahore.

RIDDELL, ROBERT VANSITTART, Major, R.E., Mint Department, Calcutta.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1858; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, March, 1861; from Aug., 1862, served in the topographical survey of India as military assistant, and was employed in Gwalior and Central India, and in the Khasi and Garo Hills; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; assistant surveyor-general with charge of the mathematical instrument department and workshops, and of the lithographic branch, Calcutta, Oct., 1876; acted as mint master at Calcutta, July-Oct., 1881, and at Bombay, Oct., 1882, to Jan., 1883; appointed mint master, Calcutta, Jan., 1884.

RIDGEWAY, SIR JOSEPH WEST, Lieutenant-Colonel, K.C.S.I., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, 1860; on civil employ from 1870 in the Central India and Rajputana agencies; attache, foreign department, government of India, 1873; assistant agent to governor-general in Rajputana, 1875; acted as political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, from 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, 1878; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1879-81; junior under secretary, 1881; with the Afghan boundary commission, 1885.

RIGHY, VANS, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, Feb., 1856, and served in the Central Provinces, Punjab, and Bengal; Nizam's state railway surveys, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, March, 1871; on special duty, Nalhati state railway, Oct., 1874; from Jan., 1875, was employed on Tirhoot state railway, and was appointed manager and superintendent of way and works, Tirhoot and Patna Gya state railways, March, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, Feb., 1881; transferred to superior revenue establishment, 1st class, 3rd grade, Oct., 1882.

RILEY, H. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 31st April, 1882.

RISLEY, HERBERT HOPE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1873; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, Nov., 1876; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Oct., 1877; under secretary, revenue and general departments, Jan., 1878; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1880; served temporarily under railway branch, public works department, on special duty, Dec., 1882; superintendent of survey of Ghatwali and other service tenures in Manbhoom, Feb., 1884.

RITCHIE, JOHN GERALD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

RITCHIE, RICHMOND T. W., India Office.—Educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 18th May, 1877; revenue, statistics and commerce department, 1881; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1883.

RIVAZ, CHARLES MONTGOMERY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1870; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, May, 1874; under secretary to government, April, 1875; superintendent, Kapurthala state, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1885.

RIVAZ, GEORGE WILMOT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner and officiating cantonment
magistrate; from March, 1877, served in the judicial department as registrar, chief court.

RIVETT-CARNAC, CHARLES JAMES, Financial Department, Bengal.—Joined the financial department, 21st May, 1872; served in the N.W. Provinces till 1876 as assistant to the accountant-general, and officiated as personal assistant to the financial member of the governor-general's council, June, 1872; assistant to accountant-general, Punjab, Jan., 1876; officiating deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Aug., 1876; served again in the N.W. Provinces from March, 1878; officiating assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Oct., 1882; 4th class, financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant comptroller-general (in charge of forest branch), Oct., 1884; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1885.

RIVETT-CARNAC, JOHN HENRY, C.I.E., F.S.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1838; assistant magistrate and collector, May, 1860; officiating secretary to income tax committee, June, 1861; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Sept., 1861; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1862; settlement officer, Chandah and Wardha, Aug., 1864; cotton commissioner, Central Provinces, Sept., 1866, and Berars, April, 1867; commissioner of cotton and commerce with the government of India, Dec., 1871; member and honorary secretary of central committee of international exhibitions; on duty in England, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; special commissioner of transport, Bengal famine; opium agent, Benares, March, 1875.

ROBB, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.M. (Aber.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1868; from Nov., 1873, to July, 1882, served as civil surgeon, Zanzibar, and acted as assistant political agent, Oct., 1874, and Aug., 1881; from July, 1882, served under the government of Bombay, as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Aden and Surat; acting deputy sanitary commissioner, Sept.–Oct., 1883; civil surgeon, superintendent of lunatic asylum, and of the Medical School, Ahmedabad, April, 1884.

ROBERTS, ALLAN SCOTT, Major, Gen. List. B.I., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd April, 1862; from June, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884, Karnal.

ROBERTS, ARTHUR WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Gen. List. Cav., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal cavalry, July, 1859; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, 1864; officiated as political agent of the eastern states of Rajputana; cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1877; political agent, 3rd class, 1877; assistant to agent, Soojanghur, 1881; political agent, 2nd class, sub pro tem., 1882.

ROBERTS, DAVID THOMAS, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Liverpool, Liverpool Institute, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1883.

ROBERTS, SIR FREDERICK SLEIGH, Bart., Lieutenant-General, G.C.B., C.I.E., V.C., R.A.—First commission, Bengal artillery, 1851; assistant quartermaster-general of the army, Feb., 1863; deputy quartermaster-general, Jan., 1872; quartermaster-general, Jan., 1875; in command of Eastern Afghanistan force, 1879; appointed commander-in-chief, Madras, and member of governor's council, 18th June, 1881; commander-in-chief in India, and member of the governor-general's council, 28th Nov., 1885.

ROBERTS, R. P., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd Aug., 1873.

ROBERTS, THOMAS, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

ROBERTS, WILLIAM HOWLAND, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 24th Sept., 1858, and served in the Central Provinces till Sept., 1864, and subsequently in Madras as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Salem; acted as zillah surgeon, Coimbatore, July, 1866, to Jan., 1868; was also in charge of meteorological observatories at Coimbatore and Salem; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish liver oil factory, Calicut, Aug., 1869; surgeon-major, July, 1870; superintendent of lunatic asylum, Calicut, May, 1872; surgeon, and district, Madras, and health officer, and superintendent of lock hospital, April, 1881; brigade surgeon, June, 1885.

ROBERTSON, CHARLES, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1856; served under the military department from Dec., 1856, up to May, 1874, and also as zillah surgeon, Masulipatam, Jan., 1862, to March, 1865; from May, 1874, served as zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail, Cuddalore.

ROBERTSON, D., Captain, M.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Aug., 1865; subaltern, 4th light cavalry, Madras, March, 1868; served from 1870 as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces; cantonment magistrate, Nusserabad, June, 1877, and political assistant, 1st class; officiating superintendent, Jhallawur, 1879; officiating assistant commissioner, Mhairwarra, 1880; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Indore, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, 1882; political agent, Bundelkund, 1885.

ROBERTSON, ELPHINSTONE POURTALES, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th March, 1851, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay to report on
abkári lands, March, 1868; senior collector and magistrate, Dhárwár, Jan., 1873; revenue and police commissioner, Nov., 1876; commissioner of the central division, Jan., 1878; commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1881.

ROBERTSON, FREDERICK ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 15th Dec., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the settlement department as assistant settlement officer; settlement officer, Rawalpindi, April, 1884.

ROBERTSON, JAMES CASAMAJOR, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; from Jan., 1856, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent, Dehra Dün, small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, Oct., 1871; officiating inspector-general of registration, and commissioner of excise and stamps, July, 1876; district and sessions judge, April, 1879; commissioner, Agra division, Jan., 1882, and subsequently of the Rohilkhund division, Feb., 1883.

ROBINSON, ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865; from Jan., 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1870; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Fyzabad, Nov., 1884.

ROBINSON, FRANK EDWARDS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dulwich College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and district forest officer.

ROBINSON, SIR WILLIAM ROSE, K.C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College in 1842; served as assistant to collector and magistrate, Canara, 1843 to 1847, and as head assistant, Malabar, 1847 to 1852, and visited and reported on the Laccadive Islands; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Madura, 1856-58; commissioner of police, Madras, 1858; inspector-general of police, 1861; served on police commission, Calcutta, 1860-61; board of revenue, Madras, 1869 to 1873, during which period he conducted for some time the duties of Inam commissioner; additional member of governor-general's council, 1871-72; member of Madras council, Dec., 1873; acting governor of Madras, April-November, 1876; presided as chairman of committee over the distribution of the lord mayor's famine fund, 1878; retired, 1878.

ROE, CHARLES ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; deputy commissioner, and class, Sept., 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawalpindi divisions, May, 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

ROGERS, ALEXANDER, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1845; served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department, and was appointed 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Broach, Oct., 1851, and afterwards at Ahmedabad, Oct., 1852; settlement officer, Guzerat, Nov., 1852; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, March, 1860, and afterwards at Surat; revenue and police commissioner, north division, April, 1865; member of council, Bombay, June, 1872; retired in 1878.

ROGERS, HENRY THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Dec., 1849; arrived in India, 23rd Aug., 1852; served in the public works department, Bengal, from 1853 to 1859, and subsequently in Madras as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and acted as comptroller of public works accounts, 1864, and as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Feb. to Aug., 1865; acting mint master, July, 1865; officiating superintending engineer, Sept.-Oct., 1870; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1872; principal, Civil Engineering College, April, 1871, to Jan., 1880; member of the committee for the management of the school of arts, March, 1877; from Nov., 1879, served as superintendent of revenue survey, Madras.

ROGERS, MALCOLM, W., Major, R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1865; assistant surveyor, great trigonometrical survey of India, July, 1866; served with the Quetta field force as survey officer, 1878-79; deputy superintendent of survey, July, 1882; assistant surveyor-general in charge of mathematical instrument office, and correspondence office, Calcutta, May, 1884; 3rd grade, deputy superintendent, Aug., 1884.

ROLLAND, ALEXANDER TULLOCH, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 11th May, 1856; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; deputy inspector-general of police, Feb., 1885.

ROMESH CHUNDER DUTT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Colootola Branch School, Calcutta, Presidency College, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884.

ROMESH CHUNDER MITTER, B.L.—Puiscne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1876.

RONSON, W. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, 1st Sept., 1873; clerk, 2nd class, Feb., 1879; attached to revenue, statistics, and commerce department; author of the report on sanitary measures in India annually presented to Parliament for the years 1878-79 to 1883-84 inclusive.

ROSE, EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Folkingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866;
arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1883.

ROSS, ALEXANDER, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Academy and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1836; served in the judicial and revenue departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of Dehra Dun, Jan., 1846; magistrate and collector, 1853; special commissioner, Farakhabad, Dec., 1857; civil and sessions judge, 1858; member of special commission for trial of Nawab of Farakhabad, 1859; commissioner of revenue and police, Agra division, May, 1859; judge of the Sudder court, N.W. Provinces, 1862; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, 1866; retired, Oct., 1871.

ROSS, EDWARD CHARLES, Colonel, C.S.I., Bombay S.C.—Ensign, 3rd European regiment, Bombay, May, 1855; assistant to political agent, Muscat, 1863-69; assistant political agent, Gwadar, 1869; political agent, Muscat, 1871; political resident, Persian Gulf, from 1873; graded as resident, and class.

ROSS, HERCULES GREY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; from April, 1858, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, city magistrate at Lucknow, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade; superintendent, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1869; officiating magistrate and collector, Benares, 1st grade, Nov., 1880, to March, 1883; officiating commissioner, Benares division, and agent to governor-general, March, 1883; on special duty, Dehra Dun, March, 1883; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Dehra Dun, Oct., 1883; commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1885.

ROSS, HENRY THOMAS, M.A., LL.B., Madras C.S.—Educated at Perth Academy and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting district and sessions judge; special assistant to the collector and magistrate, Malabar, Sept., 1884.

ROST, REINHOLD, LL.D., Ph.D., Librarian, India Office.—Educated at the Grammar School of Altenburg (1838-42), and the University of Jena (1842-46), where he graduated in 1847; came to London in the same year to continue his oriental studies; was appointed oriental lecturer at St. Augustine's Missionary College, 1851; secretary to the Royal Asiatic Society, Dec., 1863; librarian, India office, July, 1869; published in 1850 an essay on the Indian sources of the Burmese laws; edited (1862-65) Professor H. H. Wilson's selected works, H. B. Hodgson's essays (2 vols., 1880), and miscellaneous papers on Indo-China (2 vols., 1886); contributes articles on oriental philology to the 'Encyclopaedia Britannica' and the 'Athenæum.'

ROUSE, ROBERT, Brigade Surgeon, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; from May, 1869, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of jail in the Punjab; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879.

ROWE, F. J., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 15th June, 1870, and served as professor at Krishnagur, Dacca, and Hooghly Colleges, also as inspector of schools (Nov., 1876), and officiating principal, Krishnagur College (May, 1877); 3rd class, education department, Jan., 1878; professor, Presidency College, July, 1880.

ROWLANDS, PERCY J., Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1858; assistant to registrar, June, 1877.

ROYLE, JOSEPH R. F. I., India Office.—Educated at King's College School, London; entered Indian army from Addiscombe, 7th June, 1861; lieutenant H.M.'s 107th foot, 1864; retired, Jan., 1867; on the extra staff of the India Museum, 1st Jan., 1867; clerk to the special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India office, Oct., 1879; author of the official report on the Indian section of the Amsterdam exhibition of 1882, and of contributions on Indian art manufactures and other subjects to various periodicals, also of a lecture before the Society of Arts, June, 1882, on the 'Production of Tea, Cinchona, Wild Silks, and Rhea in India.'

RUDDOCK, EDWARD HARDCASTLE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Leeds Grammar School and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 2nd Dec., 1863; from Oct., 1864, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884.

RULE, EDWARD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Served in England under the board of admiralty previous to joining the financial department of government of India; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1865, and served in the comptroller-general's establishment; from March, 1868, to Sept., 1869, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and assistant commissioner of paper currency; from Sept., 1869, to March, 1875, acted as deputy accountant-general in British Burma; from March, 1875, served as deputy accountant-general, Madras, and acted for some months as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; on special duty to Port Blair, Nov.-Dec., 1877; deputy accountant-general, Burma, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general (afterwards designated comptroller of Indian treasuries) in 1st class of financial department, April, 1883.

RUNDALL, CHARLES, Salt Department, Madras.—Inspector of police, Sept., 1860; from Nov., 1860, to Sept., 1880, served in the revenue settlement department as assistant director and deputy director, and acted as director of revenue settlement, Aug., 1875, to July, 1876; on special duty in introducing the revised settlement, Nellore and North Arcot, April, 1873, to July, 1875; from Sept., 1880, served in the salt department as deputy commissioner, and was on special duty in Madras, June, 1883, and in Orissa, June, 1883, to Feb., 1884.

RUNDALL, FRANCIS HORNBLOW, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., R.E.—Madras engineers, 1841; assistant civil engineer, 1844; civil engineer, public works department, Ganjam, 1854; dis-
trict engineer, Rajahmundry, May, 1855; consulting engineer, Madras irrigation and canal company, Oct., 1859; chief engineer of irrigation and joint secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1867; chief engineer, 1st class, Aug., 1869; officiating inspector-general and deputy secretary to government of India, irrigation branch, Jan., 1871; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, April, 1872, to April, 1874.

RUNDALL, JAMES WILLIAM, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—Joined Madras public works department as supernumerary engineer, 2nd Aug., 1855, and served in the Godavari, Tinnevelly, and Bellary districts; executive engineer, July, 1863; on special duty under chief engineer, May, 1877; superintendent of works, Kistna, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, Oct., 1881; member of committee for drawing up navigation rules, Nov., 1882; 2nd class superintending engineer, April, 1884.

RUSSSELL, SAMUEL, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Santry School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; special assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Ganjam, Feb., 1885.

RYAN, PATRICK (Barrister-at-Law), Police Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 23rd Nov., 1852; from May, 1860, served as assistant secretary to government of Bombay in the political, educational, and secret departments; also acted as oriental translator to government, Aug.-Sept., 1869, and as magistrate of police, Bombay; performed duties of under secretary to government in the political and judicial departments, Feb.-March, 1879; appointed third presidency magistrate, Bombay, Nov., 1880.

RYLAND, WILLIAM HENRY, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 10th Dec., 1852, served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, and was appointed deputy magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; officiating collector of stamps, and superintendent of abkaree revenue, March, 1868; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1869; subordinate judge, 1st grade, and judge of the small cause court at Sealdah, April, 1875; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1880.

RYVES, THOMAS JAMES, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Served as a volunteer in the Bengal yeomanry cavalry from July, 1857, to Jan., 1859, and received the mutiny medal and the local rank of lieutenant for distinguished services in the field; adjutant of military police, Bijnor, 1859; assistant inspector-general, Rohilkhund, April, 1861; from Aug., 1861, served as superintendent of police in various districts, and was promoted to the 1st grade, June, 1885.

ST. JOHN, SIR OLIVER BEAUCHAMP COVENTRY, K.C.S.I., Colonel, R.E.—Joined the service, 13th Feb., 1857; officiating political officer, Kandahar, 1st March, 1879; resident and officer on special duty, Kashmir, June, 1883.

ST. QUINTIN, WILLIAM A., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Blackheath Proprietary School; temporary clerk, 31st Dec., 1866; junior examiner, Dec., 1868; senior examiner, Nov., 1878.

SAIYID MAHMUD (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as district judge, 3rd grade, Oudh, Aug., 1879; served temporarily under foreign department of government of India, June, 1881, to May, 1882; acting puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, May, 1882; served under education committee, Nov., 1882, to March, 1883; district judge, Rae Bareli, Nov., 1883.

SALMON, WILLIAM ARTHUR, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bo. S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 11th May, 1859, and served on military duty till March, 1867, and subsequently in the political department as acting assistant resident, Baroda, acting political agent, Rewa Kantha, and acting assistant political agent in Kathiawar on special duty; personal assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, Jan., 1871; acting assistant superintendent for thuggee and dacoity, Baroda, Feb.-March, 1873; served as political assistant in Kathiawar up to Jan., 1879, and was in charge of the Gondal state and of Halá Prant, July-Aug., 1877; from Feb., 1879, served as assistant political agent, Kolaba, in charge Janjira state; acting political agent, Mahi Kantha, Aug.-Nov., 1882; assistant political agent in charge of Southern Mahartha country Jaghirs, Aug., 1883; joint administrator of Rajpipla, July, 1884; joint administrator of Sangli, Feb., 1885.

SAMUELLS, CHARLES ARCHIBALD (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1869; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was placed on famine duty at Chumparun, March, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1883.

SANDEMAN, J. E., Major, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Joined at Addiscombe, 1860; ensign, Bengal infantry, 7th June, 1861; arrived in India, Oct., 1861; studied at Roorkee College, and obtained certificate qualifying for engineer, public works department, Sept., 1864; appointed to the survey department, Oct., 1864, and served as assistant superintendent in the Central Provinces, Oudh, and the Punjab; in charge of Midnapur survey, Bengal, 1873; Goalpara survey, Assam, Dec., 1873; Behar irrigation survey, Oct., 1874; in charge of British Burma cadastral survey, Dec., 1878; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, survey of India, Jan., 1879; in charge of Mirzapur and Gorakpur district cadastral survey, from Nov., 1883.

SANDEMAN, SIR ROBERT GROVES, K.C.S.I., Colonel, B.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, Feb., 1856; assistant commissioner, Punjab, May, 1859; agent, governor-general, Biluchistan, from 1877.

SANDERS, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Collegiate School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner, 3rd grade.

SANKEY, RICHARD HIERAM, Lieutenant-
General, C.B., late R.E.—Ensign, 11th Dec., 1846; arrived in India with rank of supernumerary second lieutenant, Madras engineers, Nov. 1848; officiating superintending engineer, Nagapore subsidiary force, Feb., 1850, to June, 1853; superintendent of the east coast canal, 1850-57; additional under secretary, government of India, public works department, March, 1857; on outbreak of mutiny proceeded with special appointment to Allahabad, acting for a time as superintending engineer and consulting engineer for railways, N.W. Provinces; acted as field engineer at Cawnpore, and was subsequently senior engineer officer with the Gurkha force under Jung Bahadur; executive engineer and superintendent of convicts, Moulmein, Jan.-Nov., 1859, and subsequently garrison engineer, Fort William; assistant to chief engineer, Mysore, June, 1861; chief engineer, Mysore, 1866-1877; services placed by Lord Mayo at disposal of government of Victoria for specially reporting on the waterworks of the colony, March-Oct., 1871; deputy secretary to government of India, Sept., 1877; commanding engineer of the South Afghanistan expeditionary force under lieutenant-general D. Stewart, C.B., Oct., 1878, to Feb., 1879; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, April, 1879; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; resigned the public works department in 1883; retired from the army, Jan., 1884.

SAPTE, BRAND, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1843; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal, the Punjab, and N.W. Provinces; magistrate and collector, Bulandshahr, 1857, and subsequently at Meerut; C.B. in 1859; from 1864 to 1865 served as judge of Ghazeepur, and subsequently of Farakhabad; retired 1871.

SARGEAUNT, RICHARD ARTHUR, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, May, 1871, as controller of accounts, officiating as examiner of railway accounts, Bombay; examiner, 3rd class, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, 1876; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, May, 1877; executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1880; revenue assistant, railway branch, public works secretariat, government of India; manager, Northern Bengal state railway, in class I of the state railway revenue establishment, July, 1882; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Feb., 1883; officiating manager, Punjab Northern state railway, June, 1884.

SARGENT, Sir CHARLES, Knt., M.A. (Cantab), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Judge of the high court, Bombay, April, 1866; chief justice, Aug., 1882.

SATYANDRANATH TAGORE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Presidency College, Calcutta University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 12th Dec., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, and judge and sessions judge; 1st grade judge, Sholapur-Bijapur, Aug., 1883.

SAUNDERS, ARTHUR LESLIE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

SAUNDERS, CHARLES BURSLEM, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1843; served in the Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Punjab, 1850; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1857; principal assistant to agent, Delhi, 1858; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Delhi division, 1858; financial and judicial commissioner, Hyderabad territories, 1860; judicial commissioner, Mysore, 1863; resident at Hyderabad, 1868; chief commissioner, Mysore, 1876; retired in 1878.

SAUNDERS, LESLIE SEYMOUR, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; commissioner, Ajmir, March, 1871, to Feb., 1885; graded in the political department as resident, 2nd class; commissioner, Berar, Feb., 1885.

SAVAGE, Henry, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Institute; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector.

SCHARLIEB, WILLIAM MASON, Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 25th March, 1847, in various subordinate posts, and was appointed first uncoventional assistant to the board of revenue, June, 1862; resigned the service to practise at the bar, Oct., 1867; acting administrator-general, Madras, in 1867 and 1874; acting government pleader, May, 1874; assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, Dec., 1874; from April to Oct., 1879, acted as first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, and served subsequently as presidency magistrate for the town of Madras; board of examiners, Jan., 1882.

SCHLICH, W., Ph.D., Forest Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state for India as an assistant conservator of forests, Dec., 1866; conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1872; transferred to the Punjab, 1881; inspector-general of forests, April, 1883.

SCONCE, GIDEON COLQUHOUN (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bengal.—Officiating magistrate, Calcutta, 12th Nov., 1866; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, Dec., 1870; judge of the Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1874; promoted to third judge, Oct., 1884.

SCONCE, JAMES, Colonel, B.S.C., Survey Department.—Joined at Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec. 1853; arrived in India, April, 1854; served from Oct., 1859, as assistant revenue surveyor in the Bundelcund and Central Provinces surveys; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1863; served in Bengal from March, 1866, in the office of superintendent of revenue surveys, Calcutta, and at Hazaribagh, Midnapur, and Arrah; deputy superintendent of survey, 2nd grade, Nov., 1868; deputy surveyor-general (revenue survey branch), Jan., 1879.

SCORGIE, JAMES, F.C.S., Educational De-
partment, Bombay.—Joined the service as head master of the Akola High School, Berar, 12th Nov., 1866; in charge of the office of director of public instruction, Berar, April-June, 1872; principal, Jeypore school of arts, Oct., 1872; from Feb., 1875, served as professor of mechanism and applied science, Civil Engineering College, Poona; 3rd grade of the education department, March, 1883.

SCOTT, ARTHUR GUILLUM, Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, and at private schools; East India House writer, old establishment, 7th Nov., 1857; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1872.

SCOTT, JOHN, M.A. (Oxon), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Judge of the high court, Bombay, 18th Nov., 1882.

SCOTT, MATHEW HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 16th Dec., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Kaladgi, July, 1876; and grade judge, Khándesh, Feb., 1881; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmednagar, May, 1882.

SCOTT, Ross, M.A., F.C.S. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Omagh Academy, the Royal Academical Institution and Seminary, Belfast, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Feb., 1885.

SCOTT, THOMAS AUGUSTUS, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1857; arrived in India, 29th June, 1857; from Jan., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as district superintendent of police; from June, 1865, served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Dec., 1882.

SCULLY, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, Indian Medical Department.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1872; from Nov., 1883, served as officiating assay master, and acting deputy assay master of the Bombay mint; confirmed in the latter appointment, May, 1884; also acted as assay master of the Calcutta mint, May-Aug., 1884, and again, Dec., 1884.

SEABROOKE, JAMES H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London (Jelf medallist and associate, 1871); open classical scholarship, Queen's College, Oxford, 1871-74; B.A., Dec., 1874; junior clerk, financial department, India office, 13th Jan., 1876; military department, 1877.

SEATON, WILLIAM JOHN, Lieut.-Colonel, M.S.C., Forest Department, Burma.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Sept., 1855; assistant superintendent in the forest department, Dec., 1860; deputy conservator, 1st class, April, 1865; conservator, Nov., 1867; 1st grade conservator, Sept., 1883.

SECCOMBE, HENRY L., Financial Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 14th May, 1858; junior clerk, financial department, India office, Dec., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1882.

SECCOMBE, SIR THOMAS LAWRENCE, C.B., K.C.S.I.—Entered the home service of the Honorable East India Company in Jan., 1829, as a clerk in the department of auditor of India accounts (subsequently merged in the secretary's department); on the transfer of the government of India to the Crown in 1858 was appointed assistant financial secretary; financial secretary, 1859; director of military funds, and chairman of the consulting committee, 1866; in Jan., 1869, was elected chairman of a joint India office and war office committee for adjusting the charges against Indian revenues for services of H.M.'s regiments on the India establishment, and was nominated a member of a similar committee in 1874, and again in Feb., 1879; C.B., Dec., 1869; accountant-general, in addition to his other duties, Feb., 1872; assistant under secretary of state for India, July, 1872; K.C.S.I., June, 1877; appointed one of three commissioners to represent H.M.'s Government at the International Monetary Conference at Paris, 1878; continued assistant under secretary of state until 1881, but resigned his other offices on 31st Jan., 1879; member of a joint India office and admiralty committee on financial questions connected with the India troop service, June, 1879.

SELLS, ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muzaffarnagar, Aug., 1878, and district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1882; 2nd grade judge, April, 1885.

SETON-KARR, WALTER SCOTT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, where he gained honours, in 1842; arrived in India, Dec., 1842; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Jessore, 1847; under secretary, government of Bengal, 1847-53; member of council of education, 1853; collector of Tirhoot, 1857; civil and sessions judge, Jessore, 1858-60; president of indigo commission, 1860; secretary to government of Bengal, 1860-61; legislative council of India, 1861; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Chittagong, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1862; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1862, to April, 1868; foreign secretary, government of India, April, 1868; retired, 1870; vice-chancellor of the University of Calcutta in 1868 and 1869; is a member of the council of Marlborough College.

SEWELL, EBENEZER JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant collector and additional sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877, to Sept., 1878; senior assistant collector and magistrate, Ganjam, June, 1882.

SEWELL, HENRY, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Radley, and University College,
Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from Nov., 1863, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting small cause court judge, acting under secretary to government in the revenue department, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1874, to April, 1875; from May, 1875, served as collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, and political agent, Pudukkota.

SEWELL, ROBERT, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, Oct., 1877, and on special duty in connection with the archaeological survey of the Madras presidency, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan., 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Tinnevelly, Sept., 1884.

SHAKESPEAR, ALEXANDER MURISON WAKE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

SHARP, F. W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Milton College, Ullesthorpe; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 1885.

SHARP, HENRY GRANVILLE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Horncastle Grammar School, Marlborough College, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1868; from Feb., 1868, served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; special duty at Madras on famine relief work, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Maldah, Oct., 1884.

SHARPE, CHARLES FERGUSON, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 1st Feb., 1851, and served under the military department till Sept., 1858, when he was appointed to the Oudh military police; from Feb., 1859, served as district superintendent in the police department in Oudh, and was promoted to 1st grade, April, 1876.

SHARPE, F. R., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; writer, India office, 7th Aug., 1877; clerk, 2nd class, Sept. 1878.

SHAW, ARTHUR TREVOR AMBROSE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884.

SHAW, CHARLES FORBES HUDSON, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 21st Aug., 1850, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate up to Feb., 1864, and subsequently as judge and sessions judge in various districts.

SHAW, CHARLES G., Store Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 17th Jan., 1855; junior clerk, store department, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant to director-general, Nov., 1876.

SHAW, GEORGE WATSON, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Hertford Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1879, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner.

SHAW, JOHN CARDY, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1860; served from 28th March, 1872, as civil assistant surgeon, and civil surgeon, at various stations, and officiated as superintendent of the Temple Medical School, Patna, in 1881 and 1882; rank of surgeon-major, Oct., 1880.

SHAW-STEWART, JOHN HERON MAXWELL, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, June, 1854; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1853; served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1854, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; on military duty in China, March, 1860, to Feb., 1861; deputy secretary to government, public works department, Dec., 1863; controller, public works accounts, Madras, May, 1867; consulting engineer for railways, Madras, Oct., 1867; chief engineer, Oct., 1870; joint secretary to government, railway branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, Sept., 1883; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Sept., 1883.

SHEPPARD, GEORGE FREDERICK, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and superintendent of stamps and stationery; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1870; collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1871; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Kaira, Nov., 1875; on special duty at Poona, Oct., 1878; from Nov., 1880, acted as commissioner, and was confirmed as 2nd grade commissioner, Oct., 1882 (Northern division).

SHEPPARD, THOMAS WILLIAM, Surgeon-Major, F.C.S., F.I.C., Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1859; served from 4th March, 1870, as principal assistant to the opium agent, Benares, also in Behar, Oct., 1878; rank of surgeon-major, Feb., 1871.

SHERER, JOHN WALTER, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; on special duty under board of revenue to report on Reh efflorescence, Western Jumna Canal, 1856-57; magistrate and collector of Cawnpore, 1857; civil officer with General Havelock's column in 1857, in the advance on Cawnpore; special commissioner to try rebels; commissioner to enquire into claims against the former king of Oudh, 1864; member of jail committee, Calcutta, 1864; judge of Allahabad, 1871, and afterwards of Azimgurgh, and Mirzapore; retired 1877.

SHERIDAN, PHILIP, Post Office Department.—Served in the postal department, Punjab,
