from March, 1861, as postmaster, booking agent, assistant superintendent of military horse van dák, and inspector; chief superintendent, travelling post office; Allahabad, Dec., 1873; chief inspector of post offices, Assam, Dec., 1873; assistant director-general of the post office of India, July, 1880; officiating deputy director-general, Oct., 1882.

SHEWAN, ALEXANDER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Gymnasium, Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and acting forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; on special forest duty in connection with the dahi cultivation settlement in Ahmednagar, March, 1881, and Feb., 1882; from Jan., 1885, acted as assistant judge and sessions judge.

SHIPLEY, REGINALD HEBER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1883; and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

SHIRRES, LESLIE PITTEDRIGH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882.

SHORTREDE, ROBERT, Audit Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 1st Feb., 1864; junior examiner, Sept., 1866; senior examiner, July, 1873.

SHRIDAD BABAJI THAKUR, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bombay University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; from June, 1882, served in the judicial department, and was promoted to 2nd grade assistant judge and sessions judge, Feb., 1885.

SHRI RAM BHIKAJI JATAR, B.A., Education Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Served in the Bombay education department from Jan., 1859, in the Marathi translator's office, and as assistant master in the high schools at Bombay and Belgaum, and head master of the Carwar English school; from July, 1867, served in Berar as deputy educational inspector, and acting head master, high school, Amraoti; educational inspector, Aug., 1876; director of public instruction, Hyderabad assigned districts, Aug., 1884.

SHUJAT ALI KHAN MIR, Madras C.S.—Served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Aug., 1876, in various subordinate posts, and was appointed by the government of India, as probationer for the civil service from 15th Dec., 1881; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1884.

SHUTTLEWORTH, ALLEN THORNTON, Forest Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 21st April, 1856, and served in the Indian marine till Aug., 1863; from Nov., 1863, served in the Bombay forest department as assistant conservator, and deputy conservator, and was appointed conservator of forests and superintendent of botanical gardens, Sept., 1869; 1st grade conservator, Nov., 1881; while stationed at Alibag as deputy conservator of forests was instrumental in saving upwards of a hundred lives from different wrecks; these services were acknowledged in different ways by the government of Bombay, the Bombay Harbour Board, and the merchants of Bombay; Albert medal of the 1st class; medals of the Royal Humane Society, the Shipwrecked Mariners' Company, and Lloyds, &c.

SHUTTLEWORTH, EDWARD INGLIS, Police Department, Bengal.—From 20th March, 1856, to June, 1862, served as superintendent of salt chowkies; from June, 1862, served in the police department, and was appointed district superintendent, 1st grade, Feb., 1880.

SIBTHORPE, CHARLES, Surgeon-Major, F.R.Q.C.P., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1870; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Banda, July, 1874; from May, 1875, to Nov., 1880, served as resident surgeon, General Hospital, Madras, and Professor of pathology and materia medica in the Medical College, and acted for various periods as surgeon, General Hospital, and professor of surgery, and as ophthalmic surgeon, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology; also served in the Afghan war, 1878-79; surgeon-major, April, 1882; from Oct., 1882, served as fort surgeon, inspector of seamen at Madras, and professor of anatomy at the Medical College, also acting as secretary and statistical officer to the surgeon-general, Her Majesty's forces, April-Aug., 1883, and as principal medical storekeeper, Madras, Sept., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884.

SILCOCK, HENRY FOSTER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Drogheda Grammar School and Kingstown School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877.

SILCOCK, JAMES GREER, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Armagh Royal School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived, 16th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Peshawur, Feb., 1881.

SIM, HENRY ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate and acting collector and magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served as deputy conservator of forests, Kurnool, and forest settlement officer.

SIM, JAMES DUNCAN, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, in 1842; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate till 1852, when he was appointed deputy secretary to government in the departments under the chief secretary; also Telugu translator to government, 1854; sub-secretary to board of revenue,
1855; secretary to board of revenue, 1858; secretary to government in revenue and public works department, 1861; member of board of revenue, and government director of bank of Madras, 1867; member of Madras council, 7th March, 1870; retired in 1875.

SIME, JOHN, B.A., Education Department, Punjab.—Professor, Government College, Agra, April, 1869; from Sept., 1870, served in the Punjab in the 3rd grade of the education department as principal, Delhi College, till 1877, and subsequently as professor, and officiating principal, Lahore College; inspector of schools, Nov., 1880; services lent to the Patiala state from May, 1885.

SIMPSON, BENJAMIN, Surgeon-General, C.B., M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1853; served in civil employ from 1860, as assistant surgeon in Bengal, and was in medical charge of the Bhootan mission in 1863; civil surgeon, Darjeeling, April, 1868; from Jan., 1871, served as civil surgeon of Patna with charge of the Meeta-pore jail; on special duty to the cinchona commission, Feb., 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1873; guardian to the Maharajah of Cooch Behar during his visit to Europe, March, 1878; principal medical officer, Quetta, 1881; deputy surgeon-general, March, 1882; sanitary commissioner, Central Provinces, 1882; surgeon-general in the Punjab, 1884; sanitary commissioner, and surgeon-general with the government of India, March, 1885.

SIMSON, D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grammar School and Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, in 1845; arrived in India, 5th April, 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces, and in the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner; commissioner in Oudh, June, 1859; extra judge, court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, April, 1864; judge, chief court, Punjab, April, 1868; retired 1872.

SINCLAIR, DAVID, Surgeon-Major, M.B., C.M., Jail Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st Oct., 1869; arrived in Madras, 14th May, 1870; from 1871, served in British Burma, and was employed in the analysis of potable waters in cantonments, April, 1871, to Dec., 1872; served subsequently as superintendent of the central jail at Moulmein, with occasional charge of the central jail at Rangoon; also officiated as civil surgeon and superintendent of lock hospital at Moulmein in 1874, and was in medical charge of the general hospital in that year; officiating inspector-general of prisons, British Burma, May-Oct., 1875, and again July, 1882; appointed superintendent of the central jail at Rangoon, Feb., 1883; inspector-general of jails, sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and in charge of civil medical department, Burma, Jan., 1884.

SINCLAIR, D. E., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster School, King's College School, and Merton College, Oxford; writer in post office, British museum, and admiralty, 1873-80; supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, Aug., 1880.

SINCLAIR, WILLIAM FREDERICK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Armagh Royal School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting railway magistrate, and was on special duty for demarcation of forests in Khândesh, April, 1873, and in Alibâg, Jan., 1874; on special duty, Poona, Nov., 1875; forest demarcating officer, Thâna, Jan., 1876; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; first assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Feb., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Kolaba, May, 1885.

SINKINSON, EDWARD JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Windermere College and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1873, to Feb., 1877, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, officiating first judge of small cause court, officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner, junior secretary to chief commissioner (March, 1876), inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner and superintendent of vaccination, and member of the prison conference (Jan.-Feb., 1877); from Feb., 1877, served in the financial department of the government of India, and was appointed under secretary to government, June, 1877; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner of state paper currency, April-July, 1880; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1881; deputy-accountant-general, Madras, July, 1882, to Nov., 1883; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Feb.-March, 1884.

SKEEN, ANDREW, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1865; served under the military department till Nov., 1870, when he was appointed to the medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp, Punjab; served afterwards as civil surgeon at various stations in the Punjab, and was appointed medical officer, Patiala state, April, 1882.

SKINNER, RUSSELL MORLAND, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 7th Dec., 1855; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 1st grade, April, 1862; district superintendent, Aug., 1863; on special duty, June, 1873; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1876.

SKRINE, FRANCIS HENRY BENNET, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; on famine relief duty, May, 1874, and Oct., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884.

SLACK, FRANCIS ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Taunton College School, University College, Oxford, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1874; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.

SLADEN, SIR EDWARD BOSC, Knt., Colonel, M.S.C.—Appointed to the Madras army, April,
1849; arrived in India, July, 1849; served as assistant commissioner in the Tenasserim and Martaban provinces from Dec., 1855; on military duty, 1857-59; rejoined the Tenasserim commission, 1859, and served as assistant commissioner and town magistrate of Moulmein, and afterwards of Rangoon (Aug., 1863); agent to the chief commissioner of Burma at the court of Mandalay, Jan., 1865; political agent at Mandalay, 1867; appointed to conduct an expedition overland through Burma to South-Western China, 1868; on special duty with the King of Siam in India, Dec., 1871; rejoined the Burma commission as deputy commissioner, March, 1872, and acted as commissioner of Tenasserim from May, 1873; from March, 1876, served as commissioner of Arakan.

SLADEN, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed superintendent, Dehra Dün, June, 1868, and magistrate and collector, Muzaffanagar, March, 1873; officiating commissioner, Meerut division, Aug., 1880; member of committee to consider revised rules for patwāris and kanungos, Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and agent to the governor-general, Benares, Aug., 1881; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, July, 1882, Meerut.

SLATER, J. S., Educational Service, Bengal.—From Sept., 1870, to Nov., 1875, served in the public works department, Punjab, as engineer apprentice and assistant engineer, on the Bari Doab and Indus canals; from Nov., 1875, served in the Bengal education department as professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College, and, from April, 1880, as professor of the Howrah Engineering College; officiating principal, Howrah College, Feb., 1881; 3rd class of the education department, March, 1881.

SMEATON, DONALD MACKENZIE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at the Abbey Park Institution, St. Andrew's, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from May, 1870, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Feb., 1877; transferred to British Burma as settlement secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1879; on special duty in India, April, 1882; secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, in the land revenue and agricultural department, and director of agriculture, May, 1882; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug., 1884.

SMEATON, ROBERT, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Abbey Park Institution and University of St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; first assistant secretary to government, July, 1876; under secretary, May, 1877; junior secretary, Aug., 1877; officiating secretary to government, March, 1881; secretary to government, financial department, May, 1884.

SMITH, ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; from Dec., 1857, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and collector, and was appointed senior superintendent of survey, Aug., 1872, magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and commissioner, of the Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary Mehlas, Cuttack, Oct., 1879; commissioner, Presidency division, July, 1884.

SMITH, A. CREMER, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 23rd June, 1865; junior clerk, store department, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Nov., 1876.

SMITH, CHARLES JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, Jan., 1858; executive engineer, Nov., 1865; appointed to carry out certain investigations in connection with the flood waters of the Cauvery, Dec., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, and deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oct., 1870; under secretary to government, public works department, May, 1872; superintending engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1883; consulting engineer and joint secretary to government, railway branch, 1883; chief engineer, 3rd class (temporary), July, 1884.

SMITH, F. WHITMORE, Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School and Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 23rd Jan., 1864; junior clerk, military department, July, 1866; senior clerk, Jan., 1880.

SMITH, GILBERT LESLIE, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Twyford School and St. Andrew's University; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; employed under the public works department in taking up land for the Punjab northern state railway, Aug., 1877, to Feb., 1878.

SMITH, JOHN, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

SMITH, JOSEPH, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Etah, Aug., 1881.

SMITH, ROBERT MURDOCH, Colonel, R.E., Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, Aug., 1863; director of the Persian section from June, 1865.

SMITH, SAMUEL G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 6th Jan., 1883.

SMITH, THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive
examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; appointed district and sessions judge, Tipperah, Dec., 1877, and served subsequently in the judicial department; 1st grade district and sessions judge, Nov., 1881.

SMITH, TURTON, Police Department, Punjab.—From 26th March, 1863, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, May, 1881; between Dec., 1871, and Sept., 1878, also served in the postal department as officiating assistant director-general of post offices, officiating postmaster-general at Bombay, Aug., 1876, and at Madras, May, 1878.

SMITH, VINCENT ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1874, to Nov., 1880, served in the settlement department in Hamirpur, and was appointed assistant settlement officer, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; on special duty in the Allahabad district, Nov., 1880; officiating magistrate and collector, Bareilly, March, 1881; joint magistrate, and grade, Nov., 1882; settlement officer, 3rd grade, Basti, Dec., 1883.

SMYTH, GEORGE, B.A., C.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating registrar of the chief court, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, March, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1883.

SMYTH, JOHN WATT (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and was appointed assistant magistrate and collector, Agra, Nov., 1858; transferred to Punjab, May, 1859, and served as assistant commissioner, and as personal assistant to the financial commissioner, and to the judicial commissioner; registrar of the chief court, Feb., 1866; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1869; officiated as commissioner and superintendent of the Lahore division in 1869, 1872, and 1879, and as additional commissioner of Amritsar, 1874-77; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, April, 1877; judge, chief court, March, 1880.

SMYTH, RALPH GRAHAM, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department (Hyderabad Administration).—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 7th Dec., 1855; from 6th Nov., 1857, served in the public works department in the Central and N.W. Provinces as assistant engineer; served in the field force at Lucknow, and at the final capture of Lucknow, 1858; officiating garrison engineer, Lucknow, June, 1859; on military duty, May, 1861; reappointed to public works department, April, 1862, and served in Bengal as assistant engineer and executive engineer (Jan., 1864); on special duty in investigations connected with river Selye, and with reservoirs in the Purulia and Palamow districts, Nov., 1867, to May, 1869; served in the Ramghur and Burbee divisions and on the Grand Trunk Road, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1870; superintending engineer, July, 1876; transferred to Hyderabad, Dec., 1881, as secretary to resident in the public works department; 1st class superintending engineer, Sept., 1882.

SMYTH, THOMAS WATT, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and small cause court judge; registrar of the chief court, 1867-70; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; on special duty in the civil secretariat, Feb. and Oct., 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Aug., 1882; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsur divisions, April, 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; additional judge, chief court, Feb., 1885.

SNOW, PHILIP CHICHELEY HYDE (Barrister-at-Law), Bombay C.S.—Educated at Haileybury and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, Delhi, Nov., 1876; from March, 1877, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, assistant cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; from Nov., 1881, served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate and district registrar, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885.

SORABJI PADAMJI PESTANJI, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, 14th Jan., 1880; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, March, 1882; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

SOUTER, SIR FRANK HENRY, Knt., C.S.I., C.I.E., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, Jan., 1850; from June, 1854, served in the Bombay police department as superintendent and deputy commissioner; from Dec., 1864, served as commissioner of police, Bombay, and was on special duty at Baroda, Dec., 1874, to April, 1875, and in Madras, at Ootacamund, July, 1881.

SPANKIE, ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; entered the Honourable East India company's service in 1844, and was attached to the N.W. Provinces; magistrate and collector, 1853; district judge, 1859; extra judge, Sudder Dewanni and Nizamut Adawlut, Agra, 1864, and officiated as judge in that court in 1865 and 1866; officiated as puisne judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, on its establishment in 1866, and in 1867 was confirmed in this appointment, which he held till his retirement on 31st May, 1881.

SPEARMAN, HORACE RALPH, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 91st Highlanders, 18th Dec., 1857; probationary assistant engineer, public works department, 1862; from Dec., 1862, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (Feb., 1868); also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner, and as director of public instruction; officiating assistant political agent, Bhamo,
March, 1871; appointed a deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877, and was promoted to 2nd grade, 1882; on special duty in Rangoon, Feb., 1879, and Feb., 1883; president, Rangoon municipal committee, May, 1883.

SPEDDING, ROBERT DECV, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputed to conduct demarcation of boundary between districts of Banda and Hamirpur and the native states of Bundelkund, Oct., 1870; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, April, 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Gorakhpur, Dec., 1879.

SPENCE, JAMES KNOX, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1878, to Oct., 1880, served in the postal department, as acting postmaster-general, Bombay, also in the Punjab and Bengal; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Kolaba, June, 1885.

SPENCER, EGERTON EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Tavistock Grammar School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty, famine relief works, Dec., 1876; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, July, 1881; head assistant collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1882; acting Tamil translator to government, March, 1885.

SPENCER, L. D., Surgeon-Major, M.D., Indian Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, March, 1865; served under the civil department in Nimar and Khundwa, and with the Central India horse; served in Rajputana, in civil employ, from 1872, and was attached to the Bhurtapore agency; surgeon-major, March, 1877; in medical charge, Marwar agency, 1879; Western Rajputana states, 1880; officiating agency surgeon, Rajputana, and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination, 1881; confirmed in this appointment, 1882.

SPENCER, NATHANIEL (Barrister-at-Law), Judicial Department, Bombay.—Assistant, judicial department of secretariat, Bombay, 11th Dec., 1849; clerk of the court of small causes, March, 1852; from Dec., 1861, served as judge of the court of small causes, Bombay, and was promoted to second judge, Feb., 1873; also acted on several occasions as chief judge.

SPRY, ARTHUR HUME, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 22nd Oct., 1857, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, special officer of income tax, acting collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, and acting talukdari settlement officer; junior collector and magistrate, Dhawar, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Kaira, Oct., 1882; on special duty in the Cambay state, Feb., 1883.

SREE NATH ROY.—From 4th May, 1860, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Feb., 1872; small cause court judge of Hooghly, Howrah, and Serampore, Jan., 1880; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; officiating 4th judge, small cause court, Calcutta, Oct., 1884.

STACE, EDWARD VINCENT, Major, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1862; from June, 1871, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and as boundary settlement commissioner (July, 1872); between May, 1873, and March, 1875, acted as assistant political resident, Aden, and also as cantonment magistrate; from April, 1875, acted as assistant political agent, Kathiawar, and was on special duty with the son of H.H. the Jam of Navanagar, May, 1877; also acted as assistant political agent of Kolhapur and Southern Mahatta country, and as superintendent of surveys under the Rajasthani court, Kathiawar; second assistant resident at Aden, Sept., 1880; assistant to the political superintendent, Savantadi, May, 1882; joint administrator, Rajpipla, Feb., 1885.

STACK, EDWARD, M.A., LL.D., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1872, and served in the North-Western Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant secretary to government, and assistant settlement officer; officiating under secretary to government of India, home, revenue and agricultural department, Dec., 1879, to June, 1880; transferred to Assam, and appointed director of agriculture, Sept., 1882; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, July to Oct., 1883.

STACK, OLIVER STOKES, Police Department, Bengal.—From 8th June, 1859, to May, 1862, served as deputy magistrate and deputy collector; from May, 1862, served in the police department, and was appointed superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1878.

STACK, WILLIAM GEORGE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Foyle College, Londonderry, Royal School, Ratho, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1881, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

STALEY, ALFRED EVELYN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, Concord, U.S.A., and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1875; attached to N.W. Provinces; served in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Bengal, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, Government of Bengal, March, 1884.

STANTHALL, W., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 25th Sept., 1882; attached to the public works department.

STANTON, FREDERICK SMITH, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—Date of commission, 10th Dec., 1850; arrived in India, June, 1853; assistant engineer, public works depart-
ment, Bengal, Nov., 1853; executive engineer, grand trunk road, July, 1857; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Jan., 1864; executive engineer, 1st grade, Dec., 1863; was employed on special duties in 1863-64, and also as executive engineer in the circular and eastern canal, and Darjeeling divisions, and served under the military department with the Dooar field force; officiating consulting engineer and joint secretary in the railway branch, government of Bengal, Aug., 1867, to March, 1868, when he was transferred to Oudh in the same capacity; deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces; superintending engineer on the Rajputana state railway, Feb., 1871; temporarily in charge of Tirhoot famine line, Feb., 1874; superintending engineer, 1st grade, April, 1874; extra deputy consulting engineer to government of India for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, Oct., 1875; engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, Feb., 1876; officiating director of state railways, north-eastern system, and officiating joint secretary to government of Bengal, May, 1877; chief engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1880; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, Feb., 1882.

STEAD, Ven. SAMUEL, M.A. (Oxon), Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, March, 1863; arrived in India, 24th April, 1863, and served as chaplain at Karachi, Sholapur, cantonment of Belgaum, and Poona; senior chaplain, April, 1873; archdeacon and commissary, Nov., 1878; also held charge of the diocese of Bombay, Oct., 1877, to Nov., 1878, and Oct., 1883, to June, 1884.

STEANE, W.C., Registry Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 9th Nov., 1860; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

STEAVENSON, JOSEPH, B.A., Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 25th Feb., 1873, as acting registrar of the high court (original side), Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1880.

STEEDMAN, EDWARD BRITTAIN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer.

STEEL, CHARLES DENTON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

STEEL, HENRY WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; services placed temporarily at disposal of public works department in connection with Punjab northern state railway, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1878; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1881.

STEEL, JOHN PHILIP, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; joined the public works department, March, 1860, as assistant engineer, Bengal; executive engineer, April, 1868; officiating under secretary, government of India, public works department, March, 1873, to 1875; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, May, 1879; superintending engineer, and class, Oct., 1882.

STEER, C., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1828; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and as magistrate and collector in various districts from 1837 to 1852; served subsequently as civil and sessions judge in various districts up to 1856, when he was appointed commissioner of revenue and circuit, and superintendent of hill tribes, Chittagong; judge of Sudder Dewancee and Nizamut Adawlut, Calcutta, 1861; judge, high court of judicature, 1862; retired, 1865.

STEINBELT, JEAN MARIE CONRAD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Mirzapur, Sept., 1878; district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Banda, April, 1881.

STEINBURG, ALFRED FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Dulwich College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1881, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and assistant inspector of labourers.

STEPHEN, ARTHUR, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1867; served under the military department in the Punjab as assistant surgeon and surgeon; Lahore medical school, 1875; superintendent of jail, Lahore, 1876; surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; statistical officer to government of India, sanitary and medical department, 1881.

STEPHEN, CARR (Barrister-at-Law), Uncov. C.S., Punjab.—Served in the Punjab from 11th June, 1856, as extra assistant commissioner, and small cause court judge; extra judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1875.

STERNDALE, R. A., Financial Department, Government of India.—Served during the mutiny as a volunteer, 1857; lieutenant, Behar station guards, Jan., 1858; from Aug., 1859, served in the Central Provinces as deputy collector and assistant settlement officer; from June, 1864, served in the financial department in Nagpore, Calcutta, and the Punjab, as assistant commissioner of paper currency, acting assistant accountant-general, acting deputy accountant-general, and acting assistant comptroller-general; 3rd class of financial department (new scheme), Aug., 1880; officiating assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1884.

STEVENS, CHARLES CECIL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, and Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments,
and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882; officiating commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, April, 1885.

STEVENS, JOHN FOSTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School, at Versailles, and at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 16th Oct., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Mymensingh, Sept., 1884.

STEVENS, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at King's College, Aberdeen, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Sylhet, Jan., 1885.

STEWARD, ARTHUR BENNET, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, acting junior collector and magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1882; acting postmaster-general, Bombay, Aug., 1884, to May, 1885.

STEWART, ANTHONY, Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Feb., 1855; arrived in India, 29th March, 1855; officiating cantonment joint magistrate, Mean Meer, Feb., 1858; cantonment magistrate 1st class, March, 1875, Umballa, and afterwards at Rawalpindi.

STEWART, SIR DONALD MARTIN, Bart., General, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Ensign, Bengal army (infantry), 12th Oct., 1840; adjutant, 9th Bengal native infantry, 1845; interpreter and quartermaster, 9th N.I., 1852; deputy assistant adjutant-general, Delhi field force, June, 1857; assistant adjutant-general of army, Dec., 1857; deputy adjutant-general in India, Feb., 1863; brigadier-general, Abyssinian expeditionary force, 1868; in command of Pesha-wur district, July, 1869; chief commissioner of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, 1871; in command of Lahore Division, April, 1876; commanding Kandahar and Southern Afghanistan force, 1878-80; commanding at Cabul and in Northern Afghanistan, 1880, till withdrawal from that country; military member of governor-general's council, 1880; commander-in-chief in India, and extraordinary member of the governor-general's council, 1881; member of council of secretary of state for India, Dec., 1885.

STEWART, THEODORE HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to inquire into land alienations in the Panch Mahals, Sept., 1865; boundary settlement officer, May, 1866; on special duty to inquire into titles of land in Surat, Aug., 1867; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Sholapur, Oct., 1879; survey and settlement commissioner, June, 1881.

STEWART, WILLIAM DAY, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; from May, 1874, officiated as civil surgeon of Cuttack, and was confirmed in this appointment, June, 1876; also superintendent of the jail, lunatic asylum, and Medical School; surgeon-major, Oct., 1878.

STIFFE, Captain A. W., I.M.—From 24th Feb., 1849, served in the Indian marine as midshipman, lieutenant, and senior lieutenant, and assistant surveyor; on special survey for telegraph cable in Persian Gulf, Nov., 1862; on special duty in Turkish Arabia, Feb., 1863; engineer, Persian Gulf telegraphs, and commanding "Amberwitch," Oct., 1863; officiating director, Persian Gulf telegraphs, April-Aug., 1866, and Sept., 1869, to Jan., 1871, also electrician, Aug., 1871; on special duty in England, May, 1875, and May, 1878; in command of cable steamer "Patrick Stewart," May-July, 1879; port officer, Calcutta, Aug., 1879; officiating superintendent of marine, July, 1880; ex officio shipping master of Calcutta, Feb., 1882; is also president of board of examiners in seamanship, and registrar of shipping and wrecks.

STIMPSON, E. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 21st May, 1873; resigned, 24th June, 1879; reappointed, 10th July, 1880.

STOGDON, ABRAHAM WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; services placed temporarily at disposal of government of India, military department, Feb., 1881; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Aug., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

STOKER, THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rathmines School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maháraja of Benares, March, 1878; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1884.

STOKES, GABRIEL, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kilkenny College, Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served in Bombay till Dec., 1872, and afterwards in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; acting additional under secretary to government of Madras in the revenue (famine) department, May, 1877, to April, 1879; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Sept., 1878; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1879; acting Canarese trans-
lator to government, Feb., 1830; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, July, 1830; deputy superintendent of census operations, Sept., 1830; head assistant collector, Godavari, April, 1832.

STOKES, Henry Edward, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Minehead Diocesan School, Kilkenny College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; under secretary to government of Madras in the departments under the chief secretary, Aug., 1869; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1871; fellow of the University of Madras, Feb., 1875; sub-secretary, board of revenue, July 1875; on special duty under government of India, with the Madras salt commission, Jan.-Sept., 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1877, to Feb., 1878; and additional secretary on famine duties, Feb., 1877; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, Salem, June, 1881; member of forest draft bill committee, April, 1882; member of local self-government committee, June, 1882; secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, Jan., 1884.

STOKES, Henry John, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Columba College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1863; served in Bombay from Oct., 1864, to Jan., 1870, and subsequently in Madras, and was appointed principal assistant, July, 1871, district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1877, and collector and magistrate, Madura, June, 1879; on special famine duty, Madura, Aug., 1877.

STOREY, H. F., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway; transferred to the Nee-much-Nasirabad railway surveys, 1878, and subsequently to the Indus Valley railway; engineer-in-chief, Kandahar state railway, March, 1880; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley and Kandahar railways, Oct., 1881; superintendent of way and works, Sukkur, 1883; superintending engineer, May, 1884.

STRACHAN, John Miller, Right Rev., M.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Appointed Bishop of Rangoon, 30th June, 1882.

STRACHEY, Sir John, G.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1842; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate and collector; senior assistant, Kumaon, 1848; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; officiating commissioner of Kumaon, 1861; president of commission to inquire into cholera epidemic of 1861; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, 1862; president of the sanitary commission with government of India, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1866; member of governor-general's council, 7th March, 1868; acting viceroy and governor-general on death of Earl of Mayo, 1872; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1874; retired from the civil service, 1876; financial member of the governor-general's council, 23rd Dec., 1876, to 1880; left India, Dec., 1880; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1885; joint author with Lieutenant-General R. Strachey of 'The Finances and Public Works of India,' 1882.

STRACHEY, Richard, Lieutenant-General, R.E., C.S.I., F.R.S.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1836; was employed on irrigation works in the N.W. Provinces from 1840, and appointed executive engineer, Ganges canal, July, 1843; under secretary to government of India, public works department, 1857; secretary to government, Central Provinces, 1857; consulting engineer, railway department, Sept., 1858; secretary to government of India, public works department, 1862; inspector-general of irrigation, and chief engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1866; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; inspecting engineer of machinery and stores for state railways, India office, 1871; member of council of India, 1875; special duty in India, 1878; officiating financial member of council of governor-general, 1879; officiating member of council of governor-general, 1880; president of the famine commission, 1880; reappointed member of council of India, 1880.

STRAHAN, Charles, Major, R.E., Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal engineers, June, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; joined the survey department as military second assistant, Sept., 1863; served with the Bhutan field force in charge of reconnoitering party, Oct., 1865, to July, 1866; surveyor, 3rd grade, April, 1866; served with the Peshawur field force in Afghanistan, 1879; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Jan., 1884; assistant surveyor-general in charge of cartographic and engraving branches, May, 1884.

STRAHAN, George, Major, R.E. (Bengal), Survey of India.—Joined at Chatham, Feb., 1859; arrived in India, Nov., 1860; served under the military department, and also in the irrigation branch, public works department, till July, 1862, when he was appointed to the survey department; served as assistant in the Gwalior and Central India survey, and afterwards held charges in the Rajputana, Mysore, and Khandesh surveys; deputy superintendent, Nov., 1867; officiating assistant surveyor-general, in charge of engraving and cartographic branches, Calcutta, April-July, 1883; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

STRAIGHT, Douglas (Barrister-at-Law).—Called to the bar at the Middle Temple, Nov., 1865; counsel to London banks association from 1868; junior counsel, treasury prosecution, from 1877; sat in House of Commons as member for Shrewsbury, 1870 to 1874; appointed one of the royal commissioners to inquire into corrupt election practices at Boston, 1875; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, June, 1879; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883.

STRATTON, John Proudfoot, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Bombay Medical Establishment.—Assistant surgeon, Bombay medical service, Oct., 1852; between 1854 and 1860 served as resident surgeon, Baroda, and subsequently as civil surgeon in Bundelcund; political agent, Bundelcund, 1869; surgeon-major, Oct., 1872; political agent, Western Rajputana states, 1881; officiating resident, Meywar, 1881; resident, Eastern Rajputana states, 1882.

STREET, B. H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 30th June, 1874; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878; supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, Oct., 1883.
STREET, CHARLES WALKER, Colonel, M.S.C.—Arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1853; ensign in Madras army, Dec., 1853; from March, 1859, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; magistrate of Moulmein, May, 1866; officiating superintendent of jail, Moulmein, April, 1867; officiating director of public instruction, May to Dec., 1867; from May, 1875, to Jan., 1879, served as secretary to chief commissioner, and also as officer in charge of state prisoners; employed on a mission to Siam, Jan.-June, 1879; from June, 1881, served as commissioner of the Pegu division.

STROVER, GEORGE AUGUSTUS, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the service as ensign, Jan., 1857; arrived at Madras, Feb., 1857; served in the British Burma commission from 14th April, 1862, as assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate; officiating magistrate and small cause court judge of Rangoon, 1866; superintendent of hill tribes, North Arakan, Sept., 1868; from Aug., 1869, to Sept., 1875, served in the political department as assistant political agent at Bhamo, and political agent at Mandalay (Jan., 1872); from Nov., 1877, served as deputy commissioner of Toungoo, and acted as commissioner of Arakan, Aug. to Nov., 1883; 1st grade deputy commissioner, July, 1881.

STUART, ANDREW EDMUND CASTLE-STUART, Madras C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

STUART, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Postal Department, Bombay.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1855, as postmaster in Mysore, Madras, and Hyderabad; presidency postmaster, Madras, Jan., 1864; from March, 1865, served in Bombay as presidency postmaster, and also officiated for various periods as postmaster-general, Bombay.

STUART, CHARLES JOSEPH, Colonel, M.S.C.—Arrived in India, 21st Aug., 1852; served in the Madras revenue settlement department from April, 1861, as assistant director and deputy director; special assistant to collector of Kurnool for survey and settlement purposes, April, 1871, to Nov., 1873, and again in Chingleput, Dec., 1873, and in Madura, April, 1882; 1st grade of deputy directors, June, 1883.

STUART, HAROLD ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Bishop's Stortford, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments (Dec., 1884).

STUART, R. G., Political Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 19th Feb., 1873; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, Feb., 1876.

STURROCK, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at the High School, Dundee; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting secretary to government in the revenue department, Nov., 1873; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873, and again in 1880-81; Canarese translator to government, Jan., 1874; under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, July, 1875; additional sub-secretary, board of revenue, for special duty with famine commission, Nov., 1878, also acting as secretary, Jan., 1879; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1883.

STURT, W. NEVILLE, Revenue Statistics and Commerce Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 1st May, 1862; junior clerk, store department, 1862; accountant-general's department, 1863; military department, 1863; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1863-64, and 1868-77; senior clerk, revenue department, April, 1877.

SULLIVAN, HENRY EDWARD, C.S.I., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Cuddalore, Sept., 1866; civil and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1866; collector and magistrate, Bellary, March, 1868, and subsequently of Trichinopoly; officiating director of revenue settlement, Feb., 1874; acting member, board of revenue, and president of the committee for examination of assistants, April, 1876; in charge of the Inam department, May, 1876; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, March, 1877, to Feb., 1878; board of revenue, April, 1878; famine commission, Jan., 1879; 1st member, board of revenue, and commissioner, uncovented civil service examinations, Jan., 1879; on duty studying records of famine commission, April, 1879; on special duty in Godavari district, investigating causes of the disturbances in Rumpa country, July, 1879; on duty to England as member of famine commission, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Jan., 1881; in charge of settlement department, Feb., 1881; ordinary member of council, June, 1882; president of local self-government committee, June, 1882.

SURYA KUMAR AGASTI, M.A. Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, Purneah, on probation, March, 1885.

SWAIN, W. H., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th June, 1881; attached to military department.

SWETENHAM, EDMUND, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as ensign, 13th Dec., 1856; served under the military department up to 1859; assistant engineer, public works department, N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch, Feb., 1859; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; transferred to British Burma, May, 1872; transferred to Central India, and served from Sept., 1874, to Aug., 1880, as executive engineer, Mhow division, and officiating chief engineer; transferred to N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch, Aug., 1880, and promoted to superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1880; 2nd class, July, 1884.

SYAD ALAY MAHOMED, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Acting extra assistant commissioner, 4th class, 28th Jan., 1881; probationer for the native civil service, Dec., 1882; appointed member of the civil service, and
acting assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Raipur, Dec., 1883.

SYMES, EDWARD SPENCE, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at University College School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1876; served as assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the secretariat July and Nov., 1878; on special forest demarcation duty, Feb., 1879; personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1879; junior secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1881; also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner for various periods, and as settlement secretary, March-May, 1882.

SYMONDS, WILLIAM POWELL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Hereford Cathedral School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; member of the central committee for departmental examinations, April, 1884; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, 1884.

SZCZEPANSKI, HENRY CHARLES ANTHONY, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1857; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1857; assistant commissioner, Punjab, July, 1860; on special famine duty, Nov., 1861; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Nov., 1864, and served as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (1st class, Feb., 1885); officiating judicial commissioner, Feb.-May, 1883.

TAIT, JAMES SALISBURY, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—Served as assistant engineer on railway, and received a commission in the army for distinguished services in the mutiny, Jan., 1859; from Feb., 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and as assistant inspector-general, railway police; 1st grade superintendent, March, 1885.

TALBOT, ADELBERT CECIL, Captain, C.I.E., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1867; joined the Bengal staff corps, 1867, and served with 2nd cavalry, Hyderabad contingent; officiating assistant agent, Rajputana, 1873; attaché, secretariat, foreign department, 1874; assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1875; officiating assistant secretary to the government of India, legislative department, and officiating secretary to board of examiners, Calcutta, 1875-76; additional political agent, Eastern Rajputana states, 1881; political agent, Bhurtpore and Kerowlee, 1882; political agent, Bikaniir, 1883; graded as additional political agent, 1st class.

TALBOT, GERALD H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter’s College, Radley; supervisor, 1st grade, India store depot, 19th June, 1877.

TANNER, HENRY CHARLES BASKERVILLE, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Survey of India.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1854; accompanied the Persian expeditionary force of 1855; joined the survey department as assistant in the Sind revenue survey, Oct., 1862; was afterwards employed in the Central Provinces revenue survey, and was in charge of the Bombay city survey, Dec., 1869; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1870; was subsequently employed in the Bhawalpur revenue survey and the Deccan survey, and accompanied the Lushai expedition in 1871-72, and the Khyber column in the Afghan campaign, 1878-79; was afterwards in charge of the Darjeeling and Nepal boundary parties, Nov., 1882; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Oct., 1884.

TATE, ALEXANDER CHAMBERS, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen’s College, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

TATE, WILLIAM JACOB, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector, Salem, Jan., 1883.

TAUNTON, A. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Jesuits College, Tournay; writer, India store depot, 29th July, 1868; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

TAWNEY, C. H., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the department, Nov., 1864, and served as professor, Presidency College, up to Feb., 1877, when he was appointed principal of the college, and promoted to 1st class of the educational service; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1879.

TAWNEY, JAMES WALTER, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Repton School and King’s College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1863; served as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner, Bhootan, till Oct., 1865, and subsequently in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; also acted as small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, in 1873, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur in 1876; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Oct., 1881.

TAYLER, SKIPWITH HENRY CHURCHILL, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 2nd March, 1853; between July, 1854, and Sept., 1872, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade; from Sept., 1872, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1875.

TAYLER, WILLIAM VANSITTART GRAHAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived 6th Nov., 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector 1st grade Pubna, Oct., 1866.

TAYLOR, FREDERICK BEATSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ’s Hospital and King’s College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector.
TAYLOR, GEORGE NOBLE, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, in 1840; served in the grades of assistant and head assistant collector and magistrate, and was appointed secretary to the college and university boards, and assistant collector of customs at Madras in special charge of the salt department, 1849; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Rajamundry, 1851; acted as collector and magistrate of Nellore in 1857 and of South Arcot in 1858; Inam commissioner, 1858; special commissioner for railways, Calcutta, to report upon the affairs of the East Indian railway, May, 1863, and subsequently held a similar post at Bombay; provisional member of governor-general's council, 1864; ordinary member of council, March, 1865; retired, March, 1870.

TAYLOR, JAMES, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 1st Sept., 1865, and served in Bengal as assistant to the accountant-general, and officiating deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general, Feb., 1875.

TAYLOR, JOHN HENRY, Lieutenant, R.N.R., Marine Department, Madras.—Served from 21st April, 1874, as acting master attendant and registrar of shipping for the port of Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1876; on special duty in the military department, May, 1878, and in England, Aug.-Sept., 1884; sheriff of Madras, 1885.

TAYLOR, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Epsom College; junior clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1867.

TEAGUE, GEORGE F., Funds Department, India Office.—Senior book-keeper, funds department, India office, 28th Sept., 1866; head book-keeper, March, 1873.

TEMPLE, JOHN ALEXANDER, Major, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, 12th Aug., 1861; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted at various times as cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jubbulpore, and Kamptee; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, May, 1872-74, and again 1877; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Nov., 1884.

TEMPLE, SIR RICHARD, Bart., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate and collector; settlement officer, trans-Sutlej division, 1852; secretary to chief commissioner, Punjab, 1854; commissioner, Lahore, 1859; chief commissioner of currency and chief assistant to financial member of council, 1860; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; resident, Hyderabad, 1867; member of governor-general's council, 25th April, 1868; president of the statistical committee, 1868; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1874; governor of Bombay, 30th April, 1877, to 1880; retired from the civil service in 1877; chairman of the board of visitors, Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, 1880; author of 'Men and Events of my Time in India,' 1882, and 'Oriental Experience,' 1883.

TEMPLE, RICHARD CORMAC, Captain, B.S.C.—First commission, 4th Jan., 1871; from 11th Aug., 1879, served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, and cantonment magistrate, and was promoted to 1st class magistrate, Oct., 1882.

TEUNON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884.

THOMAS, GEORGE EBENEZER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed from the East India railway as assistant engineer, 28th Aug., 1867, and posted to the Central Provinces; transferred to the Punjab northern state railway, March, 1868; locomotive superintendent, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; executive engineer, April, 1876; transferred to Indus Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; 2nd class, revenue establishment, July, 1879; transferred to British Burma, Nov., 1881.

THOMAS, HENRY SULLIVAN, F.L.S., F.Z.S., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras from April, 1857, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs, member of the board of examiners, and acting civil and sessions judge; from May, 1867, to Sept., 1874, served as collector and magistrate of South Canara, and subsequently at Tanjore and as political agent for French settlement at Karikal; from April, 1878, served on the board of revenue, Madras, and acted as secretary to government in the revenue department in 1878-79; in charge of the Inam department, Jan.-April, 1879; president, board of examiners, Oct., 1881; on special duty as a member of the local self-government committee, Sept., 1882; on duty to Calcutta as an additional member of the governor-general's council for laws and regulations, Dec., 1882, and again, Dec., 1883; on special duty in connection with the pearl fisheries at Tuticorin, and deputed to study system of management in force in Ceylon, March-May, 1884; 1st member, board of revenue, July, 1884; on deputation to Tanjore district to report on necessity for granting remissions, April, 1885.

THOMAS, ROBERT MOSELY BRYCE, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—First commission as ensign, 6th Jan., 1859; arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting small cause court judge, and was appointed cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1876, and subsequently at Kamptee.

THOMAS, WILLIAM CHARLES, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as officiating adjutant of military police, Mainpuri, Dec., 1858, having previously served as a volunteer in General Havelock's cavalry, 1857-58; adjutant of military police, Oct., 1859; inspector of district police, Jan., 1861; district superintendent of police, May, 1861; transferred to Muttra, April, 1867; officiated as assistant inspector-general of the government railway police, July-Oct., 1868; district superintendent, 3rd grade, Meerut, Nov., 1872; on special duty with the camp of the lieutenant-governor, Dec., 1876, and again in March, 1878, with the governor-general's camp; 1st grade superintendent, Lucknow, April, 1885.

THOMASON, CHARLES SIMON, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1852; joined
the public works department, July, 1855, as deputy superintendent, Ganges canal; executive engineer, Rohilkund canals, Sept., 1864, and subsequently on the Ganges canal; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary, public works department, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1873; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Central India, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1882.

THOMPSON, ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Cuthbert's, Ushaw, and University of London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector, and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector, Cuddapah, Nov., 1884.

THOMPSON, SIR AUGUSTUS RIVERS, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, June, 1850; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1850; served in the revenue and judicial departments, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; junior assistant to the governor-general's agent, south-west frontier, Sept., 1853; superintendent of survey, Jan., 1859; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1859; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1859; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, April, 1861; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1861; officiating collector of customs, Nov., 1861; civil and sessions judge, Aug., 1865; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1868; officiating commissioner of revenue and circuit, presidency division, Jan., 1869; officiating secretary to the government of Bengal in the revenue and general departments, Sept., 1869, and in the judicial and political departments, Nov., 1871; secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1873; chief commissioner of British Burma, 1st May, 1877; governor-general's council, 18th April, 1878; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 24th April, 1882.

THOMPSON, DANIEL ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.I.E., Madras Medical Service.—Acting civil surgeon, Tellicherry, April, 1865, to Sept., 1866; joined the Indian medical service as assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1867; and served under the military department, also acting as zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail at Chingleput, April, 1868; and at Tinnevelly, April, 1869, to Sept., 1870; in medical charge of garrison, lock hospital, and meteorological observatories, Bellary, Dec., 1873; resident surgeon, general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology and materia medica in Medical College, March, 1875; from May, 1875, served as surgeon, 1st district, Madras, and medical inspector of emigrants; also superintendent of auxiliary provincial medical school and native infirmary, Royapooram; companion of order of Indian Empire, for special famine services in 1876-78, 1st Jan., 1879; surgeon-major, April, 1879.

THOMPSON, C. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th March, 1883.

THOMPSON, FREDERICK C., Public Works Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, accounts branch, 9th March, 1872; public works department, Aug., 1875.

THOMPSON, GEORGE, B.A., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Head master, Saugor high school, Sept., 1869, to Oct., 1875; served from Oct., 1875, as inspector of schools, Central Provinces.

THOMSON, JAMES, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Grammar School and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant collector and magistrate, Kistna, March, 1882.

THOMSON, JOHN BROWN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Academy and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Feb., 1882; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1882.

THOMSON, ROBERT GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Islington Proprietary School and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; junior secretary to financial commissioner, Dec., 1882; officiating under secretary (revenue department) to government, Punjab, June, 1883.

THORBURN, SEPTIMUS SMET, F.R.G.S., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Feb., 1885.

THORBURN, WALTER MILLER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dalhousie College and University, Halifax, University of Edinburgh, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1884.

THORNHILL, EDMUND BENSLEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 16th Aug., 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Feb. to Sept., 1865, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Fyzabad; magistrate and collector, Banda, March, 1872; civil and sessions judge, Banda, Nov., 1877.

THORNHILL, GEORGE, C.S.I., late Madras Civil Service.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, 7th April, 1843; served as assistant to collector and magistrate
THORNTON, ARTHUR PARRY, Captain, B.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—Ensign, 14th foot, 14th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, Jan., 1868; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Sept., 1871; served under government of Bengal in Purneah and Burdwan as relief circle officer during famine, March-Dec., 1874; served under the foreign department of the government of India from Jan., 1875, and acted as assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and as magistrate, Mount Abu, and assistant general superintendent for suppression of thuggee and dacoity; in charge of office of political agent, Marwar, Jan.-March, 1877; attached to foreign office during Delhi durbar, 1876-77; on military duty, 1878-79; from March, 1879, served under foreign department as cantonment magistrate at Morar and at Nasirabad; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Jan., 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Secunderabad, Feb., 1884.

THORNTON, EDWARD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse and at Haileybury College, where he obtained honours, and from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, Feb., 1830; served in the N.W. Provinces, first as settlement officer, and afterwards as magistrate and collector; commissioner in the Punjab, Jhelum division, 1849-58; made C.B. for his services during the mutiny; judicial commissioner of the Punjab, 1858; retired, 1860.

THORNTON, JAMES HOWARD, Brigade-Surgeon, B.A. and M.B. (London), Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1856; from 9th Nov., 1861, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon, besides service under the military department; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1868, and brigade surgeon, March, 1882; principal medical officer with the Indian forces, Egypt, 1885.

THORNTON, LESLIE MELVILLE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1883; officiating under secretary to government, May, 1884.
