THORNTON, THOMAS HENRY, C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford (1st class moderations; Pusey and Ellerton Hebrew scholar; and class, final schools); appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition, 1855; assistant commissioner, Punjab, 1857-59; personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, 1859-60; personal assistant to judicial commissioner, 1860-62; small cause court judge, Lahore, 1862-63; deputy commissioner, Delhi, 1863-64; secretary to the government of the Punjab, 1864-78, and was on two occasions temporarily in charge of the administration of the province; acted as foreign secretary to the government of India, 1876-77; additional member of governor-general's council, 1877-79; judge, chief court, Punjab, 1878-81; retired, 1881; fellow of University of Calcutta, 1875; vice-president, University College, Lahore, 1879.

THUILLIER, HENRY RAVENSHAW, Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Addiscombe, Aug., 1855, to June, 1857; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June 1857; arrived in India, 29th April, 1859; appointed to the survey department as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey, May, 1859; deputy superintendent, Sept., 1869; officiating superintendent, great trigonometrical survey, April-Oct., 1876; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1878; deputy surveyor-general in charge of the revenue survey branch, Oct., 1884.

TIDY, WILLIAM MEYMOTT, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; served in the N.W. Provinces from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Sept., 1878.

TINNEY, G. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th July, 1882.

TIRUVARUR MUTHUSWAMI AIYAR, B.L., C.I.E., Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 1st May, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the Madras revenue, judicial, and educational departments; deputy collector, July, 1859; magistrate of police, Nov., 1868; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of the University of Madras, April, 1872; on duty at the Imperial assembly, Delhi, Jan., 1877; judge, high court, Madras, Aug., 1883.

TIRU VENKATA PONNUSWAMI PILLAI, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 15th April, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the public works, military, and judicial departments, and was appointed 1st grade district munshi, April, 1866, principal sudr amin, July, 1872, and sub-judge, June, 1874; from May, 1880, acted as presidency magistrate for the town of Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1883; board of examiners, June, 1884; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, March, 1885.

TODD, JAMES HENTHORN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of police, and acting collector and magistrate.

TODD-NAYLOR, HENRY PAUL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882.

TOMKINS, WILLIAM PERCIVAL, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1860; joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Assam; transferred to Rangoon, British Burma, Jan., 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; transferred to
military works branch, Meerut, Nov., 1873; assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, 1882.

TOTTENHAM, LOFTUS RICHARD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 11th July, 1856; served as assistant magistrate, collector, and salt agent, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of stamps and stationery, Jan., 1866, and registrar of the high court, Dec., 1866; from Jan., 1874, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1878; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 16th July, 1879.

TOWERS, ROBERT MASON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1863; from July, 1867, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, Feb., 1879, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, July, 1879; from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1880, served as officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur.

TOYNBEE, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 27th Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; superintendent canal revenue, Oct., 1871; on famine relief duty, Nov., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1874; inspector of registration offices, April, 1877; special duty connected with compulsory irrigation rate, May, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878; special duty at the Bengal secretariat, July, 1878; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, March, 1884.

TOZER, H. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Jan., 1882.

TRACY, THOMAS BURROWES, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; served in the N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1858, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muttra, April, 1877, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Bareilly, 1883; additional judicial commissioner, Oudh, Feb., 1885.

TRAFFORD, RICHARD WYME, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

TRAIL, DAVID HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Bengal Public Works Department, Accounts Branch.—Madras engineers, 1856; from Sept., 1859, served in the Madras public works department; employed in the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862; assistant engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1865; from Jan., 1866, was employed in the accounts branch of the public works department, and served as controller of accounts in Mysore, Madras, Punjab, and Central Provinces; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1882; examiner of public works accounts, 1st class, Feb., 1884.

TREASURE, HENRY, Legal Department, India Office.—Principal clerk to legal adviser to the secretary of State, May, 1877.

TREASURE, W. H., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state.

TREMENHEERE, JAMES HENRY APPERLEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Lancing and Cheltenham Colleges; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); from May to Aug., 1883, served in Mysore as acting civil and sessions judge; served subsequently in Madras as head assistant collector, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and was appointed acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, June, 1884; officiating private secretary to the governor of Madras, May, 1885.

TREMLETT, JAMES DYER, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Hissar, Aug., 1878; additional commissioner, Umballa and Jullundur, Nov., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1881; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, April, 1883; additional judge, chief court, April, 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884.

TRETHEWY, ANTHONY WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; attached to the N.W. Provinces.

TREVELYAN, E. J.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1879-85; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1885.

TREVOR, ARTHUR CHARLES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1861, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue, and political agent, acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, acting municipal commissioner, and deputy commissioner of customs and opium (June, 1877); collector of customs, Bombay, April, 1879; acting commissioner of customs and collector of salt revenue, May, 1884; senior collector, Dec., 1884.

TREVOR, CHARLES BINNY, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, June, 1832; served in Bengal, in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector; magistrate of Backergunge, June, 1840; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 1849; judge of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, presidency, 1859; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1863; retired in 1867.
TREVOR, EDWARD WALTER, Colonel, Bombay S.C.—First commission, Infantry, April, 1855; arrived in India, 8th May, 1855; appointed acting superintendent of bazars and cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, March, 1864; from Nov., 1864, served in Sind, as deputy collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of police, and acting collector and magistrate; on military duty, Oct., 1879, to Jan., 1881, as general transport officer, Khyber line, and director, Kuram transport; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Jan., 1881; on special duty to Calcutta, in connection with the prosecution of commissariat frauds, Nov., 1881; collector and magistrate, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884.

TREVOR, FREDERICK G. B., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Marlborough College; East India House writer, old establishment, 10th March, 1853; junior clerk, public, educational, and ecclesiastical departments, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, July, 1875; judicial and public department, 1877.

TREVOR, JOHN SALUSBURY, Major-General, C.S.I., late R.E.—Passed out of Addiscombe, June, 1847; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, April, 1848; assistant superintendent of roads and tanks, 1849-55; transferred to railway department in Aug., 1855, as deputy consulting engineer; municipal commissioner, Bombay, 1861; resigned appointment in railway department, 1864; rejoined the public works department in Nov., 1866, as executive engineer, 1st grade, Tapti irrigation; consulting engineer and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, Nov., 1868; chief engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1870; acting deputy secretary to government of India in railway branch, 1871-72; resigned appointment in Bombay railway department, 1874; in England, 1874-78; officiating deputy secretary to government of India, railway branch, June, 1878; resigned the army, 1879, continuing in the public works department; director-general of railways, and deputy secretary, railway branch, 1880; retired in 1881; chairman of the Bombay, Baroda, and Central India, and the Rohilkund and Kumaon railway companies, and a director in several other Indian railway companies.

TREVOR, SALUSBURY THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1855, to Oct., 1863, served in British Burma as assistant engineer, executive engineer, assistant to chief engineer, British Burma, and assistant secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1863; served as garrison engineer, Fort William, and superintending engineer, 3rd class, and was appointed secretary to chief commissioner, Assam, public works department, July, 1869; chief engineer, and joint secretary public works department, Bengal, March, 1881; chief engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1883; on deputation in connection with International Exhibition buildings at Calcutta, July, 1883; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, railways and roads and buildings, Jan., 1884.

TREVOR, WILLIAM SPOTTISWOODE, Colonel, V.C., R.E., Public Works Department, India.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; employed on the Pegu survey, 1854; executive engineer, Bassein, Nov., 1855; assistant engineer, Darjeeling, Oct., 1857; executive engineer, Dinapore, Jan., 1860; garrison engineer, Fort William, Aug., 1860; controller and examiner of accounts, Bengal, May, 1863; superintending engineer, Calcutta, Jan., 1867; superintending engineer, military works, Calcutta, 1872; additional chief engineer for famine relief works, Bengal, 1874; officiating chief engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Indore, March, 1875; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1876; chief engineer and secretary, British Burma, March, 1880; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1881; secretary to government of India in the public works department, Feb., 1882.

TRIMNELL, DAVID WILLIAM, Brigade Surgeon, Central Provinces.—Joined the Madras medical service in 1856; civil surgeon, Narsinghpur, Central Provinces, 4th April, 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Raipur, June, 1867; surgeon-major, Feb., 1876; brigade-surgeon, Aug., 1883.

TROWARD, THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner.

TRUEMAN, THOMAS, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1856, and served on military duty up to June, 1872, and subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate at Poona and Kirkee, and cantonment magistrate, and city magistrate, Karachi; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmedabad, April, 1877, and subsequently at Belgaum; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877.

TUCKER, ALEXANDER LAUZUN PENDOCK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883.

TUCKER, HENRY ST. GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

TUCKER, HENRY PENDOCK ST. GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, in 1842; arrived in India, 14th April, 1843; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge in various districts in the Bombay presidency, and acted as deputy registrar of the Sudder court in Bombay, in 1845-46, and as judge and sessions judge, in 1853, and in 1856-57; acting first assistant accountant-general, Bombay, July, 1858; acting civil auditor, Bombay, Dec., 1858 to March, 1859; collector and magistrate, North Canara, July, 1862; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, Aug., 1862; appointed to report on the measures necessary for a redistribution of judicial jurisdic-
tion and modification of judicial establishments, Feb., 1863; officiating judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 7th April, 1866; retired in 1876.

TUCKER, LOUIS HENRY EMILLE, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1860; arrived in India, 11th April, 1861; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty with Major Cavagnari in connection with Kabul War, Nov., 1878, and again with the staff of Major-General Bright, Sept., 1879; promoted to 1st grade, district superintendent, Sept., 1880.

TUPP, ALFRED COTTERELL, B.A., F.S.S., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1862; from Oct., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty for the conduct of the case of the Munsif of Mahoba, Dec., 1867, and again, July, 1869, for the preparation of a statistical memoir of Fatehpur; assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, 1871; also subordinate judge from March, 1873; held charge of Provincial Gazetteer of N.W. Provinces, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Azimgarh, Aug., 1877; transferred to the financial department, government of India, Nov., 1878, and served in Madras, till 1881, as deputy accountant-general, deputy controller-general, and accountant-general, and commissioner of state paper currency; officiated as accountant-general in Bombay, Dec., 1881, to Dec., 1882, and in Bengal from the latter date; officiating controller-general, Sept.–Oct., 1883; from Nov., 1883, served as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency; author of 'The Indian Civil Service and the Competition System,' 1875; 'The Statistics of the North-West Provinces of India,' 1876; 'The Imperial Gazetteer of India—N.W.P. portion,' 1877; 'The Indian Civil Service List and Record of Services,' 1880; 'The Paris International Monetary Conference of 1881, and Bimetallism,' 1881; 'The Competitive Civil Service of India, from 1856 to 1882,' 1882.

TUPPER, CHARLES LEWIS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating under secretary to government, and was placed on special duty in office of financial commissioner, Sept., 1874, and with H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, Nov., 1875; appointed under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Sept., 1878; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880; from Feb., 1880, served under the government of India as under secretary and officiating secretary in the revenue and agricultural department, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1881 (in connection with the Bengal Rent Bill), and again, Feb., 1882; junior secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1882; on special duty in connection with scheme of local self-government, June-Oct., 1883.

TURNER, Sir Charles Arthur, Kt., C.I.E., late Judicial Department, Madras.—Appointed judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, and arrived in India, May, 1866; acted as chief justice in 1870, 1875, and 1878; chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, Jan., 1879; fellow of the University of Madras, Jan., 1879; member of the Indian law commission, Bengal, Feb.–Sept., 1879; vice-chancellor of Madras University, April, 1880, and May, 1882; retired, 1st July, 1885.

TURNER, EDWARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from May, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, and was employed on state famine relief operations, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1882; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1885; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Feb., 1885.

TURNER, Henry Gribble, Barrister-at-Law, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; from Aug., 1866, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty, Madras, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, Jan., 1868; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, March, 1875; postmaster-general, Madras, March, 1875, to June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as collector, magistrate, and political agent, Vizagapatam; appointed district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1884.

TUTE, ARTHUR CLIFFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, July, 1861; officiating superintendent, Chittagong hill tracts, June, 1863; deputy commissioner, Bhutan Dooras, Dec., 1864; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, Aug., 1870, to March, 1873; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Dinagepore relief works, March, 1874; from June, 1874, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge of the small cause courts, Krishnaghur, Ranaghat, and Meherpore, Oct., 1876; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Jan., 1881.

TWEEDIE, WILLIAM, Colonel, C.S.I., B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Jan., 1857; joined the staff corps, Oct., 1858; adjutant, 1st cavalry, Hyderabad contingent, March, 1859; acted as assistant to resident, Hyderabad, from 1863;
officiating agent to governor-general, Moorshedabad, 1876-77; officiating political agent, Gwalior, 1878-79; resident, Gwalior, 1881; officiating political agent Western Rajputana states, 1881, and afterwards in Turkish Arabia; officiating political resident, Turkish Arabia, 1883-84, and again from 1885.

TWEEDY, GEORGE ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate.

TWIGG, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer.

TWIGG, JOHN HILL, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was deputed on special duty under the commissioner of cotton and commerce for the organisation of carriage and supply of fodder for Bengal, Feb. to Sept., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1880; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Hamirpur, April, 1882.

TWISADAY, CHARLES EDWARD JAMES, Indo-European Telegraph Department.—2nd clerk in the London office; first appointed to the London offices of the Indo-European telegraph department on the 29th July, 1869; accompanied director-in-chief to Constantinople in 1880, and to the Persian Gulf in 1885 with the third Persian Gulf cable expedition, and afterwards to Calcutta.

TWOMEY, DANIEL HAROLD RYAN, Bengal C.S., British Burma.—Educated at St. Stanislaus College, Tullamore, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884.

TYRRELL, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived in India, 12th May, 1859; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating under secretary to government, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; registrar, high court, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1870; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1878; district and sessions judge, and grade, Jan., 1882; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882.

UDNY, RICHARD, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Feb., 1885.

UNDERWOOD, WALTER GREGORY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School and Chester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to the Laccadives, Nov., 1881; head assistant collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, Oct., 1882.

UNWIN, ARTHUR HAMILTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Sherborne, and Tonbridge Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1873, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, inspector of schools, acting judge of the small cause court, and acting director of public instruction; from Jan., 1880, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; 1st grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883; assistant judge and joint sessions judge, for Kaira and Panch Mehals, May, 1885.

UPTON, JOHN G., Registry Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 16th April, 1845; assistant to registrar, July, 1860; despatch clerk.

UPTON, R. L.—Government solicitor, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1881.

URQUHART, GEORGE MOORE, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884.

VAN SOMEREN, GODLIEB JAMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, Madras Infantry, Forest Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Sept., 1859; appointed to the forest department, May, 1864; conservator of forests, Mysore and Coorg, Jan., 1869; transferred to Punjab, 1881; assistant comptroller-general of forest accounts under the financial department, Jan., 1883; conservator of forests, Berar, 1885.

VEASEY, JOHN CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Sylhet, Dec., 1867; assistant settlement officer, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1880; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Aug., 1884; officiating inspector-general of police, Bengal, Oct., 1884.

VENKATA JAGA RAO CHENDIKA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 22nd Dec., 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; forest settlement officer, Oct., 1883; acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1885.

VENNING, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864; served from Aug., 1865, to Nov., 1868, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Nov., 1868, served in the
Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted as small cause court judge of Jubbulpore in 1874, and as secretary to the chief commissioner in 1878; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, June, 1880; commissioner of the Jubbulpore division, Aug., 1881, and of the Nagpur division, Nov., 1883.

VENTRIS, HENRY, Revenue Statistics and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School and Brighton College; supernumerary writer, 2nd Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Feb., 1864; junior clerk, revenue department, Jan., 1873; employed in records branch, 1879-1880; senior clerk, 1885.

VERNER, WILLIAM HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived 2nd Dec., 1863; from Nov., 1864, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed officiating assistant secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1867, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1877, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; also served as inspector of schools, April, 1866, and officiated as under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871, and as postmaster-general, Bengal, in 1871, 1872, and 1875.

VERTANNES, JOHN CARAPIET, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of Bengal as apprentice engineer, 8th May, 1855, and served in the public works department in that province, and temporarily in the Central Provinces in 1862; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1872; on famine relief works, Nov., 1873; superintending engineer, and class, Sept., 1882.

VERTUE, WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, M.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Jan., 1857; from 2nd Dec., 1862, to May, 1865, served in the police department of the Central Provinces as acting district superintendent, and personal assistant to the inspector-general; from May, 1865, served as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector of schools, and superintendent of the school of industry at Jubbulpore, 1867; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jan., 1877; small cause court judge, Nagpur, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Sept., 1883.

VIBART, HENRY MEREDITH, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1859; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, Sept., 1861; executive engineer, Dec., 1866; on special duty in Bangalore, Nov., 1877, to Feb., 1878; in special charge of the restoration of Tiroomal Naick's Palace, Madura, Feb., 1878; acting deputy chief engineer for irrigation, and under secretary to government, public works department, March, 1879; superintendent of works, Presidency, April, 1880; superintending engineer, April, 1884.

VIDAL, GEORGE WILLIAM, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty connected with the Jath state, March, 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1878; on special duty as a British member of the mixed commission at Goa, March-May, 1880, and Jan., 1885.

VOWELL, CHRISTOPHER HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived 4th Dec., 1867; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, July, 1884.

WACE, ALFRED AUGUSTUS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1881; also served as officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884.

WACE, EDWARD GEORGE, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1857; officiating cantonment magistrate, Peshawur, May, 1860, to July, 1861; assistant commissioner in the Punjab, Feb., 1863; officiating superintendent of Chamba, June, 1866; on special duty in the financial commissioner's office, Feb., 1867; settlement officer, Hazara, Nov., 1869; transferred to the Jhelum settlement, Jan., 1875; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; officiating settlement commissioner in the Mooltan and Derajat divisions, June-Dec., 1877; settlement commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; settlement and agriculture commissioner, Sept., 1882; second financial commissioner, Nov., 1884.

WADDINGTON, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, district registrar, and political agent, Sholapur, Oct., 1882.

WADE, EDWARD J., M.A.—Educated at Rugby and Dublin; scholar and exhibitioner; first senior classical moderator and gold medallist; assistant librarian, India office, 23rd May, 1881; late editor 'Allen's Indian Mail.'

WAKE, HERWALD CRAUFURD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1851; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Shahabad, 1858; C.B., May, 1860; magistrate and collector, Patna, 1861; superintendent, Darjeeling, 1862; retired on invalid pension, 1868.

WAKEFIELD, GEORGE EDWARD, Punjab Administration.—From 25th Aug., 1853, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; promoted to 1st class deputy commissioner, Feb., 1881.

WALKER, GEORGE CASSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester College and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty, Lahore, in connection with viceregal durbar, Oct., 1880; from
April, 1883, served in the financial department of the government of India, and was appointed assistant accountant-general, Punjab; transferred to office of accountant-general, Bengal, Dec., 1883.

WALKER, GEORGE WARREN, Lieutenant-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Second lieutenant, Madras engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; assistant civil engineer, 1847; district engineer, Canara, Sept., 1859; superintending engineer, Coimbatore, May, 1862; chief engineer, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, May, 1872; retired from the public works department in 1876.

WALKER, H. B., Store Department, India Office.—Matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877.

WALKER, JAMES WILLIAM, LL.B., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; on special duty in connection with the Baroda commission, Feb.–March, 1875; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan.–March, 1880; and grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Feb., 1885.

WALKER, THOMAS GORDON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was settlement officer of Ludhiana from May, 1878 to 1884; attached to civil secretariat on special duty in April, 1883; officiating under secretary, revenue department, to government, Punjab, April, 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept. to Dec., 1883; registrar of the chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1884.

WALKER, WILLIAM, Brigade-Surgeon, M.A., M.D., LL.D., F.R.C.S. (Ed.), Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855, and held various military medical charges in Bengal and N.W. Provinces; superintendent, central prison, Agra, March, 1858; superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1862; also chemical examiner, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1867; honorary magistrate, Allahabad, Aug., 1867; inspector-general of prisons and dispensaries, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1871, also for Oudh, March, 1877, to April, 1879; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general with local rank of surgeon-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1882.

WALL, RICHARD, M.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Benares, Feb., 1877; officiating civil and sessions judge, May, 1877, and in 1878; commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1882.

WALLACE, A. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

WALLACE, D. MACKENZIE.—Private secretary to the viceroy and governor-general (Right Hon. the Earl of Dufferin, G.C.B., G.C.M.G., K.P.), 13 Dec., 1884.

WALLACE, WILLIAM ARTHUR JAMES, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Assistant engineer, public works department, April, 1864; officiating deputy consulting engineer, railway branch, Bengal, Jan., 1869; assistant consulting engineer, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, Oct., 1871; officiating consulting engineer, Lucknow, 1877, and afterwards at Calcutta; engineer-in-chief, and manager, Northern Bengal state railway, Nov., 1879; 1st class state railway revenue establishment, June, 1881; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, Oct., 1884.

WALLACE-DUNLOP, ROBERT HENRY, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1843; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner and joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent, Dehra Dun, 1854; magistrate and collector, Meerut, 1856, and subsequently of Bareilly; during the mutiny was actively engaged in suppressing the rising in his district; made C.B. in 1860; officiating judge of Bareilly, 1862–64; retired in 1865.

WALLER, HARDRESS EDMOND, Colonel, B.S.C., Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th Aug., 1852; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, June, 1862; district superintendent, March, 1863; 1st grade, superintendent, March, 1884.

WALLER, RICHARD MAUNSELL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1868; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1878; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1879; from Oct., 1881, officiated as magistrate and collector of Bogra and Mymensingh.

WALPOLE, HORACE G., C.B., Assistant Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Eton; temporary clerk, India office, 12th Dec., 1862; junior clerk, June, 1863; store department, 1863; accountant-general's department, 1863–64; public works department, 1864; resident clerk, 1870–77; senior clerk, April, 1877; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, 1866–74, and to the secretary of state, 1874–80; also served as clerk of the council from 1877, and was appointed assistant to the under secretaries of state in addition to his other duties, Sept., 1881; assistant under secretary of state, Nov., 1883, continuing to be clerk of the council.

WALSH, ERNEST HERBERT COOPER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trent College and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived
in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884.

WALTER, CHARLES KENNETH MACKENZIE, Colonel, B.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 73rd native infantry, Bengal, Nov., 1852; assistant to commissioner, Ajmere, Jan., 1857; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Feb., 1858; political agent, Bhurtpore, Dec., 1862; resident, 3rd class, in the political department, 1876; political agent, Jodhpur, 1876; officiating as agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and chief commissioner, Ajmere, in 1876, and 1881-82; resident, 2nd class, and political agent, Meywar, 1880; resident in Meywar, 1882.

WARBURTON, ROBERT, Major, B.S.C., Political Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1862; from Sept., 1869, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special political duty in Khyber, July, 1879; employed with Cabul force, Oct., 1879; officiating judicial assistant commissioner, Peshawar, Nov., 1881; political officer, Khyber, Feb., 1882.

WARBURTON, WILLIAM PLEASE, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1866; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1866; assistant surgeon, Jullundur, Sept., 1867; surgeon to H.H. the Raja of Kapurthala, June, 1874; surgeon-major, March, 1878.

WARD, DAVID, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Sept., 1854; joined the public works department, Feb., 1859, as executive engineer, Oude; Chakrata division, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1868; transferred to military works, 1872; superintending engineer, Lahore, March, 1877, and subsequently at Meerut; superintending engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1882.

WARD, GEORGE ERNEST, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Jaunpur, July, 1879; on special duty on the education commission under the government of India, 1882; commissioner, Jhansi division, July, 1885.

WARD, HENRY CONSTANTINE EVELYN, Colonel, B.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, April, 1855; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Dec., 1864; acting inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Nov., 1873; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Sept., 1880; additional commissioner for the administration of affairs in Kalahandi, June, 1882; acting commissioner, Chattisgarh division, March-Nov., 1883, and again in 1884.

WARD, WILLIAM ERSKINE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1861, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866, and again in 1867, and in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March, 1873; from Oct., 1873, served in judicial department as acting district and sessions judge, and was transferred to Assam, March, 1876, and served as judge and commissioner of Assam Valley districts; officiated temporarily as judicial commission of Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; appointed fellow of University of Calcutta; officiating chief commissioner of Assam, July-Oct., 1883; president of provincial committee for collecting exhibits of Assam for Calcutta Exhibition, 1883.

WARDEN, AUGUSTUS BROOKE, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Kensington Grammar School and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1842; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, March, 1856; judge and sessions judge, and agent for governor, Surat, 1861; acting judge of the high court, May, 1865; judge and sessions judge of Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, Sept., 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1865; was also president of the departmental examinations committee for junior civilians for five years; retired, 1871.

WARDEN, FREDERICK, Captain, Marine Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian navy, 2nd March, 1852; from Dec., 1865, served as portmaster of Canning, and, in addition (from Jan., 1867), as assistant collector of customs and ex officio superintendent of customs; from Dec., 1866, acted as assistant master attendant, and agent for government consignments, Calcutta, and from March, 1870, as agent for transports; also government prosecutor for trial of pilots, May, 1873, to March, 1876; officiating deputy master attendant, Aug., 1875; officiated as port officer, March, 1876, to Aug., 1879, and performed duties of superintendent of dockyard, from March, 1876, to Nov., 1877; assistant port officer, Aug., 1879; examiner in navigation, Nov., 1879; transferred to Rangoon as port officer, March, 1882; also superintendent of lighthouses, superintendent of mercantile marine, and transport agent.

WARDEN, JOHN LODWICK, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 8th March, 1852, and served in the Bombay covenanted civil service as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and deputy magistrate in charge of the Adalat, Hyderabad; resigned the covenanted civil service, May, 1858; appointed extra assistant secretary to government of Bombay, in the judicial department, Dec., 1866; assistant judge and sessions judge, April, 1867, to June, 1868; acting magistrate of police, July-Oct., 1868; from Jan., 1869, served as judge of the court of small causes, and was promoted to third judge, Dec., 1874.

WATERS, GEORGE, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (Ed.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1860; arrived in India, 27th May, 1870, and served in the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, Bombay, and civil surgeon at Bushire (1871-75); on special duty under the government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March-April, 1877; surgeon to governor of Bombay, May, 1877;
from Oct., 1881, served as third physician and registrar, Jamsetji Jijibhoy hospital, curator of the pathological museum, and professor of pathology, Grant Medical College; also acted as second physician and professor of physiology.

WATERFIELD, Henry, C.B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; junior clerk, 1st Sept., 1853; India board, financial and railway department, 1853; political and secret department, 1856; India office, financial department, 1858; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1860; financial department, 1863; senior clerk, April, 1863; assistant secretary in the military department, 1867; public works department, 1871; secretary in the statistics and commerce department, 1874; secretary, financial department, 1879; author of the first report on the moral and material progress of India, 1866, and of a memorandum on the census of British India of 1871-72, both of which were presented to Parliament.

WATERFIELD, William, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal C.S. from Haileybury in 1852; served in Bengal in the revenue and survey departments till 1859, when he was transferred to the financial department as 1st assistant to the accountant-general for India; acted as sub-treasurer, Madras, and as civil auditor and superintendent of stamps, Madras, Calcutta, and Bombay; from 1864 to 1877 served successively as civil paymaster, deputy accountant-general, and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; comptroller-general, 1877-80; retired 1881.

WATERFIELD, William Garrow, C.S.I., Colonel B.S.C. (Barrister-at-Law), Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1852; from Sept., 1857, served in the Punjab as personal assistant to commissioner of Delhi, and assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1863, to Nov., 1865; assistant settlement officer, Gujrat, Nov., 1865; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1867; on special duty for reporting on the Gujrat settlement, July, 1868; commissioner and sessions judge, Peshawur, Feb., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Sept., 1878; on special duty, Nov., 1878 (with the Kurram field force); served under the foreign department of the government of India, 1881-82.

WATERHOUSE, James, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1859; assistant revenue surveyor, Lower Provinces, June, 1866; assistant surveyor with superintendence of the photozincographic operations in the office of the surveyor-general of India, July, 1866; on special duty with the Indian eclipse expedition, Nov., 1871, to Jan., 1872, and for observing the transit of Venus, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; in charge of Indian eclipse expedition to Nicobar Islands, March, 1875; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Jan., 1884.

WATKINS, Lawrence Augustus, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1863; served in the Bombay judicial department from Jan., 1865, as deputy registrar of the high court, clerk to the high court judges, and commissioner for taking affidavits; also acted as assistant commissioner for taking accounts, and assistant taxing master, Aug.-Oct., 1878.

WATSON, H. E., Uncov. C.S., Bombay.—Arrived in India, 29th June, 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, June, 1879; in charge of the special duty of the salt department in Sind, July-Oct., 1880; on special duty in the military department, June, 1881; head assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, June, 1885.

WATSON, Sir John, Major-General, K.C.B., V.C., Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1848; from Sept., 1871, served as acting commandant Central India horse and political agent; resident, 2nd class, and agent to the governor-general at Gwalior, April, 1877; on special duty, Nov., 1878 (at Lahore), and Nov., 1880; in political charge of the district of Kurum, Nov., 1879; resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general, Baroda, Jan., 1882.

WATSON, John Whaley, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 6th Oct., 1854, and served under the military department till Feb., 1863, and subsequently in the political department as political assistant and acting political agent, Káthiáwar; also acted as assistant resident, Baroda, and superintendent of Gaékwár's contingent, Oct., 1863; special assistant, Gondal, March, 1872; political superintendent of Pálánpur, March, 1873, and political agent, Rewa Kánthá, March, 1876; appointed joint administrator of Bávnagar, March, 1877; president of the Rajasthánik court, Káthiáwar, July, 1878; acting political agent, Kolhapúr and Southern Mahratta country, May, 1885.

WATT, Arthur Chorley, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academy, Gosport, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardárs in the Deccan; registrar of the high court, Bombay, June, 1872; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Dharwar, Dec., 1880; 1st grade judge, May, 1882.

WATT, G., M.D., Educational Service, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th July, 1873; arrived, 4th Nov., 1873; served in the 3rd class of the Bengal education department as professor, Presidency, Hooghly, and Patna Colleges, and as officiating principal, Krishnagur College, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Burma-Munipore boundary expedition, Oct., 1881; services placed at disposal of executive committee of the Calcutta International Exhibition, Feb., 1883; served temporarily under government of India, revenue and agricultural department, May, 1884.

WATTS, Charles William Paxton, Bengal C.S. North-Western Provinces.—Educated at University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1859; served in the Punjab from Jan., 1860, to Nov., 1866, as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge; transferred to the N.W. Provinces, and appointed assistant settlement officer, 2nd grade, Nov., 1866, joint magistrate and deputy collector,
1st grade, April, 1867; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, July, 1877; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Saharanpur, June, 1884.

WEBB, W. T., M.A., Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 6th April, 1875; professor, Dacca College, May, 1875; officiated as inspector of schools, Feb., 1877; professor, Presidency College, from Jan., 1878; officiating principal, Calcutta Madrasa, Oct., 1880; 3rd class, education department, Dec., 1880.

WEBSTER, EDMUND FORSTER (Barrister-at-Law), Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from June, 1859, and was appointed small cause court judge, Madura, May, 1867, and afterwards at Cuddalore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, June, 1873, and at Trichinopoly, Aug., 1873; collector and magistrate and agent, Tanjore, April, 1878; on special duty in connection with the famine commission, Oct., 1878, and again, Aug., 1881, as secretary to the famine code committee; member of the forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1882; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, July, 1883, and again, July, 1885; chief secretary to government of Madras, Jan., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884.

WEBSTER, HENRY BINNY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 17th June, 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Nov., 1867, and subsequently at Gorakhpur and Meerut; commissioner, Jhansi division, Jan., 1878; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880.

WEDDERBURN, FRANCIS EDWARD KEIR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

WEDDERBURN, SIR WILLIAM, Bart., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 25th Nov., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judicial assistant to the commissioner in Sind, and small cause court judge; acting under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1866; acting registrar-general of assurances, Oct., 1866; acting secretary to government in the judicial, political, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Dec., 1866; under secretary to government, judicial and political departments, May, 1867; acting registrar, high court, Jan., 1867; acting judicial commissioner in Sind and judge of the Sadar court, May, 1874, to Feb., 1876; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, June, 1875; on special duty in Bombay, Nov., 1876; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, May, 1882; on special duty under government of India, April-May, 1884; acting judge, high court, Bombay, Jan., 1885.

WEEKES, ARTHUR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1879; on famine relief duty at Madras, Feb., 1877.

WEIDEMANN, GEORGE LEVER, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1870, and served in the British Burma commission as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner (3rd grade, May, 1884); on special duty in Rangoon, July, 1879.

WEIR, CHARLES JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Royal Belfast Academical Institution and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; from May, 1884, served in Coorg as officiating first assistant commissioner and district magistrate.

WEIR, JOHN WILLIAM ALLEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin School, Hammersmith, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885.

WEIR, PATRICK ALEXANDER, Surgeon, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service 1875; officiating 2nd resident surgeon, presidency general hospital, 22nd Aug., 1876; on special duty with lieutenant-governor on tour in cyclone districts, Nov., 1876; superintendent of vaccination, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, March, 1882; principal assistant to opium agent, Benares, May, 1882.

WEIR, THOMAS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1867, and served in Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate; deputy registrar, high court, Jan., 1870, to June, 1872; acted as registrar, high court, Feb., 1874, to Feb., 1880; Tamil translator to government, Jan., 1879; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Godaveri, March, 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; confirmed as registrar, high court, April, 1882; from July, 1883, acted as district and sessions judge in the districts of Coimbatore, North Tanjore, and Madura, and was placed on special duty in connection with the reorganization of the subordinate judicial service, Nov., 1883.

WEIR, T. S., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1870; health officer, Bombay, from 1874; surgeon-major, April, 1882.

WELD, MATTHEW RICHARD, B.A.—Madras C.S.—Educated at Dublin University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector,
acting cantonment magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as district and sessions judge, Kistna, Jan.–March, 1885, and as collector and magistrate in the same district from April, 1885.

WELDON, THOMAS, Colonel, M.S.C., Judicial Department, Madras.—Joined Addiscombe, Jan., 1852; arrived in India, 12th April, 1854; from July, 1860, served in the Madras police department as assistant superintendent and superintendent; senior magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1867; on special duty, in connection with the note forgery case, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; on special duty in Burma in connection with the commissariat case, Nov., 1879; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882.

WELLS, WILLIAM, Uncov, C.S., Accounts Department, Burma.—Assistant deputy commissioner of paper currency in Sind, June, 1865, also editor of Sind portion of 'Gazetteer,' and deputy branch registrar-general in Sind, Nov., 1868; from April, 1871, to Jan., 1882, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general, and assistant commissioner of paper currency (April, 1877), and officiated as deputy accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; from Jan., 1882, served in the Punjab as officiating deputy accountant-general, and officiating accountant-general and deputy commissioner of paper currency; transferred to Burma, March, 1883, and served as comptroller, and commissioner of paper currency for Rangoon; 2nd class, financial department, April, 1885.

WELLS, WALTER FOX WILLIAMSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner.

WELSH, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, assistant sessions judge, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, Jan., 1885.

WEST, EDWARD WILLIAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th March, 1856; acting assistant political agent, Mahi Kántha, Sept., 1865; assistant political agent, Kolhapur and Southern Mahratta country, Jan., 1867; on duty to England with His Highness the Raja of Kolhapur, Feb., 1870; acting political superintendent, Savantvadi, Dec., 1872; joint administrator of Sángli, Dec., 1873; acting political agent, Mahi Kántha, July, 1878; acting political superintendent, Pálanpur, March, 1881; assistant political agent, Káthiáwar, Sept., 1881; political agent, Káthiáwar, Sept., 1883.

WEST, RAYMOND, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, F.R.G.S., LL.D., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1856, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, officiating under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, registrar of the high court, and acting judge and sessions judge; judicial commissioner and judge of the Sadar court in Sind, June, 1872; judge of the high court, Bombay, Sept., 1873; on special duty as member of the law commission, Calcutta, April–Nov., 1879.

WESTERN, JAMES HALLIFAX, Major, R.E.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1860; assistant engineer public works department, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1863; Eastern Jumna canal, Jan., 1864; executive engineer, Ganges canal, June, 1868; superintendent of works, Betwa canal, Nov., 1881; transferred to Punjab as temporary superintending engineer, Sirhind canal, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, Nov., 1884.

WESTLAND, JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen, and Wimbledon School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 10th Oct., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1867, and officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1869, and officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1870; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Dec., 1870; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Aug., 1873; accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nagpore circle, Dec., 1873; on special duty in the home department, Nov., 1875; inspector of local offices of accounts, Nov., 1877; accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878; comptroller-general and head commissioner, department of issue of state paper currency, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884.

WESTMACOTT, EDWARD VESEY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 8th Jan., 1863; from July, 1863, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was on famine relief duty, Jan., 1874; officiating commissioner Dacca division, Aug., 1882; on special duty for the purpose of reporting on the existing Chowkidary system, Nov., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1883; services placed temporarily at disposal of financial department, Oct., 1883; officiating inspector-general of jails, March, 1884.

WESTROPP, GEORGE RALPH COLLIER, Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1851; acting assistant magistrate in Ratnágiri, May, 1860; assistant to political superintendent, Sávantvádi, Nov., 1862; assistant political agent, Kolhapur, Oct., 1866; in charge Southern Mahratta Jághir states, June, 1871; political superintendent, Sávantvádi, Aug., 1871; deputed on special duty in the Savanúr state, 1880.

WHALLEY, PAUL, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st
Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating junior secretary, and under secretary to government; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Dec., 1871; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, in Oudh, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, Pilibhit, Nov., 1879; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Oct., 1883.

WHEELER, PERCY COTTERILL (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 13th Sept., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant settlement officer, Jaunpur, March, 1883.

WHISH, CHARLES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tonbridge School and Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1883.

WHISHAW, JOHN CHARLES, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 3rd Sept., 1858, and held various military medical charges up to 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, April, 1860; superintendent, central prison and district jail, Lucknow, Nov., 1867, also civil surgeon, Feb., 1868; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Oct., 1870, also ex-officio inspector-general of prisons, March, 1871; civil surgeon, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Lucknow, Oct., 1873, also in charge of meteorological observatory, Lucknow, Dec., 1877.

WHITE, EDMUND, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, Feb., 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880; also under secretary to government in the census department; on special duty in connection with census, Sept., 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1882; director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1885.

WHITE, H. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 4th Dec., 1872; graduated B.A., London University, with French honours, in 1882.

WHITE, HERBERT THIRKELL, Bengal C.S. (British Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1878, and served in the British Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; on special duty, Rangoon, April, 1880; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1880; officiating deputy commissioner, Thayetmyo, April, 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, April-Sept., 1882, and again in 1883; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1882.

WHITE, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Dec., 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Rajputana under the foreign department of the government of India as officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and acted as superintendent, Rajputana state railway police, and also held charge of the office of political agent, Jaipur; served again under the foreign department of the government of India, May, 1876, to Dec., 1881, in Ajmere as assistant commissioner and political agent, 3rd class, and officiated as resident (3rd class) and commissioner of Ajmere, May-Aug., 1878; also acted as general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity, Nov., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, July, 1883.

WHITE, JOHN HUBBARD, Colonel, R.E., Mint Master, Bombay.—Second lieutenant, Bombay engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, Nov., 1855; from June, 1856, served in the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer and executive engineer (for irrigation); from May, 1865, to Feb., 1874, served as deputy consulting engineer and acting consulting engineer for railways, Bombay; acting superintending engineer, Feb., 1874; acting chief engineer, and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, June-Dec., 1874; transferred to financial department of government of India as acting mint master, Bombay, June, 1876; rejoined the railway department, Feb., 1878; from March, 1879, served as mint master and mint engineer, Bombay.

WHITE, PHILIP JAMES, North-Western Provinces.—Signaller in telegraph department, July, 1854; was employed in various capacities in several government offices till outbreak of mutiny, when he served with a body of volunteer horse and was present at various engagements; mutiny medal; deputy collector and deputy magistrate, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1858; assistant settlement officer, Nov., 1859; from March, 1863, served in the Jhansi commission as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jalaun, Dec., 1879; settlement officer, 1st grade, April, 1885.

WHITESIDE, WILLIAM SOUTHEY, Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras from March, 1857, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy secretary to government, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; from June, 1862, acted as civil and sessions judge of Chingleput, small cause court judge of Cuddalore, 1866-67, and as civil and sessions judge of Tanjore, 1868-70; served subsequently as collector and magistrate of North Arcot, and at Trichinopoly and Tanjore; on special duty as member of the forest draft bill committee in Otacamund, May, 1882; served on the board of revenue from Aug., 1882, in charge of the Inam department; acting president of the board of
examiners, Nov., 1882; acted as director of revenue settlement and agriculture and Inam commissioner, April-July, 1884; on deputation in the southern districts for reporting on working of Licence Tax Act, Dec., 1884.

WHITEWAY, RICHARD STEPHEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of London and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting assistant secretary to government, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1879; settlement officer, 3rd grade, on special duty at Aligarh, Nov., 1881; settlement officer, Ajmere and Merwara, Jan., 1883.

WHITMORE, JOHN (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, Dec., 1881.

WHITTEN, RICHARD JOHN, Salt Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service in Feb., 1862, as assistant patrol; deputy inspector, internal branch, Jan., 1867; on deputation to inquire into illicit manufacture of salt in Behar, 1869; personal assistant to commissioner of inland customs, Oct., 1869; collector of customs, Sept., 1871; on deputation to report on salt taxation in Sind, July-Aug., 1872; 1st grade collector, July, 1876; on deputation in Rajputana to report on salt sources in connection with proposed abolition of inland customs line, July-Oct., 1877; employed temporarily under government of Bombay in salt inquiries in Kutch and Kathiawar; deputy commissioner of inland customs, Dec., 1879.

WHITWORTH, GEORGE CLIFFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sandicroft School, Northwich, and Queen's College, Liverpool; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council, Jan., 1876; (pro tem.) under secretary to government in the public works department for relief purposes, Sept., 1877, to March, 1878; second assistant collector, Feb., 1881.

WICKES, THOMAS HAINES, Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by government of India as special assistant engineer, April, 1861; engineer to the suburban municipality, Calcutta, Jan., 1865; on special duty in the famine districts, May, 1874, and in connection with the Eastern Bengal railway, April, 1875, also with the secretary to the government of Bengal, March, 1878; assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintending engineer, 3rd class, special, Sept., 1882.

WIGHT, JOHN KNOX, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Queen's Collegiate School, Trinidad, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1872, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, April, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, March, 1884.

WIGNER, JOHN M., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's Lynn Grammar School, B.A. and B.Sc., London University; temporary clerk, India office, 17th July, 1862; junior clerk, Jan., 1867.

WILKINS, CECIL ANSDELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1868; from Dec., 1868, served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating registrar, high court, April, 1880, and again from 1881 to 1884; on special duty in the high court, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; registrar, high court, March, 1885.

WILKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the Bengal artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, Jan., 1858; studied at Thomason College, Roorkee, March, 1861, to Aug., 1862; served in the revenue survey from April, 1863, as assistant surveyor, and was employed in the Central Provinces, Punjab, Midnapur, Dearah, and British Burma surveys; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1878.

WILKINSON, FRANCIS HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Milton Abbas School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in Madras from Feb., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as under secretary to government in the revenue department, Aug.-Nov., 1867; on special duty as arbitrator of boundary disputes, June, 1870; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Salem, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, June, 1882.

WILKINSON, THOMAS ORMEROD, Bengal C.S.
