(Punjab).—Educated at Chudleigh Grammar School and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; officiated as registrar of the chief court in 1878, 1879, and 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Amritsar.

WILLIAMS, EDWARD C. S., Colonel, C.I.E., R.E., India Office.—Commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; arrived in India, 1850; adjutant of engineers, Fort William, and studying machinery in Calcutta mint, 1850; extra assistant secretary, military board, 1851; superintendent, iron bridge yard, Calcutta, 1851-52; served with the Pegu expedition, 1852-53, as adjutant of engineers and in charge of engineer park; superintendent, Pegu topographical survey, 1854-56; principal, Civil Engineering College, Calcutta, 1856-60; member of senate, Calcutta University; acted as under secretary to government of India, public works department, for one
year, during mutiny; principal, Thomason College, Roorkee, 1861-62; under secretary, government of India, public works department, 1863-69; member of Bengal sanitary commission; in charge of office of inspector-general of forests for one year; acting mint master and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, 1867; deputy secretary, government of India, public works department (railway branch), 1869-74, and again, 1877-78; director of state railways, 1874-77; deputy government director of Indian railway companies, India office, March, 1880.

WILLIAMS, FLEETWOOD, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1831; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating political agent, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1841; magistrate and collector, Bareilly, 1845; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Meerut division, 1857; retired in 1870.

WILLIAMS, GEORGE ROBERT CARLISLE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, acting deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, March, 1883.

WILLIAMS, HENRY CLISSOLD, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; from Nov., 1878, served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, Jan., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1884.

WILLIAMS, JOHN CHARLES, Bengal C.S., (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London, and Uppingham School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from Jan., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was specially deputed to Lucknow for the purpose of compiling and reporting on census, March, 1869; from May, 1875, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1880.

WILLIAMS, RALPH KING, Public Works Department, Central Provinces.—From Nov., 1869, to Feb., 1873, served in the office of the consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, as accountant and deputy controller, and was appointed assistant examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in 1872; served in Madras from Feb., 1873, to March, 1878, and was appointed deputy examiner, May, 1876; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in Calcutta, March to May, 1878, and subsequently in Madras, and at Lahore, March, 1880; examiner, 4th class, Indus valley state railway accounts, Aug., 1880; transferred to Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1885.

WILLIS, JOHN, Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 3rd Nov., 1862; junior book-keeper, Nov., 1868; assistant book-keeper, Dec., 1881.

WILLOCK, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th March, 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector; on special duty, Jan., 1876, as member of the salt commission; from March, 1879, served in the salt department as deputy commissioner, and acting commissioner (Jan. to July, 1884), and was also employed in suppressing the disturbances in the Gudum Hills, May, 1879.

WILLOUGHBY, MICHAEL WEEKES, Colonel, C.S.I., Bo. S.C.—First commission, Bombay army, June, 1849; acted as secretary to government of Bombay in the military, marine, and ecclesiastical departments from 21st May, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881.

WILLSON, J., M.A., Bengal Educational Service (Assam).—Professor, Cathedral Mission College, Calcutta, Jan., 1870; assistant, geological survey of India, Sept., 1871, to Feb., 1873; professor, Hooghly College, March, 1873; Dacca College, Jan., 1874; Patna College, May, 1875; 3rd class of the education department, Aug., 1878; from Jan., 1879, served in Assam as inspector of schools.

WILSON, ARTHUR.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1878.

WILSON, GEORGE HERBERT DASHWOOD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton and Magdalene College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 26th Nov., 1863, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, May, 1880; senior collector, May, 1885.

WILSON, JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Perth Academy and University of Edinburgh; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; on special duty, April, 1879, and again, Oct., 1880, in the civil secretariat; officiating under secretary to government, July, 1881; on special duty at Simla for the purpose of writing the final report on the Sirsa settlement, Aug., 1883.

WILSON, JOHN HATTON, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Bengal.—Probationary assistant engineer, 5th March, 1856; served in the public works department in the Central Provinces, and temporarily in Oudh, 1865-67, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; temporarily transferred to military works branch, July, 1879; in charge of the Nagpore and Chattisgarh railway reconnaissance survey division, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, Class III, and transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, Class II, sub pro tem., Jan., 1884.

WILSON, ROBERT HENRY, B.A., Bengal
C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating registrar-general of assurances, Sept., 1870; also officiating marriage registrar, Calcutta; officiating under secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1870; inspector of registration offices, July, 1872; officiating inspector-general of registration, Sept., 1872; officiating secretary, board of revenue, July, 1877, and again in 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884.

WILSON, THOMAS CORBY, Bengal C.S., (Central Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served as supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nagpur; acting district superintendent of police, Hoshangabad, Sept.–Nov., 1884.

WILSON, WILLIAM, M.A., Madras C.S.—Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, from July, 1861, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna, Feb., 1874, and collector and magistrate, June, 1877; on special duty for compiling irrigation accounts, Nov., 1875, and again, Oct., 1879, and Aug., 1881; acting director of revenue settlement, April, 1878, to Sept., 1879; collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Oct., 1879, to Aug., 1881; director of revenue settlement, and agriculture, Nov., 1882; in charge of the Inam department, March, 1883; also an additional member, board of revenue, April, 1883; permitted to visit on duty agricultural institutions in N.W. Provinces and Bombay, Nov., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; acting secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, April, 1885.

WILSON, WILLIAM HENRY, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd Jan., 1857, and was employed on military duties till April, 1864, when he was appointed acting assistant political agent, Sádra; from Nov., 1864, served as assistant superintendent of police, subordinate magistrate, superintendent of railway police on Bombay, Baroda, and Central India railway, and district superintendent; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, June, 1883.

WILTSHERE, CHARLES PALMER BLUETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at City of London School, King's College, London University, and Middle Temple; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting port officer at Karwar, and superintendent, timber depot, Kanara; and assistant collector, Oct., 1881.

WIMBERLEY, REGINALD JUSTUS, Lieutenant-Colonel, B.S.C.—Ensign, 3rd Bengal European regiment, 1859; served in the Punjab police force, Dec., 1861–67; commissariat department, March–Aug., 1867; from Aug., 1867, to 1872, served in Bengal as district superintendent of police; in command of police force to quell insurrection in the tributary Mehals, May, 1868; 1st assistant superintendent, Port Blair and Nicobars, April, 1872; deputy superintendent, 1885; called to the bar, Inner Temple, Nov., 1877.

WINCHESTER, CHARLES BLAKE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting forest settlement officer, and acting junior collector and political agent; on famine duty, Sept. 1877.

WINCHESTER, E. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 16th Dec., 1872; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1873.

WINGATE, ANDREW, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, Kensington Grammar School, University of London, and University of Heidelberg; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Bombay administration report for 1874–75, and for 1875–76; in political charge of the Jath state, Feb.–Sept., 1876; additional secretary in the famine department under chief commissioner of Mysore, Aug., 1877; assistant secretary to famine commission, Aug., 1878; on settlement duty in Oodeypore state, Aug.; 1879.

WINGFIELD, SIR CHARLES JOHN, K.C.S.I., C.B.—Educated at Westminster School and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1839; arrived in India, March, 1840; served in the revenue and judicial departments of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; on the annexation of the kingdom of Oudh in 1856, was appointed commissioner of the trans-Gogra division, and was actively engaged in the suppression of the mutiny, 1857–59; chief commissioner of Oudh, March, 1859; C.B., 1860, and K.C.S.I., 1866; retired, 1866; sat in parliament for the borough of Gravesend, 1868 to 1874.

WINTER, EDGAR FRANCIS LATIMER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WINTER, HENRY EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College and King's School, Canterbury; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate and forest settlement and demarcation officer, Poona districts, Jan., 1883.

WINTERBOTHAM, HENRY MARTIN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting Malayan translator to government; March–Dec., 1877; acting sub-secretary, board
of revenue, June–July, 1883; acted for various periods as collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, and as collector and magistrate, Tinnevelly, April to June, 1885.

WISE, FRANCIS JOHN, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd May, 1857; employed on military duties till Oct., 1863, and served subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; also served as boundary commissioner, and assistant political agent, Khândesh; member of committee to report to government on system of rural administration, July, 1873; on special duty on western frontier of Karachi district, Feb., 1875; on special duty in attendance on H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; member of the railway robberies inquiry committee, Bombay, March-Aug., 1878; superintendent of Great Indian Peninsula railway police, June, 1878; on special duty, June, 1879, to June, 1880; 1st grade superintendent, May, 1882; acting inspector-general of prisons, May-Aug., 1884; inspector-general of police for the Bombay presidency, Jan., 1885.

WODEHOUSE, CHARLES, Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, March, 1857; arrived in India, 6th April, 1857, and served in the military department till March, 1867, and subsequently as boundary settlement commissioner, Baroda; from Sept., 1868, acted in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, director of public instruction, and small cause court judge; acting assistant resident, Hyderabad, April, 1870; acting cantonment magistrate and judge, Secunderabad, Dec., 1870; acting assistant resident, Baroda, Jan., 1873; acting political agent, Rewa Kántha, Feb., 1873; from March, 1873, served in Káthiáwar as political assistant, acting judicial assistant, and acting political agent, and was placed on special duty for the settlement of boundary disputes in the Gheer forest, July, 1874; also acted as private secretary to the governor of Bombay from May, 1876, to April, 1877; political agent, Mahi Kántha, Sept., 1881; and grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, April, 1885.

WOLFE-MURRAY, FRANCIS D'Arcy Osborne, Madras C.S.—Educated at Harrow and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, acting principal assistant collector, assistant sessions judge, forest settlement officer, and sub-collector and joint magistrate.

WOLLASTON, ARTHUR N., C.I.E., Revenue, Statistics, and Commerce Department, India Office.—Educated at Stockwell Grammar School; entered the India office by open competition as writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, political and secret department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1873; assistant secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Jan., 1884; in 1877 published a translation of the 'Anvár-i-Suhaili' or Fables of Bidpai; in 1879 edited Sir Lewis Pelly's miracle play of 'Hasan and Husain'; appointed to succeed Sir F. J. Goldsmid as examiner in Persian at the Royal Staff College, Sandhurst, 1880; selected in 1881 by the science and art department to superintend the translation of the oriental inscriptions in the South Kensington Museum; in 1882 published an English-Persian dictionary (the first of its kind); C.I.E., 1st Jan., 1886.

WOMACK, ARTHUR SHAW, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882.

WOOD, EDWARD SEPTIMUS, Captain, Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland highlanders, 20th Sept., 1857; from Dec., 1859, served in the public works department on irrigation works, N.W. Provinces; officiated as conservator of forests, 1864-66; reverted to his regiment, Feb., 1866; appointed executive engineer, 4th grade, March, 1867; from April, 1867, served in the forest department, Oudh, and was appointed conservator, Oct., 1868; promoted to 2nd grade, Sept., 1882.

WOOD, G. P., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough and Addiscombe; writer, India office, 25th Jan., 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

WOOD, HENRY MACKENZIE MACDONALD, Major, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; also district judge.

WOODBURN, ARCHIBALD FRANCIS, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Ayr Academy and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; also acted as forest settlement officer, and as junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, June, 1885.

WOODBURN, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Ayr Academy, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Feb., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed officiating personal assistant to the chief commissioner, March, 1872; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1872; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, in the Oudh revenue department and forest branch, Jan., 1882; also in the Oudh political department, March, 1882.

WOODCOCK, ELBOROUGH MARTIN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bombay S.C., Police Department, North-Western Provinces; arrived in India as ensign, 9th March, 1856; appointed to Oudh military police, 27th Nov., 1858; from March, 1860, served in the police department as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1880.

WOODWARD, HILLERSDEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School and Birmingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive ex-
amination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting railway magistrate; on special duty in connection with the Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, Dec., 1882, and again Aug., 1883; forest settlement officer, Sholapur, Nov., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1884; second assistant collector, May, 1885.

WOODWARD, Willoughby, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1863, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting magistrate of police at Bombay, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Aug., 1881.

WOOTTON, J. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 20th Feb., 1872.

WORDSWORTH, William, M.A. (Oxon), Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational service, May, 1861; arrived in India, 10th July, 1861, and served as head master of the Elphinstone Institution, Bombay, acting professor of history in the Elphinstone College, and assistant inspector of schools; from May, 1862, served as principal of the Deccan College, Poona, and also acted as professor of English literature; from June, 1872, acted as principal of the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and was also appointed to select the government records at the secretariat; confirmed as principal of Elphinstone College and professor of logic and moral philosophy, Nov., 1874; principal, and professor of history and political economy, from June, 1878.

WORGAN, John Berney, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and grade, and officiating district and sessions judge; from May, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879.

WORSLEY, Charles Fortescue, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1884; on special duty, Dec., 1873 (famine), and in Nov., 1882, for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system.

WORSLEY, F., Political Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, savings bank department, general post office, April-Dec., 1868; writer, marine department, board of trade, July, 1870, to July, 1874; writer, India office, 13th July, 1874; clerk specially attached to political and secret department, Feb., 1876.

WRIGHT, Francis Nelson, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1864; from Dec., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from May, 1870, to April, 1878, in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1876; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878, and again, 1880-81; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Meerut, April, 1885.

WRIGHT, Frederick, Police Department, Hyderadad Administration.—Arrived in India, 20th Aug., 1859; served as inspector in the Madras police from Jan., 1860; transferred to Hyderadad assigned districts, Aug., 1862, and served as assistant superintendent and district superintendent of police (1st grade, April, 1877); officiating inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, July-Oct., 1884.

WRIGHT, Frederick C. B., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 4th July, 1867.

WRIGHT, J. W., Public Works Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the public works department in July, 1859; executive engineer, 4th grade, Grand Trunk road, Punjab, Sept., 1867; in charge, Madhopur workshops, March, 1868; executive engineer, military works, Chukrata road, and afterwards in the Jullundur division, 1872; transferred to the Punjab provincial list, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, Jullundur, Jan., 1882.

WRIGHT, William H., B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Appointed to the education department by secretary of state, 7th Aug., 1867, and served from 7th Dec., 1867, as professor, Benares College; professor of English literature, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1872; 3rd grade of educational officers, July, 1872; principal, Bareilly College, Dec., 1873; officiating inspector of schools, June, 1875, to March, 1876; from Jan., 1877, served as professor at the Muir Central College, and officiated as principal of the Benares College, in 1878.

WYER, Frederick, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; officiated as commissioner of the Burdwan division in 1883.

WYER, Thomas Rowland, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of Glasgow and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884.

WYLIE, Henry, Major, C.S.I., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, infantry, 1861; assistant to governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, 1877; assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, 1882; officiating additional political agent, 1st class, in Rajputana, 1885.

WYLLIE, William Hutt Curzon, Captain, C.I.E., B.S.C., Political Department, Govern-
ment of India.—First commission, Oct., 1866; served with the 106th foot; joined the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1868; assistant commissioner, Oude, 1871; officiating junior secretary to government, Oude, 1876-77; officiating assistant commissioner in Ajmere, 1879; officiating assistant to governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, 1879; political agent, 3rd class, in political charge of ex-Gaekwar of Baroda, Mulhar Rao, 1881; assistant resident, Hyderabad, 1882; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Nov., 1883; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1884; additional political agent, 1st class, 1885.

WYNNE, SYDENHAM HENRY, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Naval School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1873, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Oct., 1882.

YOUNG, GEORGE GORDON, Lieut.-Colonel, B.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from June, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1877; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Jan., 1881; and subsequently in the Jullundur division, April, 1883.

YOUNG, WILLIAM, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Basti, March, 1875, and civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Bareilly, Oct., 1880.

YOUNG, WILLIAM MACKWORTH, M.A.—Educated at Eton and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating secretary to financial commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; attached on special duty to office of financial commissioner, Oct., 1872; under secretary to government, Punjab, Oct., 1873; settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1875; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1878; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1878; secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ARTHUR DELAVAL, Bom-

bay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Clifton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, acting talukdari settlement officer, and assistant political agent.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ROMER EDWARD, B.A. (Barrister-at-Law), Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

YULE, HENRY, Colonel, C.B., Council of India.—Second lieutenant, Bengal Engineers, Dec., 1848; appointed to survey duties in the Cossaya Hills, Jan., 1841; assistant superintendent of Delhi canals, 1843; officiating executive engineer, northern division, Ganges canal, June, 1846; served with the army of the Sutlej in 1846, and with the army of the Punjab in 1848-49, and was present at the action of Ramnuggar, the passage of the Chenab, and action of Sadoolapore, and the battle of Chilianwala; deputed to report on protective measures necessary in the mountain passes of Arakan towards Burmese frontier, Jan., 1853; deputed to report on batteries for protection of Singapore harbour, August, 1853; deputy constructing engineer, railway department, Feb., 1854; deputy secretary (afterwards changed to under secretary) to government of India, public works department, Feb., 1855; deputed to proceed to Ava as secretary of the mission under Major (afterwards Sir Arthur) Phayre, July, 1855; garrison engineer, Allahabad, July, 1857, and extra superintending engineer in the N.W. Provinces, with charge of construction of defensive works at Allahabad, Benares, and Mirzapore, Aug., 1857; reappointed under secretary, public works department, Sept., 1857; officiating secretary, public works department, Nov., 1857; appointed secretary to government of India, public works department, with official rank as lieutenant-colonel, Jan., 1859; retired with honorary rank of colonel, March, 1862; from Oct., 1875, has served on the council of the Secretary of State for India, of which he is a permanent member; author of various geographical and other works; gold medallist of Royal Geographical Society, 1872, and of the Italian Geographical Society, 1871; president of the Hakluyt Society; president of the Royal Asiatic Society, 1885-86; hon. LL.D. of the University of Edinburgh, 1884; hon. fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and of the Scottish Society of Antiquaries; foreign or hon. member of the Geographical Societies of Paris, Berlin, Italy, &c., and of various other foreign and colonial societies.
